headline: EUROPEAN NATIONS TO LIFT SANCTIONS ON SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: Ignoring appeals from the African National Congress, the 12-nation European Community agreed today to lift its remaining economic sanctions against South Africa in response to the Pretoria Government's continuing moves to dismantle apartheid.   Meeting in Luxembourg, community foreign ministers said the move would result in ending a five-year-old ban on imports of gold coins, iron and steel from South Africa. Last December, the ministers revoked a prohibition against new investments in South Africa.

headline: Making a Difference; The NCR Deal and an Empty S.E.C. Chair
abstract: If the American Telephone and Telegraph Company sells the NCR Corporation on its proposed takeover this week, as many expect, the deal will still have to clear the Securities and Exchange Commission.    Because the staff is the ultimate authority on accounting rules for public companies, it is generally consulted on any major transaction that departs from usual practice, as is the case with the NCR deal.

headline: World Markets; Divining Europe's Muddled Signs
abstract: European markets were buffeted last week by political change but were buoyed as interest rates eased. Altogether, however, the week's events showed that the decline in rates is occurring very slowly and that inflation is still a worrisome problem. These factors could lead to disappointments in some stock markets.   In Germany, Karl Otto Pohl, the president of the central bank, said he would leave the Bundesbank by the end of October, ending a reign of more than 11 years as the most powerful central banker in Europe.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: INTERNATIONAL    Negotiations for a free-trade agreement with Mexico and a new round of lowering of international trade barriers were endorsed by House and Senate panels.  [ Page A1. ] THE ECONOMY    Retail sales rose 0.4 percent in March, the Commerce Dept. said, revising figures that had shown an 0.8 percent drop. The gain was viewed as a sign that the economic slide is halting.  [ A1. ]

headline: Competition Could Shut Pan Am
abstract: The Pan Am Corporation, which filed for bankruptcy protection in January, said in a document released today that strong competition could force it out of business as early as this year.   "The company has no available credit facilities and substantially all of Pan Am's remaining assets are encumbered," the airline said in a quarterly filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Fannie Mae Offers $1.4 Billion Issue
abstract: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is offering $1.4 billion in debentures divided into 5-year and 10-year maturities.    Half the financing includes $700 million in 8.05 percent debentures due 1996 that are priced at 100 to yield about 26 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

headline: North Korea Denies Interest In Developing Nuclear Arms
abstract: North Korea said today that it had neither "the need nor the capacity" to develop nuclear weapons, and that there are signs that the country's leadership may be rethinking its refusal to allow international inspection of a major nuclear center north of the capital, Pyongyang.   The statement appeared in the ruling party's official newspaper, Rodong Sinmun, according to North Korean news agency reports monitored in Tokyo. But the report made no mention of North Korea's approach to the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna earlier this week.

headline: Pro Bono
abstract: * The New York office of DDB Needham has created a series of public service announcements for the Leukemia Society of America. The ads, which depict a mother absorbing the news that her daughter has leukemia, convey the theme line: "Where there's help, there's hope."

headline: Treasuries Lower in Light Day
abstract: Treasury securities traders marked time yesterday, awaiting the terms of next week's quarterly refunding. Tomorrow afternoon, the Treasury is expected to announce the amount of notes and bonds it plans to auction on May 7-9.    Credit market analysts expect a total of $35.5 billion of Treasury paper will be offered, or $1 billion more than the record amount sold at the last refunding in February.

headline: Czechs Plan Big Sale of State Companies
abstract: The Czechoslovak Republic announced plans today to sell foreign investors all or part of more than 50 state-owned enterprises that have market values ranging from $50 million to $500 million and employ about 50,000 people.    The hope is that the sale of these large state-owned concerns will generate more than $1 billion in foreign investment in Czechoslovak industry.

headline: Carrefour of France To Buy Euromarche
abstract: The French retailer Carrefour said today that it would buy rival Euromarche for up to 5 billion francs, or $818 million, catapulting it into the top spot among France's retail groups.   Adding Euromarche's 55 restaurants and 77 hypermarkets would bring Carrefour's annual sales to more than 100 billion francs, or $16 billion. That, analysts say, would probably place Carrefour ahead of France's current retail leader, the family-owned Leclerc group, and make Carrefour one of Europe's biggest retailers.

headline: Reactor Built in Japan
abstract: Construction was completed on Saturday of Japan's first prototype fast-breeder reactor power plant. The plant will now start full-scale tests, a spokesman for the Science and Technology Agency said. The 280,000-kilowatt plant was designed to create roughly 1.2 times more fuel than it consumes. The plant, which is to begin full operations in 1994 after extensive tests, was completed after six years at a cost of 600 billion yen, or about $4.4 billion at current exchange rates.

headline: Ford Unit Offers 10-Year Notes
abstract: Ford Capital B.V., a Dutch unit of the Ford Motor Company, is offering $250 million in 10-year notes through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs.   The 9 3/8 percent notes, due in 2001, are priced at 99.77 to yield 9.411 percent, or about 133 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.   Underwriters said the notes were noncallable; they are rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.& P.

headline: Recycled Trash Is Put To Use in Construction
abstract: The country's first building that uses blocks made from recycled incinerator ash is being built in Stony Brook, L.I., on the campus of the State University of New York there.   The 8,100-square-foot building, a boathouse for the university's Marine Sciences Research Center, has 300 tons of blocks made of 67 percent ash and 33 percent sand, said R. Lawrence Swanson, director of the center's Waste Management Institute.

headline: Medeva P.L.C.
abstract: Medeva P.L.C., a British medical and science group, agreed to buy M D Pharmaceutical Inc., a privately owned pharmaceutical company in California, for about $77 million. It said it planned to finance the deal by offering new shares. The purchase would be Medeva's first move into the United States pharmaceutical market. M D's 1990 operating profits were $8.3 million on sales of $15.5 million.

headline: Economic Scene; A Better Feeling On Trade Talks
abstract: THE tension between the United States and the European Community over trade, especially in agriculture, was eased by this week's meeting in Paris of financial and trade officials of the wealthy countries that make up the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. But a lot of tough bargaining is ahead if the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations, under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, is to be brought to a successful conclusion.    Interviewed by telephone at the end of the Paris talks, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, said, "The outcome was positive, the atmospherics were better -- there was a much better feeling in the air." Indeed, the meeting's communique declared, "The Uruguay Round has the highest priority on the international economic agenda." It said success in the talks, which started in 1986 in Uruguay, remained crucial to continued growth of the world economy, and it called for "a substantial and comprehensive conclusion as early as possible, preferably before the end of the year."

headline: BAKER TO RESUME MISSION IN MIDEAST
abstract: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d announced today that he would return to the Middle East this week because, with another diplomatic push, it might be possible to get the Arabs and Israelis to agree to attend a peace conference.   In keeping with his secretive approach, Mr. Baker declined to elaborate on why he believes his fourth swing through the Middle East in two months might overcome obstacles to a peace conference. Other Administration officials, however, insist that Mr. Baker has been making slow, steady progress in narrowing the differences between the two sides -- more than he has disclosed in public.

headline: Pepsi to Spend More in Poland
abstract: Matching an earlier investment by the Coca-Cola Company, Pepsico said yesterday that it had opened a $10 million soft- drink plant in Warsaw and it would spend an additional $50 million in the Poland over five years.   The investment would bring to more than $110 million the amount Pepsico has spent in Poland, where the company first established operations in 1972 and now has eight soft- drink plants.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York, has sold a significant minority interest of its Singapore branch to Tokyu Agency International, Tokyo. The new Singapore agency will be called DMB & B Tokyu. Last year, the two agencies also became partners in a Bangkok-based agency.

headline: First Executive Chief Is at the Brink
abstract: Fred Carr, the chairman of the First Executive Corporation, has weathered intense competition in building the company into one of the nation's largest insurers. He has endured lengthy Federal investigations into his ties to Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. without being implicated in wrongdoing. And he has fought off a hostile takeover bid and an attempt to oust him by one of First Executive's largest shareholders.    But hanging on to his job and his company now will be a neat trick even for a survivor like Mr. Carr.

headline: Subaru Puts $60 Million Account in Review
abstract: EDWARD VICK, who became the president and chief executive of Levine, Huntley, Vick & Beaver just two months ago, is facing his first big test: Subaru of America, the agency's biggest client, said yesterday that it had put its $60 million account into review.   Fred Heiler, a Subaru spokesman, said the company was not specifically dissatisfied with Levine, Huntley's work but wanted to talk to other agencies to make sure it was getting the best work available.

headline: World Markets; The Dollar and Overseas Stocks
abstract: For foreign companies that do business in the United States, a rising dollar may look like a good bet. There is the bonus of translating dollar profits back into their home currencies and the competitive edge of their exports to America. But looks can be deceiving.    Take, for example, the Sedgwick Group P.L.C., a British commercial property and casualty insurance broker. More than 50 percent of its sales come from the United States. But since the dollar began to rally in February, the company has underperformed the Financial Times world index for the London market -- rising 7.8 percent compared with 11.7 percent for the index. Meanwhile, a group of other dollar-positive stocks with smaller percentages of sales in the United States have outperformed the market.

headline: 13 Reported Killed In Rioting and Fire At Mexican Prison
abstract: At least 13 people were killed and as many as 11 injured tonight in a riot and fire at a federal jail in the border city across from Brownsville, Tex., officials in the United States and a news agency reported.   The Excelsior news agency in Mexico said at least 13 people had been killed in what it described as a shootout between two gangs of prisoners armed with everything from automatic weapons to knives. It said bodies littered the entrance to the prison after the riot, which it said started about 6:30 P.M.

headline: HUNGARY RESISTING MOSCOW'S SHADOW
abstract: With two months to go before the last Soviet soldier leaves Hungary, the Hungarian Government is pressing for a new relationship with its giant neighbor that will be free of any lingering hint of Moscow's once-fast embrace.    In negotiations over a new bilateral treaty, Hungary has resisted language proposed by Moscow that would ban either country from joining any alliance that could be considered hostile to the other, or from allowing its national "infrastructure" to be used by a potential aggressor against its neighbor.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: DEBT * Kansas Power and Light is offering $327.5 million in tax-exempt pollution-control revenue refunding bonds due in 2031 through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Co. The 7 percent bonds are priced to yield 7.09 percent. The issue is insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corp. and rated triple-A by both Moody's and S. &P.

headline: Some Top Ogilvy Officials Seen in Plan to Buy Agency
abstract: SOME of Ogilvy & Mather's top executives have been quietly talking with at least one investment bank about a plan to buy the agency back from the WPP Group, its financially troubled parent, some prominent American advertising executives and bankers said yesterday.    The banking executives said that details of the plan were sketchy but that the offering price was a little more than $200 million. That is far less than the $850 million WPP paid for Ogilvy in 1989.

headline: Bad News Pummels French Premier
abstract: Barely six weeks after President Francois Mitterrand appointed Edith Cresson to be Prime Minister, the first woman in that post, there are already signs that what looked like an adroit maneuver to inject new life into his 10-year-old administration may have backfired.    Since taking office on May 15, Mrs. Cresson has been bombarded with unrelenting bad news, including a wave of strikes, violent clashes between the police and immigrants, record unemployment, several scandals and even sniping from colleagues in her own Socialist Party.

headline: Tech Notes; Beep! Paul Revere Updated in N.Y.
abstract: Commuters who want up-to-date traffic and weather reports can now get them without punching their car-radio buttons continually. A traffic beeper, just introduced, is providing reports 16 hours a day, seven days a week.   The service is a joint venture of Traffix Information Services of Brooklyn, a new concern, and Telecommunication Network Inc., a beeper company in Kendall Park, N.J.

headline: IRAQI REPORT SAYS CHEMICAL ARSENAL SURVIVED THE WAR
abstract: Iraq has informed the United Nations that a substantial arsenal of chemical and ballistic weapons survived the Persian Gulf war, but it denies having nuclear arms, nuclear-weapons-grade materials or biological weapons, according to documents made public today.    The United States quickly said the inventory was faulty.

headline: Voicing Hope, Baker Ends Mideast Trip
abstract: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d ended his fourth Middle East mission in two months today projecting optimism, even as he acknowledged that in two days of talks here he had not resolved the principal disagreements between Israel and Syria over how a Middle East peace conference could be convened.   In contrast to the bleak, exasperated manner that had characterized his last visit, as Mr. Baker left today he said: "I am not disappointed, because I do think we are making progress. There are many, many more areas of agreement with respect to this process on the part of Israel and, indeed, on the part of many Arab governments, than there are areas of disagreement."

headline: Shift in Creative Posts At Levine, Huntley
abstract: Rochelle Klein has been promoted from senior vice president and group creative director to executive creative director of Levine, Huntley, Vick & Beaver, New York, succeeding Tony DiGregorio, who left the agency in December to join Lintas New York.   "Rochelle will be one of the superstars of this business," said Edward H. Vick, chief executive at Levine, Huntley.

headline: Baltic Leaders Find Support In Congress for Independence
abstract: Leaders of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania politely asked members of Congress today to continue supporting their efforts to restore full independence to their lands.    But at a hearing on Capitol Hill, it seemed as if some Congressional members of the so-called Helsinki commission were willing to go farther and faster toward that goal than the Baltic leaders themselves.

headline: CONGRESS PANELS VOTE TO ADVANCE FREE-TRADE PLAN
abstract: House and Senate committees voted overwhelmingly today to endorse negotiations for a free-trade agreement with Mexico and a new round of lowering of international trade barriers, opening the way for passage by both houses before the end of next week.   Members of Congress on both sides of the issue described the Administration's authority to negotiate trade agreements as probably the most important and contentious economic problem facing policy makers this year.

headline: F.T.C. Votes Not to Block FNN Sale
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that it would not block a sale of the Financial News Network to a rival cable news service, CNBC, on antitrust grounds. The vote was 3 to 1, with one abstention.    The decision appeared to erase the setback CNBC suffered on Wednesday when United States District Judge Morris E. Lasker issued a ruling that reinsated Dow Jones & Company and Westinghouse Electric's Group W as valid bidders for FNN.

headline: Vehicle Sales Rose by 4.8% In Midmonth
abstract: Sales of domestically built cars and trucks rose by 4.8 percent in the middle of the month over the comparable period last year, when results were unusually weak because consumer incentives were expiring.    Retail sales during the May 11-to-20 period, reported today by the nine auto makers building cars in North America, totaled 166,826, a 3.8 percent increase from last year. Sales of domestically built light trucks were up by 6.5 percent, to 104,836. No Post-War Spurt Yet     The seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.9 million cars sold in mid-May suggested that the pickup in automotive sales that had been expected to follow the Persian Gulf war has still not materialized. Last year's rate in mid-May, using different seasonal adjustment factors, was 6.2 million. Automobile executives have been hoping for the rate to recover to closer to 7 million.

headline: Sharp Gains At Nordstrom And Dillard
abstract: Nordstrom Inc. and Dillard Department Stores, two of the nation's most widely followed retailers, reported sharp increases in quarterly income yesterday.   Considering the "continuing sluggish retail environment," both Nordstrom and Dillard "did quite well for the first quarter," said William N. Smith, retail analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York. He said that Dillard, based in Little Rock, Ark., had primarily benefited from strong growth in same-store sales and had been able to improve sales in the stores it had acquired. He said Dillard had also been helped by not having stores in economically depressed areas like New England, the West and the Middle Atlantic States.

headline: Drug Baron's Prison Has Every Comfort, Even Mom and TV
abstract: On Pablo Escobar Gaviria's first night in jail, the Mayor of this city stopped by to watch television with him.    "We watched all the news shows and had a good laugh at the way they were presenting it," said the Mayor, Jose Mario Rodriguez, referring to the surrender on Wednesday of Mr. Escobar, the country's most-wanted drug trafficker.

headline: Media Impresario Is Selling Movies Via Satellite Dish
abstract: He wrote the theme song to the 1970's game show "Break the Bank." In the early 80's, he made a failed bid to win the New Orleans cable franchise and tried his hand at television, producing an entertainment special from Las Vegas for Showtime, a cable channel. At one time, he even managed obscure rock bands in Brooklyn, envisioning, no doubt, becoming a top concert promoter or record producer.   Meet Stuart Z. Levin, aspiring media mogul. The 43-year-old entreprenuer has had his share of false starts, but thinks he has finally found a winning idea. And he has some impressive support: MCA Inc. and Paramount Pictures are his biggest investors.

headline: Expert Suspects Saudi Deal With Terrorists
abstract: A prominent counterterrorism expert said today that King Fahd of Saudi Arabia met last March with a representative of the Abu Nidal organization, probably to compensate him for the Palestinian terrorist group's restraint during the Persian Gulf war.    The meeting with a member of Abu Nidal's political leadership was reported at the time in the Saudi press, said Vincent Cannistraro, who until last fall was the head of the C.I.A.'s counterterrorism operations and who now leads a private study group on terrorism. Mr. Cannistraro said "it appeared he was getting paid off."

headline: Submarine Award Is Held Up Again
abstract: A Federal judge extended for 10 more days an order blocking construction of the nation's second Seawolf nuclear submarine. United States District Judge Robert G. Doumar made the announcement while hearing arguments regarding the Seawolf contract awarded May 3 by the Navy.    The contract went to the Electric Boat division of the General Dynamics Corporation in Groton, Conn. The competing bidder, the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, a unit of Tenneco Inc., filed suit challenging the award. Both bidders had warned the Navy before the award was made that loss of the contract could put them out of the submarine-building business.

headline: Tarnish on the Golden Arch?
abstract: To the Editor:   As a 16-year -- now former -- McDonald's franchisee I can readily attest to the veracity of "An American Icon Wrestles with a Troubled Future" (May 12).

headline: Pride in Victory Lingers, if Clouded by Middle East Chaos and Kurds' Agony
abstract: There are still yellow ribbons around many of the oaks on the University of Mississippi campus and Desert Storm bumper stickers on cars. The annual Fourth of July celebration will pay tribute to all the men and women in Oxford and surrounding communities who served in the Persian Gulf war.    But interviews here, in a town that combines Southern conservatism with a university-town atmosphere, and elsewhere show that the war seems more complicated and ambiguous to many than it did in the flush of victory after allied troops routed Iraqi troops from Kuwait.

headline: Western Union Service Acquires a President
abstract: The New Valley Corporation, the debt-laden company that changed its name from the Western Union Corporation last month, named Brian S. Gaylord president of Western Union Priority Services, a unit that until recently had been up for sale.   The unit offers paper-message services that include the Western Union Mailgram. New Valley, which is working to avoid bankruptcy, had tried to sell the operation earlier this year in an effort to raise cash for a proposed restructuring of the company's debt. But Warren Bechtel, a spokesman, said yesterday that New Valley had determined that "proceeds to be realized wouldn't be sufficient to resolve the debt problem."

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Dayton Power and Light Co., Dayton, Ohio, a subsidiary of DPL Inc., named Stewart D. Roll general counsel. * Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, New York, named Bernard Schoen vice president for sales.

headline: Targeting the Grocery Shopper
abstract: A parade of food beckoned Ursula Lozo through the maze of aisles at the well-scrubbed Wegmans supermarket here on Bridge Street. A peppy woman with a jolly demeanor, she had her cart heaped with pasta, cleanser, frozen vegetables and other groceries. One of the roughly 25,000 people who buy their food each week at Wegmans, Ms. Lozo faithfully appears every Wednesday with her list.    After the cashier scanned Ms. Lozo's choices, she whisked her jet-black Wegmans Shoppers Club card through a special device at the checkout lane. That enabled her to obtain automatic discounts on such products as Ragu spaghetti sauce, Red Rome apples and boneless chicken breasts. And she got a bag of carrots free.

headline: Bailout Agency Accuses Law Firms of Deception
abstract: The agency overseeing the bailout of the nation's savings industry has said that law firms in Cleveland and Phoenix contributed to the $2.6 billion collapse of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association and should be listed as defendants in a racketeering lawsuit.   In a motion filed here Monday, the agency, the Resolution Trust Corporation, contended that Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue of Cleveland had helped deceive Federal regulators by concealing unsound business practices of the former owner of Lincoln, Charles H. Keating Jr., and other officers of Lincoln's parent company, the American Continental Corporation.

headline: Kodak Net Dips to Low End of Forecasts
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company reported yesterday that its first-quarter earnings declined 10.6 percent, to $178 million, or 55 cents a share, from $199 million, or 61 cents a share, a year earlier.    The results were at the low end of analysts' expectations. Most had forecast that the company would report earnings of more than 60 cents a share. Kodak's stock closed yesterday down 87.5 cents, to $40.75.

headline: Merrill Lynch Begins Financing
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company entered the corporate debt market yesterday with a $200 million offering of two-year notes.   The 7.5 percent notes due to reach maturity in 1993 were priced at 100, to yield 91 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

headline: Managing; Fitting the Bonus to the Performance
abstract: Like most companies, the International Business Machines Corporation used to pay bonuses only when its business units hit some predesignated growth goal. How competitors were doing didn't matter at all.    That's not true anymore. Last year, I.B.M. built into the bonus formula sales growth relative to its industry. And this year, it is initiating a "best of breed" program, in which outside contractors are asking I.B.M. customers which computer companies provide the highest degree of customer satisfaction. "Substantial parts of some executives' bonuses will depend on whether their customers rate I.B.M. as the best," said Donald H. Edman, director of personnel progams.

headline: Kurds Trudge Into Iran, Filling a Village 6 Times
abstract: Kurdish refugees of Iraq's civil war are being put up three families to a house in Piranshahr, a tumble-down village of stone and stucco huts about eight miles from the Iraq border. They are sleeping in the school, in mosques and in plastic-sheeting tents in Pasdaran Square. They would sleep in their cars, but an ordinance bans that. So they are sleeping in the streets, too.    Swelled to six times its normal size by 150,000 destitute and debilitated refugees, Piranshahr is bursting at its already frayed seams. The mayor says the village is short of food and its 200-bed hospital and clinic are filled. Refugees complain bitterly of price gouging by merchants and money changers.

headline: Ethiopians Have New Rulers, But Famine's Specter Lingers
abstract: "A good mother feeds her children milk and meat," said Amina Abdi Ali, a 22-year-old mother of two children, as a tear rolled down her cheek. "I wish I could be a good mother."    Mrs. Amina wrapped her bony arms around her 4-year-old daughter Ferdowsa, who is so weak she needs to be fed by a refugee camp nurse by a tube through her nose and into her stomach. Then Mrs. Amina lovingly brushed the flies off her daughter's legs.

headline: U.S. Shoe Planning A Big Revamping
abstract: The U.S. Shoe Corporation, a manufacturer and retailer of footwear, apparel and eyewear, said it planned to sell 95 stores and shut a plant in an 18-month, $90 million restructuring plan. It said it would close a plant in Osgood, Ind., idling 275 workers. The company recently shut two plants in Kentucky, eliminating 510 jobs.    The company said it lost $56.2 million in its fourth quarter ended Feb. 2, compared with earnings of $23.2 million, or 52 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales fell 7 percent, to $705.5 million, from $758.3 million a year earlier. For the year, U.S. Shoe lost $31.3 million, compared with a profit of $49.2 million, or $1.10 a share, in the previous year. Sales were $2.7 billion, a 6 percent increase from the $2.5 billion a year earlier. U.S. Shoe's stock closed unchanged today at $11.50 on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: British Policy Under Study
abstract: The European Commission, the executive arm of the European Community, is considering whether to question Britain about allegations that it is discriminating against foreign state-owned companies trying to acquire British companies, community officials said on Wednesday.   The community's executive body has monitored British policy toward such takeover bids after a request from the French bank Credit Lyonnais last December, they said.

headline: Net Up 5% at Daimler-Benz
abstract: Daimler-Benz A.G., the maker of Mercedes-Benz vehicles, said today that its first-quarter profit edged up nearly 5 percent from a year earlier as sales rose 3.5 percent.    The company said its overall net profit was about $247 million in the first quarter, compared with $235.4 million a year earlier. It said sales increased to $11.6 billion, from $11.2 billion for the period last year.

headline: Text of Chairman's Message To the Employees at I.B.M.
abstract: Following is the text of the message that John F. Akers, I.B.M.'s chairman, circulated to employees on the company's electronic communications system:    In recent days, we have had a great deal of experience with communications, unfiltered and otherwise, especially concerning what I said to a small group at the Advanced Management School in Armonk. Here is the gist of what I want to communicate to everyone in the company.

headline: Baker Initiative Getting Mixed Response
abstract: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's Middle East peace mission got a mixed reception today, with Jordan endorsing the American diplomacy, Israeli officials beginning to criticize it harshly, and American officials disclosing that Saudi Arabia is not likely to come to any peace conference with Israel.   Mr. Baker met this morning with Palestinians in Jerusalem, and then flew to Aqaba, Jordan, for the first high-level meeting between a senior Bush Administration official and King Hussein since the Jordanian ruler threw his support behind President Saddam Hussein of Iraq in the Persian Gulf war. Mr. Baker ended the day in Cairo in talks with Egyptian leaders.

headline: Mortgage Rates Mixed
abstract: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.65 percent last week, down from 9.66 percent in the previous week, according to a national survey by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. But on one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 7.24 percent, up from 7.22 percent in the previous week. The rates do not include add-on fees known as points.

headline: Bush Meets and Commends Yeltsin But Cites Support for Gorbachev
abstract: President Bush gave Boris N. Yeltsin a brief pat on the back today for pushing "democratic values and free market principles," but emphasized his own support for the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.    "We have been heartened and encouraged by President Yeltsin's commitment to democratic values and free market principles, and we look forward to working with him," Mr. Bush said in a Rose Garden appearance with the newly elected President of Russia before their meeting in the Oval Office. "But at the same time -- I want to be very clear about this -- the United States will continue to maintain the closest possible official relationship with the Soviet Government of President Gorbachev."

headline: Krugerrand Revival Plans
abstract: South Africa plans to market the Krugerrand gold coin abroad again, a mining official said.    The official, Clive Knobbs, the president of the Chamber of Mines mineowners' organization, said on Tuesday that the decision was made after the European Community voted in April to lift its ban imposed in 1985 on Krugerrand imports. The community also banned steel and iron imports as an expression of its opposition to apartheid, South Africa's policy of separating its citizens by race.

headline: Greenspan's Authority Curtailed On Interest Rates, Officials Say
abstract: Amid a debate at the Federal Reserve Board over whether lower interest rates are needed to help the nation out of recession, the central bank's policy-making body has curtailed the authority of its chairman, Alan Greenspan, to reduce rates on his own, high Government officials said over the weekend.    In his nearly four years as chairman, Mr. Greenspan has never before been so openly challenged by other members of the Federal Reserve's policy-making body, the Federal Open Market Committee. Its members include Mr. Greenspan, the 4 other governors of the Federal Reserve Board and the 12 presidents of the regional Federal Reserve Banks.

headline: New Crisis Grips Yugoslavia Over Rotation of Leadership
abstract: The leadership of Serbia plunged this volatile country into a constitutional crisis today by blocking the installation of a Croat as federal President, a position that in the decade since the death of Tito has automotically rotated each year among the six republics.    The maneuver by Serbia, the largest of the country's six republics, was seen as a last-minute attempt to maintain dominance over the fragile federation. It left the country without a head of state or a commander of the armed forces as of midnight tonight, as members of the federal presidency, the supreme constitutional body, adjourned to resume talks on Thursday.

headline: Patents; A Machine to Monitor Cholesterol in Bakeries
abstract: Using principles underlying advanced medical imaging systems, a Massachusetts company has patented a machine to measure the fats, oils and moisture in baked goods as they come off the assembly line.   Among other things, its inventors said, the machine makes it easier for large bakeries to monitor cholesterol content and prevent variations in the production process. By gauging moisture content, moreover, the machine can give bakeries more precise information on when the cookies, crackers and breads are done.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Creative Group Chief Leaves BBDO for Chiat
abstract: Richard Sabean, whose work at BBDO most recently included the "You got the right one baby, uh-huh" campaign for Diet Pepsi, has left the agency to become vice president and associate creative director at Chiat/ Day/Mojo, New York.  "BBDO was my home for seven years; it was a place that treated me well," said Mr. Sabean, who was most recently a vice president-creative group head. "But I did feel I had been there for a long time, and I felt ready for a change."  In addition to the current Diet Pepsi campaign, Mr. Sabean, 35 years old, worked on the award-winning "Missing Link" spot for the soft drink, which featured three chimpanzees. His other accounts at BBDO were Pepsi, Dodge and General Electric.

headline: Sony Picks Burnett for Consumer Products
abstract: THE Sony Corporation of America has seen the future of its advertising communications for the 1990's, and it's a lot like the past. Yesterday, the electronics giant decided once again to consolidate ad work for its consumer products group at a single agency with a global reach.    Sony is moving an estimated $35 million to $40 million worth of billings for products like Trinitron televisions and Walkman personal stereos to the Leo Burnett Company. The account had been in review for four months, but the process was not discussed in the always gossipy agency community. Indeed, one current trade press write-up listed the review as being for a new product rather than for the entire product group.

headline: U.S. Persists on Camp Plan After a Meeting With Iraqis
abstract: The commander of the American-led operation to assist Iraqi refugees along the Turkish-Iraqi border met here today with two Iraqi generals, then stressed that the United States and its allies would go ahead with plans to build and defend camps inside Iraq for the refugees, despite Baghdad's objections.   "It's our intention to deploy the necessary security forces to protect the humanitarian effort," said the American commander, Lieut. Gen. John Shalikashvili, before he left the abandoned border-crossing customs areawhere the 50-minute meeting took place. "That was our intention at the beginning, and it's still our intention."

headline: Allies to Close Last Kurdish Camp in Turkey
abstract: Allied commanders have announced plans to close the last Kurdish refugee camp in Turkey this weekend, a milestone in efforts to end the two-month-old refugee crisis in northern Iraq.   About 40,000 Iraqi Kurds are still in camps in the allied-controlled zone in northern Iraq, and an equal or greater number have yet to return from sanctuaries in Iran. But the departure of the last Iraqi Kurds from Turkey will remove an irritant to ties between the Ankara Government and the other members of the coalition that opposed Iraq in the Persian Gulf war.

headline: U.S. WILL ENHANCE DEALS FOR BUYERS OF S.& L. HOLDINGS
abstract: Conceding that it has been unable to sell its growing inventory of assets taken over from failed savings and loans, the Government said today that it was giving up marketing them piecemeal and would bundle them in a new program intended to attract big investors.    The sale of these assets is supposed to hold down the already astronomical cost of the savings and loan bailout, which by some estimates could ultimately reach $500 billion over 40 years. But some lawmakers immediately criticized the new plan for terms it offers potential buyers that they said could actually increase the cost of the bailout for taxpayers.

headline: At Least 22 Die in Central American Earthquake
abstract: A powerful earthquake struck Costa Rica today, with the brunt of its force felt in this coastal city. At least 10 people were killed and scores were missing, while at least a dozen more deaths were reported in neighboring Panama.    A Red Cross worker here was quoted as saying as many as 1,000 people were injured in Limon.

headline: Nintendo to Pay $25 Million In Rebates on Price Fixing
abstract: Nintendo has agreed to pay up to $25 million in rebates to buyers of its popular video games and $4.75 million in other costs to settle allegations of price fixing, state and Federal officials announced yesterday in Washington.    The action follows an unusual joint investigation by the Federal Trade Commission and several states into allegations of antitrust violations by Nintendo.

headline: The Executive Life; Another Vote on Girls in an Old-Boy World
abstract: Last month, a furor erupted at Yale University when the 15 seniors in the all-male Skull and Bones broke with a century and a half of tradition by "tapping," or selecting, seven women for the secret society's next "delegation." Stunned, the alumni board of directors padlocked the club's windowless crypt and declared the election void.  No matter, the students countered; their hallowed rites would continue in exile until a compromise could be reached.   This has caused such consternation that the club's board is expected to meet this Wednesday to determine the future of what is perhaps the nation's most powerful secret society. Will women be accepted? That's "up in the air," said Sidney Lovett, spokesman for the group's parent, the Russell Trust Association, named after the club's founder.

headline: Stock Prices Drop Sharply; Dow Off 22.58
abstract: Extending their Tuesday decline, stock prices dropped sharply yesterday -- and in heavy trading -- with analysts forecasting that further declines may lie ahead soon.    "In my judgment," said Hugh Johnson, chief economist for the First Albany Corporation, "we're in the process of an orderly, and I think, manageable pullback, primarily because the market got somewhat ahead of itself."

headline: The Executive Computer; Instant Mail, and Other Slick Tricks
abstract: The Hewlett-Packard Company and the Lotus Development Corporation, two of the biggest companies in the computer business, have just combined to produce one of the smallest and most unusual portable computers.    The HP 95LX (list price, $699) is an 11.6-ounce machine in the new palmtop category -- computers that weigh less than a pound and can be held in one's palm. It runs the DOS 3.2 operating system, Lotus's popular 1-2-3 spreadsheet (version Release 2.2) and executive organizing software developed by Lotus. It is also a powerful business calculator. Later in the year, the 95LX will be modified to work as a digital paging device that can display and capture messages sent over radio frequencies. People who buy the machine before then will be able to purchase and add on the pager.

headline: Hard-Liners in China: Old, but by No Means Out
abstract: Two years ago, when China's hard-liners used troops and tanks to crush the democracy movement here, most Chinese and foreigners predicted that the aging leadership would not last even a couple of years.   Yet it has. Far more than most people expected, Prime Minister Li Peng and those around him have consolidated their hold and imposed a sullen stability on the land. At times, China is still likened to a volcano, but few see an eruption soon.

headline: Digital Has New 'Open' Software
abstract: The Digital Equipment Corporation introduced several new software products today that the company said could be used with other computer companies' hardware and software.   Digital is trying to position itself as a leading provider of "open systems" -- hardware and software that can be used with products from a variety of computer makers, instead of being bound by one manufacturer's proprietary system.

headline: Asea Brown Unit Plans Furloughs
abstract: Combustion Engineering Systems Inc., a subsidiary of Asea Brown Boveri Ltd. of Switzerland, has offered its 1,000 employees two choices and given them until Friday to decide: take a two-year leave or quit and receive severance benefits. Richard R. Cronin, the president of Combustion Engineering Systems, described the options in a memorandum dated June 12.    The document cited low market demand and made it clear that layoffs were coming for the company, which manufactures fuel boilers. Last year, the company laid off 200 people.

headline: Lilliputian Rival of Desktops Offered by Hewlett-Packard
abstract: In a direct challenge to Japanese companies that dominate a fast-growing segment of the computer market, the Hewlett-Packard Company said yesterday that it would start selling a personal computer about the size of a calculator.    The market for computers that can easily be carried in a briefcase or pocket, yet offer power and speed rivaling desktop systems, has already been ceded by some analysts and industry executives to Asian manufacturers.

headline: Your Own Account; Last-Minute Thoughts on Taxes
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service estimates that 34 million taxpayers -- 30 percent of those filing this year -- will mail their returns during the coming week, just ahead of the April 15 filing deadline. For many, then, the next few days will be hectic and mistakes are inevitable, say tax specialists. Never mind the really basic errors -- like forgetting to sign the return -- there are several other common oversights.  First, there is neglecting to file as head of household. An unmarried or legally separated person who provides a home for a dependent, like a child or elderly parent, may be able to use the head of household filing status rather than single status and pay less in taxes. To qualify you must meet three tests, according to Kent Klaus, a tax partner in the Chicago office of Arthur Andersen & Company. You must be single, the dependent must in most cases be a relative and must live with you and you must pay more than half of the cost of maintaining the home.

headline: Baker Says Israel Fails to Provide Needed Responses
abstract: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that Israel had failed to give all the responses he needed to continue trying to put together an Arab-Israeli peace conference and that as a result he and President Bush would have to reappraise their next steps in Middle East peacemaking.    Mr. Baker had to leave Israel abruptly because of the death of his mother in Houston today, but he had largely completed his daylong talks with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Foreign Minister David Levy.

headline: Grumman Earnings Climb
abstract: The Grumman Corporation today reported first-quarter profits of $22.5 million, but the gain was due entirely to accounting procedures taken to offset a large charge.   Before taxes, Grumman lost $12.4 million in the period. The loss was attributed to a $46.5 million charge against operating income resulting from settlement of claims in a dispute over a Navy contract in the 1980's.

headline: Stocks Dip in Tokyo
abstract: Tokyo stocks closed lower today as the lack of fresh data and the approaching release of Japan's money-supply report kept most investors sidelined. The 225-issue Nikkei stock average was down 257.62 points, or 1.03 percent, to 24,685.47. On Monday, the index lost 150.80 points.

headline: Eastern Airlines Fight Continues
abstract: Lawyers for the retirees and unsecured creditors of Eastern Airlines failed to reach agreement on how to divide about $125 million from the liquidation of the company. Burton R. Lifland, the chief judge of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York, who is presiding over Eastern's Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, scheduled another hearing for 2 P.M. today.

headline: Jury Backs Investors in Apple Suit
abstract: Two former executives of Apple Computer Inc. misled investors in 1983 about the fruitless attempt of the company to build its own disk drive and should pay millions of dollars in damages, a Federal jury has decided.   A. C. Markkula, an Apple co-founder, and John Vennard, a former vice president, failed to disclose the degree of technical problems Apple had in developing a disk drive that was nicknamed Twiggy, the panel decided on Thursday.

headline: Stocks Slump, With the Dow Sliding 24.15
abstract: Stocks slumped yesterday in the face of weakness in the bond market, which feared the sheer size of the Treasury's $37 billion bond refinancing. Program selling, particularly late in the day, contributed heavily to the decline.    The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip stocks slid 24.15 points, or almost 1 percent, to 2,917.49, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell about the same.

headline: Amid Layoffs, the Froth Is Gaining
abstract: FIGHTING recessions used to be a two-front war. The Federal Reserve cut interest rates, and the politicians raised spending and cut taxes.   This recession is different. The Fed is battling, and seems determined to keep cutting rates until the economy notices. But governments are laying off workers -- 25,000 last month -- as they gasp for funds.

headline: RJR Posts Small Profit For Quarter
abstract: In a surprise to analysts, RJR Nabisco announced a small profit for the first quarter yesterday, its first since going private in 1989 in history's largest leveraged buyout. It posted net income of $5 million, compared with a loss of $222 million in the comparable period last year.   Despite sluggish domestic cigarette sales, quarterly sales for the company over all rose 8.4 percent, to $3.47 billion from $3.2 billion, largely because of foreign cigarette sales and higher sales of food, like Oreo cookies and Grey Poupon mustard.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Britain's Liberal Democratic Party to TBWA-Holmes Knight Ritchie's London office for advertising for the general election campaign. Billings are estimated at $4.25 million, the agency said. * Carriage House Imports Ltd., Springfield, N.J., which imports liquor brands like Appleton and Wray & Nephew rums, to Omon, New York. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: Cuts at McDonnell
abstract: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it would lay off 290 union employees in the first phase of dismissals attributed to the loss of the Navy advanced tactical fighter contract and declining orders for the F-15 fighter. The company said about 100 white-collar workers would also be laid off soon. The company dismissed about 5,600 workers in January after the Pentagon canceled the A-12 Avenger attack plane, but a spokesman said the current cuts would not approach the size of the January layoffs.

headline: Lawmakers Cheer Tibetan in Capitol Rotunda
abstract: Tibet's exiled spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, speaking to a receptive gathering of members of Congress today in the Capitol rotunda, appealed to the United States to aid Tibet in its struggle against Chinese Government control.   Setting aside his prepared text to speak in halting English about what he termed the "universal responsibility" Americans should feel for conditions in Tibet, the Dalai Lama was greeted with applause and cheers from several hundred people in attendance.

headline: Brady Calls for Lower Rates To Stimulate World Growth
abstract: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that the top economic priority for the industrialized world should be to lower interest rates.    He stressed that lower rates were vital to stimulate economic growth and generate the extraordinary amount of capital needed in Eastern Europe, the Soviet Union, the war-ravaged Middle East and Latin America.

headline: Square D Agrees to Takeover
abstract: Capping a 10-week fight, Groupe Schneider S.A., a French electrical equipment company, said last night that it had at last won its bid for the Square D Company with a sweetened offer of $2.23 billion and a favorable ruling from the Justice Department.   Schneider said it had raised the cash portion of its offer to $88 for each Square D share, from $78, or $1.96 billion. The definitive agreement has the approval of Square D's board. There are 25.7 million Square D shares; Schneider already owns 318,000 shares. Square D's stock closed at $81 a share on Friday, up $1.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: MEXICO TO COMBAT POLICE CORRUPTION
abstract: Intensifying a broad crackdown on corruption in federal law enforcement agencies, Mexico's new Attorney General announced a nationwide reorganization of the Federal Judicial Police today, including the creation of special anti-corruption and internal affairs units.    Declaring that the Government is committed to rooting out the corruption and abuses that have long tainted Mexican law enforcement efforts, the Attorney General, Ignacio Morales Lechuga, said all federal police units would be reorganized and placed under the direct, strengthened control of a civilian Deputy Attorney General appointed by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari.

headline: People
abstract: * Charles B. Fruit has been named global media director for Coca-Cola Co., Atlanta. He had been president of Anheuser-Busch's Busch Media Group. Mr. Fruit replaces William H. Lynn, the former vice president and director of worldwide media, who died in November.

headline: Northwest Air Request
abstract: Northwest Airlines has asked the Transportation Department to reconsider the carrier's application to fly nonstop between Detroit and London. Northwest said in the application on Wednesday that it had asked for an emergency exemption to preserve service on the route because Pan American World Airways Inc. had suspended flights and it appeared that the service would not be reinstated.

headline: NBC Wins Approval of FNN Deal
abstract: NBC moved a big step closer yesterday toward acquiring the Financial News Network, the ailing cable channel, after a series of maneuvers in Federal bankruptcy court.    A bankruptcy court judge ruled that a competing bid for FNN by Dow Jones & Company and Group W Satellite Communications did not meet the requirements that he had specified. Then the judge approved the sale of FNN to NBC after NBC raised its bid to $115 million.

headline: Theory of a Tamil Plot to Kill Gandhi
abstract: India's Law and Justice Minister said today that the killing of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi was part of a "planned conspiracy" and not the act of an individual assassin.    "A lot of people were involved," said the Minister, Subramaniam Swamy, without offering any specific evidence. "They had picked more than one spot. They had a fail-safe arrangement. If it didn't work here, they would have tried somewhere else. It was very well organized. It was not a single assassin. It was a planned conspiracy."

headline: Dow Up 3.13 as Blue-Chip Stocks Meander
abstract: Blue-chip stocks meandered most of day yesterday as many traders moved to the sidelines. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange shrank to 147.2 million shares, from 166.2 million the day before.    While the Dow Jones industrial average closed with a gain of 3.13 points, at 2,965.12, it moved higher only in the final minute or two of trading. Another indicator of the market's lack of direction was the near balance between Big Board gainers and decliners, at 793 and 726.

headline: U.S. Company Linked to Iraqi Atom Program
abstract: A maker of electrical equipment in Brewster, N.Y., has been identified as a supplier of special power units that Iraq has used to try to make weapons-grade uranium at a secret underground site in the mountains north of Baghdad.    An Iraqi defector has told American officials about the site not far from the northern city of Mosul, and intelligence officials in Washington now say they have obtained information that corroborates the defector's assertions.

headline: Reports Name Pohl Heir
abstract: The Government will name the deputy president of the Bundesbank, Helmut Schlesinger, as the successor to the central bank president, Karl Otto Pohl, Government sources said today.    They said the 66-year-old monetarist hard-liner would be appointed for two years. A board member, Hans Tietmeyer, 59, would be Mr. Schlesinger's deputy and later replace him as president, the sources said.

headline: Gunmen Kill Judge in Trial of Bhutto's Husband
abstract: Masked men armed with automatic weapons today ambushed and killed the Pakistani judge who was trying former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's husband.   Ms. Bhutto's political foes blamed her followers for the attack, which killed Judge Nabi Sher Junejo as well as his driver and a police guard while the judge was being driven from a court complex in Karachi, Pakistan's largest city.

headline: Purchasing Index Shows Sharp Gain
abstract: Spurred by a sharp increase in new orders, the nation's manufacturing economy improved in May, according to a monthly report issued yesterday by corporate purchasing managers.   The National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of economic activity increased to 45.4 percent in May, up from 42.1 percent in April. The May reading was the highest since August, when the index stood at 47.6 percent.

headline: Market Place; The Bullish, and Bearish, Moves by Buffett
abstract: Warren E. Buffett is bullish on Wells Fargo shares, but he may be bearish on some other securities, including "junk bonds," whose prices have zoomed this year. It appears that his company has sold large quantities of RJR Nabisco bonds, and may have sold other low-quality bonds as well.    That conclusion emerged yesterday when Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the somewhat secretive company that Mr. Buffett runs, reported its quarterly earnings, showing a large increase in profits from the sale of investments. Best in Nearly 5 Years       Berkshire said it earned $59.3 million from such sales during the quarter, up from $325,000 in the 1990 quarter and the highest quarterly figure in nearly five years.

headline: Fleet/Norstar Fills Massachusetts Post
abstract: Leo R. Breitman worked at the Bank of New England in its heydey and he was around for its demise. Now, at age 50, he is the most senior official to be offered a job by the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group, which acquired the Boston-based bank last month.   Mr. Breitman will be chief executive of Fleet/Norstar's $7 billion Massachusetts banking unit, which consists primarily of the old Bank of New England business plus a small Fleet/ Norstar operation. After nearly 20 years at the Bank of New England, Mr. Breitman has the knowledge of an insider but has not been tainted with the real estate lending mistakes that led the Bank of New England to insolvency.

headline: Yield Put at 9.38% On Sears Notes
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the Chicago-based retailing giant, is offering $500 million in seven-year notes through a group of underwriters led by Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Originally the offering was to have been for $350 million, but strong investor interest prompted the retailer to increase the size by $150 million.    The notes, which have a final maturity of April 15, 1998, have a 9.25 percent coupon and are priced at 99.338 to yield 9.38 percent, or about 135.4 basis points more than Treasury securitites with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. Interest on the notes is payable twice yearly beginning next Oct. 15.    Underwriters said the issue was noncallable and rated A-2 by Moody's and A+ by Standard & Poor's.

headline: Market Place; Apple Pays Price For New Strategy
abstract: THE move by Apple Computer Inc. to gain market share by introducing lower-priced machines is succeeding, but the resulting strain on profits has driven its stock down. Its supporters among Wall Street analysts say the company is being penalized for long-term planning.    When Apple warned three weeks ago that its earnings for the quarter ending in June could be below the levels of a year before, investors hammered the stock, sending it plummeting $7.75, to $47.25, in one day of over-the-counter trading. Since then the shares have rebounded a bit, but on Friday they closed at $47, down $2 for the day. Within the last 52 weeks, Apple traded as high as $72.

headline: Talks Are Suspended On Buyout of Harcourt
abstract: Talks on the General Cinema Corporation's proposed buyout of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. broke off yesterday after Harcourt's bondholders rejected an increased bid by General Cinema.   The break in the talks puts General Cinema's proposed buyout of the publishing and insurance company in question. General Cinema's offer is scheduled to expire at 5 P.M. today. and no new talks have been scheduled, the company said.

headline: Debt Efforts Worry Japan
abstract: A recent agreement among major creditor nations to lighten Poland's debt load and a similar proposal for Egypt might mean that those countries would lose loans from Japan, officials in Tokyo said today.    Japan has a policy of not giving new loans to countries that cannot pay existing debts, the officials said. Immediately in jeopardy is $500 million in Export-Import Bank guarantees for Japanese investments in Poland.

headline: A Co-Founder of Next Is Quitting the Company
abstract: Susan Kelly Barnes, co-founder and chief financial officer of Next Computer Inc. and a longtime aide to Steven P. Jobs, the company's president, is leaving the company.    In a statement issued by Next, Ms. Barnes said the move would allow her to have more personal time. Mr. Jobs and other Next officials said the departure was unrelated to the performance of the company, which is based in Redwood City, Calif.

headline: Disney Plan For Expansion
abstract: The Walt Disney Company today made public a proposal to greatly expand its Disneyland theme park in Anaheim, Calif., by adding new resort hotels and attractions, including one patterned after the EPCOT center at Walt Disney World in Florida.    The proposal is one of two being considered by Disney to increase its theme park business in southern California. Disney is expected to choose by the end of the year whether to expand the current Disneyland or to build an entirely new theme park, Port Disney, along the waterfront in Long Beach, Calif. Disney made public its design plans for Port Disney last year.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt * Baltimore is offering $35 million in tax-exempt general obligation improvement bonds priced to yield from 4.50 percent in 1992 to 6.75 percent in 2011 through Chase Securities. The bonds are insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Co. and rated triple-A by both Moody's and S.&P.

headline: General Mills Profit Up 21%
abstract: General Mills Inc. said today that strong performances by its consumer foods and restaurant divisions helped earnings rise 21 percent in the fiscal fourth quarter.   The company said it earned $90.9 million, or 55 cents a share, up from $75.3 million, or 46 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. Sales rose 7 percent, to $1.83 billion from $1.71 billion.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Eugene B. Cofsky has left his position as president of the entertainment division of AC & R Advertising Inc. and established an entertainment and sports marketing consulting firm, Tedlor Entertainment Marketing, in Tarzana, Calif. The new firm offers creative services, media planning, licensing and merchandising and international marketing.

headline: To Cantonese, A Little Graft Is Forgivable
abstract: Lei Yu charges into the room, his extraordinary energy a fitting reflection of one of China's fastest-changing cities.   Mr. Lei, the Deputy Mayor of this frenetic and prosperous city, is one of a growing number of sharp and shrewd local officials who shun the Communist bureaucrat's life of long lunches and snoozes. Some people see him as a local hero who bucks the system; others accuse him of glaringly corrupt practices.

headline: A Plan to Undersell Sandoz on Drug for Schizophrenia
abstract: A small distributor plans to sell an extremely expensive drug treatment that could help thousands of psychotic patients for a price 30 percent below that set by the drug's maker.    Homecare Management, based in Ronkonkoma, L.I., said it is ready to distribute the drug, clozapine, under safeguards required by Sandoz Ltd., the Swiss company that makes the medication, at a price of $6,300 to $6,800 for a year's supply for an average dose, depending on the amount prescribed. Robert Clifton, a Homecare Management vice president, said the price would cover the drug and monitoring for potentially dangerous side effects, which will include a national system of blood testing by the SmithKline Beecham Company's Clinical Laboratories unit.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Nuclear Corp., Casper, Wyo., a uranium exploration company, named James Cornell chairman and Stephen A. Carpenter president and chief operating officer. * Bell Helicopter Textron Inc., Fort Worth, appointed Webb F. Joiner president.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Kameny Spitzer Felix Advertising, New York, has formed a new division, KSF/Sales Promotion, to develop programs for the agency and its Crimmins Co-op Marketing division. Irving Binder will serve as president. * Five former senior executives of Hill & Knowlton have formed an international public affairs firm, Capitoline International Group, Washington. They are: Lawrence J. Brady, Josephine S. Cooper, Larry I. Good, Paul R. Locigno and Charles R. Pucie Jr.

headline: Give McDonald's Its Due: Taste the Product
abstract: To the Editor:   I take exception to the small piece titled "McDonald's New Burger" (March 17). Caroline Levy of Shearson Lehman is quoted as saying of the company's low-calorie offering: "This doesn't even taste like a burger, based on what I've heard." Mind you, I have no financially driven interest in McDonald's, but I think that Ms. Levy should have given more thought to her analysis (i.e. kill the product). All it takes is one or two uninformed people to make or break a product. In short, Ms. Levy, Mimi Sheraton tastes the food.  MARTIN J. JOHNSON  New York, March 19

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press; Newspapers Try, Carefully, To Investigate Subscribers
abstract: As many newspapers rush toward the brave new world of building extensive data banks about their readers' interests and buying habits to help sell advertising, the issue of privacy looms as a potential land mine.   Americans are only beginning to realize that when they call a newspaper's sports line to get a score or send for a free brochure about car maintenance, they are probably also entering a data bank as a prospect for advertising about golf clubs or tires.

headline: REFUGEES IN SOUTH BEG ARMY TO STAY
abstract: More than 100 Iraqis held a peaceful demonstration at the main refugee camp here today, appealing to American forces to stay in southern Iraq.    The heavily armed American troops in southern Iraq, who numbered about 90,000 last week, will be replaced with a United Nations observer force. The refugees, who fled after President Saddam Hussein's forces put down the rebellion in southern Iraq, waved signs urging the Americans to stay.

headline: Berlin City Official Is Killed By Letter Bomb at His Home
abstract: A government planning official was killed by a letter bomb late Wednesday in what the police said they believed was a politically motivated attack.   No one claimed responsibility for the killing, in which the 48-year-old city official, Hanno Klein, was found dead in his apartment. It was the second bomb attack in two days and came a week before the legislature in Bonn is to vote on whether to return the seat of government to Berlin. Mr. Klein worked for the privatizing agency.   On Wednesday, the Revolutionary Cells, a leftist splinter group, put a firebomb in the Reichstag, the old seat of Parliament, but it failed to ignite. A message asserting responsibility said it was a warning not to shift the Government to Berlin.

headline: K.G.B. Aide Tells of Defector Who Was Kim Philby's Handler
abstract: The deputy spokesman of the K.G.B. said today that a top Soviet intelligence officer who controlled the Philby-Burgess-Maclean spy ring was in the United States as a defector when they came under suspicion.    The spokesman, Oleg Tsarev, said at a news conference here that he was collaborating on a book about the Soviet intelligence officer, Aleksandr Orlov, who defected in 1938 to the United States after serving as control officer of Kim Philby, Guy Burgess and Donald Maclean.

headline: Rule Industries
abstract: Rule Industries, a maker of marine equipment and related hardware, said its senior institutional note holders had refused to allow the company to pay the interest due Monday on its public issue of 12.5 percent subordinated notes. The company said the holders' refusal to renew some short-term notes had caused a technical default under senior institutional loan agreements.

headline: Fox Slows, but Stays Restless
abstract: The Fox Broadcasting Company turned momentum into money last year. Now the young and restless network has lost ground in the ratings even as it expanded its program base.    Advertising industry executives predict that Fox will take in less advertising money for its fall programs this year than it did last year.

headline: KURDISH REFUGEES RETURNING TO IRAQ
abstract: Thousands of Kurdish refugees who had fled fighting between the Government and rebels poured back into this northern city today, hungry, thirsty and tired.   The refugees returned home from mountain retreats on foot, in cars and in army trucks. Many said they had walked for days to return to this city, which the Iraqi Army wrested back from the rebels on Wednesday.

headline: A WIDE-OPEN VOTE AHEAD FOR RUSSIA
abstract: After two years of only qualified democracy, the voters of the Russian Federation are moving headlong into the first truly wide open balloting of the Gorbachev era, a republic presidential race of ambitious rival tickets balanced by a liberal Communist here and a patriot general there.    Leading the way into this hyperbolic new world of highly competitive electioneering for the voting on June 12 is Boris N. Yeltsin, the Russian leader and apostate Communist who is popular for wanting to throttle the party's powers yet, in this race, has tapped a "reform" Communist and military hero as his running mate to broaden his own appeal.

headline: Labor Party Wins Welsh Seat In Conservatives' Stronghold
abstract: The Labor Party defeated the governing party in a by-election Thursday in the Welsh district of Monmouth, which had been controlled by the Conservatives for 25 years.   Results early today showed that the Labor candidate, Huw Edwards, a college lecturer, received 17,733 votes. The Tory candidate, Roger Evans, a lawyer from London, received 15,327. The candidate of the centrist Liberal Democratic party, Frances David, a schoolteacher, received 11,164 votes.

headline: Kohlberg, Kravis Rouses Itself
abstract: After almost two years of struggling with its previous investments as the "junk bond" market collapsed, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the giant buyout firm that became a corporate titan in the 1980's, appears to be back on a roll.    In one week, the firm, which has not made a large purchase in two years, began to snap up corporate properties again. It backed the bid that won Federal approval to buy the assets of the Bank of New England. And K-III Holdings, a company controlled by Kohlberg, Kravis, agreed to buy nine publications from Rupert Murdoch's debt-laden News Corporation for $650 million.

headline: Seized S.& L.'s Post Losses
abstract: Federal officials said today that the 204 savings associations under Government control posted operating losses of $726 million in the first three months of this year, compared with operating losses of $905 million for the last three months of 1990.   On Wednesday, regulators reported that those institutions not under Government control posted their first profit in four years. The Office of Thrift Supervision said that those institutions had a profit of $626.8 million for the recent quarter.

headline: Allied-Signal Aerospace Names President-Elect
abstract: Daniel P. Burnham says he has loved every job he has ever had, and most of them have been within the conglomerate Allied-Signal Inc. Now, Mr. Burnham is moving to still another post in the corporation: president-elect of its Allied-Signal Aerospace Company.    Mr. Burnham will become president of the aerospace unit in January, upon the retirement of the current president, Roy H. Ekrom, 62. Mr. Burnham, 44, will also become an executive vice president of the parent company.

headline: Dow Advances by 21.92 to Close at 2,934.93
abstract: The stock market scored its broadest advance of the month yesterday, but while the advancing issues included many blue chips and second-tier issues, trading was moderate.   The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 21.92 points, at 2,934.93. Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said a big selling operation and three major buying programs added 18.34 to the Dow.

headline: Aid Sought for Sabena
abstract: The Belgian Government has asked the European Community to approve a $554 million aid package for Sabena, the state-owned airline, the community's commission said today. The commission will decide within two months if the proposal meets community competition rules limiting state assistance to companies, said a community official who insisted on anonymity. The Government also agreed to forgive $466 million of the airline's long-term debt.

headline: Tonka Headquarters to Close
abstract: Hasbro Inc. said today that it would integrate Tonka toys into Hasbro's other units, effectively shutting down the newly acquired division.   The announcement to lay off or relocate all 242 employees at Tonka's headquarters in Minneapolis came six days after Hasbro completed its friendly $486 million acquisition of the struggling toy maker.

headline: Kurdish Leaders Put Off 2d Meeting With Hussein
abstract: Kurdish rebel leaders have postponed a crucial second round of peace talks with President Saddam Hussein, which was scheduled to start today.    Neither the Kurds nor the Government explained the delay. But diplomats here said the opposition factions appeared to be divided over strategy, with some feeling they had no need to rush into a settlement unless they could get the right terms.

headline: Patents; A Dental Gel to Clean the Teeth of Infants
abstract: Two New Jersey inventors obtained a patent this week on a dental gel to clean the gums and teeth of infants and children too young for toothbrushes.    The gel, which the inventors said could also prove useful for adults who have lost their teeth, is designed to remove the plaque-like film created by the fermented residue of milk and other foods. Instead of using a toothbrush, the parent massages the gel over the infant's gums with a finger.

headline: Kurd Reports Agreement on Autonomy
abstract: The Kurdish guerrilla leader Massoud Barzani said today that the Government of President Saddam Hussein had approved a draft agreement providing for free elections for an autonomous provincial legislature within three months in the Kurdish lands in the north of Iraq.   Eventually, he said, the agreement will give the Kurds autonomy in all matters except national security and the police. He also said the agreement called for democratic elections throughout Iraq within six months.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Pathe Owner Is Pressed To Sell Stake in Studio
abstract: Giancarlo Parretti, who acquired MGM/ UA last year, is being forced by a lender to sell a large stake in the troubled studio or lose ownership control, Mr. Parretti's company, the Pathe Communications Corporation, said in Government documents released today. He was ousted as chairman last month.   Pathe also appeared close to resolving a dispute with a group of creditors who had filed a petition to force the MGM-Pathe Communications Company, the film studio subsidiary, into bankruptcy court.

headline: Communists Win Free Vote in Albania
abstract: The Communist Party, entrenched here for more than four decades, overcame voting setbacks in Albania's cities and returned to power in this country's first modern and free elections, all parties agreed today.    Among the bitter setbacks in the election on Sunday was the defeat of President Ramiz Alia, the head of the nation's Communist Party, in his parliamentary district in the capital by a young geologist representing the newly formed opposition Democratic Party.

headline: Trump Report On Finances
abstract: A report prepared by the New Jersey Gaming Enforcement Division says the Trump Organization will topple unless it completes agreements with creditors owed nearly $2 billion on assets owned by Donald J. Trump.   The New Jersey agency prepared the report as part of the relicensing hearings for the Trump Taj Mahal Casino. The state Casino Control Commission must determine if the casino and the New York-based Trump Organization can prove financial stability.

headline: Nippon Steel Reportedly Settles Patent Suit
abstract: The Nippon Steel Corporation has agreed to pay $5 million to $10 million to settle a patent infringement lawsuit filed by the Allegheny Ludlum Corporation, Allegheny Ludlum said today.   Allegheny Ludlum, a specialty steel maker, said the agreement called for Nippon to pay $5 million by May 15. Nippon also agreed to pay another $5 million, contingent on proceedings in the Federal Patent and Trademark Office.

headline: Market Place; SmithKline's Expiring Patents
abstract: SINCE last April, the prices of the British shares and American equity units of SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., the British drug company, have soared 73 percent and 80 percent, respectively.    Many analysts still recommend buying them, on expectations they could climb more. But a growing number are urging investors to be conservative in their purchases or to stop buying. They are uneasy about SmithKline's ability to come up with new drugs to take over from some of the company's main drugs on which patents have or soon will expire. Those are Tagamet, an anti-ulcer drug; Amoxil, an antibiotic, and Dyazide, an anti-hypertension medicine.

headline: Weatherford to Send New Chief to Kuwait
abstract: In a few weeks, Philip L. Burguieres plans to get on an airplane headed for Kuwait to scout out sales prospects for Weatherford International Inc. He said the destruction of the oil wells there by Iraqi soldiers would provide opportunities for the company, which makes equipment used in wells and provides services for drillers.    "We will come in after the fires are put out," he said in an interview. "A lot of the cement in the burning wells was damaged and will have to be replaced."

headline: Go-Video 'Fib' to Japanese
abstract: The founder of Go-Video Inc. says he told a "fib" when he wrote to Japanese executives in 1988 that his tiny company had received hundreds of thousands of orders for its unique dual-deck videocassette recorder.   Go-Video had no orders at the time, R. Terren Dunlap acknowledged on Thursday.

headline: U.S. and Its Allies Plan to Station Troops in Turkey to Protect Kurds
abstract: The United States and its European allies plan to leave a 5,000-member contingency force in southeastern Turkey to protect the Kurds once coalition forces withdraw from northern Iraq in mid-July, European diplomats and Administration officials said today.    British and French officials, who are under heavy pressure from large Kurdish minorities in their countries to protect their countrymen in northern Iraq, have pressed the Bush Administration to contribute forces to a multinational brigade that could quickly respond to any possible retribution against Kurds by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

headline: New York's Police Chief Offers Advice to Pretoria
abstract: The South African police, who are confronting their own transition as the country abandons apartheid, have received some blunt advice from New York City's top policeman.   "An American lesson for policing post-apartheid South Africa might be: 'Get on with it,' " said Commissioner Lee P. Brown. "Don't waste the next century attempting to devise ways to frustrate the aspirations of a subjugated people."

headline: Recovery Awaits Housing Revival
abstract: AS the recession enters its 10th month, all eyes are on home construction. When Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, talks of a recovery, he is counting on new-home construction, particularly the building of single-family houses, to give the economy its first lift. Other economists share his view that without the stimulus of home building, the recession could drag on.    Will home construction revive soon, as Mr. Greenspan hopes?
