No one is in hotter pursuit of the answer to this question than David Seiders, chief economist at the National Association of Home Builders, and he says, "The demand may be there for new homes, but the builders may not be able to get the financing to build them."

headline: Gaping Loophole For Petrie Stores
abstract: IT is a rare company that can scoff at found money. So some investors and tax experts are puzzling over why the Petrie Stores Corporation has not taken advantage of a proven technique to solve a tax problem it has had for years.    Joseph H. Flom, the well-known lawyer who sits on Petrie's board, is ideally positioned to bring the matter to the attention of Milton J. Petrie, the 88-year-old chairman and majority owner of Petrie Stores: Mr. Flom's law firm was an adviser in another deal where the technique was used.

headline: The Search for Real People For Poli-Grip Commercials
abstract: AS advertisers rely more heavily on the real touch in product endorsements, consumers are popping up far more often as featured players in commercials. But advertisers find it tough to locate the right real people.   That is what the Block Drug Company discovered when it went searching for two women denture wearers for a campaign that begins tomorrow for its Super Poli-Grip denture adhesive.

headline: Home Shopping Settlement
abstract: A class-action lawsuit against Home Shopping Network Inc. by holders of the company's convertible subordinated debentures has been settled, with the company agreeing to comply with the debentures' original conversion provisions and to pay $15 million to the plaintiffs.   The suit was brought by bondholders who contended that the television retailer, based in St. Petersburg, Fla., failed to comply with a reset of the conversion price of the bonds.

headline: Marion Merrell
abstract: Marion Merrell Dow Inc. said an advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration had recommended approval of an intravenous dosage form of Cardizem, which is used to treat a rapid, irregular heartbeat. The drug is now available in tablet form, which was approved in 1982, and in sustained-release capsules, approved in January 1989.

headline: American Air's Parent Posts $195.6 Million Loss
abstract: The AMR Corporation, parent company of American Airlines, said it lost $195.6 million in the first quarter, with the weak economy and war-related travel worries cutting passenger loads. Squabbles with its pilots' union, route changes and higher prices for aviation fuel also contributed to the deficit.    Industry analysts said American's huge loss reflected continuing turmoil in the airline industry, which lost $2 billion from operations in the last quarter of 1990. The industry's first-quarter losses will probably exceed $1.5 billion, analysts said, although prospects appear to be improving.

headline: The Smart Alecks at Sun Are Regrouping
abstract: On the eve of the introduction of a new line of faster work stations a few weeks ago, a Hewlett-Packard executive pulled a stunt aimed at pumping up his sales team. At a pep rally in Las Vegas, company officials ceremoniously tore up a picture of Scott McNealy, the 36-year-old chairman of Sun Microsystems Inc.   It was a telling ritual, symbolic of the strong emotions -- part envy, part contempt -- engendered by Mr. McNealy and Sun. Since he co-founded the company nine years ago, the wily Mr. McNealy has dismissed convention, pioneering and embracing open systems to repeatedly outfox competitors and redirect the industry. His vision has spurred Sun's sales to $2.5 billion a year and put the company at the forefront of the fastest-growing computer segment, the work station market. Last week, Sun reported that in this year's first quarter, it had an eye-opening 59 percent profit climb on a 34 percent revenue gain.

headline: Account
abstract: * Regatta Sports Ltd., New York, a sportswear manufacturer, to Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss Inc., New York, with a budget of $5 million.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Athlone Industries, Parsippany, N.J., a metals and clothing company, will discontinue its swimwear business, take a $2 million charge against second-quarter results and set up a $1 million reserve for losses on the disposition. * Bellsouth Enterprises, a unit of Bellsouth Corp., a telecommunications company, will combine its Bellsouth Mobility Inc. and American Cellular Communications Corp. to consolidate all domestic cellular operations under a new company, Bellsouth Cellular.

headline: NEW TIES TO DUTCH TEMPT SURINAMESE
abstract: When this small, ethnically diverse South American country gained sovereignty from the Netherlands in 1975, many here proudly considered it a shining model of a prospering democracy in a continent riddled with poverty and oppression.   But 16 years later, after suffering plummeting living standards, rampant drug smuggling and a violent military dictatorship, the central issue for many in elections here on Saturday will be returning control over many matters of state to the Netherlands.

headline: Account
abstract: *The United States Air Force has retained Bozell Advertising, New York, as its advertising agency for another five years. Bozell said billings for the recruitment advertising and other promotional work totaled $25 million. The incumbent agency was chosen in a review over two other agencies: Richards Group, Dallas, and Hammeroff, Milenthal, Spence Inc., Columbus, Ohio.

headline: LATIN QUAKE TOLL PUT AS HIGH AS 70
abstract: An international relief effort began delivering assistance to Costa Rica today, a day after a severe earthquake struck a broad area of Costa Rica and Panama.    A Costa Rican Government official said that "no more than 20" had been killed by the quake in this country, but an official of the Costa Rican Red Cross said that at least 50 people had died. Reuters reported 23 killed in Panama. Reports from both countries indicated that at least 500 had been injured.

headline: All About/Snack Foods; Keeping the Gobblers, Chasing the Nibblers
abstract: As aging baby boomers thicken around the middle, they nibble instead of gobble. Blithe college students shovel corn chips straight from the bag into their mouths, but paunchy young professionals count their Ritz crackers as they reach for the bean dip.   The snack-food industry, which built its fortune on the voracious, must now come up with products that appeal to a variety of appetites, as well as answer consumers' growing worries about health and nutrition. To increase sales, it must win the nibblers and keep the gobblers.

headline: Control Data Unit
abstract: The Computing Devices Company, a Canadian subsidiary of the Control Data Corporation, signed a $1 billion contract with the Canadian Defense Department to develop and make a new voice and data communications system for the Candian Land Forces. Computing Devices will also set up a new facility in Calgary, Alberta, to house engineering, manufacturing and business development operations in connection with the contract.

headline: Greenspan Asserts the Recession May Be at an End, or Nearly So
abstract: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the recession might already have ended but that no measurable expansion of the nation's economy had yet begun.   "Clearly we have data which are subject to revision and are likely to be revised one way or the other," Mr. Greenspan told the House Ways and Means Committee. "But it's very difficult to get around the data of the last several weeks, which are strongly suggestive that the bottom is somewhere in the second quarter."

headline: New Jersey Bonds
abstract: An $84.8 million bond offering by the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency was initially priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 7.10 percent for securities due in 2011 and 2012 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds were priced to yield from 5.40 percent for an issue due in 1993 to 6 percent in 1996, 6.4 percent in 2001, 6.9 percent in 2007 and 7.05 percent in 2010. Underwriters said the bonds had been rated AA+ by S.& P.

headline: SLOVENIA IS MOVING TO INDEPENDENCE
abstract: As Yugoslavia continues to muddle through one crisis after another, the republic of Slovenia is coolly preparing to declare its independence. In so doing, the tiny Alpine republic of two million people will force a question that few inside or outside the crumbling federation are prepared to face: If Yugoslavia falls apart, what will take its place?    Piece by piece, the Slovenes have erected a structure that they say will give them the political and economic autonomy they need to break loose from Yugoslavia. The republic has already established control over its foreign trade, custom levies and sales taxes, introduced compulsory military service for its own forces, and come June 26, is expected to start issuing its own money and passports.

headline: Jobless Claims Drop by 70,000
abstract: The number of new unemployment insurance claims dropped by 70,000 in late March after soaring to the highest level in more than eight years, the Labor Department said today. But analysts cautioned that the drop might not be a sign the nation's jobless situation was stabilizing.   New applications for unemployment benefits fell to a seasonally adjusted 473,000 in the week ended March 30, compared with 543,000 the week before.

headline: Article 069691 -- No Title
abstract: Ernst & Young, one of the nation's largest accounting firms, has agreed to pay $1.5 million to settle charges that it portrayed the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association as profitable.   The California State Board of Accountancy said on Thursday that the firm had also placed an auditor, Francis J. O'Brien, on probation for three years and had prohibited him from participating in audits for a year. The New York-based firm also agreed to hold classes for its California auditors.

headline: Stagnant Pay: A Delayed Impact
abstract: THE incomes of most American households have failed to gain ground on inflation since 1973. That much-repeated economic statistic is now common wisdom. What's just now coming to light is the impact that so many years of stagnant incomes is finally having on the American psyche.    Broadly speaking, the old psychology of affluence -- the confidence that homeownership and high levels of consumer spending are birthrights -- is breaking down, demographers and pollsters say. Materialism endures; young Americans still value the good life. But they pick their purchases to simulate affluence, not achieve it. Thus, purchasing a BMW or an Armani suit might be out of reach, but not other stylish clothing or compact disk players or elegant food, and that is where the money goes.

headline: Hanging On in Textile Country
abstract: Economists and free trade proponents have generally assumed that when a domestic industry shrinks, workers will do what they must to survive: pack up and seek suitable work elsewhere in a process akin to natural selection in the capitalist system.   Here in Eden, where a local blanket factory is struggling to compete with less expensive imports in a slumping economy, the mill, owned by Fieldcrest Cannon Inc., has repeatedly furloughed John M. Biggs and given only four hours of work over the last five weeks to his wife, Alma Jean. But the Biggses are not budging.

headline: Barnett in Discussions With Ailing Southeast
abstract: Barnett Banks Inc., operator of Florida's largest bank, said today that it was in discussions with the ailing Southeast Banking Corporation, which is looking for a merger partner or buyout.    Barnett, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, said it had not decided whether to pursue a deal, but that it was examining Southeast's financial records.

headline: Spokane Shuts Its Exchange
abstract: The nation's smallest stock exchange has closed because of slumping silver and gold prices and waning investor interest, its president said.   Stan Covey, the president of the Spokane Stock Exchange, said operations ceased at the close of trading on Friday and papers were filed notifying the Securities and Exchange Commission of the closing.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Lindt & Sprungli, a chocolate company based in Stratham, N.H., to Mullen Advertising Inc., Wenham, Mass., with a budget estimated at $1 million.

headline: Mild Rise in Producer Price Index
abstract: Prices of finished goods as they left the factory rose a mild two-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Labor Department reported today. The report was fresh evidence that the recession is taking the steam out of inflation.   The rise in prices that manufacturers charge for goods sold to wholesalers and distributors was the first after four months of declines. But the increase resulted mostly from flukes in two areas -- fresh vegetables and tobacco products -- rather than from strong demand driving up prices, said Craig Howell, chief for producer prices at the department's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

headline: Making a Difference; A Casual Saturday Date With Drexel and Destiny
abstract: At a Friday lunch last year, Ira M. Millstein, a senior partner with Weil, Gotshal & Manges, asked Alan Miller, another partner at the prominent New York law firm, if he would be willing to spend a couple of hours on Saturday visiting Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Drexel had a cash flow problem, and it wanted a lawyer there to discuss options.    The next day, Mr. Miller, a bankruptcy expert, dropped by Drexel's world headquarters, where executives expressed confidence that the problem was minor.

headline: Mutual Funds; Good Numbers, Uneasy Feelings
abstract: The mood was jovial as mutual fund executives gathered in record numbers at their annual convention, sponsored by the Investment Company Institute, at the end of May. Last year, fund assets exceeded $1 trillion for the first time.   But the merrymaking in Washington was punctuated by a few sour notes. The industry must watch its step or it could fall from grace as profoundly as the once-fat savings-and-loan industry, warned James S. Riepe, managing director of T. Rowe Price Associates Inc. and the new chairman of the I.C.I. "The biggest challenge to any successful business is complacency," he told the 1,400 conferencegoers.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Miscellany
abstract: * CBS Television and Nabisco announced a sweepstakes in which the grand prize is a walk-on role in the soap opera "The Young and the Restless." The promotion ties the daytime drama to five Nabisco products: Ritz Bits, Triscuit Bits, Cheddar Wedges, Honey Maid Graham Bites and Premium Bits. * Two Houston agencies, Fogarty & Klein Inc. and Winius-Brandon Advertising Inc., will merge on July 1 into the firm Fogarty & Klein/ Winius-Brandon, with total billings estimated in excess of $97 million.

headline: ISRAEL BACKS PLAN FOR SINGLE SESSION ON MIDEAST PEACE
abstract: Israel said today for the first time that it was willing in principle to attend a regional peace meeting co-sponsored by Washington and Moscow.   But American officials here accompanying Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said there was still no agreement between Washington and Israel or between Israel and the Arabs on how such talks would be structured, what the agenda and timing would be and who would represent the Palestinians.

headline: Sage-Allen Merger With Addis Seen
abstract: Sage-Allen & Company, an 11-unit department store chain based in Hartford, reached a tentative agreement to merge with Addis & Dey's of Syracuse, which operates seven stores. The two companies said a final agreement was expected within the next few weeks. No financial information about the merger was available.   The companies, which both sell merchandise aimed at middle-income families, said each chain would continue to operate under its own name. They said they would have combined annual sales of $150 million. "The hope is that as a larger chain, we will have better purchasing power that will help in the marketplace today," said David Bonney, executive vice president of Sage-Allen.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt  * Air Products and Chemicals Inc., Allentown, Pa., is offering $100 million in 8 3/4 percent noncallable debentures due in 2021 at 97.718 to yield 8.97 percent through Lehman Brothers. The debentures are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: Iraq Ends Censorship
abstract: Iraq said today that it had lifted reporting restrictions imposed on visiting journalists during the Persian Gulf war. An Information Ministry official said Western reporters in Baghdad would no longer have to submit their reports to ministry censors before transmitting them. Visiting journalists will still need to be accompanied by ministry guides on trips outside Baghdad "for their own protection," the official said, but are free to move independently in the capital.

headline: Conflict in Yugoslavia; EUROPEANS SEND HIGH--LEVEL TEAM
abstract: Scrambling to forestall further worsening of the Yugoslav crisis, the European Community sent a high-level mediation team Friday to Belgrade aimed at bringing the federal Government and the rebel republics of Slovenia and Croatia back to the bargaining table.    After meeting Friday night with Prime Minister Ante Markovic of Yugoslavia in Belgrade and with Presidents Milan Kucan of Slovenia and Franjo Tudjman of Croatia in Zagreb, the capital of Croatia, the mediation team announced early today that all parties had agreed to measures to end the conflict.

headline: Making a Difference; Energy's 'Cadillac Asset'
abstract: Companies have raised billions of dollars on Wall Street by issuing notes backed by everything from mortgages and credit-card receivables to car loans. But the $616 million that the Mesa Limited Partnership borrowed last week marked the first time big insurers and other creditors accepted investment-grade notes secured by oil and gas reserves.    The unorthodox deal was orchestrated by Michael E. McMahon, a Salomon Brothers managing director and one-time banker to the energy industry for Morgan Guaranty Trust.

headline: News Corp. Will Cut Costs
abstract: The News Corporation, the international media concern headed by Rupert Murdoch, plans to cut costs by at least 10 percent in the next year, its new chief operating officer said in an interview published today.    All sections of the company -- which owns TV Guide and the Fox Broadcasting Company in the United States -- face cuts, Gus Fischer told the Australian Financial Review in an interview in London.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt * Caterpillar Financial Services Corp., Peoria, Ill., the financing and leasing subsidiary of Caterpillar Inc., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $700 million in debt securities. On Tuesday, the parent filed to sell $500 million in debt securities.

headline: China's Message: Jailing of a Hong Kong Man
abstract: The Chinese authorities apparently wanted to send a message to Hong Kong -- "Don't meddle in our politics" -- and it is Lo Hoi-sing's misfortune to be the vehicle for that warning.   In March, a court in the southern Chinese city of Canton sentenced Mr. Lo to five years in prison, accusing him of trying to help two prominent participants in the Tiananmen Square democracy campaign escape overseas. Even his family has not been able to visit him, but he is believed to be confined with common criminals in a prison in Canton.

headline: Seoul Ousts Aide for Police Brutality
abstract: In an unusual show of sensitivity to public opinion in a country where the Government has usually quelled dissent with a heavy hand, President Roh Tae Woo dismissed his Interior Minister over the weekend after the police reportedly beat a student protester to death with steel pipes.    Although South Korean university students often throw firebombs during demonstrations and the police frequently fire tear gas, this is the first case in which a student has been killed by police officers since 1987. Outrage over that incident helped bring down the Government of Chun Doo Hwan.

headline: Assets Back Large Offer
abstract: Asset-backed securities totaling nearly $500 million dominated the corporate market yesterday in two large offerings.    The SCFC Receivables Financing Corporation, a unit of Sears, Roebuck & Company, priced $181.2 million in automobile loan pass-through certificates yesterday that are backed by a pool of auto and light-truck loans generated through the Sears Consumer Financial Corporation.

headline: Chip Makers Talk in Europe
abstract: Thomson S.A., the state-owned French conglomerate, said today that it was talking with Europe's other leading computer microchip makers to pool their chip businesses. But one, Philips N.V. of the Netherlands, said it was not interested.   Philips, Siemens A.G. of Germany and Thomson's SGS- Thomson Microelectronics B.V. unit had a combined 10.5 percent share of the world computer chip market in 1990. Each, however, is widely perceived as too small to survive on its own.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Spanish Tourism Ministry, Iberia Airlines and American Express Co. to Ogilvy & Mather, New York, for a marketing campaign to promote tourism to Spain. American Express said the three-year campaign had a $10 million budget. * Marriott Ownership Resorts, Lakeland, Fla., a division of Marriott Corp., to Bozell Inc., New York, for strategic planning, advertising, direct mail and sales promotion. Billings are estimated at $4 million.

headline: 3 Killed as Israelis Hit P.L.O. Site in Lebanon
abstract: Israeli fighter-bombers blasted a Palestine Liberation Organization base in southern Lebanon today. The police said 3 people had been killed and 11 wounded.   Black smoke billowed from a two-story building flattened by air-to-surface missiles fired by two jets as the loud explosions sent hundred of residents fleeing to safer places, witnesses said. The target, at the outskirts of the Palestinian quarter of Mieh Mieh in the port city of Sidon, had served as headquarters for the intelligence branch of Al Fatah, the main component group of the P.L.O., the police said.

headline: Britain Trims Key Rate Again
abstract: The Government cut Britain's base lending rate today by half a percentage point, to 11.5 percent. It was the fifth cut in the benchmark lending rate since mid-February and brought the rate to its lowest level since August 1988.   A sharp drop in inflation, to 6.4 percent in April from 8.2 percent in March, paved the way for the latest cut, although the financial markets had been hoping for a full-point reduction.

headline: G.E. Venture In Soviet Deal
abstract: A venture between the General Electric Company and Snecma S.A. of France received an order today for up to $1 billion in jet engines for the Soviet Union, the latest in a series of East-West aerospace deals.   The accord calls for the venture, CFM International, to provide engines for at least 20 Soviet-made IL-86 aircraft, G.E. officials said at the Paris Air Show. They estimated the deal to be worth $750 million to $1 billion.

headline: De Klerk Visits Kenya's Chief, Urging Normal Ties
abstract: South Africa's long closed door to the rest of Africa swung open wider today when President F. W. de Klerk flew to Kenya for a brief but significant visit with President Daniel arap Moi.    Kenya became the 10th African country to receive Mr. de Klerk in the two years since he replaced P. W. Botha as National Party leader and then President and promised to dismantle apartheid.

headline: Auctions Expected to Draw Buyers
abstract: The credit markets face a record volume of Treasury debt issues at the quarterly refunding auctions this week, but analysts expect the sales to attract buyers because of the recent rise in yields.   The markets ended last week in confusion, amid conflicting readings of the Government's economic data for April. After several important interest rates were lowered by the Federal Reserve and big commercial banks, the Government on Friday issued contradictory data on employment trends last month.

headline: Eritreans, Fresh From Victory, Must Now Govern
abstract: When this city of palm-fringed boulevards fell to Eritrean rebel forces on May 24 after a 15-month siege, its residents began celebrations that have yet to die down.    Electrical power and water were restored, the curfew was lifted and happy throngs returned to the late-night cafes that had been a notable feature of this cosmopolitan city's social life before it became a battle zone.

headline: Zulu King Rebukes Mandela And Followers Over Violence
abstract: The traditional King of the Zulus accused the African National Congress today of waging a campaign of violence against his people.   King Goodwill Zwelithini, at a rally of 40,000 Zulus here, also said that South Africa's black people must work together to end factional violence and abolish apartheid, but he lashed out at the congress leader, Nelson Mandela.

headline: Record Coke Earnings On Strong Sales Abroad
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company, the world's largest soft-drink maker, yesterday reported a 13.2 percent earnings increase in the first quarter, to a record $320.9 million.    Emanuel Goldman, an analyst with Paine Webber Inc., said the results were slightly better than most analysts had expected. The strong performance was attributable to Coca-Cola's international business.

headline: New Campaigns
abstract: * Hagar the Horrible is going to be drinking a lot of Mug root beer this summer. The rotund Viking comic-strip character, who appears in more than 1,800 newspapers daily, will be featured in radio and television spots as well as in-store promotions. The campaign, created by Tracy-Locke, Dallas, for the Pepsico brand has the tagline, "Horribly good root beer."

headline: Top Japanese Brokerage Admits It Repaid Losses of Biggest Clients
abstract: In a dramatic comedown for the world's largest brokerage house, the Nomura Securities Company admitted today that it had discriminated against the majority of its customers by improperly compensating some of its biggest clients for stock market losses.    In its stunning announcement, Nomura reversed a heated denial that it made just one day earlier and confirmed reports that it had made nearly $120 million in such payments.

headline: F.T.C. Investigating Pricing of Appliances
abstract: Government regulators are investigating possible price collusion among the nation's biggest makers of home appliances, officials from the companies and the Federal Trade Commission said today.   The F.T.C. apparently began its inquiry after the chairman of the Raytheon Company, manufacturer of Amana and Speed Queen appliances, called at a 1989 meeting of securities analysts for industry competitors to raise prices.

headline: New Parliament in Albania Soon Breaks Up in Discord
abstract: The country's first multi-party Parliament session broke up in political discord today only a half-hour after it began when the main opposition party boycotted the Communist-dominated legislature.   The anti-Comunist Democratic Party, which holds 75 of the 250 seats in the single-chamber People's Assembly, stayed away over demands that the Government identify those responsible for the killings on April 2 of four party members in Shkodra, 40 miles north of Tirana.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Economy    Consumer prices edged down in March, for the first monthly decline since early 1986, the Government reported. Tumbling oil prices were the main factor in the 0.1 percent decline, but even the "core" rate rose a scant 0.1 percent after two months of sharp advances.  [ 37. ]

headline: Albania Picks a Caretaker Chief
abstract: After the resignation of the Communist Prime Minister, the President of Albania designated a 42-year-old former economist today to head a nonpartisan caretaker government until new national elections are held.   Members of the opposition Democratic Party said the appointment by President Rami Alia of the economist, Ylli Bufi, an alternate member of the Central Committee of the hitherto governing Communist Party, was acceptable to them.

headline: Baker Warns China Against Selling New Missiles
abstract: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d warned China today that there would be "profound consequences" for Chinese-American relations if Beijing sold newly developed ballistic missiles to Syria and Pakistan.   China's arms exports have become a matter of controversy as Congress considers President Bush's proposal to renew Beijing's preferential trade status. Mr. Baker said the United States had no "evidence or any indication" that China had actually shipped surface-to-surface missiles to Syria, despite a recent press report suggesting that a deal was near completion.

headline: Relocating To Cut Pay Faces Curb
abstract: The National Labor Relations Board announced a decision yesterday that could make it harder for companies to relocate factories to low-wage areas. The decision was the latest installment in a nearly 10-year battle between the Dubuque Packing Company of Omaha, and the United Food and Commercial Workers Union.   In 1981, the company refused to negotiate with the union when it closed a hog-slaughtering operation that employed more than 500 workers in Dubuque, Iowa, and opened a new plant in Rochelle, Ill., where wage rates were lower.

headline: Making a Difference; Hard Times At L.A. Gear
abstract: ROBERT Y. GREENBERG sold wigs, roller skates and shoe laces before founding L.A. Gear Inc. in 1985, and since then he has sold enough sneakers to make the company third in the athletic footwear market, behind Nike and Reebok. But having been battered recently by poor merchandising and marketing and a weak economy, Mr. Greenberg said last week that L.A. Gear is now trying to sell a "substantial" minority stake in the company in what analysts say is an effort to keep it afloat.   Over the last few years, L.A. Gear was one of the fastest-growing companies in the country. Sales grew from $70.6 million in 1987 to $902.2 million last year behind Mr. Greenberg's strategy of offering a cross between the performance athletic shoes of Nike and Reebok and a fashion shoe. But then, analysts said, Mr. Greenberg's fashion sense deserted him. The company got caught with an excessive inventory heading into the recession. And Mr. Greenberg may have compounded his problems by competing directly with Nike and Reebok in performance shoes.

headline: Main Lebanese Militia Moves Weapons South
abstract: Lebanon's largest Christian militia, forced by the Government to disarm in Beirut and surrounding areas, has been moving its heavy weapons into Israeli-controlled territory in the south of the country, security officials said today.   The officials said that a ship loaded with tanks and jeeps mounted with heavy machine guns sailed today from Junieh, a Christian port 13 miles north of here, bound for Naqura, a port controlled by Israel within the border area it calls a "security zone."

headline: Official Reported to Face Ouster After His Dissent on Iraq Exports
abstract: The White House has ordered the dismissal of an Under Secretary of Commerce for telling Congress on Monday that the Administration ignored warnings to limit the export of American technology to Iraq before the invasion of Kuwait, Administration officials said today.    One official said that Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher was told by the office of John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, that Dennis E. Kloske, Under Secretary for Export Administration and among the top half-dozen officials in the Commerce Department, should be removed from the payroll by June 1.

headline: Improving Mainframes At I.B.M.
abstract: The new president of I.B.M.'s mainframe computer division said in an interview yesterday that the company was working to "reincarnate" its most powerful and expensive computers using the same low-cost and speedy technologies that have led to the explosive growth of work stations and personal computers.    The company, which introduced a new generation of mainframe computers last September, said yesterday that it was redesigning its large systems to take advantage of the growing power of inexpensive chips known as microprocessors. These chips combine all of a computer's functions onto a single piece of silicon, thereby significantly lowering costs and raising computing speeds.  'We Live in Rented Space'     Nicholas M. Donofrio, who took over as president of the Data Systems division in January, also said yesterday, "I basically believe that our single greatest competitive threat is from our nontraditional competitors."

headline: Hanson Discounts I.C.I. Bid Rumor
abstract: Dampening speculation about an imminent takeover, the chairman of Hanson P.L.C. said his conglomerate wanted to work with Imperial Chemical Industries, but he did not rule out a future bid.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Monsanto Co., St. Louis, named R. Ian Lennox president of Monsanto Canada Inc. He succeeds J. Richard Darnaby, who has been named group vice president of the carbonated soft drink/table top group at Monsanto's Nutrasweet subsidiary. * Playtex Apparel Inc., Stamford, Conn., named Lee Chaden president of its United States apparel business.

headline: The Executive Life; What's in a Voice -- Or, Worse, Is Not
abstract: Until recently, Cynthia Whitney hadn't minded her voice. Friends praised its husky tone as soothing. Some even called it sexy. But the reaction changed when Ms. Whitney began doing more public speaking after taking a marketing job with the Geometry Asset Management Company, a New York investment firm. "People would ask about my sore throat," she said. "I didn't want clients to think I was sick."   So she contacted Dr. John Haskell, a specialist in voice disorders at Columbia University. He found that she was breathing too fast, which caused her vocal cords to form nodules, small bumps that prevent vocal cords from closing properly. After three months of voice therapy, Ms. Whitney says, clients no longer offer her lozenges and tissues. "My voice sounds much healthier," she says. "I'm not hoarse anymore."

headline: Riney Official Leaves For Backer Spielvogel
abstract: Jerrold H. Gottlieb appears to be on a whirlwind tour of the more challenging corners of Madison Avenue. After only seven months as executive vice president and general manager of Hal Riney & Partners' New York office, he has resigned to become an executive vice president at Backer Spielvogel Bates.   Joseph O'Neill, Riney's executive vice president and executive creative director, will assume Mr. Gottlieb's position as general manager. "Please know that this is a happy day for us here," said Jim Travis, Riney's president and chief operating officer. "Joe O'Neill is one of the greatest talents in New York." Riney, based in San Francisco, has had problems generating business for its New York office since opening it in 1986.

headline: Peace, but Little Else, Crystallizes for Angola
abstract: A quarter-century of bloodshed financed in large part by the United States, the Soviet Union, Cuba and South Africa preceded the handshake yesterday between Jose Eduardo dos Santos, the President of Angola, and Jonas Savimbi, the longtime leader of the Angolan rebels.    And with memories of a generation of violence still vivid in the minds of Angolans, the peace accord has laid to rest none of the questions about the country's future.

headline: MCA Files Countersuit
abstract: MCA Inc. today countersued the Motown Record Company and an investment group for more than $25 million.   The suit contends that the investors, Boston Ventures, schemed to change contractual arrangements with MCA after it became apparent that Motown would not become successful enough to be resold rapidly.

headline: Beirut Journal; Under the Cedars of Lebanon, Violence Is Buried
abstract: Two clans, one Christian, the other Muslim, met recently in the shade of the cedar trees that stand as the symbol of a united Lebanon, and put an end to their 30-year blood feud.    Down below in the Bekaa region, school buses carried Christian pupils to the Roman ruins at Baalbek, long a Shiite Muslim center. Teen-age boys and girls in shorts and light shirts were a startling sight for the bearded clerics and local women covered head to toe in black chadors.

headline: Home Shopping Settles Lawsuits
abstract: Home Shopping Network Inc., a shop-by-television channel, said it would pay about $33 million to settle class action suits by bondholders and shareholders. It also said it had raised income tax reserves to about $15 million to reflect a notice of deficiency from the Internal Revenue Service received after the release of second-quarter earnings.    Home Shopping said because of the suit settlements and the tax reserve increase it had restated second-quarter results to show a loss of $24.6 million, compared with previously reported earnings of $6.7 million, or 8 cents a share.

headline: La Quinta Accepts Slate of Nominees
abstract: La Quinta Motor Inns Inc. has agreed to nominate five directors proposed by dissident shareholders who include a group led by members of the Bass family of Fort Worth, the company said. The nominees will be voted upon at a special stockholders meeting on July 12. The Bass-led group, which owns nearly 15 percent of La Quinta's common stock, has criticized management's attempts to increase the company's value for shareholders.   Sam Barshop, La Quinta's chief executive, has agreed to vote his common shares in favor of the nominees. He is the the company's largest investor, with 19 percent of the stock. Six of La Quinta's 11 board members have agreed to resign before the special meeting. Mr. Barshop said a sixth nominee would be found in consultation with the dissident group. La Quinta operates more than 200 motels in 29 states. Its shares fell 12.5 cents today, to $13.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: New Chairman Elected At Coopers & Lybrand
abstract: Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, said yesterday that its partners had elected Eugene M. Freedman to take over as chairman when Peter R. Scanlon steps down on Oct. 1.    The 60-year-old Mr. Scanlon, who has headed the firm for nine years, was not eligible to run for a fourth term because he is too close to the firm's mandatory retirement age of 62. During his tenure, the firm was heavily criticized for sitting out the merger mania that engulfed the accounting profession in the late 1980's.

headline: U.S. Resumes Aid It Suspended to Yugoslavia
abstract: The Bush Administration announced today that it was resuming economic aid to Yugoslavia after a 20-day suspension.   Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d coupled the announcement with a rebuke to the leadership of the Yugoslav republic of Serbia for its "intensified repressive measures" against the rights of the 1.7 million ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, a Serbian province.

headline: Hasbro Extends Tonka Bid Again
abstract: Hasbro Inc., which is trying to complete its planned $470 million acquisition of the Tonka Corporation, has again extended its deadline for Tonka's bondholders to tender their securities, from 7 P.M. today until 7 P.M. on Monday. The toy manufacturers said in a joint announcement that they were negotiating with each other and with Tonka's bondholders to restructure the buyout to make it more attractive to the investors, who have balked at Hasbro's offer.   Hasbro has proposed reducing the price per share to be paid to holders of Tonka's common stock and increasing the amount to be paid to bondholders, the companies said. Hasbro has offered Tonka stockholders $7 a share. It has offered $800 per $1,000 in face value and $750 per $1,000 in face value on two types of Tonka bonds. Stockholders have approved the deal, but bondholders have refused to accept it. Hasbro is the nation's largest toy manufacturer. Tonka is the third largest.

headline: Unisys Pushes Severance Offer
abstract: The Unisys Corporation, the nation's third-largest computer maker, said it was asking employees to volunteer to take severance packages and leave the company to reduce its worldwide work force by at least 2,000. Unisys, whose debt totals $3.43 billion, has posted meeting notices or met with employees, asking them to take the severance packages. Employees have until Friday to take advantage of the program.

headline: Tokyo Stocks Off a Bit
abstract: Stock prices in Tokyo were slightly lower today. The Nikkei index of 225 stocks dropped 35.21 points, or a little more than a tenth of a percent, to close at 25,390.67.

headline: Natural Gas Issues Lead Retreat in Stock Market
abstract: The stock market was battered yesterday, largely because of the poor performance of natural gas company issues.   With volume on the New York Stock Exchange a relatively low 159.7 million shares or slightly above Tuesday's 156.3 million, the few big losers weighed down all the popular indexes. In all, 414 Big Board issues advanced and 1,156 declined.

headline: Safeguarding a Company's Reputation
abstract: To the Editor:   "Realizing the Benefits of a Good Name" (Forum, June 16) proposes a new corporate position, a chief reputation officer who would report either to the chief executive or to the board. Trouble is, there's already a chief reputation officer -- the chief executive. If a chief executive needs input before making a decision affecting the company's reputation, presumably he can get good advice from the chief communicator of the company.

headline: Albanian Communists Propose a Constitution
abstract: The Communists, overwhelming victors in Albania's first multi-party election in decades, proposed a constitution today that would embrace human rights and pluralism but fall short of full democracy.   The draft of the document, due for approval when the new Parliament meets next week, also gives sweeping powers to the President, who is likely to be the Communist incumbent, Ramiz Alia. Mr. Alia lost his Parliament seat in the elections, but the proposed constitution says Presidents do not have to be Parliament members.

headline: Prices Paid to Farmers Unchanged in April
abstract: Prices that farmers get for raw products were unchanged from March to April, but the overall commodity index slipped 1.3 percent below its level a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.   Higher prices for potatoes, onions, cotton and wheat had the most upward effect on the index, while lower prices for eggs, hogs, cattle and tomatoes were the main factors on the downside.

headline: Colorado River Unit Bonds Priced to Yield Up to 7.125%
abstract: The Lower Colorado River Authority priced $161.8 million in tax-exempt priority refunding bonds yesterday with a maximum yield of 7.125 percent for an issue due in 2011, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.   Serial bonds with shorter maturities are offered at prices to yield 4.8 percent in 1992 to 6 percent in 1996 and 6.55 percent in 2001. Other longer maturities include an issue due 2015 at a price to yield 7.05 percent.

headline: U.S. Army Doing the Work in Kuwait
abstract: The men and women who are trying to rebuild Kuwait wear the brown or green camouflage uniforms of the United States Army.   It is the American Army that has turned the electricity back on here, got the water running, cleared the highways of shrapnel and wrecked cars, hooked up those telephones that work, dredged the main port at Shuaiba and unloaded the ships, brought in drinking water and food, fixed the police cars, and fed the animals in the zoo.

headline: East Europe Latest Lure For M.B.A.'s
abstract: THE shifting economies of Hungary, Poland and Czechoslovakia have become magnets for M.B.A.'s and other students wanting a taste of what one dean calls a laboratory for capitalism.    Last spring two dozen students in the middle of their two-year programs at three graduate business schools -- Cornell, the University of Michigan and the University of Pennsylania -- made arrangements to work in Eastern Europe. Some paid their way and some deans used school funds to help or raised money from donors. Students received allowances for room and board from the companies or government entities for which they worked.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 5: 1991: MONDAY Cooper Tire & Rubber Gen Mtrs Corp Jefferson Pilot Corp Lockheed Louisiana Pac Corp Rohm & Haas Co Source Cap Inc

headline: Patents; Chip Uses Light Signals to Spur Data Processing
abstract: Using light instead of electronics to overcome a bottleneck in processing data, scientists at the California Institute of Technology have invented a computer chip that they say can recognize images a thousand times more quickly than desktop computers.    Based on evidence with laboratory prototypes, the inventors foresee uses for machines that read handwriting, sort mail and help robots to "see."

headline: Door Opens a Crack for Colombia's Indians
abstract: With his brown bowler hat, striped poncho and blue wraparound dress, Lorenzo Muelas Hurtado causes more than a sartorial clash as he moves among the delegates in business suits at Colombia's constitutional convention.    In politics, Indian tribal elders like Mr. Muelas have rarely found open doors among the capital's elite.

headline: FORUM; Arbitrate, Don't Litigate, at Work
abstract: The bitter debate over new civil rights legislation has taken a new turn with a second issue emerging along with quotas as a flash point: How the law is to be enforced.   The Civil Rights and Women's Equity in Employment Act of 1991 would leave employees free to sue employers -- even if they had agreed to submit their discrimination claims to arbitration or other nonjudicial forms of dispute resolution.  The business community argues that liberalized liability rules and increased damages would accelerate the flood of employment litigation into the courts. Last month, the Bush Administration offered a solution. It proposed that "reasonable alternative means of dispute resolution" be encouraged in place of litigation, providing that they are "knowingly and voluntarily agreed to."

headline: G.E. to Build Japan A-Plants
abstract: The General Electric Company said today that it had won a license from the Japanese Government to begin building two nuclear power plants in Japan that will bring the company more than $1 billion in revenue.    G.E. said the Ministry of International Trade and Industry had granted permits for its G.E. Nuclear unit and its partners, Hitachi Ltd. and the Toshiba Corporation, to begin the project. The license gives formal approval for the joint venture to proceed with the $4.8 billion order placed Friday by the Tokyo Electric Power Company, a G.E. spokesman said.

headline: Senior CBS Executive Leaves for Thompson
abstract: Jerome H. Dominus, a senior executive at CBS during much of his 25-year career there, has left the network to join J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. as its senior vice president, director of national television and programming.    Mr. Dominus, who was most recently senior vice president for entertainment and marketing sales in the network's marketing division, will work with the agency's offices in Chicago, Detroit and New York to develop negotiating strategies for its clients. Among his responsibilities, Mr. Dominus will inherit the duties formerly undertaken by John Sisk, who retired last month as senior vice president and director of network broadcast at the agency.   "This is a man we've been pursuing for some time," said Ron Burns, chief executive of J. Walter Thompson North America.

headline: Preparing for London Conference, Gorbachev Meets With Reformers
abstract: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev conferred today with the chief architects of a radical plan for reforming the Soviet economy and was reported to be "hard at work" on his own proposal to present to the leaders of seven economic powers next month in London.   The Soviet leader described as "remarkable" the complex free-market economic strategy fashioned by a group led by Grigory A. Yavlinsky, a liberal Soviet economist, and Graham Allison, a Harvard professor, the two said after visiting the Kremlin.

headline: Japan Trade Surplus Up
abstract: Japan's trade surplus grew in April for the fourth consecutive month, swelling by 79.3 percent, to $6.31 billion, from the period a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said today. The surplus with the United States in April shrank 7.2 percent from a year earlier, to $2.26 billion, but the surplus with Europe and Asia widened sharply. Over all, exports totaled $24.07 billion, up 9.8 percent from April 1990.

headline: Stocks Lower in Tokyo
abstract: Tokyo stocks finished lower today in light trading. Brokers said that investors were reluctant to move while the direction of interest and exchange rates remained uncertain. The Nikkei index of 225 issues ended down 159.68 points, or less than 1 percent, to 26,607.65. At midday, the Nikkei was stronger, up 29.00 points, to 26,796.33, on a volume of 250 million shares. "The market is extremely boring," one trader said after morning trading. "But it is proving quite resilient in the light of Friday's fall in New York." On Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 27.72 points, to 2,896.78.

headline: Unresolved Questions
abstract: Although the draft agreement reached in Madrid appeared to satisfy environmental groups as well as the nations that had sought to keep open the option of mining in Antarctica, many questions remain unresolved.   For one, it remains to be seen whether the draft will be approved by the governments whose representative met in Madrid. Robert Ford, a spokesman of the State Department's Bureau of Oceans and Environment, said that the department had not yet had time to study the draft. Meanwhile, he said, it would be premature to guess whether the United States would ratify it or not.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chrysler Plant Manager Is Hired From Mazda
abstract: The expansion of Japanese automobile makers in the United States has provided more job opportunities for American factory managers, but few have returned to the Big Three after making the jump.   One who has is Frank L. Slaughter, who this week joined the Chrysler Corporation after five years in various manufacturing posts at the Mazda Motor Corporation's assembly plant in Flat Rock, Mich., most recently as operations manager.

headline: How Bush Overcame Reluctance and Embraced Kurdish Relief
abstract: The Administration's decision to create refugee camps for hundreds of thousands of Kurdish refugees in northern Iraq came after two weeks of resisting similar proposals by President Turgut Ozal of Turkey and Prime Minister John Major of Britain.   Caught between a desire to relieve the suffering of hundreds of thousands of Kurdish refugees and a determination to stay out of Iraq's turmoil and bring all American troops home, Mr. Bush and his senior aides were initially reluctant to agree to to any plan that they argued could fuel Kurdish separatism, contribute to the dismemberment of Iraq, set a dangerous precedent for interference in the internal of sovereign states and recommit American ground forces on Iraqi territory.

headline: A Senior Vice President for Simon & Schuster
abstract: When she joined Prentice Hall as a copywriter in 1968, Janet Wikler wrote "flap copy" for book jackets, including that on Vince Lombardi's autobiography and on the large-print edition of "The Power of Positive Thinking." Last week, she was appointed to the newly created position of senior vice president and director of strategic planning of Simon & Schuster.   In announcing Ms. Wikler's appointment, Richard E. Snyder, the chief executive of Simon & Schuster, said she would help identify new business lines, products and markets, as well as help gain leverage from existing assets.

headline: Rome Journal; Taxes Flow to the Church; Its Cup Runneth Over
abstract: Churches are about as empty as ever most Sundays across Italy, and Roman Catholic priests complain that sometimes their search for the pious is as rewarding as casting a net in fished-out waters.   But by one nonecclesiastical standard, tax collections, the church seems to be doing better than ever in this dyed-in-the-wool Catholic land, where religion is not so much a beacon of faith as an inescapable way of life.

headline: Canadian Inflation Rate
abstract: Canada's consumer price index climbed slightly in May, mainly because of tax increases, the Government said today. The index rose a seasonally adjusted two-tenths of 1 percent after rising one-tenth in April.

headline: Stanley Works Is Suing Newell
abstract: Stanley Works Inc. said it had sued the Newell Company under Federal antitrust laws to prevent it from buying 15 percent of the company. The suit, filed in Federal District Court in Connecticut, seeks to block Newell, which makes consumer hardware and housewares, from following through on its intention to buy the shares. Last month, Newell filed its intentions under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act that it sought to buy 15 percent to 25 percent of the common shares of Stanley Works.    Newell, based in Freeport, Ill. currently owns 1 percent of Stanley, which is based in New Britain. Stanley Works also said that employee stock ownership plans had bought about five million common shares at $37.125 each. Their stake in the company has risen to about 25 percent of Stanley's outstanding shares. The shares rose $3.375, on the New York Stock Exchange today, to $41.50.

headline: Tokyo Stocks Off a Bit
abstract: Stock prices were down slightly in late trading in Tokyo today. Less than an hour before the close, the Nikkei index of 225 was off 11.93 points, or less than one-tenth of a percent, to 25,777.69.

headline: People
abstract: * Clifford Scott has joined the Los Angeles office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos Inc. as vice president, director of business development. * James F. Boland has been named executive vice president of Bozell Healthcare.

headline: 2 Counties' Bonds In Pennsylvania
abstract: To finance the refunding of bonds previously sold for a Philadelphia Electric Company project, the Delaware County and Montgomery County Industrial Development Authorities are selling a total of $117.03 million in pollution control revenue refunding bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.    The $90 million Delaware County issue due on April 1, 2021, has a 7 3/8 percent coupon and is offered at 99 to yield about 7.4583 percent, while the $27.3 million Montgomery County bonds due on the same maturity date as the Delaware issue has a 7.60 percent coupon and is offered at 99 to yield about 7.6851 percent.

headline: U.S. and Allies Move to Ease Cold War Limits on Exports
abstract: The United States and its allies have decided to ease restrictions substantially on the kinds of high-technology goods, like personal computers, that the West can export to the Soviet Union and other nations considered security risks.    The Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls, known as Cocom, agreed to cut in half the number of high-technology items that cannot be exported to these countries without special licenses. It is the most sweeping action yet in liberalizing high-technology trade with the Soviet Union, other Communist countries and the members of the recently dissolved Warsaw Pact.

headline: Patent Granted For Drug From Yew
abstract: A CHEMISTRY professor at Florida State University in Tallahassee has received a patent for a method of making a partly synthetic version of a promising cancer-fighting drug that is currently available only in small amounts from the bark of the rare Pacific yew. The newly patented process offers the possibility of making larger quantities of the drug, taxol, without killing the rare trees.   The drug shows promise against ovarian, breast and lung cancer.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Atari Corp., Sunnyvale, Calif., the personal computer company, will sell its Taiwan plant to an undisclosed buyer for $60 million. * Baker Industries, Parsippany, N.J., a maker of fire detection and prevention equipment and a subsidiary of Borg-Warner Corp., reached agreement with Federal prosecutors under which its Baker Protective Services unit will pay a $1 million fine for inaccurate billing of airline clients by former employees.

headline: Caution Urged on Recovery
abstract: The White House said today that it was too early to say the recession is ending, despite some hopeful signs.   But the Presidential spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said at a news conference that the Administration still believed that the downturn, which began in the second half of last year, would be short.

headline: Kurds Overflow U.S. Mountain Camp
abstract: The stepped-up flow of tens of thousands of Kurdish refugees from the western Turkish mountains has all but filled the new tent city here, and about 3,500 people were camped today around the registration tents just outside.    "The inn is too good," said Maj. Carl Fisher, an Army civil affairs reserve officer from Green Bay, Wis., as he went on his rounds, checking on the overflow of refugees waiting in the reception area, near medical tents.

headline: Wang Loss at $48.9 Million
abstract: Wang Laboratories Inc. said today that it had lost $48.9 million in its third fiscal quarter. The computer company blamed the sluggish economy for hindering efforts to turn around its finances.   The results for the three-month period ended March 31 compared with a loss of $146.6 million in the quarter a year earlier.

headline: Pressing Iraq to Pay for Kurds
abstract: Washington wants Iraq to pay for the Kurdish relief effort. It is seeking to link approval of resumed Iraqi oil exports to such payments. Page A16.

headline: G.E. and Toshiba in Appliance Deal
abstract: The General Electric Company and the Toshiba Corporation agreed to work together to expand sales of G.E. appliances in Asia. The imported products, mainly large refrigerators and European-produced appliances, will be distributed by Toshiba in Japan, and Toshiba will provide after-sales services.    Gary Rogers, a senior vice president at G.E., said that through a venture to be established in Tokyo next month, the company hoped to increase its sales of appliances in Japan to $50 million a year by 1995, from about $5 million a year now.

headline: Dow-Marion Insider Case
abstract: A woman was charged today with providing inside information to two men who are accused of making $415,000 in illegal profits on the merger of a Dow Chemical Company affiliate and Marion Laboratories.    Barbara Aldrige was charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission with illegally passing confidential corporate information, while the men were charged with making illegal trading profits. The charges were listed in a civil complaint filed by the commission in Federal District Court in Kansas City, Mo.

headline: Report Critical of Drop in Savings
abstract: Criticizing the United States in particular, the coordinating bank for the world's central banks said today that long-term economic growth in the industrial world was slipping because of a sharp drop in savings as well as a decline in public investment by many governments.   In a report issued today, the Bank for International Settlements said the drop in savings -- which provides the money for investment for future growth -- could also hurt Eastern Europe and the third world because they need to attract investment money to spur their economies.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: THE ECONOMY    A law intended to encourage involvement of minority-owned firms in managing assets seized from failed savings and loans appears to be having little effect. Government documents show that Federal contracts to manage everything from multimillion-dollar loan portfolios to small apartment buildings have gone almost entirely to companies owned by whites.  [ Page A1. ]   The U.S. will lift itself out of recession in the second half and unemployment will stop climbing in that period, the O.E.C.D. forecast. The group is widely respected for its projections.  [ D1. ]

headline: United Air Seeks New British Route
abstract: United Airlines asked the Transportation Department for approval to fly daily nonstop flights from Chicago to Stansted Airport, 26 miles northeast of London. If approved, service could begin in October, said the airline, a unit of the UAL Corporation. "Stansted is a very attractive location for us," UAL's chairman, Stephen M. Wolf, said.

headline: Credit Card Lawsuit Filed
abstract: Visa International and Mastercard International are seeking $95 million in damages from telemarketing companies they assert cheated thousands of people seeking low-interest credit cards.    The lawsuit, filed in Federal court here on Monday, charged that fraud and high-pressure sales tactics had been used to get people to pay inflated sums -- from $70 to $200 -- on the promise they would obtain low- interest bank cards.

headline: The Media Business: ADDENDA; Top Endorsers Of the N.B.A.
abstract: The N.B.A. playoffs aren't over, but Foote, Cone & Belding, San Francisco, has already chosen the winners for product endorsements.   In a report, "Dribbling for Dollars," the advertising agency picked Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls as first in the starting lineup of endorsers. Mr. Jordan already pitches products for a long list of companies, including Coca-Cola and McDonald's.

headline: Open Positions on Short Sales Off 1.5% on Nasdaq
abstract: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that for the month ended May 15 the number of shares sold short and not yet covered fell by 4.1 million, or 1.5 percent, to 260 million. The figures represent short selling in 2,270 stocks; in April the short selling was spread among 2,279 issues.    The association also said that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered in 1,189 less active over-the-counter securities totaled 37.1 million as of mid-May. These securities are traded in the automated quotation system of the association, but not in its national market system. The total represented a decrease of about 1.6 percent from the 37.7 million shares held short in the April period, when 1,235 securities were involved.

headline: Market Place; A Vision of Profits In a Better Mouse
abstract: WITH so many young biotechnology ventures and so few successful products, most companies in the sector are still evaluated as much on their visions as on their track records.    One company benefiting from that attitude is tiny American Biogenetic Sciences Inc., which owes its existence to a strain of mice raised at Notre Dame University. The company, based in Copiague, L.I., says its mice give it a leg up in the worldwide race to develop new antibodies for a variety of medical applications, including tests for potential heart attacks, strokes and blood clots.

headline: Texscan's Shares Plunge by $2.375
abstract: The shares of the Texscan Corporation, a El Paso-based supplier to the cable television industry, fell sharply on the American Stock Exchange when trading was resumed after an eight-day suspension. The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading in the stock on April 22 after two men were indicted on charges of stock manipulation in connection with a rapid rise of the shares last month.    Texscan's stock fell $2.375 yesterday, to $5.625, with only 16,800 shares changing hands. That was in sharp contrast to trading in the four days from April 16 to 19, in which 272,400 shares, or about a quarter of the shares in public hands, were traded and the price rose from $5.125 to $8. Thomas C. Payne, chairman of the Payne Financial Group, a public relations firm in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Mark P. Malenfant, a senior vice president of Biltmore Equitites and Securities Ltd., a brokerage firm in Scottsdale, Ariz., have been charged with manipulation during that period.

headline: Do Extend Nuclear Plant Life
abstract: To The Editor:   George Sterzinger's comments on "First-Generation Nuclear Retirement" (Forum, June 2) make neither economic sense nor engineering sense.

headline: U.S. Eases Irish Trade
abstract: The Commerce Department said today that it was easing regulations governing the exports of controlled goods and technology to Ireland. The revised regulations include expedited license processing and re-exports from Ireland of more American-made products to China and some allied nations. Controls are established for national security reasons and the department's policy is to extend licensing benefits to countries that have programs designed to guard against diversion of controlled items.

headline: Kuwait Jails 5 Opponents for Homecoming Posters
abstract: Five Kuwaiti students from a leading opposition group have been jailed since Friday for putting up posters welcoming Kuwaitis home from abroad.    The arrests, announced by opposition figures here today, are the latest crackdown on opponents of the Sabah royal family, although in this case, the activity for which the five were seized was without evident political content.

headline: Publisher Looks to Hispanic Children for Growth
abstract: Generations of American children have been thrilled by Charles Perrault's 300-year-old tale about the rascally cat who became a lord. Soon, even more children in the United States -- those who primarily speak Spanish -- will be able to read "Puss in Boots."    This fall, Farrar, Straus & Giroux will publish "El Gato Con Botas."

headline: Kurds 'Are Living in Hell' Stranded on Mountain Road
abstract: A trickle of aid has begun to reach Kurdish refugees in this remote and wild border area, but for thousands stranded on the sheer drop-offs and turns of the mountain road out of Iraq, "We are living in hell," as one of them put it.    Dysentery and infant diarrhea are epidemic. Sanitation is nonexistent, and refugees defecate in the road next to their tents. Medical services are paltry. Thousands of families subsist in bombed-out hulls of villages destroyed in the Iran-Iraq war or in primitive lean-tos perched on the steep sides of 7,000-foot peaks.

headline: Drug Review Canceled
abstract: An advisory committee of the Food and Drug Administration has canceled a July 22-23 meeting at which the Cetus Corporation's interleukin-2 cancer drug was to have been reviewed, an F.D.A. official said today. No reason was given for the meeting's cancellation, and the panel has not set a new date to review the drug, the official said. In its initial review of interleukin-2, to be marketed by Cetus under the name Proleukin, an F.D.A. advisory committee last July put off action on the drug as a treatment for advanced kidney cancer. Late last month, an agency official said the drug was being reviewed.

headline: Symposium Tallies Cost of Quebec Separation
abstract: Quebec, which by itself ranks as the ninth largest trading partner of the United States, could survive economically as an independent country, but the economic costs imposed on 6.5 million Quebecers would be heavy.    That was the conclusion of a symposium on federalism in North America at McGill University, which challenged assumptions of the separatist Parti Quebecois that a unilateral declaration of independence would bring little change in the economic life of the province.It was the first time that any institution here has addressed in a substantive way the economic implications of the threatened spinoff of most of French-speaking Canada, should constitutional reform efforts collapse again, as they did last June.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Economy    The House authorized the Bush Administration to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Mexico and a 107-nation pact to reduce trade barriers. The vote was 231 to 192 amid last-minute lobbying by labor unions, businesses, environmentalists and the Administration. The Senate took up the issue immediately.  [ Page A1. ]

headline: Fannie Mae Chief Gets $27 Million
abstract: The chairman and chief executive of the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, retired this year with $27 million in compensation, The Washington Post reported in its Wednesday issue.    The chairman, David O. Maxwell, received $7 million in annual compensation and $20 million in a lump-sum pension payment, The Post said. Efforts to reach Mr. Maxwell, whose phone number is unlisted, were not successful tonight. Mr. Maxwell had been at Fannie Mae, a Federally chartered, shareholder-owned financial institution that helps to finance home purchases, since 1981.

headline: Integra Payments
abstract: The Integra Hotel and Restaurant Company, an independent operator of Holiday Inns, suspended interest payments on all its subordinated debentures issued under its former name, the Brock Hotel Corporation. The company cited a lack of sources for borrowing and negative cash flow for its decision. Integra also said it expected to pay the $2.3 million in principal owed on debentures due for redemption on May 1.

headline: 3 Iraqis Accused Of Smuggling
abstract: A Federal grand jury in Alexandria, Va., indicted three Iraqi citizens today on charges of trying to smuggle millions of dollars worth of embargoed electronic parts for military equipment to Baghdad.   The indictment said that since President Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, the three men tried to smuggle to Iraq $2.5 million worth of components, including $1.2 million worth of highly advanced electronic connectors used in tanks, military aircraft, communications systems and various radar systems.   They were indicted after an undercover investigation by agents of the United States Customs Service. Only one of the men, Mohammed Jafar, 31 years old, is a United States resident and faces immediate arrest. The other two named in the indictment, Anas Malik Dohan and Zaid Jafar, are believed to be living in either Iraq or Jordan and officials said they did not anticipate being able to apprehend them anytime soon.

headline: Bush Clears Soviet Trade Benefits and Weighs Role in London Talks
abstract: President Bush today granted an extension of trade benefits for the Soviet Union and was said to be increasingly receptive to inviting President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to London at the time of the July summit meeting of seven leading industrial nations.   In a move intended to help Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Bush took the technical steps necessary to allow $1.5 billion in credits for additional food purchases to be granted to Moscow. In December, the President, for the first time, approved measures allowing the Soviets $1 billion in credits.

headline: Economic Scene; Predicting When Upturn Will Start
abstract: ECONOMISTS once thought that by using computers and large-scale econometric models, they could develop tools for more accurate forecasting. But such hopes have given way to the more humble belief that the best they can do is to state what they think are the odds on various possible developments ("scenarios" in the current economic jargon). The problem of macroeconomic forecasting has been made even more difficult by the complex interactions between national economies and the world economy.   Prof. Rudiger Dornbusch of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology says the world economy is now in the midst of a "significant slowdown," with outright recession in the Anglo-Saxon countries and minimal growth in Europe, except Germany. Only Asia is keeping up the momentum of world growth, but even there Japan's growth rate is slipping below 4 percent.

headline: Managing; Putting a Practical Spin on Training
abstract: In conventional management development, training is training, doing is doing and never the twain do meet. Would-be mechanics get cars to fix and aspiring cooks stir pots on the stove. Yet the briefcase crowd still gets plunked in classrooms and plied with theory.    But managers at today's down-sized corporations are so loaded up with work that few have the luxury of training for training's sake. As a result, many companies are truncating the classroom parts of management training and are instead opting for "action learning," a hybrid technique in which classroom training is immediately followed by sessions in which the trainees use what they learn to tackle actual projects and problems that their companies have identified as requiring attention.

headline: Making a Difference; No Waiting in Line for These Bank Customers
abstract: Bankers have always had a special fondness for rich people, and like Mr. Drysdale in "The Beverly Hillbillies" TV show, they are more than willing to provide extra-special service for the 1.5 million households with $1 million of investments or incomes above $250,000.    In recent years, "private banking" has become a hot field, both because of high profits and the growth that is expected as the American population ages and becomes wealthier.

headline: Albanian President Gives Up His Communist Leadership
abstract: President Ramiz Alia of Albania today gave up all his Communist Party posts, including the party leadership that he inherited in 1985 from the long-ruling Stalinist Enver Hoxha, the Albanian state radio reported today.   The move followed constitutional modifications that said the head of state could not hold party office.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing; For Some, Best Prose Is in Blurbs
abstract: SIMON & SCHUSTER is apparently still deciding whether to publish "Just Killing Time," a novel by Derek V. Goodwin that was submitted with phony endorsements, or blurbs, from John le Carre and Joseph Wambaugh. Whatever is decided, one thing is sure: The "blurb industry," as some publishing executives call it, is recession-proof and is here to stay.    Few books appear without at least one testimonial to their value or to the skill of their authors. No matter that many blurbs on book jackets and in advertisements amount to literary backscratching, in that they are written by friends of the author, the agent or the editor. They serve their purpose if they call attention to a particular book in a very crowded field.

headline: B.S.B. Moves To Take Cue From Infiniti
abstract: BACKER SPIELVOGEL BATES said yesterday that it had hired Donald Easdon, a creative director best known for his unconventional campaign to introduce Nissan's Infiniti luxury car, which featured shots of rocks and trees, with nary a car in sight.    Mr. Easdon's appointment is the first in a series of top management changes that are part of a restructuring at B.S.B. in the wake of the loss last month of the $110 million Miller Lite beer account.

headline: I.B.M.'s Chief Criticizes Staff Again
abstract: John F. Akers, the chairman of I.B.M., wants all his employees to know that he meant it in April when he vented his frustrations about the company's poor performance to a group of managers.    On Friday, in an electronic message to employees, Mr. Akers punched home his original point that some of them were not working hard enough.  [ Text of message, page D5. ]

headline: Borrowing by Consumers Down for 4th Month in a Row
abstract: Consumers cut back on borrowing for the fourth straight month in March, a degree of spending restraint not seen since 1980, when credit controls were in place, the Federal Reserve Board said today.    The amount of outstanding consumer installment credit -- loans on cars, furniture and other items that are paid off in monthly chunks -- fell by $931 million after declining a revised $201 million in February.

headline: Desperation at 3 Borders
abstract: Whether they are fleeing toward Turkey, Iran or Kuwait, Iraqis are undergoing ordeals of desperation and uncertainty. Articles, page A8.

headline: Equity Issues This Week
abstract: The following equity offerings are expected this week:   Arbor Drugs Inc., two million common shares. Lehman Brothers.

headline: L'Oreal Official Investigated By U.S. Over Pro-Nazi Past
abstract: The United States Justice Department has opened an investigation to determine whether the chairman of the $1 billion American affiliate of L'Oreal, the French cosmetics company, should be barred from the United States for his pro-Nazi activities during World War II.   The department's Office of Special Investigations is looking into whether Jacques Correze, a 79-year-old Frenchman, should be barred because of activities in groups that carried out anti-Semitic attacks.

headline: General Dynamics Reports 9% Decline in Operating Net
abstract: The General Dynamics Corporation, the giant military contractor, said yesterday that its first-quarter operating earnings fell 9 percent, with sharply lower sales of military aircraft.    Net income dropped 54 percent primarily because the company had a one-time gain of $61 million from the settlement of litigation against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in the first quarter of last year.

headline: 'Mom Managers' and the 'Web of Inclusion'
abstract: To the Editor:   I am intrigued by Judy Rosener's hypothesis on women's management styles ("Grace Pastiak's 'Web of Inclusion,' " May 5). I wish, though, she had explored other facets of the principle. Is the "web of inclusion" common to all women managers? Or is it more prevalent among "mom managers" such as Mrs. Pastiak, with her two young children and most likely a pile of parent books on her reading table? Perhaps Mrs. Pastiak is in the vanguard of a different school of management theory -- those mom managers who may be incorporating principles of nurturing and developing human potential from home into their professional lives. ANN THERESE PALMER Lake Forest, Ill., May 5

headline: Stocks Fall And the Dow Drops 28.46
abstract: Wave after wave of computerized program selling, and widespread investor concern that interest-rate cuts may be out of the question for a while, toppled stock prices yesterday.    A forecast from Compaq Computer that second-quarter profits would be down this year also contributed to the decline. Compaq's stock price fell 9 3/8, to 52 1/2, and it was the most active stock on the Big Board, with 6.4 million shares changing hands.

headline: SOME KURDS IN IRAN RETURNING TO IRAQ
abstract: Riddled with dysentery and typhoid after days of foul and fruitless waiting to enter Iran, some Kurdish refugees at this checkpoint on the Iran-Iraq border today abandoned their flight from Saddam Hussein's army and began heading back into Iraq.   They said they would walk 11 miles to Halabja, a Kurdish stronghold twice destroyed by Mr. Hussein's army and the scene of an infamous 1988 massacre in which 5,000 or more civilians died from mustard gas and cyanide.

headline: For Kuwaitis, First War and Now Wheeze
abstract: The weather forecast, as carried today by the Armed Forces Desert Network: smoky with a chance of thundershowers.    This time the forecast was right, although predicting the smoke part was not much of a challenge. It travels on the breeze, and with 500 burning oil wells sending off tall columns of smoke across the flat horizon, you don't need a weatherman to know which way the wind blows.

headline: GORBACHEV YIELDS ON SHARING POWER AND CUTS IN PRICES
abstract: President Mikhail S.
