Gorbachev yielded significantly to the Soviet republics' demands for power sharing today as he promised revisions of his highly unpopular price and tax programs and announced a new agreement with the major republics for a "radical enhancement" of their role in governing.   The surprise pact was worked out with leaders of 9 of the nation's 15 republics, including Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of the Russian federated republic and chief opposition critic of Mr. Gorbachev, at a private meeting held secretly at a dacha on Tuesday.

headline: TV Stations to Get Points of Light Spots
abstract: Beginning on April 25, the Advertising Council will distribute to television stations nationwide a series of spots that support the Points of Light Foundation.    The five spots, which were created on a pro-bono basis by Saatchi & Saatchi, seek to spread the foundation's appeal for Americans to undertake volunteer work. The theme line is: "Do something good, feel something real."

headline: 2 Boeing 777 Jets For French Airline
abstract: Euralair S.A., a French charter airline, said today that it had ordered two long-range versions of Boeing's new 777 twinjet. Euralair's chairman, Alexandre Couvelaire, said at the Paris Air Show that the planes will be delivered starting in 1997.   Euralair becomes the third customer for the 777. The Seattle-based Boeing Company has previously announced firm orders for 49 of the jets -- 34 by United Airlines and 15 by All Nippon Airways.

headline: Yeltsin Vies With 5 Today in Vote to Head Russia
abstract: After a brief but boisterous campaign, Boris N. Yeltsin faces five challengers on Wednesday in the Russian republic's first election for a new executive presidency.   There is little doubt on the eve of the election that the bulk of the votes will go to Mr. Yeltsin, the popular chairman of the Russian Parliament who has emerged as the champion of radical reform and decentralization and as the prime political rival to the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

headline: MacGregor Sports In Bankruptcy Sale
abstract: MacGregor Sports Inc., the bankrupt sports equipment manufacturer, put more than $2.2 million of equipment up for auction. The sale at MacGregor's three plants in Wisconsin was forced by the First Wisconsin Bank of Sheboygan, which foreclosed on MacGregor, saying that it owed more than $4.5 million.   MacGregor once made uniforms for the National Basketball Association and sold a wide range of sports equipment. The company, whose sales fell to $40 million in 1989 from $60 million in 1986, shut most of its Wisconsin operations after seeking protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code earlier this year. MacGregor has been plagued by financial difficulties since 1989.

headline: Addamax in Suit On Software Prices
abstract: Addamax, a Champaign, Ill., maker of computer security software, filed an antitrust lawsuit against the Open Software Foundation and two of its sponsors, the Hewlett-Packard Company and the Digital Equipment Corporation. The foundation was established in 1988 to create a version of the Unix operating system as an alternative to the one being developed by Sun Microsystems Inc. and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.    The complaint accuses the foundation and its sponsors of fixing prices for software technology. Earlier this year, foundation officials acknowledged that the organization was being investigated by the Federal Trade Commission.

headline: Korean Companies in China
abstract: Three more South Korean companies said today that they had received official approval to open branch operations in Beijing.   The Lucky-Goldstar International Corporation, which set up a trade office in the Chinese capital in 1988; Samsung Group's Samsung Company, which opened its office in 1985, and the Pohang Iron and Steel Company now can operate branches officially beginning on Thursday.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co., New York, said it had been selected by Ford Motor Co., Dearborn, Mich., to provide a telephone network to Ford's 5,500 dealerships nationwide. No price was disclosed. * Cargill Inc., Minneapolis, said it had acquired four flour mills from Pillsbury Co., Minneapolis, a unit of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., for $100 million.

headline: Brazil Accord on Computers
abstract: The Brazilian Congress has reached an accord that paves the way for a long-awaited opening of Brazil's computer market to imports, starting in 1992, legislators said today.   The accord would end a policy adopted in 1984 that protected Brazil's fledgling computer industry and that prompted United States trade retaliation.

headline: Scowcroft Went to Talk With Saudis, U.S. Says
abstract: President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, traveled to Saudi Arabia last week for high-level security consultations requested by senior advisers to King Fahd, according to Administration officials.   The officials, who declined to reveal any further details about the talks, said the trip took place after President Bush decided last Tuesday not to intervene further in the internal unrest in Iraq, an issue that is of potentially vital importance to the Saudi monarchy.

headline: U.N. Discusses South Iraq Refugee Havens
abstract: Diplomats and United Nations officials have been discussing the possibility that thousands of refugees now in southern Iraq may be admitted into Kuwait, Iran and Saudi Arabia, United Nations officials said here today.    There are some 30,000 refugees in the south of Iraq, many of whom backed an unsuccessful Shiite Muslim uprising there. The refugees have been under the protection of the coalition that drove Iraqi forces from Kuwait, but the coalition's troops are being pulled out of the area.

headline: GUILTY PLEA MADE IN PENTAGON CASE
abstract: In a significant development in a four-year investigation, a former senior Pentagon official pleaded guilty today to Federal conspiracy and bribery charges related to a conspiracy by a handful of officials, consultants and military contractors to rig the bidding on contracts and defraud the government.    The former official, Melvyn R. Paisley, an assistant Navy secretary from 1981 to 1987 in charge of procurement and development of military systems and engineering, entered his plea in Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va. The plea included a statement that detailed how some of the nation's largest military contractors were eager to offer bribes for confidential information that would give them an advantage in bidding for lucrative contracts.  Sentencing Set for Fall     Mr. Paisley, who had been identified by prosecutors as the highest-ranking official involved, faces up to 30 years in jail and up to $750,000 in fines. He is scheduled to be sentenced before Judge Claude M. Hilton on Sept. 27.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Interpublic's Earnings Decline 8.7% in Quarter
abstract: The Interpublic Group of Companies reported yesterday that its net income for the first quarter fell 8.7 percent, to $7.9 million, or 22 cents a share, from $8.6 million, or 26 cents a share, in the comparable period of 1990. Revenues were up 24.4 percent to $353.8 million from $284.5 million.  Interpublic is made up of several agencies, including McCann-Erickson Worldwide, Lintas Worldwide, Dailey & Associates and the Lowe Group.

headline: Economic Scene; Semiconductor Semi-Success
abstract: THE Bush Administration negotiators who pieced together the new computer chip pact with Japan are proud as peacocks. And with reason: They managed to dismantle protectionist rules that were anathema to the President's free-trade principles.    But the victory may prove bittersweet. Japanese chip exporters remain vulnerable to retaliation under American laws that effectively prohibit foreign competitors from cutting a product's price near the end of its commercial life. More important, the deal in no way alters the sobering reality that America has lost its deft touch in translating advanced technology into jobs and profits.

headline: Broadest Protests Since '87 Rock Korea
abstract: Tens of thousands of anti-Government protesters rallied in major cities across South Korea today, demanding the resignation of President Roh Tae Woo.    Estimates of the total number of demonstrators ranged from 100,000 and 400,000, and the rallies were probably the largest since the student and worker uprising in 1987 that helped lead to democracy here. One million people were said to have walked off the job or to have boycotted classes.

headline: F.D.A. Delay Is Criticized
abstract: A Federal appellate court said today that the Food and Drug Administration was taking too long to act on applications to sell new generic drugs. The court, however, refused to order the agency to work faster.    "Congress sought to get generic drugs into the hands of patients at reasonable prices -- fast," the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit said in ruling on a suit by Barr Laboratories. "The record before us reflects a defeat of those hopes."

headline: A REVIVAL IS SEEN FOR 'JUNK BONDS' AS MARKET GAINS
abstract: The Wall Street market for high-risk corporate bonds, which fueled the corporate takeovers of the 1980's only to collapse after a series of defaults and bankruptcies, is showing signs of life.   More than a year after the bankruptcy of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which pioneered and promoted the market, prices for high-risk, low-grade "junk bonds" have improved sharply, the market seems calmer and major buyers, sellers and underwriters are starting to describe the recovery as viable and real.

headline: Fears on Cut In U.S. Arms; Shrinking of Industry Is Called Dangerous
abstract: As Pentagon budgets decline sharply, every big weapons contract takes on added importance for military contractors. But few contracts define the stakes so starkly as the selection the Navy will make soon of a company to build its next attack submarine.    Industry executives and Government officials say that what is at stake is the survival of one of the two remaining submarine-building shipyards -- the General Dynamics Corporation's Electric Boat division in Groton, Conn.

headline: El Al Reports a Profit
abstract: El Al Israel Airlines today reported a $14.1 million profit for 1990 despite a slump in tourism caused by the Persian Gulf crisis. Revenue increased 10.4 percent, to $785.3 million. It was the fifth consecutive annual profit for El Al, Israel's national airline, but the figure was down from $24.2 million in 1989. El Al said it was one of only a few international carriers to show a profit after overseas travel declined in the gulf crisis. The number of passengers increased to 1.767 million in 1990 from 1.741 in 1989. The airline also converted planes to cargo flights during the tourism downturn.

headline: REGULATORS PICK BUYER TO OPERATE NEW ENGLAND BANK
abstract: The Government today selected Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc., a Rhode Island banking company, along with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the big corporate buyout concern, to buy the failed Bank of New England and two affiliated banks that collapsed in January.   L. William Seidman, the nation's senior banking regulator, said Fleet/Norstar's bid had been selected because it represented "the lowest cost" to the program that insures bank deposits. Officials acknowledged that as part of the deal, Fleet, which has a comparatively healthy capital base for a Northeast bank, would have to raise money to satisfy Federal regulations on its financial health.  Outlay of $5 Billion     Mr. Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, also said the bailout would require an initial outlay of about $5 billion from the bank fund and would ultimately cost the sharply deteriorating fund that insures deposits as much as $2.5 billion.

headline: Japan Fumes at Reliance on West
abstract: Through the 1980's Japan built what is widely regarded as one of the most technologically sophisticated television systems. Largely forgoing cable networks, it sent aloft satellites that beam programs directly to millions of Japanese households equipped with receiving dishes no larger than pizza pans.    Now the system that brought television to remote mountain villages and formed the building blocks for the world's first high-definition television service is on the brink of collapse.

headline: Market Place; Hunt Transport At a Crossroads
abstract: FOR most of the last 10 years, J. B. Hunt Transport Services Inc. has thrived under the freedoms brought by the deregulation of the trucking industry in 1980.    A nonunion carrier, it benefited from lower costs, an absence of union work rules, and an aggressive management that knew how to exploit the opportunities created when hundreds of older unionized companies failed. Hunt, based in Lowell, Ark., saw its revenues grow to $579 million in 1990 from less than $100 million in the early 1980's. Hunt is the second-largest full-truck-load long-haul carrier, behind Schneider National Inc. of Green Bay, Wis.

headline: Stocks Slide in Tokyo
abstract: Stock prices fell today in Tokyo. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed at 25,523.03, down 178.91 points, or about seven-tenths of 1 percent. Last week, the Nikkei lost 572.35 points, or about 2.2 percent.

headline: FMC Is Awarded Army Contract
abstract: The Army awarded the FMC Corporation a $1.12 billion contract to build 1,600 Bradley Fighting Vehicles and 251 multiple-launching rocket systems.    The Chicago-based military contractor will perform the work at its plants in San Jose, Calif., and Aiken, S.C. It is scheduled to be completed by the end of October 1994, the Army said. FMC stock lost 12.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange today, closing at $40.875.

headline: Seoul Student Killed in a Clash With Police
abstract: A student was killed today in a street battle here between the police and protesters as anti-Government violence erupted across South Korea.   The woman, Kim Kwi Jong, a 25-year-old third-year student at Sungkyunkwan Confucian University in Seoul, was killed as police officers tear-gassed a group of protesters near the city center.

headline: Soviet Miners Vote an End to 9-Week Strike
abstract: Soviet coal miners have voted to end a devastating nine-week old strike, averting a clash with President Mikhail Gorbachev and opening the way for radical reforms in the industry.   The Soviet news agency Tass said the central strike committee in the Kuznetsk caol basin in central Siberia, the largest in the country, voted today to suspend the strike effective Friday. Miners in the other major Russian republic coal region, Vorkuta, backed their leaders' decision to return to work on the same day.

headline: Mandela Calls West Europe Racist on Sanctions
abstract: Nelson Mandela today accused the European Community of racism over its lifting of sanctions against South Africa this month against the wishes of his organization, the African National Congress.    "This decision also once again shows clearly how Europe allies itself with white South Africa and has no regards for the lives, the views and the needs of black South Africa," the anti-apartheid leader said in a speech prepared for delivery at a conference of the National Union of Mine Workers, a black union that has supported the congress's call to maintain sanctions.

headline: Ford Aids Workers
abstract: The Ford Motor Company borrowed $150 million from a $473 million reserve left over from the 1987-90 labor agreement with the United Automobile Workers union to help pay benefits for laid-off workers. The transfer was announced earlier this week to local union officials by Ernest Lofton, U.A.W. vice president and head of the union's Ford Department, and confirmed by Ford.The auto maker and the union signed a contract last fall requiring Ford to pay up to $1.6 billion in supplemental unemployment benefits. The money will be paid out as needed.

headline: Union Carbide Earnings Off
abstract: The Union Carbide Corporation said today that its first-quarter earnings dropped 11.7 percent, primarily because of costs from an explosion at one of its Texas plants.   The earnings were consistent with the company's announcement in March that its profits would be reduced by $18 million for the quarter.

headline: Company News; UAL Asks Boeing To Study Big Jet
abstract: The UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, said it had asked the Boeing Company to study making a new 650-seat jet that would be the world's largest commercial airplane. Boeing, based in Seattle, has talked about developing a new jumbo jet for the last year. If the new jet were built, it would be for delivery by 1998.

headline: Patents; A Composition for Use In Food and Cosmetics
abstract: Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology obtained a patent this week for a composition produced by bacteria that has possible uses in food and cosmetics as well as in waste-water treatment.   Called Zooglan, the composition is essentially a long string of sugar molecules that is secreted by a bacteria strain known as zooglea ramigera. According to Donald D. Easson, one of the inventors, Zooglan acts like a lubricant and as a thickening agent, and appears to be well suited for use in skin creams and as a low-calorie substitute for oil and fat in foods like salad dressing.

headline: Technology; Metals That Memorize a Shape
abstract: When most eyeglasses are accidentally bent out of shape, it is hard to repair them perfectly. But if the frame of a pair of glasses is made with a metal with "shape memory," the frame can be restored to its original shape by dipping it in warm water. And in the latest refinement, some glasses are now available with frames that regain their shape without the liquid.   Although they have been around for almost 30 years, memory metals were used almost exclusively on military hardware and aircraft until the early 1980's. Now they are increasingly found in industry and everyday consumer goods.

headline: Hachette to Buy Knapp's Home Magazine
abstract: Hachette Publications Inc. has signed an agreement to acquire Home, a consumer magazine about renovation and interior design, from the Knapp Communications Corporation, the two companies announced yesterday. A price was not disclosed.    Hachette officials said the magazine, which has a circulation of 942,000, would fit well and provide joint advertising opportunities with the company's other home-design and remodeling publications, known as "shelter" magazines in the industry. These include Elle Decor, a stylish interior design publication that is an offshoot of Hachette's Elle; Sound & Image, which focuses on the interior design aspects of stereo systems, and more than a dozen Woman's Day special issues about home improvement.

headline: Drug Baron's Jailing Heartens Colombia
abstract: With Colombia's most violent drug trafficker now in a luxurious prison in his hometown, Colombian leaders said today that they believed that a two-year scourge of bombings and assassinations might finally be coming to an end.   "It may be the end of narco-terrorism in Colombia," the nation's President, Cesar Gaviria Trujillo, said in an interview about the surrender of Pablo Escobar Gaviria. "He is responsible for the main terrorist activities of the last few years."

headline: All the Rage in Fiction: Serial Murder, Multiple Murder, Hideous Murder
abstract: Murder -- mass murder -- seems to be the latest trend in the field of fiction, a field historically dominated by women readers. In fact, serial murders, multiple murders and hideous murders are all the rage.    Among such current books are "Sliver" (Bantam) by Ira Levin, "Chicago Loop" (Random House) by Paul Theroux, "Shadow Prey" (Berkley) by John Sandford and "Mercy" (Bantam) by David L. Lindsey.

headline: Almost New Is Good Enough, Much to Detroit's Annoyance
abstract: Two gray Ford Taurus sedans, seemingly identical, sit in a car dealer's showroom. One, fresh from the factory, has a sticker price of about $16,900. The second is almost but not quite new: shiny and still under warranty, it began life as a Hertz rental car, logged 8,000 miles over four months and is priced at $12,500.    To the annoyance of American car makers, more and more shoppers are deciding that at today's new-car prices, "almost new" is good enough. This year some two million almost-new cars, or about 25 percent of the depressed new-car market, are cycling back from rental car companies and other big car fleets and winding up in American driveways.

headline: Arabs Adding Maxwell To Company Blacklist
abstract: The Arab League said today that it had lifted an official boycott of the Coca-Cola Company but imposed one on businesses owned by the publisher Robert Maxwell because of his dealings in Israel.   Coca-Cola, based in Atlanta, was on the league's blacklist of companies doing business with Israel for more than 20 years. But it had been unofficially removed from the list two years ago. Egypt, Oman, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates have allowed bottling plants to be opened, and Coca-Cola sponsored a World Youth Soccer tournament in Saudi Arabia in 1989.

headline: In Unforgiving Haste, A Shift Atop Bantam
abstract: In a move that underlines how unforgiving the publishing business has become, Bertelsmann A.G., the German media giant, yesterday named Jack Hoeft, a former Pepsico marketing executive, as the second new chief of Bantam Doubleday Dell in just nine months.   He replaced Paul D. Neuthaler, who was named vice chairman of the publishing house, a new position.

headline: BUSH IN OVERTURE TO CUBAN LEADER
abstract: In a radio address marking the 89th anniversary of Cuban independence, President Bush today held out the prospect of improved relations with Cuba if Fidel Castro held democratic elections and freed all political prisoners.   "Ninety-nine percent of the people of this hemisphere live either in a democracy or a country that is on the road to democracy," Mr. Bush said in a radio message that was taped for broadcast today and beamed into Cuba with a Spanish translation on Radio and TV Marti, the Government-owned stations. "One percent live under the hemisphere's last dictator, Fidel Castro."

headline: Dow Drops by 10.51 to Close Below 3,000
abstract: Stock prices gave way yesterday for the second straight day, as trading turned sluggish. Investors appeared increasingly worried that the stock market could be losing ground. Concern also grew that bond market yields, already very strong, could soon begin pulling money out of stocks and into bonds.    The Dow Jones industrial average, which lost 22.58 on Wednesday, lost 10.51 points yesterday to close at 2,994.86 -- the first time the blue-chip index had moved below the 3,000 mark since May 29.

headline: General Tire Begins Layoffs
abstract: General Tire Inc. plans to cut its salaried work force of 3,100 by more than 20 percent this year to reduce costs. The company, owned by Continental A.G. of Germany, said 160 employees were cut immediately, including 100 at its headquarters in Akron. Continental is the world's fourth-largest tire maker.

headline: HOUSE VOTE BACKS BUSH'S AUTHORITY ON TRADE ACCORDS
abstract: In a vote that was divided as much on regional as party lines, the House of Representatives today authorized the Administration to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Mexico and a 108-nation pact to lower international trade barriers.   The House vote was 231 to 192. The Senate, which began debate on the issue late this afternoon, is expected to vote on Friday to extend for two years the President's authority to negotiate trade agreements.

headline: Review Is Reported On Pratt Engine
abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration is investigating the Pratt & Whitney Company's JT8D jet engine for corrosion after an accident that destroyed a Boeing 727 freighter, according to an article in The Washington Post today.    The Ryan International Airlines flight crashed in Connecticut on May 3. The three crew members were not injured, but the cargo of mail was destroyed. The National Transportation Safety Board said metal fatigue had caused a fan disk to fly apart during takeoff, severing fuel and hydraulic lines and knocking a hole in the fuselage. A spokesman for Pratt, based in East Hartford, Conn., told the newspaper that the company was not alarmed by one corrosion failure in the jet's 400 million flight hours.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: THE ECONOMY    The Fed cut interest rates, noting that the latest data showed the economy to still be quite weak. It cut the discount rate to 5 1/2 percent and the Federal funds rate to 5 3/4 percent.  [ Page A1. ]   Four regulators urged lawmakers to adopt a Treasury proposal for a banking overhaul, setting the stage for a showdown between the Administration and Congressional Democrats.  [ D1. ]

headline: Saudis to Accept Refugees From Camps in South of Iraq
abstract: Saudi Arabia has decided to accept and shelter all Iraqi refugees now under American and Saudi control in the south of Iraq and is building a camp to accommodate as many as 50,000 people, a senior Saudi official said today.    The official, Lieut. Gen. Khalid ibn Sultan, a prince who commanded the Arab forces in the coalition that ousted Iraq from Kuwait, also reaffirmed the kingdom's commitment to abide by international law and "Islamic humanitarian tradition" in handling nearly 14,000 Iraqi prisoners of war who do not wish to return to Iraq.

headline: 2-Day Gain by U.S. Issues Ends
abstract: The two-day advance in Treasury bond prices came to a halt yesterday as the market in long-term securities absorbed various economic factors.   The number of initial claims for unemployment insurance rose 47,000, to 498,000, in the week ended April 13, the latest period covered by the Government's survey. Bond prices rose slightly on the news, but an increase had been expected and was thus not taken as serious negative news by investors in fixed-income debt issues who count on negative economic reports to protect their holdings from inflation and higher interest rates on newer offerings.

headline: Chinese Ties: Frosty to Icy
abstract: While China is normalizing its ties with many Western countries, its relations with the United States are severely strained and may deteriorate further in the coming months. Behind the strains are both specific disagreements and a fundamental gulf in the way the two countries see each other.    "I'm not optimistic about relations improving," said David L. Shambaugh, an American scholar of China who is doing research in Beijing. "I think they'll get worse before they get better. And I don't see them getting better soon, because I don't see a new 'glue' emerging in the relationship to replace the mutual security interests of the 70's and 80's."

headline: G.M. Outlet In Manhattan Closes Doors
abstract: The last remaining General Motors Corporation dealership in Manhattan, a Cadillac-Buick-Chevrolet franchise belonging to Roger S. Penske and G.M., quietly closed its doors today.    Mr. Penske is a transportation entrepreneur with interests as diverse as truck leasing and Indianapolis 500 racing. A spokesman for Mr. Penske said the decision to close the dealership was based on declining prospects for automobile sales in New York City and the poor state of the Northeast economy.

headline: Financial Executive Is Suspended
abstract: Consumers Union, publisher of Consumer Reports, said yesterday that it had suspended its chief financial officer, saying he had been involved in a kickback scheme.    The organization said the officer, David Granston, was suspended after an investigation into an arrangement Mr. Granston had with a broker to share commissions for the purchase by Consumers Union of Government mortgage-backed securities, known as Ginnie Maes.

headline: Penny Stock Broker Barred
abstract: The National Association of Securities Dealers said today that it had expelled First Alliance Securities Inc. in Atlanta from the securities business for charging exorbitant prices -- sometimes 3,300 percent above market -- for penny stocks.    In one of its toughest penalties ever, the association also barred the company's president, William Lincoln, from the securities industry for life, ordered $2.5 million be refunded to defrauded customers and levied $120,000 in fines.

headline: Afghan Rebels Take Garrison Town, U.S. Reports
abstract: Afghan guerrillas have seized the garrison town of Khost and captured 6,000 Government troops to begin a spring offensive to try to topple the Soviet-backed Government, Administration officials said today.   "This is definitely a major victory for the mujahedeen," a State Department official said, referring to the rebels. He noted that Khost, near the border with Pakistan, guards the vital supply routes connecting the capital, Kabul, to the north, with the southwestern provinces.

headline: Cray and Beta Pact
abstract: Cray Research Inc. has signed a licensing agreement with Beta Phase Inc., a maker of high-performance electronic connectors based in Menlo Park, Calif. The pact, which includes license fees of $750,000 payable over the next year, gives Cray the right to develop and manufacture connectors for its supercomputers based on Beta's patented technology. As part of the agreement, Cray purchased 833,334 shares of common stock in Beta for $250,000, or 30 cents a share.

headline: Payment Set By Shearson
abstract: Shearson Lehman Brothers has agreed to reimburse Consumers Union, publisher of Consumer Reports, for money it spent as a result of a kickback scheme between Consumers Union's former chief financial officer and a Shearson broker, the organization announced yesterday.    Consumers Union dismissed the officer, David Granston, in April after an investigation into an arrangement Mr. Granston had with a broker, Stanley Feminella, who had worked at three firms: David Lerner Associates in Syosset, L.I.; Paine Webber, and Shearson Lehman, to share commissions for the purchase by Consumers Union of securities.

headline: The Executive Computer; Intel's Latest Microprocessor Addresses a Niche
abstract: The Intel Corporation, which makes the microprocessors that are the heart of most I.B.M. PC-compatible computers, recently introduced a chip called the i486SX, a scaled-down version of its i486 chip. To create the i486SX, Intel engineers disabled the powerful, built-in math processing component of the i486, which is used for intensive computational chores like extremely complex financial analysis and three-dimensional graphics. They also made the i486SX operate more slowly than its i486 sibling. In return, computer makers can buy the i486SX chip for half the cost of the i486.   For now, computers built around the i486SX chip fill a gap between the fastest 386-based computers and the powerful i486-based machines. But whether the gap is strategically important to businesses is unclear.

headline: Data Bank/June 16, 1991
abstract: Sales at Retail Outlets   May   April   March        Monthly percent change   1.0   --0.4   0.3        Consumer Price Index                Monthly percent change   0.3   0.2   --0.1       Capacity Utilization                Output as a percentage of capacity   78.7   78.8   78.4        Producer Price Index                Finished goods, annual rate in percent   0.6   0.2   --0.3       Industrial Production Index                Percent change   0.5   0.3   --0.6        Mfg. Inventory-Sales Ratio   April   March   Feb.        Current dollars   1.54   1.57   1.57       Auto Production   June 14   June 7   May 31        In units    118,950   110,345   89,662       Truck Production   79,362   79,807   65,168

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * C&S/Sovran Corp., Atlanta, a bank holding concern that says it has $50 billion in assets, has narrowed its advertising account review to three agencies: DDB Needham Worldwide, New York, GSD&M, Austin, Tex., and Young & Rubicam, New York. The company said it has not included the two incumbent agencies, the Atlanta office of Ogilvy & Mather and Earle Palmer Brown/Lawler Ballard, Norfolk, Va. The two incumbents created campaigns for C&S and Sovran respectively before they merged in September.

headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; A Manhattan High-Rise Will House School Gyms
abstract: The Dalton School, one of New York City's top independent schools, needs more space, and that has led a Manhattan developer to break with tradition in building a 22-story residential project on the Upper East Side.   Instead of building it of reinforced concrete, a method favored by developers of residential high-rises, the developer, Norman Segal, is building it with a steel frame. That will allow the building to accommodate the 32,000 square feet of gymnasium and physical education space that Dalton will either buy or lease on the third through seventh floors.

headline: Stocks Climb, With Dow Up 19.05 Points
abstract: Spurred by heavy program buying and a sharp drop in mid-April car sales, stocks and bonds moved sharply ahead late yesterday.    Traders, apparently convinced that the economy is now so weak that the Fed surely will lower interest rates, moved heavily into the market in the final hour, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average 19.05 points, to close at 2,949.50.

headline: Refugees Fear Future in Iraq Without U.S.
abstract: For many Iraqis who are flocking to this region, the Americans who are handing out food and medicine are regarded as benefactors. For others here, these same Americans are seen as the major threat to a cherished way of life.    Many Iraqis who have lived in this sleepy community for years say they want to see the United States Army go, even though they appreciate the goods that the Army has been distributing.

headline: Wringing More Costs Out of Wall St. Firms
abstract: The falling ax on Wall Street has become as commonplace as the rising Dow. But now, with the most obvious cuts of employees and expenses out of the way, investment houses are picking up the scalpel in hopes of completing a historic and complex reorganization of the back office, one of the least understood aspects of their business.    Some major firms are considering merging their underused back offices, through which stocks, bonds and other financial instruments are moved to the account that purchased them and cash is moved to the seller. Some plan to sell part or all of the operations to outside contractors and then lease them back, or move pieces of the back offices out of Manhattan -- even to third-world countries -- to reduce overhead and labor costs.  Accompanying Layoffs     "The cost pressure on Wall Street generally is encouraging people to look at lowering costs through changes in their back office and support systems," said Rick Adam, the partner in charge of global operations and technology at Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: Pepsi's Theme, And Variations
abstract: Is Pepsico again expanding its successful "Uh-huh" advertising campaign for Diet Pepsi? Uh-huh.   New print versions of the campaign, which the singer Ray Charles introduced in a series of elaborate television commercials in January, are being created by BBDO Worldwide, New York. Three- and four-page ads, featuring the sports stars Magic Johnson, Rickey Henderson and Joe Montana, will run in Sports Illustrated from now through the start of football season. Other "Uh-huh" tie-ins include a line of licensed clothing and a consumer home-video contest.    As for Mr. Charles, BBDO still is keeping him busy. A new television spot, in which he introduces "Celebration Cans" of Diet Pepsi and Pepsi-Cola with patriotic designs, is scheduled to begin airing June 10.

headline: President Quits At Circle K
abstract: The Circle K Corporation, a convenience-store chain that filed for bankruptcy protection in May 1990, said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Robert A. Dearth Jr., had resigned.   In a statement released by the Phoenix-based company, Mr. Dearth cited personal and family circumstances. He said that since Circle K was unable to file a proposed reorganization plan now, he would step aside so the company could find a successor who could remain throughout the reorganization.

headline: International Phone Venture
abstract: The major telephone companies of Britain, Japan and Germany are discussing a joint venture that would provide services to international business customers.   British Telecommunications P.L.C. said it was in talks with the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation and Germany's Deutsche Bundespost Telecom to form a venture to operate global internal telecommunications systems.

headline: Insurer's Role Raises Pension Fear
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of insurance policy holders and investors across the country are worried about the seizure of the Executive Life Insurance Company last week by California regulators, but few are as fearful and angry as those whose retirement benefits depend on the insurer's financial health.   Dozens of companies have refinanced their pension plans in recent years by purchasing annuities from Executive Life, the primary subsidiary of the First Executive Corporation of Los Angeles. Annuities are contracts to pay cash over a period of time, usually in return for a single payment up front.

headline: Bondholders Hire Firms to Fight Orion
abstract: Bondholders of the Orion Pictures Corporation have hired the investment banking firms of Rothschild Inc. and Gerard, Klauer & Mattison and a California law firm, Stutman, Treister & Glatt, to represent them in negotiations with the company.    In late May, financially troubled Orion Pictures asked its bondholders to accept an arrangement that would include swapping $285 million in interest-paying bonds for zero-coupon notes and equity.

headline: Fishing For the Workplace Imposter
abstract: Recently, an executive with a large pharmaceutical company was promoted to head an overseas office. Although the executive had been with the company for nearly two decades, and his performance was deemed consistently outstanding, top management hired an investigator to examine his credentials before sending him abroad -- and was dismayed.   The executive did not have the Ph.D. in biology he claimed and the university he said he received it from did not even exist. "His certificate was a phony, from one of the diploma mills," said Jeremiah McAward, president of McAward Associates Inc., the New York-based firm that handled the case.  "The situation could have been terribly embarrassing if he'd gone to Europe and been uncovered as a fraud."

headline: ALLIES TO EXTEND SAFE ZONE IN IRAQ 70 MILES EASTWARD
abstract: British and American marines prepared tonight to push their security zone in northern Iraq roughly 70 miles eastward at dawn to enable Kurdish refugees in remote mountain camps to join the return home.    Even as thousands of refugees continued to pour down from the mountains into the area around this border city already secured by American, British, French and Dutch troops, allied armored vehicles and reconnaissance patrols were seen late this afternoon pressing astward in the direction of Amadiya, where a new refugee transit camp is to be set up.

headline: Owner Rejects Thrust as Cause of Air Crash
abstract: The owner of the Austrian airliner that crashed in Thailand last month said today that he did not believe the plane went down solely because one engine suddenly went into reverse.    The comments by the owner, Niki Lauda, owner of Lauda-Air, corroborate statements by investigators from Boeing, which manufactured the 767-300ER jet that crashed last month in Thailand, killing 223 people. Mr. Lauda earlier this week cited the deployment of the thrust reverser as a possible cause of the crash. He is not part of the official investigation.

headline: Apple Suit With Hewlett
abstract: A Federal District judge today heard several motions from Apple Computer Inc. and the Hewlett-Packard Company in the long-running copyright infringment suit brought by Apple against Hewlett-Packard and the Microsoft Corporation.    Apple sued in 1988, claiming that visual elements in Microsoft's Windows and Hewlett's New Wave programs infringe its copyrights on the Macintosh user interface.

headline: Iraq Accepts U.N. System for Weapons Inspections
abstract: After an initial show of resistance, Iraq agreed today to a rigorous system of inspections of its military and scientific installations by an international commission charged with locating and destroying its most dangerous weapons.    Rolf Ekeus of Sweden, the executive chairman of the commission created by the Security Council to oversee the destruction of the Iraqi weapons, said Baghdad had now accepted all his demands.

headline: Yugoslav Republic Of Croatia Declares Independent Nation
abstract: Croatia declared itself an independent state today, after receiving overwhelming support for sovereignty in a referendum held on May 19.   The declaration was included in the latest issue of People's News, the official gazette, and was signed by the state President, Franjo Tudjman. It is expected to be proclaimed at the current session of the Croatian legislature.

headline: Pope Calls on Poland to Reject Western Europe's Secular Ways
abstract: Pope John Paul II urged his fellow Poles today to reject the sensual, secular culture of a Western Europe that he contended had betrayed the roots of Christendom.   "Do not let yourself get caught up by this civilization of desire and consumption," the Pope said, his voice filled with emotion. He offered his vision of a post-Communist Poland that could stand as a spiritual exemplar for the continent. "Is it civilization or an anti-civilization, a culture, or an anti-culture?"

headline: Technology; Fuel Cells: Finally Coming of Age or Too Good to Be True?
abstract: First developed in the 1960's for use in space, fuel cells have come down to earth. This month, the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, the northern California utility, started up the first complete power plant based on a molten carbonate fuel cell.    A fuel cell is a device that converts the energy of a fuel directly to electricity and heat, without combustion. Because there is no combustion, fuel cells give off few emissions; and because there are no moving parts, fuel cells are quiet. Although a fuel -- in this case natural gas -- is consumed, P.G.& E.'s fuel cell plant is about 50 percent more efficient than conventional gas-powered turbine power generators.

headline: Flour Tax refund Will Improve Net
abstract: The Fluor Corporation said today that it will receive a Federal income tax refund, plus interest, that will add more than $12 million, or 14 cents a share, to second-quarter net income. The refund resolves a tax dispute between Fluor's St. Joe Minerals unit and the Internal Revenue Service for the tax years 1975 through 1981.    Fluor said the Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation had approved the refund, and the I.R.S. was computing the interest. Fluor stock lost 87.5 cents a share on the New York Stock Exchange today, closing at $47.125.

headline: Rates on Treasury Issues Ease
abstract: Rates on long-term Treasury securities continued to ease yesterday, prompting a flood of corporate debt offerings. Most corporate bond and other debt issues are priced relative to comparable Treasury maturities.    Thus when yields on Treasury debt issues decline, many corporate borrowers seize the opportunity to sell bonds and other debt issues. Dealers estimate that roughly $1.5 billion of corporate debt came to market on Wednesday and perhaps as much yesterday.

headline: Tandy Offers Certificates
abstract: The Tandy Corporation, Fort Worth, is offering $350 million in asset-backed certificates through the Tandy Master Trust.    Underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation said the certificates were backed by receivables of Tandy and of its Radio Shack chain of consumer electronics stores.

headline: COMPANY NEWS; Litton Scaling Back Systems-Control Unit
abstract: Litton Industries said today that it was scaling back operations of its disappointing Integrated Automation division. The decision will result in a $100 million after-tax charge in the company's fourth quarter, which ends July 31.   The division, based in Alameda, Calif., is small, with annual revenue of less than $50 million. But the charge includes $70 million of good will resulting from Litton's acquisition of Integrated in 1987. Good will is an accounting term for the difference between the price paid for an entity and the value of its physical assets.

headline: Ex-Mayor and the Mafia: A Sicilian Morality Play
abstract: If a politician were to get much more popular with voters than Leoluca Orlando, they would have to give serious thought to entering him in a hall of fame.   But consider the fate that has befallen Mr. Orlando, Palermo's anti-Mafia Mayor for five years, until he was abandoned in early 1990 by elders of his Christian Democratic Party.

headline: Making a Difference; Modest Fireworks At Amoco
abstract: With drillers searching the world for crude oil and natural gas, and refiners battling by the hundreds for market share, global oil giants chart varying courses. Some routes paid off handsomely in the first quarter. The Exxon Corporation, for example, reported its best profits ever last week. For others, the results weren't nearly as spectacular.  Consider Amoco Inc.   H. Laurance Fuller, who became chairman in February, had few fireworks to offer. An accounting change slashed taxes, creating most of a 72.3 percent gain in net income, to $803 million. But income from operations rose just 5.6 percent, to $492 million.

headline: Sikh Bomb-Maker Sentenced
abstract: A Canadian judge sentenced a Sikh man to 10 years in jail today for helping to make the bomb that killed two Japanese baggage handlers in a Tokyo airport. Last month the Sikh, Inderjit Singh Reyat, was found guilty of manslaughter and explosives counts in the June 1985 blast at Narita Airport. British, Indian and Canadian authorities say the blast was part of a reprisal against the Indian Government for the 1984 killing of Sikh militants at the Golden Temple in Amritsar. Mr. Reyat, an electrician, was extradited from Britain in 1989.

headline: BankAmerica's Eastward Push
abstract: When the BankAmerica Corporation was reeling from losses a few years ago, executives renounced their global ambitions and said they would concentrate on retail banking in California and the West.    The bank's executives still say that, only now they joke that "West" means anything west of Bermuda. That is because BankAmerica is poised to make itself a major presence on the East Coast if it wins the bidding for the insolvent Bank of New England.

headline: As Things Ease in China, an Envoy Departs
abstract: Two months ago a man named Zhang boarded a train with nearly $2,000 in life savings, disembarked more than 400 miles later at the nearest United States Consulate and plunked his money down as a contribution to helping American soldiers wounded in the Persian Gulf.   That would never have happened two years ago, when the embassy in Beijing was surrounded by armed Chinese soldiers and ordinary citizens did not dare linger by the compound, much less attend a banquet at the Ambassador's residence.The difference in atmosphere reflects how some things have changed in the two years that Ambassador James R. Lilley has been in Beijing. In recent weeks, Mr. Lilley, who retires as Ambassador on Friday, has been able to draw large crowds of Chinese to his farewell parties.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Network Sales Executive In New Role After 25 Years
abstract: JERRY DOMINUS, the vice president of sales at CBS for seven years, had an unusual lunch partner recently -- Larry Hoffner, who runs sales at NBC.  "We found we had a lot to talk about," Mr. Dominus said with a laugh.  The reason: Jerome Henry Dominus is scheduled to start his new job today as senior vice president and director of national television and programming in the United States for J. Walter Thompson.

headline: Holders Approve Utilities' Merger
abstract: Shareholders of IE Industries and Iowa Southern Inc. voted to merge the utility companies through an exchange of stock valued at $670 million. The merger, which would create Iowa's second-largest utility holding company, is scheduled to take effect on July 1 but is still subject to approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission.   The new company, IES Industries, would be based in Cedar Rapids and would own utilities that provide electricity and natural gas to 463,000 customers in almost 550 Iowa communities. Under the merger, holders of Iowa Southern stock would receive 1.6 shares in the new company for each share of their common stock. IE Industries shareholders keep their stock. IE Industries closed today at $27.875, up 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Continental Air Has a Loss
abstract: Continental Airlines, citing a drop in passengers because of the recession and the Persian Gulf war, announced today that it lost $195 million in the first three months of 1991.   The loss compares with a $21 million profit for the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues for the most recent quarter were $1.263 billion, up slightly from $1.258 billion a year earlier.

headline: Mutual Funds; Backing Away From Bonds
abstract: As a group, bond funds greatly increased their share of the mutual fund market in the last decade. While money markets declined, taxable bond funds more than doubled and tax-free bond funds increased almost fivefold.   Most of the industry's growth in the last 10 years was created by "the conversion from savers to investors," said A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services in Summit, N.J. Many people shifted money from bank accounts or certificates of deposit into mutual funds.

headline: Disney Center In Singapore
abstract: The Walt Disney Company said today that it would set up a regional headquarters in Singapore to sell more than 16,000 different Disney products in Southeast Asia.   A Disney spokesman, William Laws, said that Disney Consumer Products International Inc. would sell items like Goofy and Donald Duck T-shirts, computer games and toys. A formal announcement is to be made next week.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Pizza Hut Tries to Sway People Named Domino
abstract: In a publicity gimmick designed to tweak its main competitor, Domino's Pizza, Pizza Hut said it would deliver free pepperoni pizzas today to "scores" of Americans whose last name is "Domino."  "We know that if we can convince people named 'Domino' to make a switch for the best, we have an excellent chance with the rest of America," Marcia Thomsen, Pizza Hut's director of delivery marketing, said in a statement.

headline: Accounting Board Member to Be Dropped
abstract: After meeting in closed session, the trustees who oversee the chief rule-making body for accountants said yesterday that they would not reappoint C. Arthur Northrop to the board when his term expires.    The move capped a week of speculation about Mr. Northrop's position on the Financial Accounting Standards Board. The decision also signals the growing sway that some leading business groups have over the board and its overseers at the Financial Accounting Foundation, both in Norwalk, Conn.

headline: The Clark Bar Finds a Buyer
abstract: The Clark Bar, the 105-year-old candy bar that was on the road to extinction, was saved today by a local restaurateur who agreed to buy the struggling confection concern from its Finnish parent.   Michael Carlow, who has also been involved in business turnarounds, said he and a group of partners would buy the Clark candy bar brand and plant from Leaf Inc. North America.

headline: The Fed Eased, But Where's the Money?
abstract: Economic indicators, like clothing styles, go in and out of fashion. It has been more than a decade since the money supply was the most-watched and most-feared statistic, the number that every trading room had a pool on, the one that could send stock and bond prices spiraling up or down if Wall Street's crystal balls had been cloudy.   Perhaps, however, it is time to again delve into the arcane world of the M's. The figures released late Thursday were stunning, showing sharp declines for the final week of April.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization                  May 10   May 3   May 11        1991   1991   1990        Gasoline production, daily   7.0   6.8   6.7        Distillate production, daily   2.9   2.9   2.9        Gasoline stocks   206.2   204.3   215.0        Distillate stocks   101.7   101.3   96.8        Crude imports, daily   6.2   5.2   6.3        Product imports, daily   2.2   2.0   2.5        Crude stocks   338.7   338.6   376.2        Crude production, daily   7.4   7.4   7.3        Refinery utilization (%)   87.0   86.1   84.2       (Source: American Petroleum Institute)

headline: Square D Bid May Be Raised
abstract: The stock of the Square D Company rose $2.50 yesterday, to $81.25, on the Big Board, after Groupe Schneider S.A. of France said it would raise its $78-a-share bid if Square D would drop its opposition to a takeover.    Square D, which has rejected the bid as inadequate, had no immediate response to Schneider's latest offer.

headline: FORUM; The Greening of America's Taxes
abstract: EVIDENCE of the earth's physical deterioration mounts each year. Forests disappear, the concentration of heat-trapping gases in the atmosphere rises, ground water supplies dwindle and air pollution spreads.   Yet the marketplace lets businesses and consumers ignore environmental damages in decision-making, like whether to generate electricity from coal or the sun, or to commute by car or public transportation. Americans annually incur health-related damages estimated at $40 billion from air pollution, but car drivers pay little or nothing at the pump for their part in this assault.

headline: Ship Orders for Japan
abstract: Foreign ship orders received by Japanese yards in April rose sharply, to 12 ships of 1.3 million gross tons, from 7 ships of 338,770 million tons in March, the Japan Ship Exporters Association said today. The April order figure is still below the figure for April 1990, when 25 ships were ordered weighing a million tons.

headline: Boeing Contracts For Work on 777
abstract: The Boeing Company said it had awarded subcontracts for work on the primary systems and structures for its new 777 aircraft.

headline: GUATEMALA PEACE IN ARMY'S HANDS
abstract: Negotiations under way between the Government of President Jorge Serrano Elias and leftist guerrillas have raised hopes of ending Latin America's longest-running insurgency, but the army may prove to be the sticking point.    Distinct from neighboring El Salvador, where there is a near standoff between the two sides in the field, in Guatemala the army is confident that it has the upper hand and, therefore, has no reason to make concessions.

headline: Israel Expels 4 More From the Gaza Strip
abstract: Israel expelled four Palestinians from the Gaza Strip to Lebanon early this morning. All four were accused of fomenting and carrying out violent acts on behalf of the Palestine Liberation Organization .    "The expulsions were carried out following a Supreme Court denial of their appeals against the orders," the army said. The four -- Jamal Yassin Abu-Habel, Muin Mohammed Maslan, Hisham Mohammed Ali Dahalan and Jamal Abed Abu-Jadyan -- were taken by helicopter to southern Lebanon and dropped off to search for a taxi to Beirut.

headline: Treasury Issues Narrowly Mixed
abstract: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed again yesterday, as dealers placed bids at an auction of $12.5 billion worth of new two-year notes.   Memories of last month's two-year note auction, when a small handful of firms made an aggressive, enormous bid for the securities, hung heavy over yesterday's sale, traders said.

headline: Help Lines: The Benefits Are Mutual
abstract: Every 30 seconds or so, a consumer calls one of the toll-free numbers at the Kraft General Foods office here, adding another voice to a chorus of complaints, praises and questions on products like Kool-Aid and Stove Top stuffing.   Companies like Kraft, Procter & Gamble and Dowbrands have greatly expanded the number of products that carry "800" numbers, which are now found on everything from candy bars to coffee makers. Big corporations hope these help lines demonstrate that they are reliable and responsive. They also use them to encourage consumers to stick with their brands, whatever their complaints about recipes or defects.

headline: Where Car Makers Fear to Cut
abstract: Auto executives traditionally do not discuss future car and truck models for fear buyers might put off a purchase until the new ones arrive. But the Chrysler Corporation took that risk by recently allowing dealers, journalists and others onto its test track to give them a glimpse of the 1993 mid-size models on which Chrysler is pinning its hopes for a recovery.    The slump in car sales and the national recession, which coincide with yet another big push by the Japanese for American market share, is squeezing Detroit and causing a torrent of cash to flow out the door. All of the auto makers are cutting costs and conserving resources. What they are struggling to avoid, though, are any deep cuts that would delay or eliminate new products. A Matter of Perceptions     Chrysler, like the others in the Big Three, does not want investors, suppliers or lenders to get the idea that it is paring spending for new models, a perception that would only worsen its problems on the showroom floor.   The pressure to spend, even when money is scarce, is a matter of market share for the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, and a matter of survival for Chrysler. All three are striving to avoid having their need to save money force them into canceling or delaying important vehicle projects. G.M. on Monday announced plans to float an issue of preference stock to raise $600 million, partly to pay for future vehicle models, among them eight new-car and thee new-truck models in the next year.    "Spending for new products must go on in good times and bad," said James B. Fitzpatrick, a G.M. vice president for communications and marketing. "It is our lifeblood." Cash generated internally at G.M. has shrunk from $10.08 billion in 1987 to an estimated $5.27 billion this year, according to estimates by Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.    Japanese auto makers can develop a new vehicle in far less time than Detroit can, and they are invading market niches in the United States where they have never been before. Today, for example, Nissan showed journalists its first mini-van, named the Quest. It was designed in California and will be built at a Ford plant near Cleveland starting next April. Last year, Nissan withdrew from the market its Axxess station wagon that was meant to attract mini-van buyers but was a flop.    American auto makers know they cannot compete unless they compress their normal five-year product-gestation period to three years, like the Japanese, and bring out more new cars more frequently. Indeed, the most scathing criticism that could be leveled at the American auto industry would be to say that it was mortgaging the future by scrimping on new-product development.   But new products take money. Depending on the extent of the redesign, the cost of bringing a new car to dealer lots ranges from $500 million to $1 billion.    While G.M. has been able to keep most models on schedule, it has acknowledged a few delays. Rumors among parts suppliers say G.M. has delayed its redesigned S-10 Blazer utility vehicle to 1995, from 1994.  Taking on More Debt     As for Ford, it borrowed $800 million in the first quarter of the year, raising its debt to $8.2 billion; a year ago, debt stood at $4.4 billion. Ford's debt-to-equity ratio on March 31 was 38 percent, compared with 16 percent a year ago. Ford is trying to keep most future models on schedule, but analysts and suppliers say it has delayed the redesign of the Taurus and the Sable models for one year, to 1995.    After Ford announced a first-quarter loss of $884 million, David N. McCammon, vice president-finance, said projects "are basically intact, but we always are making timing adjustments" to cut costs and looking for ways "to get a dollar's worth of new products for every 80 cents we spend."    Chrysler, which has suffered critical losses and has little financial cushion, has the least borrowing power among the Big Three, the lowest relative stock price, and the least ability to put money into new products. But Chris Cedergren, an automotive analyst for J. D. Power & Associates, an automotive consulting firm in Agoura Hills, Calif., said Chrysler more than any other American auto maker might be trying to pull spending forward.    Perhaps because of its well-publicized financial weakness, the No. 3 auto maker must go to the greatest lengths to prove that its $3 billion in cost-cutting is not hampering development of new models. The company renegotiated a $1.5 billion line of credit after the lowering of its debt ratings made borrowing from the public too expensive.    "The fear is that Chrysler is cutting into muscle and bone," said Ronald Glantz, automotive analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds in San Francisco. "But I hope not, because I love the way the L/H looks." He was referring to the code name for Chrysler's 1993 mid-size sedan, which will be sold by the Eagle, Dodge and Chrysler divisions; it will be built, starting next year, at a factory in Bramalea, Ontario.    Other Chrysler vehicles badly need replacement, too. The full-size pickup truck -- referred to by some Chrysler engineers as "Festus," the grizzled codger in the "Gunsmoke" television western -- has not been redesigned for more than 15 years. Chrysler is planning to replace it in 1993.  No Profits, No Cash     In economically healthy times auto makers pay part of their new-product costs with cash from current sales. But with no profits, auto makers must increase borrowings or sell equity. In the last six months, the Big Three have been forced to trim dividends and drastically cut costs to strengthen balance sheets enough to finance new-product spending.    One-time expenses have also been a drain on cash. G.M., for example, was obligated on March 1 to buy $600 million worth of its class H stock from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute as part of the renegotiated terms of the sale of Hughes Aircraft to G.M. in 1985.    The three-year labor contract negotiated in the fall with the United Automobile Workers union has become a huge financial burden as well. Under its terms, the Big Three must pay most workers even if they are laid off, a situation that makes labor costs akin to a fixed expense. In previous recessions, labor expenses went down as sales and production dropped, allowing auto makers to keep losses in check.    In 1982, under an earlier labor agreement, the industry was operating at only 62 percent of capacity, yet auto makers were breaking even. But last year, utilization was at 78 percent and still the industry lost about $5 billion in North America, according to an analysis by Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.  The Cost of Competition     Of course, foreign imports and transplants -- Japanese cars made in America -- were not as much of a factor during the last recession. Vicious competition is hurting the Big Three's ability to maintain prices. Even with much lower production, the auto makers have been forced to continue offering large rebates on most car and truck models -- another drain on cash.    Shorter development cycles for cars like Chrysler's L/H model should help to cut costs, analysts say. Chrysler will have brought the L/H out in 42 months, a 30 percent reduction in the typical development time, helping produce a 25 percent cut in development costs, according to an estimate by Sanford C. Bernstein.    Chrysler believes the length of the cycle will be about 39 months, said Glen Gardner, who heads the project; that compares with the Japanese average of about 36 months. "The trick is going to be to get the rest of our projects on this schedule," he said.

headline: Vehicle Sales Dropped 21.4% in Late April
abstract: Domestic sales of cars and light trucks made in the United States and Canada fell 21.4 percent in late April from a year earlier, deflating the industry's hopes that a rebound was imminent.   The dismal results represent a serious blow to the auto industry. Many executives thought sales had reached a low in January, but the numbers reported today were below even the January level.

headline: A Murdoch Paper Is Closed
abstract: The Australian arm of Rupert Murdoch's media empire said today that it would close one of its major newspapers just six months after merging the morning and evening dailies in Sydney and Melbourne.   Melbourne's Sunday Herald, begun by News Ltd. in August 1989, will cease publication immediately, after posting annual losses of $15 million, or $11.5 million (United States), said Malcolm Colless, the managing director of The Herald and Weekly Times Ltd.

headline: Treasury Securities Up Slightly
abstract: Expectations that employment data to be released on Friday will show that the economy weakened further in March helped push prices of Treasury securities up modestly yesterday.    The gains, which were recorded across the maturity spectrum, came on thin volume.

headline: New Campaigns
abstract: * Would James Dean have sold insurance? Liberty Mutual Insurance may find out, as it begins a corporate campaign on Saturday that includes one commercial with shots of the film actor who died in a car accident in 1955. The campaign portrays the company as a longtime advocate for air bags, safety belts and other safety measures. "We understand the cost involved," is the tagline for the five commercials. Wells, Rich, Greene Inc., New York, created the campaign, which has a budget exceeding $10 million. * Bill and Ted, the two teen-age movie characters who popularized the phrase "most excellent," will be pitching their own cereal. The animated commercials begin Monday for Ralston-Purina Co.'s new Bill & Ted's Excellent Cereal, inspired by the movie "Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure." The spot was created by the New York-based agency Avrett, Free & Ginsberg. * American Express Travelers Cheques will begin using a new theme on Sunday. Along with their now famous slogan, "Don't leave home without them," two new commercials will include the tagline: "It's your vacation. Do something about it." The first commercial shows a thief spending someone's vacation money, while actor Karl Malden, who has appeared in American Express Travelers Cheques commercials for 18 years, provides the voice-over. Ogilvy & Mather, New York, created the campaign. * The Bronx Zoo started advertising Wednesday to dispel what it fears is a widespread image: that the zoo is a depressing place, where animals are locked in cages. The television commercials and 60-second spots for movie theaters show a black panther, baboons and other animals running about in their natural-habitat homes, called Jungle World and Baboon Reserve. Geer, DuBois Inc., New York, created the $1 million campaign.

headline: Goromonzi Journal; But Should the Good Earth Stay in White Hands?
abstract: At a time when most of Africa cannot feed itself and deserts are eating into fertile soil, Zimbabwe stands as an oasis.   Despite a growing population, this southern African country is self-sufficient in food and even able to spare some to help impoverished neighbors teetering on the edge of famine.

headline: NEC May Acquire Stake In Ailing Bull of France
abstract: The NEC Corporation, one of Japan's largest computer makers, said today that it was negotiating with Compagnie des Machines Bull about buying shares in the faltering French computer giant.    NEC offered few details, but a spokesman said that if an agreement was reached NEC would acquire no more than 10 percent of Bull. It would be the second Japanese investment in a major European computer company in less than a year. Bull is mostly owned by the French Government.

headline: PACT WOULD BAN ANTARCTIC MINING
abstract: In an action praised by environmentalists, delegates at a meeting on Antarctica have drafted an agreement to ban mining there for at least 50 years.   The accord, reached at a meeting here that ended today, will now be considered by the governments of the 39 nations that are parties to the Antarctic Treaty, which governs international activity on the continent.

headline: Defensive Step By Northrop
abstract: The Northrop Corporation said today that its directors had adopted measures to protect its pension-fund surplus and to defend against hostile takeover attempts.   The military contractor said that the action was not in response to any acquisition attempt, and that it knew of no efforts to gain control of the company.

headline: More Wheat for China
abstract: China has been authorized to buy an additional two million metric tons of American wheat at subsidized prices, Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan said today. Mr. Madigan said the allocation would be open to China for a year. The wheat, about 73.4 million bushels, would have a current value of about $194 million under the department's recent price estimates of $2.64 a bushel.

headline: Coach at Georgetown Will Join Nike Board
abstract: Nike Inc., which has been under fire from some blacks, named John Thompson, Georgetown University's head basketball coach, who is black, to its board of directors yesterday.    Nike is one of the world's largest sellers of athletic shoes. Among its most enthusiastic customers are urban teen-agers, many of whom are black. Last year, Operation PUSH, a civil rights group founded by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, charged that Nike did not hire enough blacks.

headline: Business Diary: May 12-17
abstract: COMPANIES A Giant Killer Stumbles and Takes a Big Fall

headline: Treasuries Down in Slow Trading
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities moved lower at the end of a slow session yesterday, as dealers continued what has become a lengthy process of distributing notes and bonds purchased at last week's refunding auctions and digested reports that provided little new economic insight.   A report showing that housing starts rose by 6.2 percent in April was counterbalanced by Labor Department data showing that initial unemployment claims rose slightly in the week that ended on May 4.

headline: Investment Firm Head Widens Insurance Role
abstract: Donald H. Rundlett has always liked the insurance industry. And with the decision of the firm he heads, Private Capital Partners Inc., to rescue the healthy life insurance subsidiary of the troubled Monarch Capital Corporation, he has thrust himself into the industry's spotlight.    Mr. Rundlett, who has worked as a broker, a commercial banker and an investment banker, is the chairman and chief executive of Private Capital, in Purchase, N.Y.. The private investment banking group said late Monday that it was forming the Old Bay State Life Insurance Company to acquire the stock of the Monarch Life Insurance Company of Springlfield, Mass.

headline: Article 821091 -- No Title
abstract: The Carolina Power and Light Company yesterday priced $100 million in first mortgage bonds through a competitive bidding won by a group of underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.    Underwriters said the bonds, which mature in 2022, had a coupon of 9 percent and were offered to the public at a price of 98.85, to yield 9.111 percent, or about 100 basis points more than a 30-year Treasury bond. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.    Noncallable by the utility for the first five years, the securities are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's.

headline: Rig Count Falls in Week
abstract: This week's tally of working oil and gas rigs in the United States fell by 39 to continue a seasonal slide, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. As of today, 835 rigs were working nationally, 97 fewer than a year ago at this time. Last week's count was 874. The company has said the rig count traditionally falls in the first quarter of the year and continues to decline through April. The count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for petroleum and natural gas, not those producing oil and gas.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: DEBT * Sonat Inc. is offering $100 million in 9 percent noncallable notes due in 2001 at 99.5 to yield 9.077 percent, through Goldman, Sachs & Co. * Texas Utilities Electric Co. is offering $300 million in 9.75 percent bonds due in 2021 at 100, through Bear, Stearns & Co. The issue is not callable for 10 years and is rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB by S.& P.

headline: Split Stock Approved For USX
abstract: Shareholders of the USX Corporation approved a plan yesterday to separate the company's vast energy business from its steel operations by issuing new common stock linked to its steel business.    The plan will give shareholders the option of investing in either energy or steel, and was widely viewed when it was approved by the company's board in January as a step toward getting out of the steel business. USX, the former United States Steel Company, is the nation's largest steel producer. It also owns the Marathon Oil Company, which it purchased for $6 billion in 1982.

headline: Kohlberg-Granite Deal
abstract: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company and the Granite Capital Group said yesterday that they had formed the Granum Communications Company to buy and manage radio stations. Herbert W. McCord was named president and chief executive of Granum, which will be based in New York. Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts would not disclose how much capital it had invested in the new company. Granum is similar in structure to K-III Holdings Inc., a company formed in 1989 by Kohlberg, Kravis and several former executives of Macmillan Inc. to acquire publishing companies.

headline: United and American Show Jump in Air Travel in May
abstract: The nation's two largest airlines, American and United, posted big increases in traffic for May. It was the first significant advance since the beginning of the year, when the Persian Gulf war discouraged many people from air travel.   American Airlines said yesterday that its traffic had risen 6.6 percent in May over May 1990. On Tuesday United showed a surge of 14.9 percent.

headline: Interest Rates Still Climbing
abstract: Interest rates continued their climb yesterday in both the long- and short-term Government debt markets.    Rising concerns about the large volume of Treasury debt scheduled for sale over the next three weeks caused a sharp fall in prices of long-term Government issues, and pushed rates up for a third straight day.

headline: Suzuki Starts Joint Venture In Hungary
abstract: The Suzuki Motor Corporation began the first major Japanese investment in Eastern Europe today, signing a joint venture project that will start producing hatchback passenger cars at a former Soviet military base in northern Hungary next year.   The $235 million Magyar Suzuki plant, near the Danube River in the city of Esztergom, represents the largest single foreign investment in Hungary.

headline: British Government Offers Bill to Neuter Pit Bull Dogs
abstract: The Government proposed today that owners of dangerous dogs be required to have their pets neutered, but backed off from a stricter plan.   The Government said it would not seek the immediate destruction of the 10,000 American pit bull terriers in Britain, as it proposed earlier. Instead, owners of dogs bred for fighting would be required to have them neutered, obtain a permit, hold third party insurance, and keep their dogs muzzled and on a leash in public.

headline: Announcement by Nissan Sends Platinum Tumbling
abstract: The global platinum market was shaken yesterday after the the Nissan Motor Company, the Japanese auto maker, said it had developed a catalytic converter that uses palladium instead of more expensive platinum to remove pollutants from motor vehicle exhausts.    As a result, platinum prices tumbled first in Tokyo, then in London and New York, while palladium prices soared. Within the platinum group of metals, only rhodium is used with its sister metals in exhaust antipollution devices. The other members of the platinum family are iridium, osmium and ruthenium, all hard, corrosive-resistant metals used for products as diverse as pen points, phonograph needles and the linings for jet engines.

headline: A Permit Plan For Polluters
abstract: Federal regulators today announced a plan that requires major industrial air polluters to obtain permits to help the Government and the public monitor their compliance with clean air laws.   The plan, under which states would issue permits for about 34,000 primary industrial sites, will clarify industries' obligations under the Clean Air Act, the Environmental Protection Agency said.

headline: Soviets' Real Issue: Aid
abstract: In clearing away the last obstacles to the treaty reducing nonnuclear forces in Europe, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union has today sent another strong signal that he wants to focus on what for him is a real life or death issue: economic assistance from the West.   The increasingly desperate requirements of the Soviet leader for Western economic help bring with them both opportunities and demands for the Bush Administration. The opportunities are for Washington to squeeze the Soviets for as many concessions on arms control as possible, while at the same time pressing Mr. Gorbachev to undertake economic reforms far more sweeping than he is now prepared to consider.

headline: BUSH BACKS LOANS FOR SOVIET FARMS WORTH $1.5 BILLION
abstract: President Bush approved $1.5 billion in agricultural loan guarantees for the Soviet Union today, a major step toward helping President Mikhail S. Gorbachev bolster his country's economy.   The loan guarantees, which Mr. Bush had recently indicated he would approve after extending $1 billion in similar credits last December, will be made available in three installments starting this month with $600 million, said Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman.

headline: New Convex Lines
abstract: The Convex Computer Corporation introduced three new families of supercomputers. The C3 series includes the high-end C3800 family, the departmental C3400 family and the low-cost C3200 family. The units are priced from $350,000 to $8 million. Convex now offers a range of air-cooled supercomputers and the largest library of Unix-based, third-party applications software in the industry.

headline: In Addis Ababa, a War Comes Home
abstract: With rebels at the outskirts of this Ethiopian capital, residents here today demonstrated all the emotions associated with a crisis.   Some people showed great tenderness, some the deepest sorrow, some anger, while others refused to give up hope that Ethiopia could still be saved from disintegration.

headline: China Warns On Luxuries
