abstract: China's ruling State Council warned today that spending on luxury goods by the leaders of debt-ridden state companies and other operations threatened to undermine the country's official austerity program and increase inflation.    "The desire for high consumption is once more on the rise," the council said through the state news media. It added that too many organizations were "lusting after the new and seeking out the foreign."

headline: A PAKISTANI PLAN FOR ISLAMIC CODE
abstract: The Government introduced legislation today that would make the Koran the supreme law of Pakistan and subject all aspects of life, from social behavior to civil liberties, to Islamic tenets.   The proposed legislation fulfills Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's election promise to small but powerful Islamic religious parties that are crucial to the survival of his six-month-old coalition Government.

headline: Former Engines of Kuwait Line Up Bleakly for Alien Status
abstract: They squatted on curbs amid garbage and broken glass, the men on one curb, the women along another, waiting to register with the Government of Kuwait as Palestinians.    They are now the most despised residents of this emirate. But to many, they are also considered essential to making this country work again.

headline: Ammirati Is Said to Lose Nynex Account Review
abstract: Ammirati & Puris has been eliminated as a finalist in the hotly contested review for the Nynex Corporation's $20 million to $30 million corporate account, apparently clearing the way for Ogilvy & Mather, the other finalist, industry executives said.   Pete Goodale, a spokesman for Nynex, said the telephone company had no announcement to make concerning the account. A spokeswoman for Ogilvy said the agency had not been told that it would be awarded the business.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Central Bancshares of the South Inc., Birmingham, Ala., completed the acquisitions of two Dallas area banks from Metroplex Bancshares Inc. for undisclosed terms. * Chili's Inc., Dallas, a restaurant operator, changed its name to Brinker International Inc.

headline: Head Quits At Ferruzzi
abstract: Six months after losing a battle for control of Italy's chemical industry, Raul Gardini has resigned as chairman of the family holding company that runs the Gruppo Ferruzzi agriculture and industrial empire.   Arturo Ferruzzi, 51 years old, Mr. Gardini's brother-in-law and the only son of the group's founder, Serafino Ferruzzi, will succeed Mr. Gardini.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Etonic Tretorn Puma, a footwear and apparel manufacturer in Brockton, Mass., to Arnold Fortuna Lane, Boston, for its Tretorn division. Billings are $2.5 million to $3 million. Arnold Advertising and Emerson Lane Fortuna consolidated to form the agency last week. The incumbent agency on the account was Altschiller Reitzfeld/Tracy-Locke.

headline: Father of Eurodollars Becoming a TV Star
abstract: As prime-time subjects go, the creation of the Eurodollar just does not have the sex appeal of "Dallas."    Yet here, before the cameras, klieg lights and white marble fireplace, was a charcoal-haired Sam Waterston, portraying Siegmund Warburg, the late British-German banker, laying out plans to create the Eurodollar, the financial tool that revolutionized European markets in the 1960's.

headline: OPPOSITION OFFICE IN MOSCOW BOMBED
abstract: A powerful blast wrecked the headquarters of the Soviet Union's leading anti-Communist opposition movement on Thursday night, and leaders of the group today described the explosion as an act of political terrorism.    No one was hurt, but petitions with thousands of signatures supporting the candidacy of Boris N. Yeltsin in next month's popular election for the presidency of the Russian republic were destroyed when the old brick building that houses the opposition group, Democratic Russia, exploded about 10:20 P.M. Thursday.

headline: Regulator Praises Kohlberg
abstract: T. Timothy Ryan Jr., director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, yesterday praised the investment by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company in the acquisition of the failed Bank of New England by the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group.    Mr. Ryan, the nation's top savings and loan regulator and a member of the board of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said the move "marks the entry of sophisticated investors into the process of the consolidation of our banking system." He made his remarks at the annual meeting in New York of Financial Security Assurance, a bond insurer.

headline: Careers; Managers Lack Fluency In Languages
abstract: FEW American managers can claim fluency in foreign languages, despite the growing emphasis on globalization, according to a survey made by Dunhill Personnel System Inc.   Dunhill found that most American managers were not "ready to compete globally," because they did not even feel that language skills were important and they lacked "sufficient cultural understanding." Although about 80 percent of the managers surveyed studied a foreign language, only 25 percent said they were fluent.

headline: Panel Asks Bush to Cite 3 Nations
abstract: A panel of Cabinet officials has recommended to President Bush that the United States officially cite China, India and Thailand on Friday for tolerating violations of American copyrights and patents, Congressional and Administration officials said today.    Such a move would require the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills to begin a formal investigation and negotiations with each country. It would also authorize, but not require, her to increase duties or introduce other restrictions on imports from these countries if no improvements were made by December or early next year.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Care Group Inc., Lake Success, L.I., a provider of home health-care services for AIDS patients, will acquire Children's Nursing Services/Medstaff, Houston, a provider of pediatric nursing services. Terms are being negotiated. * Chrysler Corp., Highland Park, Mich., will open a parts distribution center in Belgium next month.

headline: Mandela Urges Convicts to End 37-Day Fast
abstract: Nelson Mandela, the leader of the African National Congress, appealed today for political prisoners to stop a hunger strike, now in its 37th day.   Mr. Mandela has been in Nigeria this week attending the meeting of the Organization of African Unity and is scheduled to fly to France before returning home. The African National Congress issued a statement today saying Mr. Mandela wanted the protesters in prison to stop.

headline: Soviets Brace for Less of Less On Eve of Big Price Increases
abstract: Consumer prices across the Soviet Union will soar by an average of 250 percent on Tuesday as the Government begins its long-awaited price reform. Outside the Kremlin, there are not many who believe that the measure will bring more than another spiral of misery.    The increases, announced on March 19, have long been considered a prerequisite for authentic economic change in the Soviet Union, where centrally set prices long ago lost any relation to the cost of producing the goods.

headline: Taiwan Ends Emergency Decree, Opening Way to Closer China Ties
abstract: President Lee Teng-hui declared an end to 43 years of emergency rule today, paving the way for greater democracy on the island and closer relations with China.   Mr. Lee took a symbolic step toward reconciliation with Beijing by ending the "Period of Communist Rebellion," a decree issued by the Nationalist Government a year before it lost the Chinese civil war and fled to Taiwan in 1949.

headline: Greece Expels 26 Palestinians In Botched Attack That Killed 7
abstract: The Greek Government said today that it had ordered 26 Palestinian diplomats and students expelled from the country in connection with an attack on a British consulate in which seven people were killed and eight wounded.    Seven Palestinians have already been charged with murder in connection with the attack, and have been jailed pending trial.

headline: Star-Studded India Vote Gets Mixed Reviews
abstract: Lal Kishan Advani, leader of the right-wing Bharatiya Janata Party, is a sobersided, meticulously articulate, scrupulously courtly man. He also happens to be a proven vote-getter in this capital city's most powerful district, and Rajiv Gandhi's most serious competitor for the prime ministership of India.    What is a frustrated Congress Party to do in the face of all this gravity? Send in a celebrity.

headline: U.S. Is Said to Offer to Back Israel With Veto in U.N.
abstract: The Bush Administration has assured Israel that the United States would veto any United Nations Security Council resolution affecting the Middle Eastern peace process as long as peace talks were under way, people close to efforts to convene such talks say.   The proposal is aimed at breaking the deadlock over efforts to convene an international peace conference on the Middle East. It was made in a letter to the Israeli Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, which was given to the Israeli Foreign Minister, David Levy.

headline: GTE Debentures Have 9.118% Yield
abstract: Paine Webber Inc. led an underwriting group yesterday that priced $500 million in GTE Corporation debentures due in 2003.

headline: Rich's Plans To Close Its Main Store
abstract: Rich's Inc., a landmark in downtown Atlanta for more than a century, announced yesterday that it would close the huge store on July 13 after five years of continuing losses.    The announcement at 5 P.M. surprised the store staff, competitors and the public. Many had assumed that Rich's would stay put in its flagship location because of its participation in local affairs and continue its brisk competition with Macy's, its rival downtown.

headline: A Miller Account Chief Is Returning to B.S.B.
abstract: There was advertising news on two fronts yesterday involving the Miller Brewing Company.   In New York, Backer Spielvogel Bates Inc. announced the return of Frank Assumma to work on its Miller account. On June 17, Mr. Assumma will rejoin the agency, where he worked as an executive vice president from 1984 to 1989.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Qantas Airways Gives Account to D.M.B.&B.;
abstract: Qantas Airways has awarded its worldwide advertising account to D.M.B.&B.;/Weekes Morris Osborn, the Sydney, Australia, office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.   The airline declined to disclose its advertising budget, which industry executives estimated at $35 million.

headline: Dollar Up in Quiet Trading; Gold Prices Also Higher
abstract: The dollar rose yesterday in quiet trading as investors were heartened by the results of the Treasury's bond auction.   Gold prices were mostly higher, rising in all major markets except Zurich. Gold picked up 60 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $357.10 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $357, up 70 cents.    There were few events to influence domestic currency trading, but the market was reassured by good demand for the $11.96 billion in 10-year notes the Treasury sold yesterday, said Kevin Logan, chief economist for the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.

headline: Earnings Up At Eli Lilly and Upjohn
abstract: Eli Lilly & Company and the Upjohn Company each reported double-digit earnings increases for the first quarter, confirming the ability of drug makers to do well despite problems in the economy.   Lilly, based in Indianapolis, said net income rose 14 percent from the same period last year. Upjohn, based in Kalamazoo, Mich., said earnings had increased 16.6 percent. But analysts said both drug companies had important products that faced marketing problems.  Eli Lilly    Lilly said net income in the quarter was $388.6 million, or $1.35 a share, compared with $340.8 million, or $1.16 a share, a year ago. Quarterly sales rose 15.7 percent to $1.44 billion, from $1.24 billion a year ago.

headline: Foreign Stocks Gain, But U.S. Investors Lag
abstract: It was a good quarter for investors in foreign stock markets. But it was not so good for Americans.    Mexico's bourse again led the pack, rising 36.9 percent in local currency, and continuing its recent dominance of world market performance. And stock markets in Europe, even with a relatively weak performance by Germany, outperformed Wall Street, according to the Financial Times index of world markets. European markets rose 15.4 percent, compared with a 14.1 percent rise in the United States. The Tokyo market was up 13 percent in local currency.

headline: GERMAN FAR LEFT DOGS NEW AGENCY
abstract: Until recently, the privatizing agency known as Treuhand was only the most hated Government agency in eastern Germany. Now it has become a target of deadly terrorism.    A Treuhand office in Berlin was firebombed on Friday, and three days later the director, Detlev Karsten Rohwedder, was killed by a sniper from the far-left Red Army Faction. The assaults have thrust the Treuhandanstalt, or Public Trustee, to the forefront of political debate.

headline: Pier 1 Buyback
abstract: Pier 1 Imports Inc., a retailer of household furnishings, said it would buy back all the Pier 1 formula-rate preferred stock owned by Intermark Inc., a holding company that is Pier 1's largest shareholder. Pier 1 said the stock it was acquiring had an aggregate redemption value of $2.5 million. Pier 1 said the transaction represented 1.4 million shares, or 92 percent of its formula-rate preferred shares outstanding.

headline: Vehicle Sales Rose 9.4% In Early June
abstract: An especially strong performance by the General Motors Corporation helped raise sales of domestically built cars and light trucks 9.4 percent in early June.    Although sales are still relatively weak and analysts predict that auto makers may be forced to trim their third-quarter production schedules, the latest numbers suggest that the United States automotive market continues slowly to gain strength.

headline: In Kurdish Havens, the Big Danger Is Underfoot
abstract: Among the standing orders for American soldiers in northern Iraq is that they may not imitate the fabled giveaway habits of their fathers and grandfathers.    No chocolate bars or other candy may be thrown from Army trucks and jeeps to Kurdish children who line the streets, thick as wildflowers, across the allied security zone in northern Iraq.

headline: Groups Explore Effort For Rights to the Clios
abstract: In the wake of the problems that plagued the 1991 Clio Awards, at least two groups are exploring the possibility of taking over sponsorship of the awards.    Herbert Rickman, president of New York Pride, a not-for-profit foundation that promotes New York City, said that four top advertising executives had asked his organization to consider running the Clios. "It's not in our current scope, but our board has talked about it," said Mr. Rickman, who was liaison to the advertising industry for Edward I. Koch, the former Mayor of New York.

headline: Valentine-Radford Gets Campaign for U S Sprint
abstract: U S Sprint, which has its corporate headquarters in Kansas City, Mo., has selected Valentine-Radford Inc., a Kansas City agency, to develop a marketing campaign that highlights the company's community service activities there.   The campaign is intended to foster good will and attract customers in Sprint's hometown, and the company is considering similar efforts in other markets around the country, said Jorge Rodriguez, vice president, consumer marketing and advertising, at U S Sprint. Initially, the company intends to spend "just shy of $1 million" on the Kansas City campaign, Mr. Rodriguez said.

headline: Resignation in Brazil
abstract: Economy Minister Zelia Cardoso de Mello resigned today, ending a 14-month struggle to rein in her nation's astronomical inflation rate. The decision was announced late today by Justice Minister Jarbas Passarino, who said Brazil's Ambassador to Washington, Marcilio Marques Moreira, would replace Ms. Cardoso de Mello.

headline: Pacific Telesis Advances Slightly
abstract: Pacific Telesis yesterday reported a slight earnings gain, while two sister Baby Bells, Ameritech and Southwestern Bell, posted modest declines. Analysts said the figures showed that all the telephone companies were feeling the impact of slower growth during the recession, especially among business customers.   United Telecommunications Inc., the owner of U S Sprint, reported that earnings dropped sharply from a year ago but were up from the previous quarter. Analysts who follow the long-distance companies use comparisons with the previous quarter to determine who is gaining market share, but it will be unclear how favorable yesterday's figures were for Sprint until the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the market leader, and MCI Communications Corporation, No. 2 in long distance, report their earnings.

headline: U.S. Securities Are Little Changed
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities were little changed and interest rates were stable in quiet trading yesterday. Barring some big surprise, market participants said activity would remain slow until Friday, when May employment figures are released.    "People seem to be positioned the way they want to be in front of the employment data," one government bond trader said.

headline: Tartikoff's TV Valedictory: It's Tougher Now Than Ever
abstract: NBC was still the No. 1 network last week when the chief architect of its six years of prime-time leadership, Brandon Tartikoff, announced that he was leaving network television to run a movie studio.   Eleven years earlier, when Mr. Tartikoff began running the NBC entertainment division, the network was in a shambles -- a distant, hopeless third in the ratings, the joke of the television industry.

headline: Patents; Low-Calorie Substitute For Sugar
abstract: A small chemical company has patented a method for producing a new low-calorie sugar substitute that executives say comes closer to the real thing than alternative sweeteners.   The search for new sugar substitutes has accelerated sharply in recent years. Aspartame, sold primarily by the Nutrasweet subsidiary of the Monsanto Company, constitutes a $1 billion market. But a number of companies, including Nutrasweet, are working on newer compounds that are thousands of times sweeter than both natural sugar and aspartame and could be cheaper to produce.

headline: Move on Unscrambling Of Messages Is Assailed
abstract: A measure tucked inside a recently proposed Senate bill calls on telephone and computer companies to give the Government the means to unscramble private electronic messages and telephone conversations that have been encrypted to insure privacy.   The provision is defended as a way to prevent the concealment of illegal activity, but it has alarmed business executives and civil libertarians.

headline: F.D.I.C. Deal With Fleet
abstract: The Fleet-Norstar Financial Group said today that it had reached an agreement with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to liquidate, collect and manage certain assets for three of the Bank of New England bridge banks.   Fleet said it had created a new company, the Recoll Management Corporation, to manage the assets, which will initially total about $5.5 billion.

headline: All About/Hiking Shoes; A Resurgence for Hiking -- Make That Strolling -- Boots
abstract: Hiking boots, those heavy, bomb-proof wedges of leather and rubber that were all the rage on college campuses 20 years ago, have gone through a metamorphosis. They have emerged in a flutter of colorful, high-tech designs that weigh almost nothing and cost anywhere from $50 to $250. In the last few years, the popularity of these boots and their high-tech cousins -- low-cut, hiking shoes -- has spread far beyond the traditional outdoor-enthusiast market.   Behind the growth in this nearly $300 million market is the renewed interest in the environment and the shift -- especially among the aging baby-boom generation -- away from vigorous aerobics to the more family-friendly joys of walking, now the nation's leading form of exercise. And where baby boomers wander, the market follows.

headline: A Warhol Protege Alters The Tastes of Connoisseur
abstract: When Hearst Magazines dismissed Thomas Hoving as editor in chief of Connoisseur and replaced him with Gael Love, the message was as clear as a piece of Baccarat crystal: pomp was out and pop was in at the 90-year-old magazine.    Since the departure of Mr. Hoving, the former director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, in January, the magazine has changed noticeably.

headline: Best Products Closing Stores
abstract: The Best Products Company said today that 24 of its 195 catalogue showrooms would close, along with 15 of its 33 jewelry stores.   The retailer, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization in January, will lay off 1,550 employees, leaving about 13,900.

headline: Agencies Are Urged to Revitalize Industry
abstract: SOME people in advertising think their industry needs another David Ogilvy. Others think their industry needs another William Bernbach. But Keith Reinhard thinks the industry needs another Ted Turner.   "The Ted Turner of our industry has yet to identify himself," Mr. Reinhard, outgoing chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, said in an interview before the group's 73th annual meeting opened here yesterday. "Yet we better get about reinvigorating our industry before someone else does it for us."

headline: Schneider Changes Its Square D Slate
abstract: The Square D Company, the target of a hostile takeover attempt by Schneider S.A. of France, said Schneider had changed the slate of directors it had originally proposed for election at Square D's upcoming annual meeting. Square D said Schneider was trying to change its candidates to avoid a legal conflict with the interlocking director provisions of antitrust laws raised by Schneider's initial slate of nominees.    In response, Schneider said the new slate was an alternative in case the original nominees are not allowed to stand for election. Schneider said earlier this week that it had received about 68.9 percent of Square D's shares in response to an unsolicited $78 a share offer. Shares of Square D, a maker of electric equipment, lost 75 cents each on the New York Stock Exchange today, closing at 77.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: DEBT * CPC International Inc., Englewood Cliffs, N.J., is offering $250 million in liquid-yield option notes, due in 2006, at a price of 411.99 for every $1,000 of bonds through Merrill Lynch. The notes are zero-coupon and pay no interest but if held to maturity yield 6 percent. They are also convertible into 4.112 common shares of CPC. The issue is rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A- by Standard & Poor's. * J. P. Morgan & Co., New York, has filed with the S.E.C. to extend a shelf registration for subordinated debt to cover offering an additional $400 million in securities, for a total of $600 million.

headline: Making a Difference; Sony Is Betting Big on Its Man From Iceland
abstract: Iceland is not one of the world's great consumer electronics markets. Nonetheless, the Sony Corporation has tapped a 29-year-old native of Iceland to spearhead its attempt to storm the $4.7 billion video game business. President of Sony's Electronic Publishing Company, which was created just three months ago, Olaf Olaffson now finds himself in the middle of Sony's battle with the Nintendo Company over who will profit from the next generation of video games.   The dispute between Sony and Nintendo erupted a week ago, when Sony announced that it planned to enter the game market with a machine called the Play Station. In effect, Sony said it would be adding a compact disk player to Nintendo's new video game machine, the Super NES. Sony said that a contract it signed with Nintendo last year to develop the Play Station gave it the rights to profits from compact disk games made for it.

headline: Iraqi Town Remains Calm
abstract: The streets of this American-occupied town were calm today after an outburst of violence Sunday that left at least five dead, and Kurdish leaders here said they expected no further trouble.    There are no longer any Iraqi police officers or civilian agents of the Saddam Hussein Government in Dohuk. All fled after Sunday's attack, in which two officials of the ruling Baath Party were beaten to death inside their headquarters.

headline: New Chairman At Fleet Banks
abstract: The Fleet-Norstar Financial Group today named Robert J. Higgins chairman and chief executive of Fleet's Connecticut banks, including the Fleet Bank of Connecticut and the New Connecticut Bank and Trust Company.    Fleet-Norstar recently took over operation of the Bank of New England and its units, including Connecticut Bank and Trust, under an interim agreement with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

headline: Economic Index Posts 3d Advance In a Sign Recession May End Soon
abstract: Posting a third straight advance, the Government's main economic forecasting gauge signaled today that the 10-month-old recession would soon be over.   "The end is imminent," said Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc. "We're going to have a summer recovery."

headline: U.S. Reluctant to Aid Soviets, Bush Aide Says
abstract: With the finance ministers of seven leading industrial countries scheduled to meet on Sunday in London, a senior Administration official said today that the United States was reluctant to give financial aid to the Soviet Union without strings attached.   The official, who insisted on anonymity, said he was against any effort in which "substantial amounts of money are put up against promises of reform."

headline: U.S. Says Iraqis' Uranium Is Still Enough for One Bomb
abstract: Despite the intensive allied bombing of Iraq's strategic military sites, Iraq still has enough undamaged weapons-grade uranium to make one nuclear bomb, according to Administration officials and scientists who reviewed an Iraqi letter delivered to the United Nations that details its nuclear holdings.    "The principal purpose of bombing the nuclear sites was to destroy their fuel, which this document proves was not achieved," said Leonard S. Spector, a nonproliferation analyst and author at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

headline: Saga of Milken's 'Dream' (Don't Hunt for Warts)
abstract: Michael R. Milken is in jail. Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. is in bankruptcy. The "junk bond" market is in disarray.    But to a loyal former aide to Mr. Milken, and to companies like Safeway Stores, MCI Communications and dozens of others that were financed by junk bonds issued through Drexel, the benefits of the high-yield, high-risk securities and the financial genius of Mr. Milken live on.

headline: Enthusiasm Fades for Tying Agency Pay to Performance
abstract: IN recent years, the concept of paying advertising agencies based on criteria like how well sales pitches sell products has been one of the hottest trends in the business. But the latest version of an annual survey of client-agency relationships suggests that the appeal of the concept, known as performance-based compensation, may be waning.   A preview of the 1991 Salz Survey of Advertiser-Agency Relations showed a surprising shift in attitudes toward such compensation practices, said Nancy L. Salz, an industry consultant and author. She is head of Nancy L. Salz Consulting, a New York-based firm that specializes in counseling companies on ways to improve relations with their agencies.

headline: U.S. Aides Hold Talks With Premier of Russia
abstract: Displaying their readiness to expand ties with reformist leaders of the Soviet republics, senior Administration officials met today with the Prime Minister of Russia, Ivan S. Silayev, to discuss how to improve the investment climate there for American business.   The officials emphasized that their meetings with Mr. Silayev, an ally of Boris N. Yeltsin, the Russian republic's leader, was not intended as a slap at President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

headline: Trump Aims to Turn Most of Plaza Hotel Into Condominiums
abstract: If Donald Trump's latest plan goes through, most of the rooms at the Plaza Hotel will be converted into condominium units.   Mr. Trump and some of his bankers yesterday confirmed the existence of the conversion plan, which is subject to the approval of the New York State Attorney General's office. The plan is expected to be filed with that office within 60 days.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   9.00   8.75-9   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.82   5.92   8.18        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.64   5.70   7.80        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.70   5.74   7.96        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   7.90   7.98   9.01        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   8.20   8.26   8.97        TELEPHONE BONDS   9.27   9.32   10.06        MUNICIPAL BONDS**   7.27   7.29   7.66       *Estimated daily average, source Salomon Brothers **Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: U.S. IS SKEPTICAL ON AUTONOMY PACT FOR KURDS IN IRAQ
abstract: White House officials expressed skepticism today over President Saddam Hussein's accord with Iraqi Kurds and said the Bush Administration was committed to building camps for the Kurdish refugees in northern Iraq.   The American reaction to the Iraqi-Kurdish agreement, announced in Baghdad on Wednesday, paralleled that of the Kurdish refugees themselves. Since their flight to the mountains, the refugees have insisted that they will not return to Iraq until Mr. Hussein is out of power, and they repeated that insistence today.

headline: U.S. Auto Makers' Research Venture
abstract: The Big Three auto makers formed a research consortium to study automotive electronics.   The General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation said the High Speed Serial Data Research and Development Partnership would conduct research and develop devices that electronically process data from components like brakes and direction sensors. The venture must be approved by the Justice Department, but little opposition is likely.

headline: Trade Group Gets New Head
abstract: Anyone familiar with Alex Kroll's exploits as a college and pro football star would not be surprised to learn that he will have a "blocking and tackling" agenda during his term as chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.   Mr. Kroll, the chairman and chief executive of Young & Rubicam Inc., became the chairman today as the 73d annual meeting of the organization ended. He succeeds Keith Reinhard, chairman and chief executive of DDB Needham Worldwide, New York.

headline: JMB Real Estate Venture Is Battered in London
abstract: A closely watched $425 million European real estate venture involving the JMB Realty Corporation and several big American pension funds has been battered by falling property values in London and for a second time in less than a year is hard pressed for cash.   Randsworth Trust P.L.C., which JMB bought in 1989 with the pension funds' help, stumbled last year because of Britain's high interest rates and falling property values. Last June, JMB told about 15 of the funds that Randsworth was paying out too much on its floating-rate debt and that the partnership would need some fresh capital. JMB got some of the money, but it has not proved enough. Another Infusion Needed     JMB is once again asking some of the funds to help recapitalize the investment because although British rates have fallen, appraised property values have been falling faster. The Randsworth portfolio was bought at a high point in the London market, and the idea was to sell a few big properties to pay down the debt used for the purchase and provide working capital. But property values started to slide, and the partners decided not to sell into a falling market, which meant that the tens of millions of dollars needed would have to come from somewhere else.

headline: Your Own Account; When a Private Banker Can Help
abstract: Eleanor K. H. Blayney, a McLean, Va., financial planner, has a client with a problem: he needs to come up with $250,000 in 45 days to pay for a piece of raw land that he bought at a bankruptcy auction. Undeveloped land is often difficult to finance, particularly on such short notice. But Ms. Blayney has a solution: using a private banker. The client's financial background is strong enough to meet the banker's guidelines, Ms. Blayney said, and a check should be available in a matter of days.   Getting loans quickly and with a minimum of red tape is perhaps the most useful service provided by private banking departments, which exist at most commercial banks and some savings banks. At their most elaborate, the departments are designed to pull all the disparate resources of a bank together in one place to help clients with all of their financial needs. In return for being assigned to a specific banker and given access to a range of financial experts, the client is expected to generate a certain amount of business or pay a minimum annual fee.

headline: DDB Needham Names Two Creative Directors
abstract: DDB Needham Worldwide's Chicago office went outside and inside to name two co-executive creative directors.   From outside, the agency is bringing in David Jenkins, 37 years old. He was an award-winning senior art director with Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., where he worked on the Nike account.

headline: First Nationwide Picks 3 To Bolster Management
abstract: In an effort to strengthen its management team, First Nationwide Bank, the savings institution owned by the Ford Motor Company, named three banking industry veterans today as executive vice presidents in charge of data processing, retail banking and real estate.    First Nationwide, based in San Francisco, has come under criticism from Federal regulators for what they termed sloppy management and questionable transactions. Last week, the savings bank signed a supervisory agreement with the Office of Thrift Supervision, promising to take steps to correct the problems and insure adequate capital.

headline: A Senior P.L.O. Aide Wounded in Lebanon
abstract: A senior aide in the Palestine Liberation Organization was seriously wounded and four of his bodyguards killed Wednesday night in the latest of a spate of attacks on guerrilla leaders in southern Lebanon, security officials said today.   Unidentified gunmen ambushed Maj. Amin Kayed as he and his escorts were driving outside the Palestinian base at Mieh Mieh near the port of Sidon, 25 miles south of Beirut, the officials said.

headline: Baghdad to Disband Militia and End Travel Ban
abstract: Iraq said today that it would disband its million-man militia and let citizens travel abroad.   The part-time militia, called the Popular Army, was originally recruited from members of the governing Baath Party. Expanded during the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war, it now consists mainly of volunteers too young or too old for compulsory military service.

headline: Armco-Kawasaki
abstract: The Armco Steel Corporation L.P., a joint venture of Japan's Kawasaki Steel Corporation and Armco Inc., has decided to postpone a planned $200 million investment on a new continuous galvanizing line in the venture's Ohio plant, a Kawasaki spokesman said. The decision was made in response to the sluggish United States car market, he said. A continuous galvanizing line makes thin steel plates for car parts. The spokesman said Armco Steel would build the facility when the United States auto market recovered. Armco is 55 percent owned by Armco and 45 percent owned by Kawasaki.

headline: GAF Subsidiary To Offer Shares
abstract: The GAF Corporation said yesterday that its newly formed subsidiary, International Specialty Products Inc., had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of 17.4 million common shares, or 17.8 percent of its common stock, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.    Company officials said the initial offering price was expected to be $13.50 to $15.50 a share, for a total of as much as $269.7 million.

headline: A.T.& T. and NCR
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it had extended the expiration date of its $90-a-share cash tender offer for the NCR Corporation to midnight May 20, from midnight this past Tuesday. A.T.& T. said it had received tenders for about 18.4 million shares, or about 27 percent of NCR stock. Analysts said the low number of shares tendered for the $90 offer was not surprising because A.T.& T. had said it was willing to pay $110 a share for NCR if the two companies could negotiate terms. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, NCR shares closed at $103.50, up 12.5 cents, and A.T.& T. shares gained 37.5 cents, closing at $37.50.

headline: Highland Superstores To Cut Management
abstract: In its latest effort to cut expenses, Highland Superstores, the financially pressured chain of electronics and appliance stores, said yesterday that it was eliminating five vice presidential positions and that Yale Levin, its chief operating officer, was resigning.   The company, based in Plymouth, Mich., said the management reduction reflected a recent curtailing of its operations and an overall expense-cutting program. Early this month, the company, one of the country's largest electronic chains, said that it had ceased paying creditors and was closing 32 stores in Texas, Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Rhode Island to avoid a bankruptcy court filing.

headline: Stocks Decline in Japan
abstract: Japanese stock prices fell again today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues dropped 223.35 points, or 0.94 percent, to close at 23,543.03. On Wednesday, the Nikkei lost 141.04 points.

headline: Hughes May Build Thai Satellites
abstract: The Hughes Aircraft Company said it planned to build two spacecraft for Thailand's first domestic communications satellite system. Hughes said it had a memorandum of understanding to begin formal negotation on a contract that the company said would be worth about $100 million. Delivery of the first of two Hughes HS 376 satellites would be due in 1993.

headline: First U.S. Troops Arrive in Bangladesh to Begin Large-Scale Relief Effort
abstract: A team of about 64 marines and Army Special Forces troops flew from Okinawa to Bangladesh today to begin preparing for a large-scale American relief effort in the cyclone-battered country.    The team is the vanguard of a disaster relief force of nearly 8,000 dispatched by the United States military on Saturday to aid survivors, ferry food and clothing by helicopter and set up water-purification centers.

headline: Hyundai Plans China Venture
abstract: South Korea's Hyundai conglomerate plans to invest in vehicle manufacturing in China, a company spokesman said today.    The spokesman said Chung Ju Yung, Hyundai's founder and honorary chairman, was expected to visit Beijing in the next few months.

headline: ABC Agrees To Broadcast Cable Show
abstract: ABC and the cable network Nick at Nite have agreed to run a new situation comedy on each network on separate nights. It is the first time that a program produced by a cable network will be carried by a broadcast network.   ABC has bought the rights to the first six episodes of the series, a comedy called "Hi, Honey, I'm Home," and will begin running them in July. ABC is expected to announce a date for the series today.

headline: Market Place; The Riklis Offer: A Fair Exchange?
abstract: MESHULAM RIKLIS, the owner of the McCrory Corporation, is making an offer to bondholders that would appear to be eminently resistable. But given Mr. Riklis's previous tough dealing with bondholders, it is possible that some holders will choose to take it.   McCrory, the parent of such retail chains as T.G. & Y., J. J. Newberry and S. H. Kress, has a bond issue maturing on July 15, at which time holders are supposed to get back full par value for the bonds.

headline: Wholesalers Post Gain
abstract: Sales by American wholesale companies rose seven-tenths of a percent in April, to $144 billion, from $142.9 billion in March, the Commerce Department said today. Sales of durable goods, items expected to last at least three years, dropped to $68.5 billion, from $69.3 billion in March, while sales of nondurable goods rose to $75.5 billion from $73.6 billion.

headline: Beijing Marks 40 Years of Tibet's 'Liberation'
abstract: Somewhere in the far west of China, nestled in the Himalayas, is a Shangri-La brimming with contentment and human rights -- or so say the Chinese newspapers these days.   It is Tibet, although it does not entirely resemble the Tibet that Western visitors describe. The Chinese newspapers are full of reports about progress there, as China on Wednesday celebrates the 40th anniversary of what it calls "the peaceful liberation of Tibet."

headline: Congress Party Leader Faces Challenge for India's Top Post
abstract: With the dominant Congress Party set to form a new government, a major power struggle erupted today over the Prime Minister's job that pits the frail party president against a younger, influential regional leader from the business capital, Bombay.    Meeting through the day and this evening in closed sessions at party headquarters and at various hotels, party officials were faced tonight with a potentially bruising clash between P. V. Narasimha Rao, the 70-year-old former Cabinet minister who stepped into the party's presidency after the assassination of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, and Sharad Pawar, the tough, pragmatic, 51-year-old Chief Minister of India's key industrial state, Maharashtra. Although Mr. Rao is favored, Mr. Pawar is staging a dogged fight.

headline: Tokyo Stocks Lower
abstract: Stock prices were lower today in Tokyo. The Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 181.09 points, or less than 1 percent, to 26,093.20. But at midday, the Nikkei was up 10.85 points, to 26,285.14, with 120 million shares changing hands. Brokers said investors shrugged off Wall Street's 50.98-point dive on Friday, to 2,920.17, but were remaining cautious. Last week, the Nikkei fell 203.57 points.

headline: Telesat Satellite
abstract: Arianespace, a European consortium, said it had signed a contract with Telesat Mobile Inc. of Canada to launch its MSAT 1 mobile telecommunications satellite. Telesat estimated the contract at $120 million (Canadian), or about $105 million (American). MSAT 1 will provide 3,200 channels for mobile telephone and radio communications over North America. MSAT 1, built by Spar Aerospace Ltd. of Canada and the Hughes Aircraft Company of Los Angeles, will be launched from French Guyana in 1994.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M.  ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE -- 3 P.M. DISARMAMENT COMMISSION -- 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Ford Plans to Cut Staff in Europe
abstract: The Ford Motor Company said it would cut its salaried support staff in Europe by 30 percent over the next three years. The cuts mostly involve clerical and accounting workers and will not affect manufacturing and production staff, the company said.   A Ford spokesman declined to give the number of jobs to be eliminated from Ford's total of 21,000 salaried workers in the auto maker's Ford of Europe subsidiary. "We're reviewing our cost structure and need to make ourselves more competitive," the spokesman said. "Things are tough at the moment." Ford's total European work force was 126,300 in 1990. Staff workers in Britain totaled 44,000 in 1990, compared with 76,000 in 1979.

headline: There's No Stopping Europe's Airbus Now
abstract: Five years ago, when Airbus Industrie was still an unproven underdog, many airlines hesitated to order its aircraft because they were uncertain that Airbus would be around in a few years' time.    But Airbus is still alive and kicking. The European aircraft consortium has captured 30 percent of the world market and is gunning for close to 40 percent. It has shoved McDonnell Douglas aside to take the industry's No. 2 spot, and its rapid ascent even has some Boeing officials worrying about their company's survival.

headline: PARTY OF GANDHI NARROWLY AHEAD IN INDIA ELECTION
abstract: After the most violent election campaign in India's 44 years of independence, the Congress Party appeared to be leading in the national election today, but by a margin that would force it into a coalition with another party in order to form a new government.    Political experts projected that the party, which had hoped for a sympathy vote after the assassination on May 21 of its leader, Rajiv Gandhi, would win about 210 seats; 256 are needed for a majority in Parliament that would permit it to name a Prime Minister. At 10 A.M. today, the Congress Party had won 136 of the 237 seats decided.

headline: Plans to Aid New Hampshire Banks
abstract: Gov. Judd Gregg said today that he did not care whether regulators support the plan of his choice or another to save New Hampshire's banks, just so long as they do the job.   Private meetings organized by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation this week produced a plan to save the state's five most troubled banks this summer by closing them, and reopening them immediately under new, unburdened ownership, people involved said.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Economic Scene; Giving the Banks Greater Powers
abstract: EXECUTIVES of the big money center banks are the strongest supporters of the Administration proposals for overhauling the banking system -- especially freeing the banks to expand all over the country and giving them broader powers, like the sale of securities and insurance.    "The fundamental problem in banking is colossal overcapacity," said Thomas C. Theobold, the chairman of the Continental Bank of Illinois. Writing in the current issue of the Journal of Applied Finance, he added: "We don't have 10,000 independent banks because the market needs or will support 10,000 banks. We have them because banks have been too tightly regulated and almost completely insulated from normal market forces."

headline: Business Digest
abstract: The Economy    Most of the nation's largest banks cut their prime rates to 8 1/2 percent from 9 percent, reducing borrowing costs for small businesses and consumers.  [ Page A1. ]

headline: Shengli Journal; China Is Learning English and Finds It a Mouthful
abstract: It was time for a pronunciation drill in Chen Xinyu's first-year English class, so the 45 junior-high students sat back on their wooden benches and gazed toward Ms. Chen and the blackboard.   "Bose," Ms. Chen said, pointing to the word "both" on the blackboard.

headline: World Markets; Hong Kong Shivers to China's Chill
abstract: June is creeping closer, which is fine for summer buffs. But in the Hong Kong stock market -- one of the top performers in the world this year -- it is not a fun time. June 3 is the deadline for President Bush's decision on extending China's most-favored-nation trade status, and June 4 is the second anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre in Beijing.    The anniversary of the massacre is a reminder of all that can go wrong in Hong Kong when things are not right in China. In 1997, Hong Kong will revert to the control of China, and the British colony is already on edge with every twist and turn in China, as shown when the stock market plummeted 22 percent after Tiananmen Square.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt * Campbell Soup Co., Camden, N.J., is offering $200 million of 8 7/8 percent debentures due 2021, at 99.81, to yield 8.92 percent, through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The issue is rated Aa-2 by Moody's and AA by S.& P.

headline: A Young Airline's Battle to Survive Lean Times
abstract: America West Airlines, which filed for bankruptcy court protection late Thursday, is one of the few carriers created after deregulation that are still flying.    The airline, the nation's ninth largest, said it would continue in service while seeking to reorganize its finances and business under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

headline: Hungarians Debate How Far Back to Go To Right Old Wrongs
abstract: For months now, Hungary has been debating how to compensate people who were summarily stripped of their farms, shops, factories and other property during the Communist era. But as it goes about righting the perceived wrongs committed by the Communists, the Hungarian Parliament has stumbled onto other wounds that were hidden, but never healed, during the last half century.    Consider a hypothetical case, raised recently in parliamentary debate: A Jewish shopkeeper lost his store in 1939, when Hungary's quasi-fascist Government began to curtail Jewish property rights. The store was then owned by a Swabian German, who in turn lost it shortly after World War II, when many ethnic Germans, held collectively accountable for the Nazi occupation in 1944, were driven from Hungary.

headline: Allegheny Acquirer Spent $5.8 Million
abstract: The New York investment firm that acquired Allegheny International Inc. last year spent $5.8 million on legal and other professional fees to buy the company, according to court documents. The firm, Japonica Partners, also reimbursed itself for $940,879 in expenses it incurred during the acquisition, the court documents show.   The United States Bankruptcy Court has been reviewing rates billed by all professionals in the case, following charges by the Sunbeam-Oster Companies that the Pittsburgh law firm of Buchanan Ingersoll overbilled Allegheny by as much as $1.7 million. Sunbeam-Oster, which succeeded Allegheny when it emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, is managed by Japonica's principals, Paul Kazarian and Michael Lederman. It disclosed the fees in a filing with the court.

headline: Making a Difference; Compaq Fires Back at Dell, But the Upstart Keeps Coming
abstract: For the past nine months, the Dell Computer Corporation of Austin, Tex., has been taking potshots at a giant rival, the Compaq Computer Corporation, with ads suggesting in no uncertain terms that Compaq's comparable products were grossly overpriced. Last week, Compaq fired back with both barrels: it slashed prices by up to 34 percent and filed suit in Federal court to block Dell from running its ads.    Michael S. Dell, the 26-year-old chairman and chief executive of the company bearing his name, is unbowed. Dell started life in Mr. Dell's dorm room at the University of Texas in Austin and is now the largest mail order company producing personal computers. Still, the company is dwarfed by its competitor -- Compaq had revenues of $3.6 billion last year, Dell had $546 million -- and Mr. Dell said the suit is an ill-advised attempt to intimidate a small competitor. He has no intention of dropping his ads.

headline: A Village Focuses Peril to Yugoslavia
abstract: Three days after the country's political leaders agreed to disarm all civilians and paramilitary groups, this village in the republic of Croatia today remained the focal point of an armed standoff.   The road was blocked by young men with guns in camouflage uniforms who said they were from Krajina, a Serbian enclave that has announced its secession from Croatia. Nearby, a contingent of heavily armed Croatian police officers manned their own checkpoint and permitted travelers to pass only after a thorough search. Soldiers from the Yugoslav Army patrolled the no man's land in between, enforcing an uneasy truce between the nation's two largest ethnic groups.

headline: SOVIET REPUBLICS ARE SAID TO AGREE ON CRISIS PROGRAM
abstract: The Soviet Government announced today that 13 of the nation's 15 republics had agreed on the details of an emergency plan to steer the nation out of economic crisis. The plan includes a new effort to ban strikes, budget cuts and fresh assurances for skeptical foreign investors.    "We let down many of our partners and punished ourselves most of all," said Prime Minister Valentin Pavlov, who resolved to revive the tattered economy now that greater agreement had been reached with most of the balky, sovereignty-minded republics.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: COMPANIES    I.B.M.'s chairman read his managers the riot act earlier this month, saying the company had "too many people standing around the water cooler waiting to be told what to do," according to notes of his remarks.  [ Page D1. ]   L.A. Gear agreed to sell a 30 percent stake for $100 million to an investment firm headed by Roy E. Disney. L.A. Gear's shares rose more than 10 percent.  [ D1. ]

headline: IN THE IRISH SOUTH, SOME COMPROMISE
abstract: The opening of new talks on peace and stability in Northern Ireland has stirred a growing willingness on this side of the border to compromise on one of the most cherished and long-held ambitions of Irish nationalists: a united Ireland.   Weary of sectarian violence in the north, and eager to see the new British-Irish diplomatic initiative succeed where others have failed, an increasing number of politicians and ordinary citizens in the south say it may be time to rethink the Republic's territorial claim to the six counties of Northern Ireland.

headline: ANTI-SOVIET RALLY IN A REPUBLIC FAILS
abstract: The leaders of Byelorussia's anti-Government labor movement began to discover today how difficult it is to sustain popular protest in the Soviet Union.   After an initial walkout three weeks ago by perhaps 100,000 factory workers fed up with higher prices, the best the protest organizers could manage on this sunny day was 20,000 workers in Lenin Square cheering calls for an end to the Gorbachev leadership and Communism.

headline: Uniroyal Goodrich To Cut 1,000 Jobs
abstract: The Uniroyal Goodrich Tire Company said yesterday that it planned to cut about 1,000 jobs under a restructuring plan that would consolidate two tire plants in Ontario.  Uniroyal Goodrich, based in Akron, Ohio, and owned by Groupe Michelin S.A. of France, said the Ontario plan would proceed only if the company could reach agreement with the United Rubber Workers union, which represents about 2,000 workers at the plants.    If no agreement is reached, Uniroyal Goodrich said, both plants will be closed and the company will rely on its factories in the United States. Uniroyal Goodrich said that the two plants, in Kitchener, Ontario, are the least competitive of its nine operations. Another of its factories, in Eau Claire, Wis., is already scheduled to close next year.

headline: Chinese Reformer Quitting as Governor in Canton Area
abstract: Ye Xuanping, the popular Governor of Guangdong province in southern China, is stepping down after six years of overseeing the economic transformation of what is now the most prosperous region in this country, the official People's Daily said today.    National leaders have been trying for a couple of years to lure Mr. Ye, a 67-year-old Cantonese who strongly favors economic change, out of Guangdong. In March he was named vice chairman of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, a largely ceremonial and advisory post.

headline: Following the German Lead
abstract: To the Editor:   In "Demystifying the Japanese Mystique" (Forum, May 26), Charles Wolf Jr. seeks to apply Occam's razor to existing scholarship upon the subject of Japanese competitiveness, but I think the article itself can be "simplified."

headline: Listerine Risk Minimized
abstract: A television report by ABC News has linked Listerine mouthwash with increased cancer risks, but a spokeswoman for the National Cancer Institute said yesterday that any risk was slight.    The Warner-Lambert Company, based in Morris Plains, N.J., makes Listerine, a 112- year-old product that had $280 million in 1990 sales. Warner- Lambert's share price declined $3.375 yesterday, closing at $75 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange before the cancer institute made its comment.

headline: Modest Steps In Yugoslavia
abstract: The latest round of violence in Yugoslavia has jolted the nation's quarreling leaders into taking the first modest steps toward a negotiated settlement of their differences.    But the vaguely worded agreement on Thursday by the eight-member collective presidency, the national executive body, to disarm civilians and paramilitary groups appears to be more of a respite than a resolution. It does not even begin to address the fundamental issues over the future shape of this country that divide Serbs and Croats, the nation's two largest ethnic groups.

headline: Bulgaria Releasing Data on Shooting of Pope
abstract: Bulgaria is releasing more than 127 volumes of documents to investigators from several countries, including the United States, in an effort to discover the truth about allegations of Bulgarian involvement in a 1981 attempt to assassinate Pope John Paul II.   The documents, from the archives of the Bulgarian secret police, document an official investigation mounted in the early 1980's at the request of Bulgaria's Communist Government. It came to the conclusion that Bulgaria played no part in the assassination attempt, which was carried out by a Turk, Mehmet Ali Agca.

headline: Iraq Asserts Its Weakening Will Mean a Stronger Iran
abstract: With United Nations sanctions still in place two months after the end of the Persian Gulf war, senior Iraqi officials say the West should be concerned that Baghdad's weakening economic and military position will shift the regional balance in favor of Iran.    "Iran is more pragmatic in dealing with the outside world now, but its regional power aspirations have not changed," a senior Foreign Ministry official said.

headline: KURDS AND IRAQ IN ACCORD ON AUTONOMY FOR REGION; REFUGEES URGED TO RETURN
abstract: Iraqi Kurdish leaders said today that they had reached a broad new agreement with President Saddam Hussein that they hope will allow more than a million Kurdish refugees to return home.    Announcing the agreement in principle after several days of talks here, Jalal Talabani, who leads one of the largest of the Kurdish political groups, said it provided a new measure of autonomy for Kurdistan, and guarantees of democracy, pluralism and "protection of the national unity of Iraq."

headline: Chinese Party Chief Mending Relations in Moscow
abstract: The Chinese Communist Party leader, Jiang Zemin, began a visit with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today and quickly demonstrated improving relations by confirming that part of the two nations' once-volatile border dispute had been settled through compromise.    Important matters remain to be negotiated in the 30-year dispute that once kindled cross-border skirmishing. But a Chinese spokesman confirmed at a news conference that a partial settlement of the eastern border had been reached "on the basis of mutual understanding and mutual concessions" and would be signed Thursday.

headline: Visitors to North Korea Denounce Rights Abuses
abstract: Delegates to an international conference here have accused North Korea of human rights abuses, almost certainly the first public attack over human rights made against the Communist Government of North Korea on its own soil.    The accusations, made on Friday, prompted an angry reaction from Pyongyang delegates to a conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union.

headline: Medicaid Payment Ordered for Drug for Schizophrenia
abstract: The Federal Government has ordered all state Medicaid prescription drug programs to pay for clozapine, an expensive drug that could help tens of thousands of psychotic patients.    Clozapine, a treatment for schizophrenia, was available to only about 9,000 patients. The number was small because state Medicaid programs, which serve the poor, delayed approving the drug. Clozapine, together with a monitoring system needed to watch for lethal side effects, costs thousands of dollars a year.

headline: Refugee Kurds Occupy Tent City After Guerrillas Lift Barricades
abstract: Allied officers ordered Kurdish guerrilla leaders today to let Kurdish refugees through rebel checkpoints and into a safe-haven zone in northern Iraq. A Kurdish commander complied, and the first refugee families arrived tonight at the tent city near this occupied town.    Until today, the guerrillas had barred many refugees from trekking down the mountain roads from their muddy camps along the Turkish-Iraqi border, insisting that the zone set up by the United States, Britain, France and the Netherlands was not secure.

headline: Forum; Is Curbing Crime Worth the Cost?
abstract: A relatively obscure Federal agency -- the United States Sentencing Commission -- has proposed huge increases in criminal penalties that will affect both innocent and guilty corporations. In effect, these guidelines have already claimed their first victim -- the Exxon Valdez settlement, where the judge determined that Exxon's plea bargain was not tough enough.  Unfortunately, these proposals were not the result of a careful study.

headline: Pesticide Uses Bacteria to Harm Only the Pest
abstract: Using genetic engineering to combine traits from three species of bacteria, a biotechnology company in Langhorne, Pa., has patented an insecticide to fight the Colorado potato beetle, a major farm pest, and two species of caterpillars.   Developed by Ecogen Inc., the new bacteria produce three proteins that are poisonous to the pests but harmless to humans and other animals. When used as an insecticide, the bacteria are deprived of nutrients and die, secreting the proteins as toxic crystals that kill the unwanted pests.

headline: Mandela Group Moving to Arm Black Townships
abstract: The African National Congress is pressing ahead with plans to help residents of South African black townships form paramilitary self-defense units, despite the misgivings of the police and rival black groups.   Nelson Mandela, the congress's leader, has called on township residents to defend themselves against continuing violence between rival black factions, which has killed more than 550 people so far this year.

headline: Judge Won't Delay Sears Annual Meeting
abstract: A Federal judge in Philadelphia today denied a shareholder request to postpone Sears, Roebuck & Company's annual meeting so that new proxy materials could be distributed.   The shareholders wanted to distribute more information on Sears's troubles in retailing and give greater details of a lawsuit against Sears management.

headline: White House Hopes to Lift Sanctions
abstract: After the South African Parliament's repeal of the last legal pillar of apartheid, senior Bush Administration officials said today that they would move ahead with plans to lift a five-year-old set of economic sanctions against South Africa by the end of the summer.   Mr. Bush's efforts to lift the sanctions are almost certain to set off an effort in Congress to retain them by several lawmakers, who say that South Africa has not yet earned their repeal.

headline: Turkish First Lady in Politics
abstract: Turkey's First Lady, Semra Ozal, formally entered politics today, winning leadership of the governing Motherland Party's Istanbul branch. The semi-official Anatolian News Agency said Mrs. Ozal, the wife of President Turgut Ozal, won 351 of the 646 votes cast. Her opponent was Talat Yilmaz, the candidate of the party's conservatives. The party postponed the vote until today after a session on March 4 dissolved into chaos, with fistfights and scuffles among delegates.

headline: Otis Elevator Deal
abstract: The Otis Elevator Company, a subsidiary of the United Technologies Corporation, said it had signed an agreement to acquire a majority interest in the Hankook Engineering Company, an elevator company based in Seoul, South Korea. Hankook, which makes freight elevators, has been Otis's sales agent in South Korea for the last year. The new company will be named the Hankook Otis Elevator Company. It will sell, manufacture, install and maintain elevator and escalator equipment using Otis designs and technology.

headline: U.S. Deplores Moves
abstract: The Bush Administration today deplored the actions of Croatia and Slovenia to move toward secession from the Yugoslav federation as "a threat" to stability and "a dangerous situation." But these characterizations were couched more in terms of sorrow than anger.   An Administration official said the sorrow reflected the fact that the United States, long friendly with Yugoslavia, had made great efforts over many months to persuade the various contending parties to settle their differences -- including a day of meetings by Mr. Baker with all major Yugoslav leaders in Belgrade last Friday.

headline: Money Fund Assets Off
abstract: The assets of the nation's 544 money market mutual funds fell by $901.3 million, to $469.87 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 190 institutional funds rose by $1.94 billion, to $134.91 billion. The 264 general-purpose funds' assets were down by $631.5 million, to $180.18 billion. Assets of the 90 broker-dealer funds dropped by $2.21 billion, to $154.78 billion, the institute said.

headline: IRAN IS SCATTERING KURDISH REFUGEES
abstract: Travelers on the main road from the Iraqi border to this provincial capital on Monday night passed a line of 17 dump trucks under Iranian military escort. Each truck was filled with Kurdish refugees fleeing the Iraqi Army.    It is not known where they were bound, but Iran appears to be scattering the Kurds far and wide through western Iran both in organized camps and in the homes of villagers.

headline: Moet Will Buy Guinness Shares
abstract: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the French luxury goods maker, will buy up to 23.4 million shares of Guinness P.L.C., the British brewer, at up to $:10 each, or about $16.60 each for a total of up to $390 million. The French company, which said it was seeking to raise its Guinness holdings to the 24 percent level permitted under the companies' cross-holding arrangements, said S. G. Warburg Securities would acquire the shares by June 21.   LVMH already owns 23.4 percent of Guinness, and the British concern owns 24 percent of LVMH under the agreement. The shares of Guinness, which said it welcomed the purchase, jumped 30 pence each on the London Stock Exchange today, to 696 pence, or about $11.55 a share.

headline: United Technologies' Bumpy Ride
abstract: These should be heady days for the United Technologies Corporation.   Last week, the Air Force chose an engine made by its Pratt & Whitney division to power a new fighter plane. Three weeks ago, the Army tapped the company's Sikorsky division to help build a new light helicopter. And just yesterday, Malaysian Airlines said it had selected Pratt & Whitney engines to go on the airline's new Boeing 747 wide-body jets. That order could be worth as much as $266 million.

headline: Mutual Benefit Life And Cigna Ratings
abstract: The debt ratings of two large insurance companies were adjusted or affirmed yesterday by Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.   S.& P. reduced the Cigna Corporation's commercial paper rating to A-1, from A-1+. The rating agency cited the increased debt burden of the holding company, as well as a higher-than-expected debt burden because of underwriting losses at the property-casualty and life insurance subsidiaries, which offset a strong recovery in group health earnings.

headline: Glaxo Sues Maker Of Generic Drugs
abstract: Glaxo Holdings P.L.C. filed a lawsuit in the United States against a generic drug company that wanted to invalidate the Glaxo patent for the ulcer drug Zantac, the world's top-selling drug. Glaxo said Genpharm Pharmaceuticals Inc. had filed an Abbreviated New Drug Application with the Food and Drug Administration for a generic form of Zantac. Sales of the drug account for 50 percent of Glaxo's revenues.    "We are suing them for infringement," said Miles Wilson, a Glaxo spokesman. "We are taking the lead on this one." He said the company's United States patent expires in June 2002. Analysts said Glaxo's move was the start of a long legal battle. "Glaxo is going to make it extremely difficult and expensive for generic firms to get anything like Zantac on the market," said Didier Cowling at Nomura Securities in London.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; The Industry Tries to Laugh in the Face of Hard Times
abstract: THE leaders of the country's advertising industry might not be smiling through the apocalypse, but as their annual meeting continues here they are trying at least to chuckle their way through their two recessions.   Loud laughter greeted John O'Toole, president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, when at yesterday's general session he quoted from a spoof of graduation speeches by Woody Allen. "More than any other time in history mankind faces a crossroads. One path leads to despair and utter hopelessness. The other to total extinction. Let us pray we have the wisdom to choose correctly."

headline: Pro-Syrian P.L.O. Renegades Propose to End Split
abstract: Renegade Palestinian factions based in Damascus put forward a Syrian-backed initiative today for reconciliation with the mainstream Palestine Liberation Organization after an eight-year split during which they sought to overthrow Yasir Arafat.    The offer, by the Palestine National Salvation Front, a loose alliance of small factions including people known in the West as leading international terrorists, was seen by Arab diplomats as an attempt by President Hafez el-Assad to strengthen his influence over the P.L.O.

headline: Making a Difference; Playing for Keeps at a Squeezed Columbia Gas
abstract: John H. Croom rolled the dice in a big way last week. He said Columbia Gas System Inc. would stop making dividend payments and would even consider filing for bankruptcy unless it could renegotiate high-priced supply contracts with gas producers and keep its bank credit lines intact.   Mr. Croom, who is chairman, president and chief executive of the big pipeline company, offered the gas producers $600 million in securities in a Columbia subsidiary to abandon contracts signed when natural gas was scarce and expensive. Their only other choice, he said, was to stand in line as unsecured creditors in a bankruptcy proceeding that might not yield them anything more.

headline: Corporate Finance Magazine Suspended
abstract: Corporate Finance magazine, which was started in 1986, will suspend publication today. The June issue will be the last to be published by the Handelsblatt Group, the magazine's German publisher.   Claus G. Firchow, the chairman and chief executive of CF-VH Associates, the Handelsblatt subsidiary that publishes Corporate Finance and Scientific American magazines, said the company was talking with a potential buyer.

headline: OPEC Output Fell in April
abstract: OPEC production fell by 804,000 barrels a day in April, to around 22.35 million barrels, roughly in line with a cutback proposed by the group's oil ministers in March, an oil industry newsletter reported today.    The newsletter, the Middle East Economic Survey, published in Nicosia, said the fall in output resulted almost entirely from a cut in Saudi Arabian output to around 7.5 million barrels a day, from 8.4 million in March.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; People
abstract: * Jon Baker has joined Earle Palmer Brown, Bethesda, Md., as executive vice president-corporate development. * Edward A. Orgon has been named to head the business-to-business and corporate-financial groups at Creamer Dickson Basford, New York.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   10.00        DISCOUNT RATE   5.50   5.50   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.66   5.76   8.31        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.46   5.49   7.65        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.64   5.67   7.69        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   7.92   7.92   8.61        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   8.27   8.24   8.57        TELEPHONE BONDS   9.30   9.30   9.70        MUNICIPAL BONDS**   7.22   7.22   7.54       *Estimated daily average, source Salomon Brothers **Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Silicon Graphics, Microsoft in Deal
abstract: Silicon Graphics Inc. said it had agreed to license its three-dimensional graphics technology to the Microsoft Corporation for use on personal computers. The agreement allows Microsoft to integrate Silicon Graphics' Iris graphics library technology with Microsoft systems and applications software.    Iris makes it possible to display on a computer screen full-motion pictures and objects that can be manipulated to appear three-dimensional. Silicon said the first area to benefit from the deal would be computer-aided design.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Economy    The leading indicators posted their third straight advance, signaling that the 10-month-old recession will soon be over. The 0.6 percent rise followed increases of 0.7 percent in March and 1.2 percent in February. In the postwar period, three straight advances have almost invariably signaled an imminent recovery.  [ Page 1. ]

headline: CALIFORNIA SEIZES INSURER BURDENED WITH 'JUNK BONDS'
abstract: In the largest failure of an insurer, California regulators seized control today of the Executive Life Insurance Company, which had been among the heaviest buyers of high-risk "junk bonds" in the last decade under its high-flying chief executive, Fred Carr.    John Garamendi, the California insurance commissioner, said the state had taken over the management of Executive Life because the company was in hazardous condition, primarily because of defaults and declining values in its huge portfolio of junk bonds.

headline: People
abstract: * Kenneth E. Caffrey, executive vice president and worldwide media director of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, New York, will resign, effective July 15. "I just feel I did everything I could do here and want a new challenge," said Mr. Caffrey, who is 52 years old and has worked at O.&M. for 28 years. * Norman Cooper, president and chief operating officer of Kallir, Philips, Ross, New York, has been named to the additional post of chief executive. He succeeds John Kallir, who continues as chairman.

headline: Memo Says Reagan Trade Policy on Iraq Helped Hussein
abstract: A State Department memorandum released today by a Congressman said that Reagan Administration policy in the late 1980's, while barring most arms exports to Iraq, allowed the export of military equipment intended to protect President Saddam Hussein.   A Government official confirmed today that there were shipments of equipment for the protection of Mr. Hussein but that they were probably limited to military radios for his bodyguards. Congressional officials, however, said some weapons might also have been involved. All the officials spoke on the condition that they not be named.

headline: Israel's Farming Success Drains It of Water
abstract: Israel, having made the desert bloom, a proud early achievement, is now counting the costs of its remarkable development of agriculture. It finds this symbol of national success withering.    Israeli reservoirs are at their lowest levels ever, and increasingly, top officials blame the abundant availability of cheap water to farmers for what is described in terms ranging from crisis to catastrophe. The Government is considering plans to import fresh water from Turkey, Yugoslavia or Bulgaria.

headline: Albania Is Rife With Disease, Short on Essentials
abstract: Albania is facing chronic health and medical deficiencies, including serious malnourishment and shortages of such hospital essentials as disposable syringes, members of a United States Government emergency relief team have concluded.    One member of the team, Dr. Richard Kunkel, director of emergency services at the Latrobe Area Hospital in Pennsylvania, said there were no documented cases of AIDS in Albania, but an outbreak was "just waiting to happen" because syringes and intravenous tubing were sterilized and reused. Contaminated syringes can transmit the AIDS virus.

headline: Top Japanese Businessman Is Charged in Stock Fraud
abstract: A prominent Japanese businessman has fallen in a big stock market scandal. Hirotomo Takei was arrested here last week on charges that he failed to pay about $24 million in taxes owed on profits he made by using inside information to trade stocks.    Mr. Takei, a billionaire real estate entrepreneur, and Takatoshi Yasuda, an aide, were arrested on Thursday and charged with tax evasion. Prosecutors accused the men of making more than $40 million by purchasing shares of companies whose stock was manipulated by Mitsuhiro Kotani, who is at the center of the year-old scandal.

headline: 350 Libyans Trained to Oust Qaddafi Are to Come to U.S.
abstract: For two years, United States officials have been shopping around for a home for about 350 Libyan soldiers who cannot return to their country because American intelligence officials had mobilized them into a commando force to overthrow Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader.   Now, the Administration has given up trying to find another country that will accept the Libyans and has decided to bring them to the United States.

headline: British Interest Rates Cut
abstract: The British Government cut interest rates on Friday for the fourth time in two months as the annual increase in the Retail Price Index, the main indicator of inflation, fell to 8.2 percent in March from 8.9 percent in February.

headline: Futures Brokers Indicted
abstract: Two futures brokers who were expelled from the industry and fined last year for cheating customers have been indicted on Federal criminal charges, according to the United States Attorney's office in Chicago. Norman Furlett and Ira Greenspon, who solicited customers for the defunct futures trading company GNP Commodities Inc., are charged with diverting more than $100,000 in profits from winning trades into their personal accounts while allocating losing trades worth more than $200,000 into their customers' accounts in 1986. If convicted on all counts, the two could each face up to 70 years in prison, a spokesman for the United States Attorney's office said.

headline: Bank Funds and C.D.'s Fall
abstract: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were down for the ninth straight week ended yesterday, with the size of the declines diminishing in recent weeks.    Analysts at The Bank Rate Monitor said yesterday that deposit rates could bottom out in July. They said that as interest rates rose in past cycles, IBC/Donoghue's average yield on money market funds, which compete with the bank money accounts, was higher than The Monitor's average yield on a bank money market account. Conversely, when rates dropped, the spread between the measures narrowed as the declines continued, and eventually they paid nearly the same yield.

headline: CHEMICAL PROGRAM GETS WIDE SUPPORT
abstract: An American-sponsored plan to limit the spread of chemical weapons by strictly controlling the exports of chemicals used to make them has won approval from 19 other industrial nations, American officials said today.
