The agreement marks a watershed in curbing the proliferation of chemical weapons to developing nations, a key concern of Western policymakers who view the spread of such weapons as a threat in future regional conflicts.

headline: Austin, Tex., Offers Insured Bonds
abstract: The City of Austin, Tex., is offering $56.8 million in combined utility systems revenue refunding bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.    Underwriters said the tax-exempt bonds had a maximum yield of 6.875 percent for a bond due in 2007. For shorter maturities, there are serial bonds with yields ranging from 4.5 percent in 1991 to 5.8 percent in 1996, 6.35 percent in 2001 and 6.55 percent in 2003.

headline: Drexel Reorganization Plan Accepted by Most Creditors
abstract: The likelihood that Drexel Burnham Lambert would emerge from bankruptcy as an operating company grew stronger yesterday, as all but one of the groups of creditors and equity holders in the case accepted an outline for the firm's reorganization.   By moving the plan forward, Drexel's creditors and equity holders averted a threat by Federal Judge Milton Pollack that he would have put the company into liquidation if substantial progress in the negotiations had not been made at yesterday's hearing.

headline: Canada Bankruptcies Up
abstract: The number of bankruptcies in Canada soared 77 percent in April from a year earlier, the Government has reported. It said last week that bankruptcies rose to 6,671 in April, from 3,765 a year earlier, and that the number of business failures was the highest since Canada's recession began a year ago.

headline: Macy Edges Away From Abyss
abstract: Success is a relative thing, and nowhere is that clearer than at R. H. Macy & Company, the huge retailer, where the financial picture is finally starting to look brighter after more than two years of severe problems.    Once Macy measured success in rising market share and innovative retailing concepts. Now, hobbled by debts and recession and reduced to seeking permission from bankers for moves that its merchants once would have made on their own, Macy measures its success simply in survival short of bankruptcy.

headline: Druse Give Up Ammunition
abstract: Warriors of the Progressive Socialist Party, one of Lebanon's main militias, gave up their firepower today by handing over 300 tons of ammunition to Syrian troops in the mountains southeast of here. Druse fighters delivered 50 trucks loaded with artillery shells, Soviet-built Katyusha rockets and machine-gun cartridges to Syrian officers at two towns in the Shuf mountains, the party's radio station reported.

headline: Singapore Airlines Orders 4 Airbuses
abstract: Singapore Airlines Ltd. said it had placed orders for four more Airbus Industrie A310-300 aircraft worth $347 million, including spare parts and spare engines. The planes, two firm orders and two options, are scheduled for delivery in 1993 and 1994, the airline said in a statement. The Airbuses will be powered by the United Technologies Corporation's Pratt & Whitney PW4152 jet engines, the same engines that are used on the current A310-300 fleet, Singapore Airlines said.

headline: Making a Difference; Going to Bat For Aerospace
abstract: As the owner of a small military subcontractor scrambling to win new business at a time of declining Pentagon spending, Ronald L. Cedillos is angry about how California's elected officials are responding to the challenges facing the state's huge aerospace industry. Last week, Mr. Cedillos, who runs the Cedillos Testing Company of Long Beach, took a big step in organizing what he thinks could be a blistering political response.   Mr. Cedillos, a major contributor to the Republican Party, helped set up a meeting between Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican, and the heads of most of the state's major contractors, including Kent Kresa of Northrop and Daniel M. Tellep of Lockheed.

headline: Mobil Gas Find
abstract: The Mobil Oil Corporation said it had found natural gas in the North Sea about five miles north of an area where the company discovered gas five years ago. Mobil North Sea Ltd., a unit of the Fairfax-based oil company, said the well opened up a new area for development. Mobil North Sea Ltd. supplies natural gas to Britain through an affiliate company, Mobil Gas Marketing Ltd.

headline: S.& L.'s Backed on Tax Issue
abstract: The Supreme Court rejected an Internal Revenue Service position today and ruled that savings and loan institutions can create paper losses for Federal income tax purposes by swapping portfolios of low-value mortgages with other institutions.   Lower Federal courts had disagreed with one another over whether the popular tax-saving practice, known as "reciprocal sales," was valid. The Supreme Court resolved the issue today in two 7-to-2 decisions, both written by Justice Thurgood Marshall, involving savings and loan associations in Ohio and Texas.

headline: ALGERIAN PREMIER FAVORS VOTE SOON
abstract: Algeria's new Prime Minister, Sid Ahmed Ghozali, has told close associates and potential ministerial appointees that he intends to pick a Cabinet of "independent personalities" who are not tied to political parties and will see to it that Algeria holds free parliamentary elections before the end of the year, Algerian officials say.    These comments and Mr. Ghozali's meetings with Algerian technical experts suggest that he may end up choosing a Cabinet that is fundamentally independent from the ruling National Liberation Front, which has governed Algeria since independence from France in 1962, Algerian officials and Algerian affairs experts say.

headline: Routine Replaces Disorder at Turkey's Camps
abstract: In an improvised incubator slapped together from a cardboard box, some plastic sheeting and a blanket, Sahat Mahudi, 2 days old and purple in the cold, fights for life.    Just yards away, other Iraqi refugee children splash one another in a polluted stream, lug cases of water and food from trucks to distribution areas and hurry with glee to feel the rush of wind beside medevac helicopters as they take off.

headline: Ambassador to U.S. Warns Israel That New Settlements Imperil Aid
abstract: The Israeli Ambassador to Washington warned his Government today that it would have to choose between building more settlement housing in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip or receiving additional United States aid for the resettlement of Soviet Jews.    "Sometimes there are moments when governments must face issues and take hard decisions one way or another," Ambassador Zalman Shoval said in a radio interview here. "The Israeli Government, when it has all the data in hand, will have to decide if it prefers settlements or aid."

headline: Associates Corp. Yield at 8.713%
abstract: The Associates Corporation of North America yesterday priced $300 million in notes, due in 1997, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.   The notes of the Ford Motor Company subsidiary have an 8 5/8 percent coupon and are priced at 99.591 to yield 8.713 percent, or about 66 basis points more than both the Treasury five-year and seven-year notes combined. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

headline: Japanese Volcano Erupts Again and Scientists Fear Worse to Come
abstract: With a powerful midnight explosion that hurled stones more than three miles, a Japanese volcano erupted today for the second time in nine days, and scientists warned that a new and far more dangerous blast was in prospect.   The second eruption of Mount Unzen, near Shimabara in southwestern Japan, smashed windows and roof tiles but was not reported to have caused any injuries. But scientists said their instruments had detected a swelling of the volcano, indicating a buildup of pressure within the 4,450-foot peak, and counted 18 tremors near the mountain today.

headline: Former F.C.C. Chief Named Time Warner Unit's Head
abstract: Time Warner Inc. yesterday named Dennis R. Patrick, a former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, to be chief executive of a newly created subsidary, Time Warner Telecommunications.    The company said the subsidiary would identify and develop new technologies and focus on the use of the radio spectrum in various mobile communications applications. A top priority will be increasing Time Warner's role in the Personal Communications Networks business. The networks, known as P.C.N.'s, are a form of small, lightweight handsets based on a technology that allows many more users on a system at a lower cost than existing systems. Has Experimental Licenses     There are a variety of ways to enter the personal network business, and some cable companies, including Tele-Communications Inc., have already become involved with it through alliances with cellular telephone companies. In March, Time Warner was awarded experimental licenses to try different band widths in several cities as it develops its own personal communications networks.

headline: Sony Profits Are Up 13.7%
abstract: The Sony Corporation said today that its net income rose 13.7 percent for the year on a 25 percent increase in sales.   The electronics and entertainment company said it earned 116.9 billion yen, or $850 million, in the fiscal year ended March 31, compared with 102.8 billion yen in the previous year.

headline: High Hopes At Microsoft For Product
abstract: More than 60 million computers now use the DOS software developed by the Microsoft Corporation, and when the nation's largest software company introduces a new version on Tuesday, it expects many customers to welcome the chance to improve their computing.    DOS is an operating system -- the software that controls the basic operations of a personal computer and allows it to work with other software that perform specific functions, known as applications software.

headline: Hachette Sets Publisher For Elle Decor Magazine
abstract: Elle Decor magazine and Home magazine will share the same publisher and advertising staff, Hachette Magazines announced yesterday. The company named John J. Miller, the publisher of Home, as publisher of Elle Decor as well, succeeding Polly Perkins, who resigned. She will remain a consultant to the company.   "I launched this magazine two years ago and I had different ideas about a long-term strategy than Hachette," Ms. Perkins said.

headline: BAKER CITES ISRAEL FOR SETTLEMENTS
abstract: In an unusually blunt criticism of the Israeli Government, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that nothing has more complicated his efforts to convene Middle East peace talks than Israel's continuing settlement building in the occupied territories.   Mr. Baker's declaration marked something of a shift in stated American policy on this issue by singling out Israeli settlement building. It was prompted, the Secretary said, by his four trips to the region in the last two months, during which the Israeli Government initiated or expanded Jewish settlements on each trip, antagonizing Arab leaders and making it more difficult for them to show flexibility.

headline: FORUM; Yes to a National Health Care Plan
abstract: As health care reform heats up in Congress, key lawmakers who privately favor national health insurance based on the Canadian model have decided instead to try to expand the current employment-based system of medical coverage. The United States, they say, "just isn't ready" to replace private insurance benefits with a universal tax-supported insurance plan.  That's simply not true.

headline: Despite Rights Issue, Chinese Hope U.S. Trade Status Stays
abstract: As a battle looms in Washington over whether to end normal trade relations with China, many Chinese are finding themselves reluctantly siding with their hard-line rulers in hoping that the status is maintained.   While they appreciate the concern for human rights in their country and hope that the debate will force the Government to become less repressive, some worry that a cutoff of so-called most-favored-nation status would hurt their standard of living, harm the most reformist segments of the economy and prompt the hard-liners to restrict contacts with the United States.

headline: Judge Convicts Winnie Mandela As Accessory in Assault on Youths
abstract: After a trial lasting 14 weeks, Winnie Mandela, wife of the African National Congress leader, Nelson Mandela, was found guilty in a Johannesburg court today of kidnapping four youths who were taken to her home late in 1988 and severely beaten.    But Mrs. Mandela escaped conviction for assault with intent to commit grievous bodily harm. The presiding judge, Michael S. Stegmann, said prosecutors had not discredited Mrs. Mandela's alibi, in which she said that she was 200 miles away when the assaults took place. She was convicted of the less serious charge of accessory after the fact to the assaults.  Lengthy Verdict     Justice Stegmann, who is described by lawyers who know him as a scrupulous jurist without evident political bias, delivered a detailed verdict that took him six and a half hours to read. He variously described Mrs. Mandela's testimony as vague, evasive, equivocal, inconsistent, unconvincing and brazenly untruthful.

headline: Exxon Project Finds Deep-Water Reserves
abstract: The Exxon Corporation said today that it had made a potentially large oil and gas discovery in the Gulf of Mexico. Conoco Inc., a Du Pont subsidiary, holds a 50 percent interest in the project.    Exxon said, however, that tapping the find would require an underwater well about four times as deep as any current Exxon operation. The field is under 4,350 feet of water, while the deepest wells now in production in the gulf are at 1,000 and 1,200 feet. said Henry Beathard, an Exxon Company U.S.A. spokesman.

headline: Honeymoon Sours for Haiti President
abstract: When the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide was elected President by an overwhelming margin in December, crowds of jubilant Haitians filled the air with cries proclaiming their country's rebirth.   But a couple of months into Father Aristide's presidency, the optimism has begun to give way to a realization that Haiti's road to economic and political revival is thickly strewn with obstacles, and many wonder whether the new Government has the ability to surmount them.

headline: Towns Under Siege As Lebanon Militias Trade Fire In South
abstract: Christian and Muslim towns in southern Lebanon came under attack today for the second straight day as rival militias traded artillery fire.   Security officials said shells and rockets crashed into Jezzin, the largest population center in the south, and the predominantly Sunni Muslim port of Sidon some five miles to the west. Three people were wounded in Sidon and two in Jezzin.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday  None

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Greenstone Roberts Inc., Melville, L.I., has acquired the MacKenzie Group, an Orlando, Fla., ad agency. Greenstone Roberts said the purchase would add billings of about $8 million. Clients brought in by the acquisition include Sundor Brands Inc., a subsidiary of Procter & Gamble Co., and the Daytona Beach Hilton Hotel.

headline: The Creature That Lives in Pittsburgh
abstract: The last few months have been heady ones for William L. Whittaker, the Carnegie-Mellon University professor considered one the nation's foremost robot designers. First came the demonstration for Government officials of the Ambler, Dr. Whittaker's 19-foot tall, six-legged robot designed to explore Mars someday. In a rock garden on the Carnegie-Mellon campus here, Ambler stepped over high boulders and avoided holes, a formidable achievement for a robot. "It was one of those holy moments," said Dr. Whittaker, 42, a former Marine whose friends call him Red. "It was mystical to see the Ambler get up and go. My heart was in my throat."   Then one afternoon a few weeks later, in a less formal demonstration, Dr. Whittaker and his colleagues took a van crammed with electronics out onto Pittsburgh's streets. While a human driver controlled the vehicle, a computer and a laser vision system in the back "watched" the van follow the white lines up and down streets. Then the driver let go of the steering wheel and the computer took over, flawlessly steering the van down the street, staying in its own lane. This, too, was a significant accomplishment for a robot, since tasks seemingly as simple as guiding a vehicle down a straight line have long confounded machines built to mimic the most elementary actions of humans. "At that point, there was nothing to do but break out the beer and celebrate," Dr. Whittaker said.

headline: Tokyo Election Defeat Stuns Japan's Governing Party
abstract: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's Government was badly jolted today by the lopsided defeat of the ruling party's candidate for Governor of Tokyo, forcing the resignation of the party's chief political operative.    The resignation of the official, Ichiro Ozawa, secretary general of the Liberal Democratic Party, was widely seen as an embarrassment for Japan, since it discredited Mr. Ozawa within a month after he met with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Moscow and President Bush in Washington as a representative of the Government.

headline: Toyota to Sell Cars in Israel, Officials Say
abstract: The Toyota Motor Corporation is expected to announce that it will begin selling cars in Israel despite the continuing Arab economic boycott of that country, officials of the Japanese auto maker said today.    For the last two years, Toyota officials say, they hve been under mounting pressure from Jewish organizations in the United States to begin sales operations in Israel. The pressure has taken the form of letters to Toyota and to newspapers but has not involved any threats of a boycott, according to the officials.

headline: Time Warner In Sales Shift
abstract: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it was revamping the sales staffs of its magazines by creating four regional managers who will be responsible for all Time Warner magazines in their respective markets.   Sales executives at Time Warner's individual magazines will now report to one of these four corporate regional sales managers: in the past, they had reported to the heads of individual magazines.

headline: U.N., Near Cease-Fire Deal, Sets Aside Rebels' Plight
abstract: The Security Council moved closer today to a resolution setting terms for a permanent cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war, and it temporarily set aside calls by France and Turkey for action to halt Iraq's suppression of Kurdish and Shiite Muslim rebellions.    The plight of the Shiites and the Kurds has gained urgency in recent days as forces loyal to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq have put down their twin uprisings in southern and northern Iraq, sending tens of thousands of refugees into Iran, Turkey and allied-occupied Iraq.

headline: 7 Industrial Nations Plan Meeting On Soviet Aid and Rise of Dollar
abstract: The Finance Ministers and central bank presidents of the Group of Seven industrial democracies are hastily trying to arrange a meeting for this weekend, perhaps in New York, to discuss aid to the Soviet Union and what to do about the sharply rising American dollar.   A Treasury Department spokeswoman said yesterday afternoon that "active discussions" concerning such a meeting were under way, but that a final decision had not been made. The issue was not whether to hold the meeting -- that has already been decided, by all accounts -- but whether the session can be scheduled on short notice.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   10.00        DISCOUNT RATE   5.50   5.50   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.79   5.89   8.18        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.42   5.41   7.75        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.58   5.59   7.74        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   7.93   7.99   8.77        30-YR. TREAS. headline: 2-Part Offering By Fannie Mae
abstract: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, priced a two-part bond offering yesterday totaling $1.3 billion through various securities dealers.    Fannie Mae said it had priced $700 million in 8 percent callable debentures due April 10, 1996, at 99.9375 to yield 8.015 percent, or about 30 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The $600 milllion in 8 5/8 percent callable debentures due April 10, 2001, were priced at 99.875 to yield 8.644 percent, or about 60 basis points more than Treasuries. Interest payment for both debenture issues begin Oct. 10, 1991.

headline: Georgia Issuing Revenue Bonds
abstract: The Georgia State Tollway Authority issued $97.5 million in guaranteed revenue bonds through competitive bidding won by a group of underwriters led by Dean Witter Reynolds.    Yields on the tax-exempt issue range from 5.45 percent for a bond due in 1995 to 6.25 percent in 2001, 6.75 percent in 2006, 6.9 percent in 2009 and 6.95 percent in 2010 and 2011.   Underwriters said the debt offering had been rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service and AA+ by Standard & Poor's.

headline: Making a Difference; A Turnaround for Mr. Tellep
abstract: A year ago, Daniel M. Tellep, the chairman and chief executive of the Lockheed Corporation, was a man under siege. Lockheed's earnings were being battered by losses on weapons development programs and Harold Simmons, the Dallas investor, was waging a bitter proxy fight to unseat the board.    But now Mr. Tellep is on a roll. Lockheed's earnings have rebounded. Mr. Simmons has given up his attempts to gain control. And last week a team led by Lockheed won the biggest prize of the decade in the weapons business, the contract to build the F-22, a new generation of Air Force fighter plane. (Forum, page 11.)

headline: New View Of Ethiopia
abstract: The United States became the midwife at the birth of a new leadership in Ethiopia and presided over the death of the old because two unrelated issues grabbed Washington's interest: the exit of Ethiopia's Jews to Israel and the desire to avoid another humanitarian disaster like the flight of the Kurds, Bush Administration officials said.    To achieve those two goals, the United States, according to participants in the process, had a hand in removing from power Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, the Marxist dictator who managed to turn one of Africa's potentially most productive countries into one of its poorest.

headline: Mycogen Obtains E.P.A. Approval
abstract: The Mycogen Corporation, an agricultural biotechnology company based in San Diego, said it had received the first approval ever from the Environmental Protection Agency for a new class of genetically engineered microbial pesticides. Mycogen's two pesticide products, MVP and M-Trak, encapsulate proteins that are produced by naturally occurring bacteria and are toxic to insects.

headline: Police Raid Hostels in Effort to Halt South African Chaos
abstract: The police raided workers' hostels and squatter camps today in an effort to halt chronic violence that has killed more than 100 people in a week.   Officials said the raids were at the request of the African National Congress, which has set a deadline of Thursday for Government action on halting the carnage in black townships.   Most of the township fighting, which has killed more than 600 people this year, pits supporters of the congress against rivals from the Zulu-dominated Inkatha Freedom Party. Both groups oppose apartheid but differ on the policies of a future nonracial South Africa.

headline: Cambodia's Voiceless - A special report.; No Haven From Agony for Cambodians
abstract: There is a Cambodian proverb that neatly sums up the life of Say Nom and her husband, Chel Chim, and the circumstances of their country, after more than 20 years of superpower intervention, immeasurable brutality, invasion and civil war.   "In the river, there is the crocodile," the Cambodians say. "On the river bank, there is the tiger. If you go to the forest, there are the thorns. If you go to the market, there is the policeman."

headline: Businessland Expected to Post Loss
abstract: Businessland Inc. is expected to report another huge loss this week that could deepen the computer retailer's financial woes, industry analysts and company executives say.    Analysts had been expecting Businessland, which runs the largest chain of company-owned computer stores, to report a loss of $6 million to $10 million for its third quarter, which ended on March 31.

headline: Executive to Oversee 2 Columbia Studios
abstract: Jonathan Dolgen, who is president of the theatrical division of Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., has been named president of a newly formed motion picture group at the company. The new division encompasses Columbia Pictures Entertainment's two motion picture studios, Columbia Pictures and Tri-Star Pictures Inc.    Under the new structure, Mr. Dolgen will work with Frank Price, the chairman of Columbia Pictures, and Michael Medavoy, the Tri-Star Pictures chairman. Mr. Dolgen will report to Alan J. Levine, president and chief operating officer of Columbia Pictures Entertainment's filmed entertainment group, creating another layer of management.

headline: Tokyo Stocks Advance
abstract: Stocks were higher in Tokyo today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 244.6 points, or 0.94 percent, to close at 26,252.

headline: LTV Puts Past Glory On Block
abstract: The LTV Corporation, which had long insisted it would not sell its once-renowned aircraft and military electronics operations, said today that it was putting those glamour assets on the block to help meet future pension obligations.   The decision to sell the division that has built combat planes since shortly after World War I raised fresh anxieties for the aircraft unit's 16,100 employees. It also underscored the high price LTV must pay to make good on pledges made more than 10 years ago to pay income and health benefits to its current and future retirees.

headline: A Big Letdown From the Clios
abstract: Not just the longtime professionals of the advertising industry were affected by the abrupt cancellation of the Clio Awards ceremony on Monday.   Three students from Portland State University in Oregon -- the winners of the first Citibank/Clio College Advertising Awards -- had been brought to New York to attend the ceremony, which was called off because of financial and organizational problems at Clio Awards Inc.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Overall automobile advertising on national and regional television increased 13 percent, to $3.21 billion, in 1990, according to figures from the Television Bureau of Advertising Inc. Eight of the top 10 auto companies increased their spending on television advertising in 1990, the bureau said.

headline: Arms Talks: A Warm-Up
abstract: Although the Soviet and American Foreign Ministers have been meeting almost weekly to try to tie up long-delayed arms control agreements, the real focus of relations between Moscow and Washington has radically shifted to economics and the question of how the West can help transform Soviet society.   Don't be fooled by the recent attention that Washington and Moscow have been paying to arms control, both Soviet and American officials say. They are the wave of the past. The reason for the recent burst of arms control activity is that the Soviets are eager to get the conventional and nuclear agreements out of the way -- because Washington has made this a condition for a summit meeting that would focus primarily on economic help -- and Washington is eager to exploit Moscow's vulnerability.

headline: UAL's Denver Plan
abstract: The UAL Corporation's United Airlines unit said it intended to move its Denver operations to the new Denver International Airport, set to open in 1993, where United would occupy up to 45 gates. United also said it would locate a 2,000-employee regional reservations center at a new business development site at the current Denver airport, Stapleton International.

headline: Iraq Asserts It Has Retaken 3 Vital Towns From Kurds
abstract: Challenged by the most intense and widespread uprising in Iraq's modern history, Baghdad asserted today that the worst of the revolt was over, saying loyalist forces had retaken three important towns in the Kurdish north, including the oil town of Kirkuk.    The official Iraqi press agency said Government forces had also driven Kurdish rebels from the northern towns of Dohuk and Erbil. Kurdish dissidents based in Damascus reported sustained attacks in the Iraqi towns by Government warplanes, helicopter gunships and artillery. Erbil is the administrative center of Iraq's Kurdish north.

headline: OPEC Raises Bank Deposits
abstract: With higher profits from the war-related surge in crude prices, Middle East oil- exporting countries increased their bank deposits in the West by a record $21.5 billion in the last quarter of 1990, according to a survey released today.   But the Persian Gulf crisis and weaker economies in many countries slowed the overall pace of international banking for the last three months of 1990, said a report by the Bank for International Settlements.    The report on banks in 17 major Western industrialized countries and several offshore banking centers showed that Persian Gulf OPEC members initially drew down their Western accounts after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait.

headline: An American Wrestles With a Troubled Future
abstract: For the McDonald's Corporation whose name, golden arches and Big Mac are American icons -- a reckoning is at hand.    For two years, maybe more, McDonald's restaurants in the United States have been struggling to prevent a decline in their business from snowballing.

headline: U.N. Begins Inspection of Iraqi Atom Plants
abstract: United Nations experts began inspecting Iraq's nuclear installations today under Persian Gulf war cease-fire terms requiring destruction of Baghdad's most lethal weapons.   The 34-member team from the International Atomic Energy Agency is the first of several disarmament groups scheduled to examine Iraq's nuclear stocks for military potential, remove or destroy chemical weapons and long-range missiles and search for any biological weapons.

headline: World Markets; Hugo Boss: a Fading Status Symbol
abstract: Hugo Boss A.G. was one of the brightest stars on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange in the late 1980's, both as a stock and as producer of the designer fashions sported by status-conscious brokers, bankers and young executives. In a country where knickers, knee socks and dull green loden coats abound, a Boss suit was a declaration of sophistication and success.   The Boss look -- a combination of traditional cuts and vibrant colors -- also caught on with upwardly mobile professionals around the world. In the last six years, sales grew an average of 25 percent annually and earnings rose an average of 19 percent. Securities analysts were almost unanimous in issuing buy recommendations on Hugo Boss, which was founded near Stuttgart by two hard-driving brothers, Jochen and Uwe Holy, who named it after their grandfather.

headline: Tokyo Stocks Gain a Bit
abstract: Stock prices closed higher today in Japan. At the close of the afternoon trading session, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks was up 117.77 points, or about four-tenths of a percent, to 26,813.30.

headline: Time Warner Is Reported To Weigh a Stock Offering
abstract: The board of Time Warner Inc. met last night to vote on a proposal to raise $3 billion in equity through a highly complex rights offering to existing shareholders. The plan would involve as many as 30 million new shares of Time Warner, several executives close to the talks said.   No one at the company could be reached to comment on the meeting or its outcome last evening. But certainly, the plan represents a big shift in strategy at Time Warner, which for months had hoped to attract foreign investors.

headline: Graft Takes the Gloss Off Mexican Drug Haul
abstract: Stressing its commitment to combat drug trafficking, the Mexican Government announced this week that it had intercepted a Colombian aircraft carrying more than five tons of cocaine, worth up to $100 million on wholesale markets. But praise for that achievement was quickly muted by the news that no suspects were apprehended and that the flight was protected at its destination by corrupt officials of the Government's own Federal Highway Police.    The drug seizure, carried out on Saturday at an airstrip in the southern Mexican state of Chiapas, ranks as one of the largest in a growing series of Government anti-narcotics operations that have netted more than 12 tons of cocaine in the last 30 days alone.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * The Dial Corporation's Breck hair-care line to Rosenfeld, Sirowitz, Humphrey & Strauss, New York, to reintroduce the Breck brands in advertising later this year. While neither Dial nor the agency would discuss billings, campaigns to restage hair-care products typically cost $8 million to $15 million a year. Dial said that under Breck's previous owner, the American Cyanamid Corporation, the Breck account was assigned to KCS&A Inc., New York. * Swarovski Jewelry U.S. Ltd., New York, a subsidiary of Daniel Swarovski Co., a manufacturer of crystal stones, to McCabe & Co., New York for the Swarovski and Savy lines of jewelry. The Swarovski company said the assignment was for a $4 million print campaign. The company said its incumbent agency was Connell, May & Stevenson Ltd., London.

headline: JOBLESS RATE FELL TO 6.6% IN APRIL, REVERSING A TREND
abstract: The Labor Department reported today that payroll jobs fell in April but at a much reduced pace and that the unemployment rate edged down two-tenths of a point, to 6.6 percent. The figures point over all to an economy that while probably not yet starting to recover from recession seems to be approaching its low point, analysts said.    They cautioned, however, that the decline in the unemployment rate, the first in almost a year, was probably an aberration.

headline: A.T.& T.-NCR Talks
abstract: In their first joint statement since the American Telephone and Telegraph Company began its pursuit of the NCR Corporation five months ago, the companies announced last night that "discussions are continuing and that progress is being made toward reaching an agreement." The companies added that there was "no assurance that any agreement will be reached." Traders and analysts said NCR's board met over the weekend in New York to review A.T.& T.'s $7.48 billion offer for NCR. The companies declined to comment.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt * Michigan State Hospital Finance Authority is offering $449 million in tax-exempt hospital revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.65 percent. Yields on shorter-maturity serial bonds range from 6.25 percent in 1995 to 7.25 percent in 2001. The issue is rated A by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corp,

headline: Few Minority Companies Get Contracts in Savings Bailout
abstract: A two-year-old law intended to encourage the involvement of minority-owned concerns in managing assets seized from failed savings and loans appears to be having little effect. Internal Government documents show that Federal contracts to manage everything from multimillion-dollar loan portfolios to small apartment buildings have gone almost entirely to companies owned by whites.   Of the 126 contracts issued by the Resolution Trust Corporation, just 2 have been awarded to black-owned companies and 3 to Hispanic-owned companies, according to the documents. The agency, which supervises the bailout, has issued contracts to manage more than $26 billion in assets from hundreds of collapsed savings associations.

headline: 6 Greek Police Officers Hurt As Bomb Explodes in Athens
abstract: Six Greek police officers were wounded when a time bomb exploded here at dawn today.    The officers were on patrol, and a Government spokesman said it was not clear if they were the intended targets of the bomb, which went off near the Athens headquarters of the Greek Communist Party. The police speculated that the explosion might have been aimed at the party, which is facing a major internal dispute.

headline: Comptroller to Put Holdings in Trust
abstract: Robert L. Clarke, one of the nation's senior banking regulators, said today that he would place his investments in a blind trust in an effort to "lay to rest" questions about his financial affairs.   Mr. Clarke, the Comptroller of the Currency, has been at the center of a political controversy since disclosures last month that he had been making regular investments in stocks and "junk bonds," occasionally financed by borrowing from banks. No evidence has appeared that the trading was based on improper inside information or that he violated regulations or favored any of the 4,000 nationally chartered banks that his office regulates. Regular Investments    For five years, Mr. Clarke has regularly disclosed the investments and loans in publicly available documents. But his most recent disclosure last month, coming as he is up for nomination to another five-year term, was seized by critics on Capitol Hill who said he was insensitive to the appearance of impropriety. His trading and loans are also being investigated by the Treasury Department and the Office of Government Ethics, which may issue rulings next week.

headline: F.D.I.C. to Get $49.5 Million From Silverado Settlement
abstract: Federal regulators agreed in principle on Wednesday to a $49.5 million settlement in their $200 million lawsuit against Neil Bush and 12 other former directors of Denver's defunct Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association.   It was not disclosed what portion of the settlement, if any, Mr. Bush, the President's son, will be liable for. Details of the agreement are to be made public on Friday afternoon in Denver, according to a two-page order issued late Wednesday by the chief judge of the Federal District Court for Colorado, Sherman Finesilver.

headline: Talking Deals; Larger Mergers Delayed by War
abstract: THE economies in the United States and Britain were slumping, Saddam Hussein had invaded Kuwait and President Bush was building an international coalition to oppose the Iraqi leader. But the business of buying or merging companies apparently went on almost as usual late last year, except that some big deals seemed to fall by the wayside.   But when the Persian Gulf war began in January, activity plunged. By then the United States and Britain were in recession, and European economies were beginning to slide as well. Banks were still tight with loans, and executives were not traveling to make deals or look for them.

headline: Market Place; New Amex Rule On Super Classes
abstract: THE American Stock Exchange adopted rules yesterday that will make it easier for companies listed on that exchange to issue super-voting shares, which provide disproportionate voting powers to their holders.   The move could send the issue of shareholder voting back to Congress, something that most of Wall Street hope to avoid. But it also could give the Amex a competitive advantage in getting companies to list their stocks on it, rather than on the New York Stock Exchange or the National Association of Securities Dealers' National Market System.

headline: Honda Option: Tokyo Parking
abstract: The Honda Motor Company has a gimmick that it hopes will bolster car sales in congested, parking-scarce Tokyo.   The company said on Tuesday that it had formed a joint venture with Ishikawajima- Harima Heavy Industries to manage parking lots and to help potential Honda owners locate spaces.

headline: Kuwait Says Martial Law Ends Today
abstract: The Justice Minister said today that martial law in Kuwait will end on Wednesday. His announcement ended speculation that the rule by martial law imposed at the end of the Persian Gulf war might be temporarily extended again, as it was a month ago.   With the expiration of martial law, further trials of defendants charged with collaborating with Iraq during its occupation of Kuwait will move to regular civil courts. But beyond that, the change is expected to have little immediate effect on how Kuwait's royal family rules the emirate.

headline: Apple May Expand Its Copyright Suit
abstract: A Federal District Court judge granted Apple Computer Inc.'s request to add two software packages to the list of products that Apple contends infringe the copyrights for the company's Macintosh personal computer. The additional products in Apple's three-year-old copyright suit are Windows 3.0 by the Microsoft Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company's New Wave 3.0. The suit had applied to Windows 2.03 and New Wave.

headline: Occidental Selling Half Of Gas Unit
abstract: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell a half interest in its natural gas liquids business to a Texas investment company in a two-step deal for $600 million.    The deal marked the first big sale by Occidental under a new strategy of paring back to its core oil and chemical businesses and using the proceeds to reduce its debt. The new strategy was started after the death last year of Dr. Armand Hammer, who in more than three decades as Occidental's chairman had led the company into a variety of non-oil businesses, including meatpacking and horse breeding.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   10.00        DISCOUNT RATE   5.50   5.50   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.72   5.82   8.25        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.57   5.62   7.76        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.76   5.80   7.66        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.17   8.18   8.57        30-YR. TREAS. headline: 100 Years of Encyclicals: Church and Capitalism
abstract: 1891: "Rerum Novarum" ("Of New Things," often given the English title, "On the Condition of Workers"). Increasing class conflict, the emergence of a revolutionary socialist movement and appeals from groups of Catholic workers and thinkers moved Pope Leo XIII to write this document. The encyclical defended private property, attacked socialism and reflected a medieval ideal of a static society where rich and poor carried out mutual duties. But Pope Leo also condemned the "inhumanity of employers and unbridled greed of competitors" and "the yoke almost of slavery" laid on "unnumbered masses" of propertyless workers. He called for government regulation of working hours and conditions, and his endorsement of the right of workers to form their own associations was a charter for Catholics to support the labor movement.    1931: "Quadragesimo Anno" ("In the Fortieth Year," usually given the English title "On Reconstructing the Social Order"). Pope Pius IX marked the anniversary of "Rerum Novarum" with an equally impassioned condemnation of the concentrated power of capitalist owners and an equally complete rejection of socialism. The encyclical recommended the establishment of associations or councils bringing management and labor together. Although similar proposals were made under liberal auspices, fascist leaders in Italy, Austria, Portugal and elsewhere claimed papal approval for the structures they used to bring the economy under state coordination.

headline: Scandal Over Cheating At M.I.T. Stirs Debate On Limits of Teamwork
abstract: The largest cheating scandal in the history of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has touched off a campuswide debate over how far collaborative work on scientific projects can go before it crosses the line into cheating.    The scandal, in an entry-level computer programming course, resulted in 73 students being disciplined this spring. It has shocked much of the faculty to discover that so many high-caliber students would feel compelled to cheat. But many M.I.T. students say they are not surprised, given the heavy workload and the competitive pressures.

headline: Bid Made For Healthnet
abstract: An investment firm offered $200 million today to acquire Healthnet, a California not-for-profit health maintenance organization. The California Department of Corporations is already considering a $108 million offer from Healthnet's management.   The new offer, from Shamrock Investments, a Los Angeles firm, consists of $40 million in cash and $160 million in notes. Because Healthnet's managers and Shamrock propose converting Healthnet to a profit-making operation, the state agency must approve the transaction. Under California law, the money would go to a public trust. Healthnet's management is offering $15 million in cash and $93 million in notes.

headline: United Asks Anonymity In Frequent-Flier Deal
abstract: American Express's ballyhooed frequent-flier program has hit a snag, at least for United Airlines. One of the country's two largest carriers, United is not officially part of the program and yet it is.   And United is not happy about it.

headline: Monsanto Cutbacks To Cost 2,500 Jobs
abstract: The Monsanto Company said yesterday that it would eliminate about 2,500 jobs, close three plants and take a $325 million after-tax restructuring charge in the second quarter to improve efficiency and earnings.   The company, based in St. Louis, said it hoped to achieve most of the job cuts through a voluntary program that includes early retirement or help in finding other jobs, said Scarlett L. Foster, a Monsanto spokeswoman. She said if not enough people agreed to leave voluntarily then the company would begin making layoffs.

headline: Wall Street; Looking for a Winner as the Railroads Roll Again
abstract: The railroads are rolling again after last week's brief strike. Tough labor issues remain, but that did not deter George O. Zimmermann, a Gruntal & Company analyst, from recommending the Santa Fe Pacific Corporation, owner of the euphonious Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe line.   His chief argument is that there is a lot more to Santa Fe than a railroad -- like abundant low-sulfur coal reserves, substantial gold reserves, real estate assets that are slated for early sale and a profitable refined-petroleum-products pipeline operation. He also expects the rail business to improve this year as the economy recovers, and he is impressed by the company's rapid reduction of the debt from a 1988 restructuring program.

headline: European Bank Aid for Poland
abstract: The first loan offered by the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development will help heating businesses in Poland, the new bank said today.    The bank said its board approved the $50 million loan today.

headline: Goldome Closed and Split Between Rivals
abstract: Goldome, New York State's largest savings institution, will be closed and divided between local competitors -- the First Empire Corporation of Buffalo and Keycorp of Albany, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced yesterday. The troubled Buffalo-based savings bank failed to attract the new investors it needed.    Branches of Goldome will open under their new names either Saturday or Monday with no interruption in service or change in deposit insurance coverage.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; People
abstract: * Jerry Grossman has been promoted to vice president-management supervisor at Ammirati & Puris.

headline: O.E.C.D. Sees Recovery for U.S. in 2d Half
abstract: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a 24-nation group promoting economic growth, forecast today that the United States would lift itself out of recession in the second half of this year and that unemployment would stop climbing during that period.    The Paris-based organization, widely respected for its economic projections, said the American economy would grow at an annual rate of 2.7 percent in the second half, compared with a 1.8 percent drop in output in the first half.

headline: Dollar Loses Momentum
abstract: Last   Prior   Year       Week   Week   Ago              Japanese Yen   136.65   140.50   157.50       per Dollar       German Mark   1.6855   1.6970   1.6955       per Dollar       Canadian Dollar   1.1543   1.1588   1.1647       per U.S. Dollar       British Pound   1.7655   1.7480   1.6390       U.S. Dollar per British Pound       Gold   $359.00   $356.00   $370.25       Republic National Bank       Currency: Friday NY Close

headline: India Refuses Pakistani A-Talks
abstract: India today rejected Pakistan's request for international talks on creating a zone free of nuclear weapons in South Asia.    Reiterating India's position that regional nonproliferation pacts are meaningless, a spokesman for the Ministry of External Affairs said India stood behind its call for a "nuclear-free world."

headline: U.S. Approves Pipeline Plan
abstract: The Government today approved a natural gas development project that will allow six companies to build pipelines to tap a huge supply in southern Alabama.    The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission approved the project, under which 152 miles of onshore and offshore pipeline would be built for about $188.3 million.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Hewlett-Packard Co., Palo Alto, Calif., a computer maker, said it had established a Budapest joint venture for sales and support with Controll, a private Hungarian company. Hewlett also established a sales and support subsidiary in Czechoslovakia. * Kellogg Canada Inc., a unit of Kellogg Co., Battle Creek, Mich., said it had put its Shirriff products and Farm House frozen pie businesses up for sale.

headline: An Opposition Leader Seeks to Reinvent Soviet Agriculture
abstract: The green flourish of spring across the Russian earth is so inviting and the shortage of food in the city so daunting that increasing numbers of desperate urban families are migrating to start patchwork country farms, ignorant as all pioneers.   "We figure there are 20,000 small family farms in Russia right now and by the end of next year there will be 150,000," said Yuri Chernichenko, founder of the new Peasants Party of Russia, who is not at all delighted with such a bumper crop of humans hurrying to the land from their worsening lives in Moscow and other urban centers.

headline: American Express to Try A Pan-European Campaign
abstract: AMERICAN EXPRESS will begin a series of innovative commercials in Europe this month that essentially use the same message to sell its credit cards in five countries.    Many American advertisers have been reluctant to use pan-European campaigns because they have found it difficult to come up with a single message that will not lose its effectiveness in translation or cause confusion among consumers from different cultures.

headline: Kodak Introduces Electronic Camera
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company took its first real step into digital photography by introducing an electronic camera system that can turn a conventional Nikon into a high-tech electronic camera. Kodak's professional digital camera system will sell for about $20,000 and is intended primarily for photojournalists and government surveillance, the company said. The system also marks Kodak's first move into pure electronic photography, where images are captured and created without film.   The system uses a regular Nikon F3 camera body and lenses that are attached to an electronic back. When the photographer shoots a picture, the images are stored on an electronic chip instead of on film. The camera can take 2.5 images a second and can store up to 600 images. Images can be transmitted directly by telephone lines to a computer, without developing or finishing. The camera is being tested by several newspapers, including USA Today.

headline: Corporate Profit Fall Is Slowing
abstract: In the latest sign that the recession may be ending, corporate profits in the first quarter of 1991 fell markedly less than in the two preceding quarters, the Commerce Department said today.   The decline, to an annual rate of $288 billion, was just three-tenths of 1 percent, following declines of 1.9 percent and 3.9 percent, respectively, for last summer and autumn.

headline: Rockwell's Point Man in the Health-Care Campaign
abstract: The bad news comes in a telephone call to Daniel P. Heslin, the employee-benefits director of the Rockwell International Corporation. Doctors attending to an employee report that she has leukemia. They want to do a bone marrow transplant. The cost: more than $100,000. Will Rockwell pay?   Experts at various medical centers tell Rockwell it is customary not to perform such a transplant on people older than 40 because the chances for success are slim. The patient is 50, and she is very weak. Physician reviewers at Rockwell's insurance administrator, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, recommend denying payment. The woman's doctors appeal.

headline: Winnie Mandela Loses Women's League Vote
abstract: Winnie Mandela, the wife of Nelson Mandela, has suffered a major political setback by failing in a bid for the presidency of the African National Congress Women's League.    The league ended a four-day conference today in the Cape Province town of Kimberley by announcing that Gertrude Shope, its president, had been re-elected. Albertina Sisulu, the wife of Walter Sisulu, Mr. Mandela's prison comrade, had also been a contender, but withdrew after several hours of heated discussion that preceded the closed ballot Saturday night.

headline: Trade Talks Get a Lift In Europe
abstract: American and European officials said today that faltering international trade talks received a much-needed impetus last week when Congress extended the Bush Administration's authority to negotiate an agreement and when the European Community said it would reduce farm subsidies slightly.    But whether the momentum is enough to overcome crucial hurdles is far from certain.

headline: Caution in West On Aiding Soviets
abstract: WITH ever-increasing urgency, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is asking the West for tens of billions of dollars to help salvage the Soviet Union's economy. But a troubling theme runs through these requests and the reactions to them in Washington, Bonn and Tokyo. Can the deteriorating Soviet economy absorb so much money without wasting it?    More to the point, Western governments and commercial banks express reluctance to lend even small amounts unless Moscow moves irrevocably to a free-market economy from central planning. William R. Rhodes, a Citicorp senior executive who often represents American banks in foreign debt negotiations, outlines the preconditions.

headline: Ex-S.& L. Chief Granted Relief
abstract: Federal regulators are willing to grant hardship status to the ousted chairman of the Centrust Savings Bank, David L. Paul, on the condition that he stay on a short financial leash, according to court documents obtained on Friday.   Mr. Paul, known for his lavish spending before Centrust was seized by regulators in February 1990 at a loss of $1.7 billion, applied for relief in January, contending that he was unable to pay all his legal bills and other personal and business expenses.

headline: All About/Automobile Testing; The Test Track Is King Of the Road No More
abstract: To the auto makers, a skilled driver sensitive to every nuance of a vehicle's performance is still a valued resource at the proving grounds. But increasingly the leading role in automobile testing is being played by computer experts who generate and interpret data from high-tech wind tunnels, simulators and other stationary testing equipment.   "There's a definite trend toward testing in the laboratory," said Bruce Greene, chief engineer in the Engineering Technology Services group at the Ford Motor Company. "We can have a more controlled environment with more repeatable tests. And it can be done in shorter time."

headline: Honda Faults A U.S. Audit Of Its Imports
abstract: Senior executives of the Honda Motor Company have met with top Treasury officials to express concern about the status of a Government audit suggesting that the company may owe millions of dollars in duties on cars imported into the United States from Canada, lawyers for the auto maker said today.   Donald Harrison, a lawyer for Honda, said the company wanted to make clear to American officials that it was strongly committed to the American market. In addition, he said, Honda protested the disclosure of details of the audit, being conducted by the United States Customs Service.

headline: Hierarchical Management Is Still Around
abstract: To the Editor:   In "Grace Pastiak's 'Web of Influence' " (May 5), you suggest that hierarchical management styles are in decline, perhaps because more women are replacing authoritarian males as executives, or because Japanese-style "participative management" has influenced us. There are reasons to suggest the opposite:

headline: Your Money; New Regulations on Stock Options
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has adopted new rules, effective on Wednesday, that will allow many company officers and board members to realize the benefits of their stock options sooner and with less risk, an important matter to many of these officers.   "This makes stock options much more attractive," said Avery E. Neumark, a partner in Weber, Lipshie & Company in New York and the director of employee benefits and executive compensation at the accounting and consulting firm. "Under the new rules, if my client were a corporate insider, I would feel comfortable negotiating a generous stock option package."

headline: Schwarzkopf to Capitol Hill
abstract: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the commander of allied forces in the Persian Gulf war, will address a joint meeting of the House and Senate to honor him on Wednesday, Congressional leaders said today. General Schwarzkopf, who returned from Saudi Arabia last month, was honored at a ceremony on Sunday in Tampa, Fla., where his Central Command headquarters stands.

headline: Sonesta Hotels Expects Sale Profit
abstract: The Sonesta International Hotels Corporation said it expects to report an after-tax gain of about $19 million, or $6.52 a share, from the sale of the Amsterdam Sonesta Hotel to a group of German investors. The transaction, which is expected to be completed on May 31, calls for Sonesta to receive, after sales expenses, about $47 million in cash and a $5.8 million second-mortgage note, based on current mark-dollar exchange rates.    Sonesta said the $47 million would be used to pay about $16.7 million of debt on the hotel and for taxes on the transaction, other debt retirement and for general corporate purposes. Sonesta also reported a first-quarter loss of $1.8 million, compared with a loss of $937,000 in the same quarter last year. Revenues dropped to $13.2 million, from $14.7 million in the quarter last year. Sonesta shares gained $2.25 each in over-the-counter trading today, closing at $7.75.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * British Sky Broadcasting, London, to McCann-Erickson London, from in-house, with a budget of $42 million. * Gerber Products Co., Fremont, Mich., to Font & Vaamonde, New York, for Hispanic marketing efforts. The budget for the account, previously handled in-house, will exceed $3 million. * Lenbrook Industries, Pickering, Ontario, to Hakuhodo Advertising, New York, for its subsidiary, NAD Electronics, Norwood, Mass., which was handled in-house. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: Treasuries Show Slight Losses
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities dipped in light, trendless trading yesterday as market participants continued to grope for a sense of where the economy is going.    Data released last week seemed to reassure traders that for now an apparent upturn in the economy was not feeding inflationary pressures. Indeed, to some analysts, the increase of five-tenths of 1 percent in industrial production in May provided evidence that growth has not turned positive at all.

headline: To Refugees, a Saudi Town Offers Hope
abstract: Ahmed al-Mansawi had not heard of the plan to send him and 15,000 other Iraqi refugees to a new refugee camp being built in Saudi Arabia. Neither had Maj. Tom Grubbs, an Army civil affairs officer helping run one of the refugee encampments here in southern Iraq.   The two men do not know each other, but they share a similar emotion: moving the refugees to a settlement near the Saudi town of Rahfa is infinitely preferable to the uncertainties of life within reach of Saddam Hussein's police, who will soon have enforcement powers here.

headline: GULF WAR AFFECTS FATE OF HOSTAGES
abstract: The invasion of Kuwait and war that followed created opportunities and obstacles for the release of Western hostages still held in Lebanon, Administration officials and independent experts on international terrorism say.   But despite the positive signals, unfulfilled demands of the captors continue to block any release of the 12 Western hostages, including six Americans, held by the Shiite Muslim Party of God, an Iranian-backed organization believed to be the umbrella group for the kidnappers.

headline: Eljer Industries
abstract: Eljer Industries said its board voted to accept an invitation from Hanson P.L.C.'s Jacuzzi Inc. unit to discuss Jacuzzi's offer of $20 a share, or $145 million, for Eljer. Eljer also said it would appeal a recent Federal court ruling against the company in a liability suit involving problems with a plastic plumbing system manufactured by Eljer's United States Brass Corporation unit. Dozens of such suits have been filed, and Eljer said it had set aside $12.2 million for claims.

headline: Kuwait Emir Schedules Elections for October 1992
abstract: The Emir of Kuwait declared today that parliamentary elections would be held in October 1992, later than opposition politicians had demanded.   Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah's decree, announced on state radio, said an interim assembly, the National Council, would meet on July 19 for the first time since the invasion by Iraq. The council is likely to consider new election rules that could help determine how open the voting will be next year.
