headline: Brazil's Amazon Basin Becomes Cocaine Highway
abstract: A small airplane loaded with cocaine-refining chemicals crashes and explodes along Brazil's border with Bolivia. Another plane runs out of fuel and lands on a dirt road near Brazil's border with Peru. The police seize chemicals and $858,690 in United States currency.    A plane from Colombia misses a smuggling connection near Brazil's northern border with French Guiana. The pilot mistakenly drops his cargo -- 880 pounds of cocaine -- on an Indian village.

headline: Suspect in Egyptian's Killing Escapes From a Police Van
abstract: A man held in connection with the killing of the Speaker of Egypt's Parliament, Rifaat al-Mahgoub, escaped from a police van on Friday while being driven from one prison to another, Interior Ministry officials said today.   The officials said Safwat Abdel-Ghani and another detainee had broken the door of a van, which had been transporting a group of prisoners to take university examinations, and ran away. The other man was captured, but Mr. Abdel-Ghani escaped.

headline: U.S.S.R. Without 'Socialist' Is Discussed
abstract: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that 9 of the 15 Soviet republics were close to an agreement that would fundamentally change the structure and the formal name of the Soviet Union.   The structural changes would decentralize authority, giving the nation's republics more power and reducing the influence of the Kremlin.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: The AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, priced $350 million in 30-year debentures yesterday through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The financing orginally called for $200 million in debt to be sold, but was raised because of strong investor demand.   The 10 percent debentures, due in 2021, were priced at 99.369 to yield 10.067 percent, about 190 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

headline: Protecting the Secrecy of Faxed Data
abstract: Facsimile machines are so much a part of office life that few people think about them beyond the constant flow of curled up sheets of glossy paper that the machines generate. But think about this, communications industry experts say that most fax machines are as easy to tap as telephones.    "Executives have no idea how sensitive facsimile transmitters are and how easily they can be intercepted," said David Day, executive director of the International Facsimile Association. "Executives have stuck things in fax machines, thinking they are only going to be received at the other end."

headline: American Express Unit Names New President
abstract: James M. Li has been named president of the American Express Company's Consumer Financial Services Group, a division of the company's American Express International unit.    Mr. Li, who was appointed last week, succeeds Steven D. Goldstein, who was named president and chief executive of the American Express Bank on March 1. Mr. Li, 44 years old, will report to Mr. Goldstein, who started the Consumer Financial Services Group in September 1989. The group operates only overseas, providing insurance and savings products primarily to American Express credit card customers in 26 countries.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Health-tex Inc., Greensboro, N.C., a children's wear unit of VF Corp., Wyomissing, Pa., to the Martin Agency, Richmond, from AC&R Advertising, New York. Billings were not disclosed. * Wesley-Jessen, Chicago, manufacturers of contact lenses, to Kobs & Draft Advertising, from Wunderman Worldwide, both New York, for its direct-marketing account. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: Campaign for Luxury Car Polishes Up Diamond Image
abstract: MITSUBISHI, the auto maker whose name means "three diamonds" in Japanese, is leaving no gemstone unturned in image-laden advertising for an important new model.   The ads are for the 1992 Diamante (Spanish for "diamond") being introduced by Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America Inc. The sedan, priced from $22,000 to $28,000, is heading into a market segment more crowded than a millionaire's garage: luxury models aimed at affluent, well-educated buyers.

headline: Japanese Deny 'Dumping'
abstract: Japanese auto makers reacted with surprise and anger today to charges that they were "dumping" mini-vans in the United States.   The Big Three American car makers filed a petition with the Commerce Department and the International Trade Administration on Friday saying that Japanese producers were selling the mini-vans in the United States more cheaply than in Japan.

headline: Bankruptcies On the Rise
abstract: The number of bankruptcies filed in United States courts each year has more than doubled since 1981, with most cases now filed by consumers, the American Bankruptcy Institute said today.    Bankruptcies rose to 782,962 last year, up from 360,329 in 1981, it said, and filings are expected to jump to 810,000 this year and 890,000 next year as the recession and problems in the banking industry take their toll.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: THE A.T.& T.-NCR DEAL    NCR agreed to be acquired by A.T.& T. for $7.4 billion worth of A.T.& T. stock, or $110 a share, after five months of stubborn resistance. A.T.& T. is seeking a solution to its money-losing computer business and a way to expand into new markets.  [ Page A1. ]   The acquisition finally seems to give A.T.& T. the chance for success in the computer business that it has long craved. But rivals are not trembling.  [ D6. ]

headline: Wall Street; A Family's Odd Bid To Cash Out
abstract: The Krieble family of Hartford is a frustrated bunch. Millionaires many times over, the Kriebles are the Rockefellers of the glue business, but they are having trouble getting a premium for their shares of the family business, the Loctite Corporation. And no one except their advisers seems to care.    Loctite, the company that Vernon K. Krieble founded in 1953, has prospered under the managers that his descendants installed six years ago. Today, the company rakes in tens of millions of dollars a year in profits from selling high-performance adhesives and other products to consumers and more important, to industrial users like car companies. Last year, for instance, Loctite earned $67.4 million on sales of $555 million.    And yet, almost inexplicably for the founding family of a superbly run company, six of Mr. Krieble's descendants notified the Securities and Exchange Commission in March that they wanted out. They want their 9.8 percent stake in Loctite sold at a premium over its $115 million market value and will be exploring their options, they warn.   Equally strange, the company's stock has since dropped from around $35 before their filings to $32, a contrary move for a company seemingly in play.    One answer is that the market correctly sees the family's virtual powerlessness to force the company to put itself up for sale. It is not that the company has lots of takeover defenses; it does not. The predicament is entirely of the family's own doing. Six years ago, just after handing the company to Kenneth W. Butterworth, the current chairman and chief executive, the Kriebles sold $87.5 million worth of stock to Henkel, a German chemical company, helping it to accumulate a 26.3 percent stake in Loctite. Family members also gave Henkel the right of first refusal over their remaining holdings, a right that Henkel has made clear it would exercise.    "Potential buyers look at Henkel's sizable position and the probability that Henkel could block an unfriendly bid and say 'We'll pass,' " said Robert Bartels, a chemicals analyst at William Blair & Company, who thinks the Kriebles are "grasping at straws."    Another explanation for the stock's mysterious drop is that the market is wondering what it is the Kriebles and specifically Frederick B. Krieble, the only Krieble still on Loctite's board, know about Loctite's prospects that it has not already figured out.    Certainly, without more information about why the Kriebles are selling, the market can hardly be blamed for its bearish reaction. Especially since some of the Kriebles are getting on in years and there are usually good estate-planning reasons for keeping valuable stock in the family: children are generally not taxed on any capital gains that predate their inheritance.    The family did not return phone calls left last week at their business office in Hartford. Their advisers at the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore and at the investment firm First Boston profess to know little about their motives, other than the proceeds from a sale would obviously help the older members enjoy their old age.   Robert H. Krieble, the son of the founder and Loctite's chairman until 1986, is understood to be bent on using his riches to help spread glasnost in the Soviet Union, although it is not clear how.   What the other relatives plan to do with the money is more of a mystery. Frederick B. Krieble, Robert's son, is a resident of the Turks and Caicos Islands, a tax haven. Helen K. Fusscas, Robert's daughter, is an art dealer in Hartford and the wife of a state representative, James Peter Fusscas.    Sentimentality is apparently not an issue. "It's clearly not a family company anymore," said Joseph Mitchell a lawyer at Reid & Priest. He represents Gladys Krieble Delmas, the civic-minded daughter of Loctite's founder and the only Krieble who is not part of the dissident group -- the dissident dissident, so to speak. And while she would consider selling her 2.4 percent stake for the right price, she apparently sees no reason to pay Cravath or First Boston to hustle the shares.    Another possibility the advisers do not entirely dismiss is that the family may be worried about the recent softening in Loctite's unit sales even while dollar sales have climbed. Mr. Butterworth says he is confident about the company's future, but when pressed said: "Yes, we are in the middle of a recession that's affected 75 percent of the business we do. And so in the recent five or six months, there has been a slowing down of unit sales."    So far, the Kriebles' strategy seems designed to scare the board into thinking that they might get angry and sell their holdings to the first available suitor knowing full well that Henkel would snap up the shares and increase its holdings to 40 percent. Henkel would then be within a whisker of gaining control without having paid a premium for it.    The other option is to seek a buyer who would pay such a fancy price for the company that even Henkel would part with an investment it has described as "a core holding." That might be tough. The past six years' performance suggests that this management knows how to extract value from Loctite's assets as well as anybody.   Certainly, both Henkel and Loctite's management feel confident that Loctite's independent directors can safely ignore the family's threats. "We do not feel forced in any way to take any action," Mr. Butterworth said on Thursday after a board meeting in which the directors discussed the latest threat. "We believe the company is well managed, and nothing they've suggested will offer the shareholders a better deal than what we can offer by just continuing to manage it."    The family cannot count on Wall Street for support either. "This management is doing everything right," said Stuart Pulvirent, a chemicals analyst for Lehman Brothers. "I'm not sure somebody lends all that much to it who comes in from the outside."

headline: How to Pick A Hit Show: Just Guess
abstract: THE fall television season starts in three months, but the handicapping, in the form of ratings projections by advertising agencies, has already been completed.   The early line: no new breakout hits in sight, but a couple of strong candidates for rookie of the year.

headline: Poland Ends Subsidies for Birth Control Pills
abstract: The Polish Government, which finances at least 70 percent of all medicines, has eliminated subsidies for birth control pills, more than tripling their price.   The decision, made in January, was announced this week, just days before the Polish Parliament is scheduled to vote on a bill banning abortion, the country's chief form of birth control.

headline: Bush Signs Bill Cutting Off $55 Million in Aid to Jordan
abstract: President Bush signed a bill today that cuts off United States aid to Jordan but allows him to restore the funds if he feels it would help the Middle East peace process.   The United States' relations with Jordan, a longtime ally, were strained by the Persian Gulf war and the way King Hussein assailed American intentions in the conflict.

headline: U.S., Deeming Policy Outmoded, May Cut Off Aid to Afghan Rebels
abstract: In a growing recognition that an 11-year policy aimed at overthrowing the Soviet-backed Government of Afghanistan is outdated, the Bush Administration has not requested funds for the Afghan rebels in its proposed 1992 budget, senior Administration officials say.    In interviews this week, the officials stressed that the Administration reserved the right to request funds for the program as the budget process continues over the next two months. And Congress can still recommend a continuation of the program on its own.

headline: Omens Amid the Ruins: A Voyage Across Iraq's Tattered Southlands
abstract: In town after town of southern Iraq, places tied by broken bridges and blighted dreams, President Saddam Hussein has reasserted control after revolts in March that threatened his Government.    His soldiers subdue the land from makeshift tented garrisons whose tanks and armor evoke the high and bloody price of revolt. Publicly, there is no murmur of dissent. In the markets, a foreigner's conversation with Iraqis soon draws the attention of silent men who stand nearby to listen and report.

headline: Reebok Rebounds With the Pump
abstract: SINCE Reebok International Ltd. started selling its Pump basketball shoe 18 months ago, the company has shipped four million pairs of the inflatable sneakers. Pump sales alone have reached $500 million, a figure that would make the Pump the fourth-largest athletic shoe company in the United States if it were a separate company.    Using savvy marketing and sports star endorsements, Reebok, No. 2 after Nike in the highly competitive athletic footwear market, is riding the Pump to what industry analysts say is the beginning of a new surge. The company had been stuck on a three-year treadmill after a spectacular rise in the mid-1980's. Profits were basically flat from 1987 to 1990.

headline: Seeing the Light in a Miniature Office
abstract: With neat little desks, five tiny windows and ceilings that are 10 inches high, it looks at first glance like a doll house. But playtime is at a minimum in this elaborate little world.   The Lighting Research Center at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., has created a miniature office to measure the effects of tinted window glazings on office occupants. Full-sized researchers spend their time poking their noses and instruments into this simulated world to assess window tints under various indoor and outdoor lighting conditions.

headline: Small Rise In Outlays Set By Businesses
abstract: American businesses plan to increase spending on plants and equipment 3.2 percent this year, the smallest advance in five years, the Government said today.   The Commerce Department said a survey conducted from January to March found businesses planning to spend $540.9 billion for expansion and modernization amid concerns over the recession and the recent Persian Gulf war.

headline: Goodyear Bets on an Outsider
abstract: On this, his second full day as chairman and chief executive of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, Stanley C. Gault had already called for a complete review of the company's costs, summoned senior executives for a battery of sunrise-to-sundown meetings and started looking at what pieces of the company might be sold.    Mr. Gault, who reinvigorated Rubbermaid Inc. as its chairman in the 1980's, was off to a running start in the formidable challenge of resuscitating Goodyear, the world's second-largest tire maker.

headline: Boeing Reports 2% Increase In First-Quarter Earnings
abstract: The Boeing Company today reported a slight increase in earnings for the first quarter, but it said sales were down, primarily because fewer 747 jumbo jets were delivered than in the period last year.    The results were in line with most analysts' estimates, and on the New York Stock Exchange today, Boeing shares closed at $45.875, down 25 cents.

headline: Lockheed Project With Grumman
abstract: The Grumman Corporation and the Lockheed Corporation said they would market an airborne early warning system that could monitor 148,000 square miles of ocean surface. The companies said the system would use the abilities of Grumman's E-2C Hawkeye on board a C-130 Hercules or a P-3 Orion vessel.

headline: Despite Their Setbacks, Slovenes Remain Defiant
abstract: Slovenes appeared firm today in their resolve to resist despite a Yugoslav Army blitz that largely succeeded in returning Slovenia's border crossings to federal control.   Throughout Slovenia today, people expressed disgust at what they insisted on calling an occupation by a foreign army instead of a civil war.

headline: Angola's New War; As Battle Lines Form for Elections, Ruling Party Secures Grip on Power
abstract: It will long be debated who won and who lost Angola's 16-year civil war, but most diplomats and political experts here believe that as the nation prepares to hold its first free elections, the leftist Government has an edge in the coming campaign.     The peace accord signed in Lisbon on May 31, culminating a year of talks involving Washington and Moscow as well as the warring factions, provides for elections in the second half of 1992. But the pact gives the Luanda Government sweeping powers in the interim, at least for the moment, say analysts examining the document's fine print.

headline: Debt
abstract: * Amax Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $200 million in 10-year notes through Merrill Lynch & Co. and First Boston Corp. * Bear Stearns Cos. has filed for up to $150 million in senior notes. * Morgan Guaranty Trust Corp. is offering $200 million in noncallable 6 3/4 percent senior notes, due in 1993, at 99.80 to yield 6.859 percent through Merrill Lynch. The notes are rated triple-A by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation. * Navistar Financial Corp. is offering $117.5 million in noncallable 9.5 percent notes, due in 1996, at 99.6168 to yield 9.6 percent through J. P. Morgan Securities. The notes are rated Baa-3 by Moody's and BBB- by S.& P. * Phillips Petroleum Co. is offering $250 million in noncallable 9 percent notes, due in 2001, at a price of 100 through Morgan Stanley. The issue is rated Baa-1 by Moody's and BBB by S.& P.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Bruce McGowin, John Barchi, Ken Taub and David Terrell have formed a new advertising and design group, McBT&T, in Smithtown, L.I.

headline: Britain Selects Tank Produced By Vickers
abstract: The British Government said today that it would buy a domestically built battle tank, rejecting competing bids from the United States, France and Germany.   The contract for about 130 tanks ended months of speculation over which design would be chosen as a replacement for the British Army's 25-year-old Chieftain tanks.

headline: Hanover Energy Gets $50 Million
abstract: An investor group that includes the Pritzker family of Chicago has invested $50 million in the Hanover Energy Holding Corporation, a natural gas company in Dallas. The group, GKH Partners, is controlled by Tom and Jay Pritzker, owners of the Hyatt hotel chain. GKH is best known for a $3.3 billion takeover of American Medical International Inc. in 1989.

headline: Bold and Nimble Banker With Few Flops in Past
abstract: With a wall of television cameras facing him and a bevy of aides at his side yesterday, J. Terrence Murray, chief executive of the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group, looked more like a politician on the campaign trail than a banker.    At a Manhattan news conference, Mr. Murray fielded questions about his bank's latest acquisition, the purchase of the failed Bank of New England, an audacious and controversial move.

headline: 'Baby Bell' Arguments Set
abstract: Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene today scheduled oral arguments for April 18-l9 on whether the regional Bell telephone companies should be allowed to own information services.   Under the consent decree that broke up the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in 1984, the Bell companies are prohibited from owning information services, like as on-line data bases, as well as from manufacturing equipment or entering the long-distance business.

headline: SOVIETS ASK WEST FOR HELP ON RUBLE
abstract: The Soviet Prime Minister said today that if the West was genuinely interested in the success of economic reforms in the Soviet Union it could not take a "wait and see" attitude.    "If two people are fighting and you are interested in victory for one of the sides, you have to get into the fray and not just shout, 'Let's go!' " the Prime Minister, Valentin S. Pavlov, said in an interview.

headline: Trade Issues Enter Crucial Political Phase
abstract: At their meeting Thursday, President Bush warned Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu that Congressional concerns over Japanese trade practices could damage the relationship between the two countries. In Houston Sunday, Mr. Bush presumably told President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico that American lawmakers would require Mexico to adopt stronger environmental measures and perhaps take other steps before Congress would accede to a bilateral free-trade pact.    In part, this is an age-old dance: Lawmakers, prepared to accept a trade accord eventually, appease local interests by threatening to block the agreement. And Presidents, stepping in tune with the music, emphasize the Congressional threats when they try to win overall trade concessions from other countries.

headline: Israel Kills 2 Guerrillas At the Lebanon Border
abstract: Israeli soldiers killed two Palestinian guerrillas late Sunday night after the Arabs cut through the Lebanon border fence, crept 200 yards into Israel and exchanged fire with an Israeli Army patrol, the army said.   An statement said the clash took place two miles north of Kibbutz Dan. There were no casualties among Israeli forces.

headline: Quayle Urges Japanese To Open Markets to U.S.
abstract: Vice President Dan Quayle pressed Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and other officials today to open Japan to more American exports and investments as a crucial step toward improving relations with the United States.    But Japanese officials were still resisting American demands in several trade disputes that were being negotiated while Mr. Quayle held meetings with Japanese leaders. The American negotiators said that in many cases Japan's stance was "disappointing."

headline: RJR Debt Request Reported
abstract: RJR Nabisco Inc., the maker of Oreo cookies and Camel cigarettes, reportedly wants its banks to relax terms on about $6 billion in loans so it can use its excess cash flow to invest in developing products or buying back expensive "junk bonds."    The American Banker, a trade publication, reported yesterday that RJR Nabisco was arguing to its bankers that it ought to enjoy lower interest rates and greater freedom in investing its money because of its stronger balance sheet. The publication cited "sources with knowledge of the talks."

headline: Italy Pledges $50 Million in Aid for Albania
abstract: Italy has pledged about $50 million in emergency food, medical and economic aid to Albania to help ease the effects of this country's economic collapse on its three million people and to cut the number of Albanians fleeing to Italy, the Italian Foreign Minister said here today.    "We surely hope this aid will discourage the pressure of immigration," Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis said at a news conference. He said he was not certain how effective the measure would be, "but surely it's a first important step."

headline: People
abstract: * Joseph Philport has joined Young & Rubicam Advertising, New York, as senior vice president and director of media research worldwide. He had previously been senior vice president of market development for the A. C. Nielsen division of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation. * Jack V. Walz has been promoted to director of account management, BBDO South, Atlanta, from executive vice president.

headline: A.T.&T. and NCR Hit Snag; New Round of Talks Seen
abstract: The negotiations between A.T.& T. and NCR appear to have hit another snag, and analysts and Wall Street executives say the long-running takeover effort appears due for more talks.    "It is my sense that we are in for at least one more round of negotiations," said Maria Lewis, a telecommunications analyst with Cowen & Company in Boston.

headline: BAGHDAD REBUILDS BUT HAS FAR TO GO
abstract: Three months after the cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war, Iraqi engineers have produced a tally of achievement that says something about their ingenuity in rebuilding some of their land -- and more, possibly, about the precision, extent, and ambiguities of the allied bombing campaign.    As the summer heat builds along the Tigris, residents here say electric power has returned for up to 16 hours a day, water runs from faucets, gas stations pump gas and, sometimes, even a telephone rings.

headline: Polish Cardinal Withdraws Demand on Link to the State
abstract: Poland's Roman Catholic Primate, Jozef Cardinal Glemp, has withdrawn a demand by the church to abolish its constitutional separation from the state and make Roman Catholicism, in effect, an official religion.   "The church and state stand on different levels, should be independent from each other, but somehow bound to cooperate for the benefit of man," Cardinal Glemp said in a sermon broadcast nationally on Sunday night. "If such autonomy is called separation, that is acceptable."

headline: How Business Can Help in Schools
abstract: With great hoopla, American corporations are entering into all sorts of partnerships with their local public schools -- such things as awarding cash grants to excellent teachers, donating computers to classrooms, encouraging corporate employees to tutor slow learners. But these represent scatter-shot approaches to America's core educational problem: the nation's growing number of young, unskilled workers.    The earnings of workers with only high school diplomas dropped 9 percent during the 1980's and the earnings of dropouts fell 12 percent. Before it is too late, American business must launch a coordinated national strategy to rescue youth who are not bound for college. Specifically:

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * ACTV Inc., New York, named John A. Lack president and chief executive of the cable technology company. * Advanced NMR Systems Inc., Wilmington, Mass., named Jack Nelson chairman, succeeding Charles Harr.

headline: India Arrests Two Suspected Of Helping Gandhi Assassin
abstract: A man and his mother have been arrested in India's southern Tamil Nadu state and charged with sheltering the suspected assassin of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, the United News of India reported today.   The news agency said S. Bhagyanathan, 25 years old, and his mother, Padma, were arrested on Tuesday on charges of providing shelter to a woman suspected as Mr. Gandhis assassin.

headline: Newspapers and Magazines Dial 900 for New Revenues
abstract: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. used a "900" telephone line last year to sign up 1.6 million subscribers to Episodes, a magazine about its soap operas, charging the subscription price to phone bills and saving millions of dollars in mailing costs. USA Today recently provided ski conditions on a 900 line, drawing fees from callers and advertising from Miller Lite beer.   And at The Atlanta Journal and Constitution, churches and synagogues offer free previews of sermons by phone, paying the newspaper to advertise the service.

headline: Shifts at Fleet/Norstar
abstract: The Fleet/Norstar Financial Group appointed a top executive today to head its newly acquired Bank of New England operations in Massachusetts and Connecticut. H. Jay Sarles, an executive vice president at Fleet/Norstar for the last five years, will become president and chief executive officer of the Bank of New England in Massachusetts and the Connecticut Bank and Trust. Anne Szostak, the president and chief executive officer of Fleet Bank of Maine, will head a third Bank of New England subsidiary, the Maine National Bank.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: The Georgia Power Company of Atlanta has arranged a $51.3 million pollution control revenue bond issue through the Development Authorities of Bartow and Putnam Counties. J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. is the lead underwriter for the bonds, which will be offered at par and bear a 7.25 percent annual interest rate.

headline: Mexico-U.S. Phone Lines To Increase
abstract: A.T.& T. announced today that it would increase the telecommunications capacity between the United States and Mexico fivefold by the end of this year, as part of a broad new focus on Latin America.    Officials of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said the increased capacity, which will be made possible by the completion of five new fiber-optic cables across the border, is planned to coincide with an expected surge in demand for telephone and computer services after a new North American free-trade accord is reached.

headline: Accounting Seat Denied
abstract: Robert A. Orben, vice president for accounting policy at the Cummins Engine Company, has been rejected by the Financial Accounting Foundation as a member of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, a foundation trustee said yesterday.    The move is likely to delay the naming of a seventh member to the board, which sets most of the accounting rules for the private sector. The trustee said that the foundation would continue its search.

headline: BUSH SEES ACCORD ON 'SAFE HAVENS' FOR KURDS IN IRAQ
abstract: After meeting with European leaders today, President Bush said the United States had reached "total agreement" with them on informal safe havens in northern Iraq where aid would be given to the Kurdish refugees from the Baghdad Government of President Saddam Hussein.   The Bush Administration's description of the refugee zone it was trying to establish inside Iraq reflected a compromise intended to sidestep problems of international law and regional sensitivities about the nature and future of the area.

headline: King Coffee Bean vs. King Coffee
abstract: In the cool Andean air of this mountain village, Juan Francisco Gomez shook rainwater from a coffee bush and displayed its glistening, ripening red berries. When dried and roasted, those beans will feed the river of arabica coffee that has swept Colombia to the top of the world coffee business.    Last year, in a historic upset, Colombia displaced Brazil as the world's top coffee exporter, in terms of income.

headline: Treasury Prices Up Moderately
abstract: Fresh reports presenting a mixed picture on the economy and inflation had little impact in the credit markets, where prices of Treasury securities moved modestly higher yesterday in light trading.    Analysts noted that another important inflation report, one on consumer prices, is scheduled for today.

headline: Magazine Name Change
abstract: World Tennis magazine will change its name to Tennis Illustrated starting with the September issue. The magazine, owned by the Family Media publishing company, has used its current name for 38 years. The revamped monthly will have later deadlines, allowing for more timely coverage. It will also use bolder graphics, more photographs and higher-grade paper.

headline: New England Bank Report
abstract: The Bank of New England in Boston turned to its sister bank, the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company in Hartford, for billions of dollars in emergency loans in late 1989, a House Banking Committee said.   The report detailed the events that brought down both banks and their parent company, the Bank of New England Corporation, last January.

headline: Communists Take Early Lead in Nepal Vote
abstract: As early returns began to arrive from the first openly contested election in Nepal in 30 years, Communist candidates took strong leads in many areas today, threatening to upset the country's oldest party, the Nepali Congress.    A victory for the left would make this country the first on the Indian subcontinent with Communists heading a national government or playing a major role in a coalition administration.

headline: U.S. Envoy Tries to Reassure Lebanese on Pact With Syria
abstract: Ambassador Ryan Crocker of the United States, trying to reassure Lebanon of Washington's support for peace, today guardedly endorsed a treaty of cooperation between Lebanon and Syria.    "We hope that the treaty will be a step toward Lebanon's full independence and sovereignty," he said after a meeting at the Foreign Ministry.

headline: Nassau County Prices Notes
abstract: Nassau County, L.I., priced $140 million in tax and revenue anticipation notes yesterday in competitive bidding.   The bulk of the financing was awarded to Lehman Brothers Inc., which took $80 million in revenue anticipation notes due April 15 and priced them to yield 4.6 percent. The securities firm also took $30 million of the tax anticipation notes due March 2 and priced them to yield 4.55 percent.

headline: Canada Admits Errors in Giving Speedy Entry to Ex-Hussein Aide
abstract: The Canadian Government has acknowledged a series of mistakes that gave fast-track immigration privileges to one of the chief apologists of Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein.   The refuge obtained here by Mohammed al-Mashat, Iraq's former Ambassador to Washington and one of the senior members of Iraq's ruling Baath Party, has stirred sharp controversy over the country's immigration procedures.

headline: U.S. IS CONCERNED
abstract: Western diplomats and experts are concerned by indications that China is seeking to increase its share of the world market for missiles.    The Chinese military, the experts say, may begin shipments of two new kinds of missiles to Syria and Pakistan, and perhaps to other countries as well. The new missiles, which are said to be more accurate than the Soviet-designed Scuds used by Iraq in the Persian Gulf war, are thought to be at the end of the development stage and could be deployed soon.

headline: U.N. AIDES SAY IRAQ MAY BE CONCEALING NUCLEAR MATERIAL
abstract: United Nations officials said today that they had intelligence information indicating that Iraq has tried to mislead the United Nations by understating its nuclear weapons program and the amount of weapons-grade nuclear material it possesses.    As a result, the special commission appointed by the Security Council to oversee the destruction or removal of Iraq's chemical and biological arms and its nuclear weapons materials has ordered its experts to make new inspections of undisclosed nuclear sites in Iraq next week.

headline: Ethiopian Rebel Faction Is to Govern Separately
abstract: The leader of the rebel group that won control of the Ethiopian province of Eritrea earlier this month said today that it would form its own separate provisional government, until a United Nations-supervised referendum on Eritrean independence could be held.   The leader, Isaias Afwerki, secretary general of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front, gave no date for the proposed referendum.

headline: Avis Reviewing B.S.B. Account
abstract: There may soon be more bad news for one of Saatchi & Saatchi's agencies, Backer Spielvogel Bates. Avis is quietly reviewing its estimated $30 million account, Ray Noble, a spokesman for the car-rental company, said yesterday.    Last month, B.S.B. lost the $110 million account for Miller Lite beer and has since laid off dozens of employees.

headline: FORUM; Unlock American Energy Policy
abstract: With the gulf crisis simmering down and the Administration's new energy policy on the table, critics are howling for more Federal energy regulations and initiatives.   To them, the Bush proposal is a "nonpolicy" and lack of a Federal energy program is to blame for energy waste, dependence on oil imports, even the Bad Boy of Baghdad. We have been through this drill before. Have we learned nothing from the last 18 years?

headline: TENSION IS EASING IN ALGERIAN CITIES
abstract: Army tanks and patrols were less conspicuous in the streets of Algerian cities today, and public places and shops opened for business for the first time since the violent clashes on Wednesday that led to the imposition of martial rule.   The easing of tensions came after the announcement that Islamic fundamentalists would end their strikes and demonstrations and that the Government would hold elections for both a new parliament and a new president.

headline: Vehicle Sales Dropped 21.4% in Late April
abstract: Domestic sales of cars and light trucks made in the United States and Canada fell 21.4 percent in late April from a year earlier, deflating the industry's hopes that a rebound was imminent.   The dismal results represent a serious blow to the auto industry. Many executives thought sales had reached a low in January, but the numbers reported today were below even the January level.

headline: Channels Seek Identity In Made-for-Cable Films
abstract: Cable television channels are spending heavily on original programming in their efforts to attract audiences on the increasingly crowded cable systems.    On March 16, for example, Home Box Office presented its production of "The Josephine Baker Story." The next two nights, Turner Network Television presented its two-part production, "A Season of Giants."

headline: Ireland Issues Bonds in U.S.
abstract: Ireland issued its first bonds in the United States yesterday through a group of underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.    The $200 million bond offering has an 8 5/8 percent coupon with a maturity date of April 15, 2001. The bonds are priced at 99.375 to yield 8.72 percent, or about 72 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.    Underwriters, which report that the issue is all sold, said the 10-year bonds were rated Aa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by Standard & Poor's.

headline: Europe's Plan for Japan
abstract: The European Community introduced a trade promotion program today meant to increase the quantity of community products sold in Japan and to prevent worsening political relations with that country. The move, at a critical time in the community's relations with Japan, came as the European Commission president, Jacques Delors, is leaving on a mission to persuade Japan's Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu, of the need to mend decades of trade friction.

headline: Bonn Officer Is Shot Near Soviet Base in Germany
abstract: A Soviet soldier guarding an arms depot in eastern Germany opened fire on Friday on three uniformed German Army officers apparently in the act of photographing the Soviet base, wounding one of them in the arm, officials said.    It was the first serious incident involving the two armies since Germany was united last year and Soviet forces began to withdraw from the former East Germany.

headline: Abortion Ban, Sought by Church, Is Rejected by Polish Parliament
abstract: The Polish Parliament today rejected legislation that would have banned abortions, dealing the Roman Catholic Church here its first political setback since the fall of Communism in 1989.   The decision closed the door on Poland's bishops and other Catholic leaders, who had been lobbying energetically to have a comprehensive ban on abortions passed as a gift for Pope John Paul II, who is due to begin a visit to his Polish homeland in two weeks.

headline: A U.S. Clinic, Harassed, Withdraws From Iran
abstract: The only American charity operating inside Iran has withdrawn its seven-member medical team from a Kurdish refugee camp after harassment by Iranian officials, including one who threatened to shoot a nurse, the doctor who headed the team said today.   The physician, Dr. Curtis Bakken, said the team was forced on Friday to abandon a $500,000 clinic and more than $2 million in medicine and food at the refugee camp, near the northwest Iranian town of Bowkan. The clinic, physicians and supplies had been sent by Americares, a Connecticut-based group that provides medical treatment and other aid in 59 countries.

headline: Israel Sets New Condition for Joining Peace Talks
abstract: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has added a new and potentially difficult qualification to the list of conditions that the Israeli Government has attached to its participation in any American-sponsored regional peace conference.    By adding the new condition, the right to veto the names of any Palestinians who would attend the conference, Mr. Shamir seems to be backtracking from an agreement he made with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d during Mr. Baker's most recent visit to Jerusalem last month.

headline: Overflights to Continue
abstract: The White House said today that the United States would continue military surveillance flights over Iraqi territory even after the withdrawal of American forces to insure that Iraq obeys the United Nations cease-fire resolution.   The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, would not say how long the flights would continue, but other officials said they did not foresee an unending commitment.

headline: Large Gas Find in China
abstract: A large natural gas deposit found in northern China will be developed quickly in hopes it will be an economic boon for the area, The China Daily newspaper said today. The area includes parts of Shaanxi and Gansu provinces and the Ningxia and Inner Mongolia regions, the official newspaper said. It is one of the poorest areas of China. Preliminary estimates set an annual output of three billion cubic meters of natural gas for the field.

headline: Recession Grew Worse in Quarter As Economy Shrank at 2.8% Rate
abstract: The economy contracted more rapidly in the first three months of the year than it did at the end of 1990, as national output recorded its first consecutive quarters of decline since the recession of 1981-82, the Commerce Department reported today.   Most analysts had come to expect in recent weeks that the decline would exceed the fourth quarter's 1.6 percent annual pace, and today's report, which showed a 2.8 percent rate of decline in the January-March period, was not seen as significantly worsening prospects for pulling out of recession. Some analysts still say recovery will begin by midyear.  Officially in Recession     The data on the output of goods and services were accompanied by what appeared to be worrisome figures on inflation -- various gauges rising to annual rates above 5 percent -- but close examination suggested that these were aberrations related to imported oil.

headline: U.S. Uses Photos to Argue Iraq Hides Nuclear Material
abstract: The Bush Administration showed reconnaissance photographs to the United Nations Security Council today to back up its assertion that Iraq is trying to conceal equipment used for making nuclear explosives.   At a private briefing this morning, American intelligence officials showed the 15-member Council classified photographs of uranium-enrichment machinery being moved around on trucks or buried to evade detection by United Nations inspectors.

headline: BUSH HAILS ACCORD
abstract: The United States and Soviet Union announced today that they had settled their differences on a far-reaching treaty reducing conventional arms in Europe and that they were preparing for a summit meeting, possibly by the end of June, between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.    After a long meeting with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today's agreement would allow the two sides to step up negotiations on a new strategic arms reduction accord, which is scheduled to be signed at the summit meeting.

headline: Kuwaitis Urged to Halt Attacks on Palestinians
abstract: American military and diplomatic officials are pressing the Kuwaiti Government to prevent further attacks against Palestinians like those that occurred in the first weeks after the end of the Iraqi occupation.    A half-dozen younger members of the royal Sabah family formed what a Western diplomat called "goon squads" and carried out some of the attacks, diplomats, Kuwaitis and Palestinians say. Other attacks came at the hands of low-ranking Kuwaiti troops and armed civilians at roadblocks.

headline: Finlandia Drops the Puns To Take On a New Identity
abstract: A VIVID new advertising campaign for Finlandia vodka shifts the focus of the pitch for the "super premium" brand from Finland to strong imagery from weak puns.   In an advance look at the campaign, the signature style of Finlandia's new agency, Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein, which won the $10 million account in September from Young & Rubicam, is evident.

headline: 'Thirtysomething' Turns To the Classified Section
abstract: Although ABC is canceling "Thirtysomething," the weekly ABC drama that involved an advertising agency in many of its story lines, that fictitious agency lives on, in a way, via classified advertising.   Among the ads appearing in help-wanted section of The New York Times on Sunday was one seeking a public relations account executive "who is ready to move UP!" The ad listed an address and a fax number in care of DAA -- the name of the agency on the television series, which is ending its run on Tuesday after four seasons.

headline: Sticking With the Intermediates
abstract: One rule of thumb of investing is that the greater the risk, the bigger the return. And interest-rate risk increases over time. So investors who tie up their money in long-term bond funds should get returns that are markedly better than the returns of shorter-term funds.   That, however, has not happened in high-quality corporate bond funds. For the last five years, there has been virtually no difference in the returns of the long-term A-rated corporate bond funds and intermediate bond funds, the bulk of whose holdings are comparable in quality to the A-rated funds'. After 7 and 10 years, the spread widens somewhat, but it is still less than one percentage point.

headline: In Hard Times, A Realty Coup
abstract: THE surprising success of a recent real estate deal seems to suggest that even in bad times strong properties with good cash flow can be used to raise a barrel of cash.    The deal, which has inspired much buzzing in commercial real estate circles, is the complex refinancing of 48 properties that are part of the Saks Fifth Avenue retail chain. Goldman, Sachs & Company put the deal together late last year in the midst of the Persian Gulf showdown and one of the worse real estate markets in anyone's memory.

headline: U.S. Issues Up in Slow Trading
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in very slow trading yesterday and short-term bill rates were at the lowest levels since 1987, as dealers began to mark time in advance of inflation reports scheduled later in the week.    Even though the economy is mired in recession, inflation remains stubbornly high. Most market participants say it is unlikely that the Federal Reserve Board will push down short-term interest rates further until there is evidence that price pressures are easing.

headline: Big 3 Charge Mini-Van Dumping
abstract: Faced with a continuing loss of sales to Japanese auto makers, the Big Three filed an anti-dumping petition with the Government today, accusing four Japanese concerns of importing mini-vans at unfairly low prices.   The industry's action seemed sure to aggravate trade tensions between the United States and Japan. Although the petition focused on a relatively narrow category of vehicles, one Big Three executive who requested anonymity described it as a warning shot.

headline: Creditors Back Polly Peck Plan
abstract: Creditors of Polly Peck International P.L.C., the heavily indebted British conglomerate, have backed a repayment plan that allows the company to retain rather than be forced to sell its Del Monte fruit and Sansui electronics operations.    Court-appointed administrators said their package offered creditors their best chance of recovering some of the $2.4 billion the company owed. Some creditors had advocated a complete liquidation of assets.

headline: The Executive Life; The Overstressed Sniff for a Dose of Relaxation
abstract: People will try almost anything to expel stress -- acupuncture, yoga and isolation tanks, shiatsu and the Canyon Ranch. Then there are always seaweed tablets, environmental music and smelling.   Smelling?

headline: Nabisco Delays Debt Offering
abstract: Reflecting rising prices for corporate bonds, an anticipated offering of $750 million worth of new seven-year high- yield securities from the RJR Nabisco Capital Corporation was delayed yesterday.    Traders and analysts said they believed that the issue was not priced because demand for the securities was so strong that the size of the issue might be doubled, to $1.5 billion. The yield is expected to be 10.5 to 11 percent.    The lead underwriters, Merrill Lynch & Company and Salomon Brothers Inc., declined to comment. In January 1990, lack of investor demand forced RJR to cancel a planned $1 billion note offering.

headline: I.B.M. Adds 11 Models To Minicomputer Line
abstract: I.B.M. "refreshed" its three-year-old midrange computer line yesterday, introducing 11 new models that perform up to 60 percent faster and cost 10 to 40 percent less than the minicomputers they replace. But at the same time, the company acknowledged that sales of its minicomputers lagged behind the rest of its hardware products in the United States in the first quarter of 1991.   The midrange line, called AS/400, was introduced in 1988 to merge I.B.M.'s System/36 and System/38 minicomputers, used by small businesses and the departments of large corporations. The International Business Machines Corporation has sold more than 100,000 of them, mostly outside the United States, the company said.

headline: Top Effie Award Goes for Humorous Ads That Helped Win Senate Seat
abstract: AN advertising award honoring results, as well as creativity, has been presented for an unusual series of humorous ads that achieved the ultimate result in politics: They helped a candidate for the United States Senate win election.   The New York chapter of the American Marketing Association last night presented its Grand Effie Award, for the most effective advertising of 1990, to the Wellstone for Senate campaign (that's campaign as in series of ads, not as in stump for office). The chapter is calling the award -- previously won by product-selling pitches for Absolut vodka, Quaker oatmeal, Pizza Hut and other consumer marketers -- the first such national honor bestowed on political advertising.

headline: Nagasaki Mayor Re-elected In Spite of Insult to Hirohito
abstract: In a rebuke to Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's Liberal Democratic Party, voters in Nagasaki elected Hitoshi Motoshima to a fourth term as Mayor on Sunday, despite a ruling party campaign to oust him.    The Mayor had drawn international attention because of his comments in late 1988, as Emperor Hirohito lay dying, suggesting that the ruler bore some responsibility for World War II. A year later, the Mayor was shot in front of City Hall by a right-wing extremist.    In other elections, Harue Kitamura of Ashiya became the first woman to be elected Mayor of a Japanese city.

headline: N.A.S.D. Reports Slight Drop in Short Positions
abstract: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that the short interest in actively traded over-the-counter securities in its national market system declined slightly for the four weeks that ended on April 15.    A total of 264.1 million shares were held short and not yet covered in mid-April, it said, compared with 264.3 million shares in the corresponding period that ended in mid-March. The figure represents short selling in 2,279 stocks; in March the short selling was spread among 2,244 issues.

headline: Sallie Mae Offers $500 Million Issue
abstract: The Student Loan Marketing Association, which is known as Sallie Mae, priced a $500 million short-term note issue yesterday through a group of underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.    The noncallable notes will reach maturity in 1994. The issue has a 7.30 percent coupon and was priced at 100 to yield about 14 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of percentage point.

headline: Iraq Acts to Halt the Spread Of Allied Zone for the Kurds
abstract: A top-ranking Iraqi general met with American commanders today, apparently in an effort to block expansion of the allied-controlled zone for Kurdish refugees.   Maj. Gen. Abu Firas Saber of the Iraqi general staff met with Lieut. Gen. John Shalikashvili, the United States Army officer in command of the allied military relief effort for an hour and a half this afternoon to deliver what one American officer described as "a strong message."

headline: As Kurds Limp Back In, Ghost Town Relives '88
abstract: Once a Christian and Kurdish mountain village, Kani Masi today is inhabited by many but home to no one.   The forces of President Saddam Hussein have reduced Kani Masi to a dangerous, junk-strewn ruin in a rocky valley below jagged mountain peaks.

headline: U.S.-Mexico Pact Faces Hurdle on Tuna Fishing
abstract: With the North American free-trade agreement at a critical stage, the United States and Mexico are locked in a dispute over the environmental damage caused by Mexico's tuna-fishing fleet.    The fishing disagreement, which has already provoked a United States embargo on imports of Mexican tuna, pits American environmentalists with wide public support against one of Mexico's largest and most powerful export industries, which traps and kills tens of thousands of dolphins in its tuna nets each year.

headline: 2 Economic Advisers Leaving Bush Council
abstract: Two of the three members of President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers are leaving the Government to resume academic careers.   John B. Taylor announced yesterday that he was resigning effective Aug. 2 to return to Stanford University. Last week, Richard L. Schmalensee submitted his resignation to return to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

headline: Cubatao Journal; Signs of Life in Brazil's Industrial Valley of Death
abstract: After school let out one recent afternoon here, Cleiton Celio Silva Araujo grabbed hooks, line and a bamboo pole and scrambled down a bank of the Cubatao River. Within an hour, the gangly 13-year-old was filling a plastic bag with fish.   Out of place in this tableau was the background: metal chimneys and ducts of a riverside styrene plant. Even more out of place was a label that Brazilian environmentalists long ago gave to this industrial city: the Valley of Death.

headline: Panama's U.S. Envoy Quits
abstract: Eduardo Vallarino, Panama's Ambassador to the United States, has resigned, apparently to protest the ouster of his Christian Democratic Party from the coalition Government here, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today. The move came a day after President Guillermo Endara dismissed all five Christian Democrats from his 12-member Cabinet, accusing them of arrogance and disloyalty.

headline: Kuwait Orders 3 More to Die
abstract: Three men were sentenced to death today by a martial law court, bringing to 12 the number of defendants facing hanging for collaborating with the Iraqis during the occupation of Kuwait. Eleven other defendants were given prison terms ranging from 7 to 25 years of hard labor.

headline: New Storms Add to Misery in Bangladesh; Disease Threatens Many
abstract: A tornado and thunderstorms today brought new misery and death to Bangladesh.    The new storms occurred as Bangladeshi officials renewed their appeals for more international aid to cope with the effects of last week's devastating cyclone, which has killed more than 125,000 people, according to an incomplete official count. Aid workers raised new alarms that disease could threaten millions of the cyclone's survivors.

headline: Chapter 11 Plan By Developer
abstract: The General Development Corporation, which was accused of defrauding buyers of 11,000 housing sites, presented a bankruptcy reorganization plan today that would keep the Miami- based developer in business.   The company, which builds planned communities, intends to cancel its stock, held largely by insurance companies and investment houses, and pay unsecured creditors from $200 million in new notes and 9.75 million shares of new common stock. Secured creditors would eventually be paid in full.

headline: Florida Shop Acquires Needham & Grohmann
abstract: It is not uncommon for New Yorkers to sell their homes and head down to Florida when they reach retirement age. But it is a little more unusual when it happens to an advertising agency.   Needham & Grohmann Inc., a small 60-year-old agency in New York, said yesterday that it would close in the next three weeks and hand over its $10 million in accounts to Robinson, Yesawich & Pepperdine Inc., an agency in Orlando, Fla. Both agencies specialize in campaigns for hotels and resorts, but the Florida-based agency is more than seven times as large in staff and billings.

headline: Disney Film's Cool Debut
abstract: The Walt Disney Company's highly awaited new release "The Rocketeer" had a lukewarm opening this past weekend, taking in roughly $9.5 million at 1,600 theaters. While inital sales were considered respectable, according to one executive close to Disney, the company had hoped it would open stronger.    In the film industry, the initial performance is measured on a per-screen basis. The figure for the 'Rocketeer' is about $6,000 a screen. By way of comparison, "Robin Hood," the Warner Brothers film starring Kevin Costner, earned about $11,000 a screen on its opening weekend.

headline: Patents; 'Daddy-Longlegs' Robot for Exploration of Mars
abstract: Researchers at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh patented a robot this week that resembles a daddy-longlegs and was designed to explore the rugged landscape of Mars. The robot was developed with financing from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.    Although the number of appendages on the robot can vary, it typically features six legs that sprout from the top of a central "brain."

headline: Is It Really What's Inside That Counts?
abstract: To the Editor:   It was painful for me -- a lifelong wearer of Chuck Taylor All Stars high-topped sneakers -- to read that the Converse people are going to try to build the company up around a slogan like "It's What's Inside That Counts." ("Converse in Adland, Playing Catch-Up Ball," March 24.)    Inside what? Inside the sneakers? You mean, after all these years, it's really been my feet, and not my Chuck Taylors, that have enabled me to achieve legendary status in pick-up games with my brothers in our parents' driveway?   I've been wearing high tops on my hospital rounds for years, and they have greatly aided in patient care (in heavy intensive-care-unit traffic, in quick emergency room appearances, etc.). If Converse could focus on these more ordinary uses of their products, and try to keep the melodrama to a minimum, then my Chuck Taylors may still be available in a few years. MARK R. HEITZMAN, M.D.  Barre, Vt., March 24

headline: Jordanian King Names Palestinian Prime Minister
abstract: King Hussein has dismissed the Jordanian Cabinet and asked the Foreign Minister, a Palestinian who favors a negotiated settlement with Israel, to form a new administration, senior officials said here today.    The selection of the Palestinian, Taher Masri, who is well liked in Washington, is viewed as an effort to regain favor in the United States and bring Jordan out of the diplomatic isolation into which it fell for its support of Iraq during the Persian Gulf crisis.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Economy    Gasoline prices are likely to rise by 10 to 15 cents a gallon at the pump by mid-May, to an average of $1.20 to $1.25, analysts say. The nation's gasoline stocks have fallen to the lowest level in 16 years, and imports this month remain below normal levels with the summer driving season approaching.  [ Page 33. ]

headline: Making a Difference; Trimming the Sails At Public TV's Flagship
abstract: William F. Baker is president of New York's Thirteen/ WNET, the largest public television station in America. He is also a fellow of the Explorer's Club and has been to both the North Pole and the South Pole. So the current chill at the station has not fazed him unduly.   "I think we can even be better for having to go through this," he said last week.

headline: A Press War Splits Berlin Anew
abstract: Berlin's newest daily newspaper, a flashy tabloid called Super, hit the newsstands this month, unleashing a fierce price war at the low end of eastern Germany's rumbling newspaper market.    The paper is remarkable for its price, 30 pfennigs, or about 17 cents, roughly a fifth that of many German dailies, as well as for its upbeat tone, stressing eastern German accomplishments amid a mood that is starkly dark, and its feisty policy of bashing western Germans, or "Wessies," in tall headlines that scream out, "Western Official Seizes Farmers' Lands in Mecklenburg" and "Wessie Buys Village; 256 Citizens in Panic."

headline: Big LTV Order From Boeing
abstract: The LTV Corporation, the steel and aerospace company that is struggling to emerge from bankruptcy, received a $1.5 billion order from the Boeing Company.    The contract to make sections of 747, 757 and 767 aircraft came a day after LTV made its first formal proposal to end its five-year bankruptcy reorganization.

headline: Testimony By Clifford
abstract: Clark Clifford, a former Defense Secretary, testified today before a Federal grand jury here that is investigating a foreign bank's large stake in First American Bankshares Inc. Mr. Clifford is the chairman of the company.    Mr. Clifford has said that he did not know of the hidden stock ownership by the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, based in Luxembourg, and that he had acted in good faith when he told a Federal official that the bank was not involved with First American.

headline: Company News; T.C.I. Alters Plan For Cable Billing
abstract: Telecommunications Inc., the nations largest operator of cable television systems, cancelled plans to to bill customers automatically for a new pay movie channel after the practice was criticized by consumer groups and made the subject of lawsuit by state attorneys general in Florida, Iowa, Texas ans Washington.

headline: Groups Taking Aid for the Kurds
abstract: American Friends Service Committee, 1501 Cherry Street, Philadelphia, Pa. 19102   American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee Open Mailbox for Kurdish Refugees, 711 Third Avenue, 10th Floor, New York, N.Y. 10017

headline: Dollar Falls Amid Pressure From a Bundesbank Rumor
abstract: The dollar fell against major currencies yesterday, under pressure in part from persistent speculation that the president of Germany's Bundesbank, Karl Otto Pohl, would resign.   "The mark rebounded as the market seemed to rethink the implications of a Pohl resignation," said Lisa Finstrom, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers. "If he resigns and is replaced with someone in the bank who will maintain policy or if he doesn't resign, that will be friendly for the mark."

headline: Fatal Clashes in El Salvador
abstract: Weekend clashes between rebels and Government troops killed more than 10 people and wounded 24, army and rebel spokesmen said today.

headline: Sony Is Reportedly Near Deal To Lease A.T.&T. Skyscraper
abstract: In what is shaping up as one of the biggest real estate deals in New York City this year, A.T.& T. has tentatively agreed to lease its headquarters building, one of Manhattan's architectural highlights, to the Sony Corporation, real estate executives said yesterday.    A proposed 20-year lease with an option to buy the eight-year-old tower would consolidate Sony USA's corporate presence in New York. The 35-story building, sheathed in rosy granite, is sometimes called the Chippendale skyscraper for its pediment resembling the top of an 18th-century highboy,

headline: 3 Companies Cited on Cholesterol Claims
abstract: Attacking what it regards as mislabeling of low-cholesterol foods, the Food and Drug Administration yesterday assailed three large food concerns, including the Procter & Gamble Company.   Just last month the agency said Procter & Gamble had misrepresented processed orange juice as fresh, and yesterday it attacked the company's Crisco Corn Oil, CPC International Inc.'s 100% Pure Mazola Corn Oil and Great Foods of America Inc.'s Heartbeat Canola Oil.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Amoco Chemical Co., Chicago, a subsidiary of Amoco Corp., appointed William T. Harper Jr. executive vice president. He will also remain president of Amoco Fabrics and Fiber Co., Atlanta, a unit of Amoco Chemical. * Equitable Capital Management Corp., New York, a subsidiary of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, named Barbara J. Krumsiek senior vice president.

headline: Making a Difference; Battling Textile Imports and Industry Frictions
abstract: For Donald R. Hughes, the vice chairman of Burlington Industries, 1991 has offered little to cheer about.    As chairman of the Fiber, Fabric and Apparel Coalition for Trade, he led the industry's opposition to a free-trade agreement with Mexico and to a new round of multilateral trade liberalization, which is likely to result in larger quotas for textile imports.

headline: Iran Said to Want U.S. Deal
abstract: Iran wants to sell up to 400,000 barrels of oil a day to the United States, but obstacles like freedom for Western hostages in Lebanon must be cleared, the Middle East Economic Survey reported today.    The Iranian oil authorities have set no date for accomplishing their goal of 300,000 to 400,000 barrels a day in crude sales to the United States, the journal said.

headline: Regeneron Shares Post 13.6% Decline
abstract: The shares of Regeneron Pharmaceuticals Inc., which on Tuesday completed one of the largest initial public offerings in the history of the biotechnology industry, dropped sharply. The stock, traded over-the-counter, fell $2.875 a share, or 13.6 percent, to close at $18.25, after a drop of 87.5 cents on Tuesday. That means the stock is already 17 percent below its initial price of $22.    Regeneron, based in Tarrytown, N.Y., is working on treatments for neurological diseases. It had initially planned to sell its shares at $16 to $19 each but raised the price to $22 because of strong demand. But some analysts had said that the company's market valuation was too high, given that Regeneron is far from having any products on the market.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Security Council Meets at 10:30 A.M. on Iraq and Kuwait.

headline: MBIA Holders Are Selling 11.5 Million of Their Shares
abstract: MBIA Inc., which through its MBIA Corporation subsidiary is a leading insurer of municipal bonds, began a secondary offering of 11.5 million common shares at $35 a share yesterday, or a total of about $402 million. The underwriting group is led by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Inc.    According to underwriters, the offering is made up of shares held by the major investors in MBIA: the Fund American Companies; the Cigna Corporation and the Aetna Casualty and Surety Company unit of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company. Of the shares being offered, 9.5 million are expected to be sold in the United States and Canada, with the rest in other countries.

headline: Gulf Victory: An Energy Defeat?
abstract: While the allied victory in the Persian Gulf eliminated for now the threat to Western access to Mideast oil, there is widespread agreement in the oil industry that the United States' long-term energy security may have been set back.    The quick war brought oil prices back down near prewar levels, and those lower prices provide little incentive for energy conservation or new drilling in the United States.

headline: Panel Denies Chevron Bid On Tankers
abstract: A state agency today denied a request by the Chevron Corporation for temporary permission to transport oil by tanker from a field off the central California coast to refineries near Los Angeles.    The vote, by the California Coastal Commission, means that Chevron must move the oil by overland pipelines if it wants to begin full production from the field. Chevron has long resisted using pipelines for most of the oil from the field, saying existing pipelines would be inefficient.

headline: Yields Decline for 7th Week
abstract: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts fell for the seventh consecutive week in the period ended yesterday, with most declines on the moderate side.    Analysts at The Bank Rate Monitor, an interest rate publication based in North Palm Beach, Fla., note that yield spreads among money market funds, funds that invest in United States Treasury securities and bank money market accounts have narrowed considerably since the beginning of the year. Money market and Treasury funds had yielded as much as 175 basis points more than the average bank money market account, but as recently as last week the spread had narrowed to as little as 50 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

headline: Stocks Climb in Tokyo
abstract: Japanese stock prices rose today in moderate trading. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 244.99 points, or nearly 1 percent, to close at 25,643.65. On Wednesday, the Nikkei lost 82.55 points.

headline: Free Agents Put Pinch On Networks
abstract: Like baseball owners, the networks have to deal with some expensive free agents this year, and they have an enormous incentive to try to keep their costs down.    "Cheers" seems to be the Roger Clemens of prime-time television, renewing its deal with NBC for top dollar.

headline: Head of Quaker State Steps Down at Meeting
abstract: Quentin E. Wood, who rose during a 43-year career at the Quaker State Corporation from field engineer to chairman, resigned at the motor oil company's annual meeting yesterday. He will be succeeded by Jack W. Corn, who will also retain the title of chief executive.    Under Mr. Wood's leadership, as chief executive from 1975 to 1988 and chairman since 1982, Quaker State undwerwent a sizable expansion. From 1979 to 1986, sales increased from $292.9 million, to about $1 billion, and net income rose from $23.2 million, to $50 million.

headline: New Kind of U.S. Trade Complaint: By Foreign Companies
abstract: With more manufacturers from abroad setting up shop in the United States, it is getting harder to tell which company is foreign, which domestic. And when trade disputes arise, the confusion mounts.    Such confusion erupted today when the American manufacturing subsidiary of a Japanese company asked the International Trade Commission to impose duties on the imports of the Singapore unit of an American rival that is 48 percent owned by a British company.

headline: French Prime Minister Quits; Woman Named to Post
abstract: Prime Minister Michel Rocard resigned today after three years in office, and Edith Cresson, a Socialist and former Cabinet minister, was named to replace him, making her the first woman to serve as Prime Minister of France.    President Francois Mitterrand's decision to appoint Mrs. Cresson, who served as Trade Minister, Agriculture Minister and Minister of European Affairs, is viewed as an effort to move the Government further to the left and to add new spark to it during the President's remaining four years in office.

headline: Business and the Law; Congress Moves On Price-Fixing
abstract: CONGRESS is moving quickly to adopt significant antitrust legislation that its supporters assert will encourage price competition by making it more difficult for manufacturers and retailers to fix prices.   Last week the Senate approved legislation that would essentially codify some court rulings, making vertical price-fixing by manufacturers and retailers automatically illegal. The measure, approved on voice vote, would also roll back decisions by the United States Supreme Court and Federal appeals courts in the last decade that have made it increasingly more difficult for plaintiffs to bring such actions.

headline: MAN IN THE News; Congress Party's Calculating Loyalist: Pamulaparti Venkata Narasimha Rao
abstract: An intellectual who speaks at least six languages, a quiet-spoken poet and linguist, a Hindi and Sanskrit scholar, P. V. Narasimha Rao, a frail, elderly South Indian, seems at first glance a curious choice to lead a nation of 850 million that is seized by poverty, illiteracy and increasing violence.     Even friends speak a bit cautiously about a politician who faithfully served Prime Minister Indira Gandhi as well as her son, Rajiv, who was also Prime Minister.

headline: Kurds Outline Their Demands for More Autonomy
abstract: With thousands of Kurds still seeking American protection in Iraq, Kurdish leaders are pressing Baghdad for enough autonomy to encourage the refugees to return home, say exiled members of opposition groups.    In talks now under way in Baghdad, Kurdish leaders are demanding that the oil-producing northern city of Kirkuk be declared the capital of a new self-governing Kurdistan region, with a portion of its oil revenues earmarked for the Kurds. They are also asking for a new interim coalition government for Iraq as a whole, free elections, a new constitution and a separate Kurdish militia and police force.

headline: Proxy Challenge At Moore Medical
abstract: IN fights for corporate control, the dissident is at a severe disadvantage. While management's pleas for votes are paid for by the company, the dissident must finance his own campaign. Thus, unless there is a large and angry holder, or a bidder trying to buy the company, proxy fights are highly unlikely.   But one is now going on at the Moore Medical Corporation, a wholesaler of drugs and medical supplies where little has gone right in recent years.

headline: Making a Difference; Ken Miller's Lodestar Makes Another Global Play
abstract: Ken Miller has come a long way from the 1960's, when he dedicated himself to teaching government at Philander Smith College in Little Rock, Ark.    These days, Mr. Miller, 48 years old, is expanding the Lodestar Group, his three-year-old investment banking boutique.

headline: Salvadoran Legislature Passes Reforms in Time
abstract: The outgoing legislature unanimously approved constitutional reforms tonight that are expected to widen the path toward an end to the 11-year-old civil war.   The reforms, most of which emerged from talks between the Government and rebel leaders, would diminish the autonomy of the military, which has been blamed for many rights abuses; strengthen the judiciary, and make changes in the electoral system.

headline: Finally, Some Good News For Ayer and 'Fresh' Backer
abstract: AS large national advertisers made decisions yesterday on nearly $100 million in advertising accounts up for review, there was good news for two agencies -- Backer Spielvogel Bates Inc. and Ayer Inc. -- that had been more used to bad news lately.    Backer Spielvogel Bates, New York, ended a string of account losses, including the $110 million Miller Lite beer account, by retaining the Avis Inc. account, with billings of as much as $35 million.

headline: Stocks Decline in Tokyo
abstract: Japanese stock prices retreated today, despite Wednesday's rally on Wall Street. The Nikkei index of 225 issues dropped 291.35 points, or 1.1 percent, to close at 26,038.86, just off its low for the day. Trading was light. On Wednesday, the Nikkei lost 161.63 points.

headline: Making a Difference; Big Computer Discounts, Courtesy of Arnold Cohen
abstract: ARNOLD COHEN, the Digital Equipment Corporation's sales manager for the Boston area, likes his job. And he's good at it. Although the computer maker as a whole has been posting sluggish results, its sales in Boston are holding up nicely.    But Mr. Cohen hates it when small businesses routinely bypass Digital because of the company's reputation for preferring large customers. And he hates seeing the Massachusetts economy so stuck in the doldrums that few entrepreneurs can afford to buy anyone's computer equipment.

headline: Japan's Sleight of Hand in Trade . . .
abstract: America's trade deficit with Japan often serves as a rallying point against adversarial Japanese trade practices, but because of the gulf war, the Commerce Department's release of the 1990 trade figures passed almost unnoticed.    America's trade deficit with Japan fell substantially -- to $41 billion from $49 billion the year before -- and the gap stands far below 1987's record of $56 billion.

headline: U.S. Sees New Mideast Peace Momentum
abstract: American officials said today that the decision by Saudi Arabia and five other Arab gulf states to participate in a peace conference with Israel should intensify pressure on both Syria and Israel to drop objections to such a gathering.    Trying to make most of the Saudi initiative, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d distributed copies of the statement describing it to reporters traveling with him as he took off for Damascus from Washington on Friday night. He did so before the Saudi Foreign Minister, Saud al-Faisal, formally issued the statement today at a conference in Luxembourg.

headline: Baker Defends Refugee Plan at European Meeting
abstract: Secretary of State James. A Baker 3d started his new Middle East diplomatic mission today by defending the Bush Administration's decision to establish sanctuaries for Kurdish refugees, asserting that it was a humanitarian effort and was consistent with United Nations resolutions.    Mr. Baker met here with foreign ministers of the 12 European Community nations as he began a trip that will take him to Israel on Thursday, and then to Jordan, Egypt, Syria and Saudi Arabia over the next few days.

headline: Technology; A Faster Path to Finished Steel
abstract: In a wide stretch of quiet farmland in northwestern Indiana, the Inland Steel Company is engaged in a joint venture with the Nippon Steel Corporation to produce finished steel using a new process that cuts manufacturing time to less than an hour, from about 12 days.    The process, in which unfinished steel coils are converted into high quality finished steel, is unique in North America. It is being hailed by some steel industry experts as the most advanced technique for producing high quality steel for the appliance, office furniture and automotive industries.

headline: Disney's Quarterly Profits Fall 29%
