abstract: The Walt Disney Company said today that its earnings for the quarter ended March 31 fell 29 percent as a weak economy and the Persian Gulf war hurt attendance at its theme parks, and box-office flops depressed results from its film division.    Disney said its net income for the quarter, the second of its fiscal year, was $126.6 million, or 95 cents a share, compared with $178.5 million, or $1.29 a share, in the comparable period last year. Revenues for the quarter were $1.44 billion, an increase of 10.8 percent over the period a year earlier.

headline: Agamemnon Koutsogeorgas, 69, Greek Aide
abstract: Agamemnon Koutsogeorgas, a close aide to former Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou and his main co-defendant in a corruption and embezzlement trial, died today at a hospital after having a stroke nine days ago. He was 69 years old.   Mr. Koutsogeorgas collapsed in court while questioning a prosecution witness at his trial and was taken to a hospital, where he remained in a coma until his death.

headline: Marion Merrell Dow Job
abstract: The president of Marion Merrell Dow Inc., the phamaceuticals concern, will add chief executive to his title at the first of the year. Fred W. Lyons Jr. will succeed Joseph G. Temple Jr., 61 years old, who will stay on as chairman. Mr. Lyons, 55, had been president and chief executive of Marion Laboratories from 1984 until its merger with Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals at the end of 1989.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Blistex Inc., Oak Brook, Ill., named Ronald H. Kovich vice president, sales. * Collection Clothing Co., New York, a newly formed subsidiary of Aeneas Group, an affiliate of Harvard Management Co., named G. Raymond Empson president.

headline: Hungarian Cardinal Is Reburied in Homeland as 'Red Star' Is Extinguished
abstract: The body of Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty, the implacable foe of Communism who died in exile in 1975, was reburied today inside Hungary's main Roman Catholic church here in a ceremony celebrated as the triumph of righteousness over accommodation.    Despite an unseasonably cold rain, more than 50,000 pilgrims, many from Hungary's small towns and villages where the Roman Catholic Church draws its greatest strength, filled the hillside below the giant basilica, to listen to a funeral service that also made a political point.

headline: Putting L'eggs on Ice: Capades Gets a Sponsor
abstract: Ice Capades, the feathery, glittering ice skating show, has named a corporate sponsor for the first time in its 51-year history.   L'eggs Products, a unit of the Sara Lee Corporation, has signed a two-year agreement with the show, beginning in September. As part of the multimillion-dollar deal, Ice Capades, a unit of the International Broadcasting Corporation, Minneapolis, will change its logo to include the L'eggs Sheer Energy logo, and there will even be a production number incorporating L'eggs products.

headline: Roy Disney Firm to Buy Stake in L.A. Gear
abstract: L.A. Gear Inc., the athletic footwear company that has fared poorly in the last year, said today that it had agreed to sell a 30 percent stake for $100 million to an investment firm headed by Roy E. Disney.  On the New York Stock Exchange, the company's shares, which have plummeted from a high of about $50 in May 1990 to less than $10, rose more than 10 percent today, gaining $1.25, to $11.75.

headline: Hard Times For Innovator In Graphics
abstract: Steven P. Jobs's other company, Pixar, is having difficulties, just as his Next Inc. has begun to report improved sales of its computer work station.   Pixar said today that it had laid off 30 of its 72 employees, including its president, Charles F. Kolstad. Edward Catmul, who co-founded Pixar with Alvy Ray Smith, will serve as president.

headline: All About/Computer Retailers; Superstores Force PC Chains to Reinvent Themselves
abstract: For personal computer sellers looking ahead, the future suddenly offers very few alternatives: get big, get specialized or get out.    The entry of a new breed of warehouse-sized superstores is putting the squeeze on traditional computer retailers. As do their predecessors in home furnishings, consumer electronics and toys, the PC superstores offer selection, discounts and convenience.

headline: U.S. BEGINS STORING MILITARY SUPPLIES IN ISRAELI BUNKERS
abstract: Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney announced today that the United States was stockpiling American military equipment in Israel for use in any regional conflict.   "We currently are implementing an agreement with Israel to pre-position materials and equipment here," Mr. Cheney said as he left a meeting here this afternoon with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. "That's under way as we speak."

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Next Inc., a computer maker in Redwood City, Calif., to Cleary, Kvamme & Suiter, San Francisco, for a portion of its advertising and marketing account with billings of $1.5 million to $2 million. The company is still searching for an agency for its national campaign. Ammirati & Puris resigned the account in March.

headline: International Data Corp. Appoints a New Chief
abstract: The International Data Corporation has named Kirk S. Campbell president and chief executive. Mr. Campbell has been chief operating officer at International Data, based in Framingham, Mass., a leading research and consulting concern for the computer industry.   Mr. Campbell, 37, succeeds Axel Leblois, who resigned to become president and chief executive of Bull HN Information Systems Inc., the United States subsidiary of Groupe Bull of France. Before joining International Data, Mr. Campbell was vice president of planning and worldwide analysis at the International Data Group, the parent company. The parent also controls I.D.G. Communications, which publishes computer magazines and newspapers in 49 countries.

headline: Drug Baron In Colombia May Give Up
abstract: Topic A in Colombia these days is whether Pablo Escobar, the most notorious of the world's cocaine traffickers, is about to turn himself in.    Mr. Escobar, who has been on the run for more than 18 months, has indicated he is ready to accept a Government offer of leniency.

headline: Panel Gives Chip Outlook
abstract: A panel of experts has concluded that advanced semiconductor factories are likely to cost about $2 billion each by 2000 and that the world would be able to afford only about 25 of them, with 10 in the United States.   Few companies will be able to afford even a single such factory, the panel predicts, so semiconductor companies will have to share resources and technology to an unprecedented degree.

headline: Berlin Wall Guards Accused of Shooting Escapees
abstract: Sensitive to charges that crimes committed by the ousted East German Communist Government are going unpunished, German prosecutors have announced the arrests of four former border guards in the shooting of the last people who tried to flee before the Berlin Wall fell.    The guards, who were detained on Friday, are charged in the death of Chris Geoffroy, a 20-year old waiter, and the wounding of a companion, Christian Gaudian, who were fired upon as they tried to dash to West Berlin on the night of Feb. 6, 1989. Nine months later, rebelling throngs in East Germany forced the Government to open the wall that had divided the old German capital since 1961. Border guards sometimes joined in the ensuing celebrations.

headline: Earnings Up at Quaker
abstract: The Quaker Oats Company said today that earnings in its third quarter, ended on March 31, more than doubled from its third quarter of 1990, when the company took a $34.8 million write-off for its attempt to spin off to shareholders its Fisher-Price toy business. Net income for the three months was $63.1 million, or 82 cents a share, compared with $25.6 million, or 32 cents a share, in the 1990 quarter.

headline: Philip Morris Net Up 21.5% In Quarter
abstract: The Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest consumer-products company and the maker of Marlboro cigarettes, reported yesterday that it had first-quarter earnings of $942 million, or $1.02 a share, compared with $775 million, or 84 cents a share, for the corresponding period last year. That increase of 21.5 percent was slightly better than many analysts' expectations.   Also yesterday, American Brands Inc., the fifth-largest cigarette company, said its first-quarter profit totaled $216.7 million, or $1.06 a share, up 10.9 percent from $195.4 million, or $1 a share, a year ago.

headline: Rebel Attacks in El Salvador Cut Power Supplies in Half
abstract: In what they say is a tactic to put pressure on the Government to negotiate a cease-fire, leftist guerrillas have sabotaged the power system in recent days on a scale that has left El Salvador with about half its normal electricity supply.    The clandestine radio station operated by the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front proclaimed with a tone of glee on Wednesday morning that the sabotage campaign had made the head of the power company, a retired army colonel, "electric, frenetic, epileptic and dialectic."

headline: CNBC Wins Bidding War For FNN
abstract: After an increasingly tense bidding war, a Federal bankruptcy judge decided yesterday that the Financial News Network should go to NBC's Consumer News and Business Channel for $154.3 million and a share of future revenues.    The price is more than 70 percent higher than the first bid for the ailing network, which was made by Dow Jones & Company and the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company in February.

headline: TECHNOLOGY LINKS WILL BE DISCUSSED BY APPLE AND I.B.M.
abstract: Top executives of Apple Computer Inc. will be visiting the headquarters of the International Business Machines Corporation in Armonk, N.Y., on Monday to discuss a far-ranging technology alliance that could have a major impact on the computer industry, industry executives say.    One part of the talks, according to these executives, is a proposal for I.B.M. to license from Apple, and perhaps even to help develop, basic software for a new line of Apple computers that will be a successor to its Macintosh family.

headline: Profits Up 6.6% At McDonald's
abstract: The McDonald's Corporation, the world's largest fast- food chain, said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose 6.6 percent, to $168.5 million, or 46 cents a share, compared with $158.1 million, or 43 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago.    Revenues rose 3.3 percent, to $1.56 billion from $1.51 billion.

headline: Plan on Iraqi Arms Is Faulted
abstract: The United Nations program to destroy Iraq's chemical and biological weapons is unworkable, a member of the commission set up to do the job has said.    "The plan is absolutely unrealistic," said the official, Marjatta Rautio, Finland's representative on the 20-member special commission charged with finding and destroying the Iraqi arsenal. She made her comments on Tuesday in an interview on Finnish radio.

headline: Gunmen in Santiago Slay Pinochet Adviser
abstract: A longtime friend and close adviser to Chile's former military ruler, General Augusto Pinochet, was shot and killed this evening in Santiago, apparently by leftist gunmen.    The victim, Jaime Guzman, who was a prominent rightist Senator in Chile and counsel to General Pinochet and his ruling military junta, was attacked around 6 P.M. outside the Catholic University Law School in Santiago after teaching a law school class.

headline: Ford Slashes Dividend As Bad Times Worsen
abstract: As worse news piled on top of bad in the automobile industry recently, the Ford Motor Company tried hard to hold its dividend steady, even as G.M. and Chrysler passed some of the pain along to shareholders. But Detroit's third shoe dropped today as Ford, saying business conditions were even tougher than those usually encountered when car sales are soft, cut its quarterly payout nearly in half.   Directors meeting at Ford headquarters in Dearborn, Mich., declared a second-quarter dividend of 40 cents a share, down from 75 cents, which had been paid since the first quarter of 1989. A dividend cut had been widely expected, and on the New York Stock Exchange today, Ford's shares were unchanged at $31.875.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Creditanstalt-Bankverein A.G., Vienna, named Max Kothbauer deputy chairman and deputy chief executive. * Eastman Kodak Co., Rochester, appointed Carl F. Kohrt company vice president.

headline: U.S. Won't Give Soviets Credits
abstract: President Bush said today that the United States was not ready to extend additional agricultural credits to the Soviet Union, because Moscow had "regrettably" not made sufficient market reforms.   Mr. Bush made his disclosure in a meeting with agricultural broadcasters. The Washington Post said that the Soviet Union unsuccessfully sought $1.5 billion in credits to purchase American grain but that White House officials said the United States would look for other ways to offer aid.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Companies    NCNB is negotiating to acquire C&S/Sovran Financial, a large Southeastern banking company, in a deal that could become the largest merger in national banking history.  [ Page A1. ]

headline: Research Venture For Cell Genesys
abstract: Cell Genesys Inc., a privately held biotechnology company based in Foster City, Calif., and J T Immunotech U.S.A., a subsidiary of Japan Tobacco Inc., entered an agreement under which J T will pay Cell Genesys up to $30 million for a minority stake and to finance research and development.

headline: Wall Street; A Spring of Catastrophes for Property Insurers
abstract: A disaster. That's what this year has been for property insurers. Industry numbers show that through April catastrophe damage from severe spring weather, mainly in the nation's midsection, was $1.35 billion -- compared with just $550 million in the corresponding season last year.   Property-damage claims tend to be paid quickly, said Myron M. Picoult, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Company, so this unsilent spring is going to hurt the industry's cash flow at a time when competition is restraining the premiums insurers can charge. Logic suggests that premiums will rise to reflect the higher losses, he said, but "the property-casualty industry has a way of defying logic."

headline: European Labor Law
abstract: Labor ministers of the European Community agreed on a law today that would make companies give workers a document detailing the terms and conditions of employment, officials said.

headline: Pricing Garbage To Reduce Waste
abstract: HOW much does it actually cost to haul away the trash? Many Americans do not know, because garbage-disposal fees are lumped in with other municipal services, like police and fire protection. As a result, there is little incentive to reduce the amount thrown out, despite the rising costs of disposal in much of the country.    Most approaches to dealing with the disposal of solid waste have been administrative and legislative. Some states now ban yard waste from landfills; others bar home appliances to conserve scarce space. Maine even banned the brick-shaped drink boxes popular with children on the ground that the boxes' paper-plastic-metal foil composition made them difficult to recycle.

headline: Cray Computer
abstract: Cray Research Inc. announced a new mid-priced supercomputer it said would make supercomputing more accessible. The Cray Y-MP4E will be available in May for about $7.3 million, about two-thirds as much as similar supercomputers, said John A. Rollwagen, chairman and chief executive of the Minneapolis-based company. Mr. Rollwagen said Cray was announcing the computer in Japan because it expected the computer would sell well here. Supercomputers are used for high-speed, repetitive and scientific calculations.

headline: People
abstract: * David Meador has been promoted to senior vice president and senior art director at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York, from vice president and senior art director. * Robert J. Clancy has joined Griswold Inc., Cleveland, as executive vice president and executive creative director. He had previously been vice president and associate creative director at McCann-Erickson New York. * Kathy M. Hyett has been named senior vice president and director of the consumer marketing, food, health-care and creative services group at Creamer Dickson Basford, New York. She had previously been senior vice president and group manager at Burson-Marstellar, New York.

headline: Leningrad or St. Petersburg?
abstract: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today denounced an effort to restore the name St. Petersburg to the city of Leningrad, saying such a change had no moral or political basis. A proposal to restore the city's old name is supported by the local government and is on the ballot as part of the June 12 elections for mayor and Russian Federation president.

headline: Business Technology; Satellite System Helps Trucks Stay in Touch
abstract: Until recently, some trucking companies used index cards to keep track of drivers and shipments. Between the times a trucker called in, he was virtually unreachable, his whereabouts at best a guess.    Now, more and more companies have found a way to stay in constant touch with their drivers, and check their locations automatically. About 15,000 trucks are linked to their headquarters through a communications system that bounces signals from a satellite. Industry experts expect the network to eventually include 300,000 trucks.

headline: P.& G. Paper Deal
abstract: Canadian Pacific Forest Products Ltd. agreed to sell its Facelle tissue business to the Canadian subsidiary of the Procter & Gamble Company for undisclosed terms. Under the agreement, which requires approval of Canadian Government authorities, Procter's Canadian unit will acquire all of the tissue business of the Canadian Pacific operation, including a manufacturing plant in Toronto and the Facelle franchise for facial and bathroom tissues and paper towels. Sales for those products totaled $170.5 million (Canadian) last year, or about $148 million (United States) at current exchange rates.

headline: American Express Has Concerns Over Ogilvy
abstract: With the departure from Ogilvy & Mather of several important executives on the American Express Company account, the company has expressed concern about the changes.   "We have a longstanding relationship with Ogilvy that is not up for review," an American Express spokesman said yesterday. "We are, however, very concerned with the loss of such talented people." Rumors about the state of Ogilvy's relationship with American Express, its largest client, have been circulating throughout the advertising community recently.

headline: CIT Group Notes
abstract: CIT Group Holdings Inc. yesterday priced $150 million in notes due in 1998 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The notes have an 8 3/4 percent coupon and are priced at 99.75, to yield 8.80 percent, or about 90 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. The underwriters said the notes were noncallable through maturity and were rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by Standard & Poor's.

headline: Kuwait Sentences 6 Journalists to Die as Collaborators
abstract: A martial law court today sentenced six defendants to death for collaborating with the enemy by working for Al Nida, the newspaper that Iraq published here during its occupation of Kuwait.   Pandemonium erupted as the five judges, two of them military officers, announced their verdict. Defendants and their friends and relatives cried out and wept as soldiers with automatic rifles shoved them out of the courtroom.

headline: Treasury Issues Sharply Higher
abstract: Interest rates plunged yesterday as prices of Treasury and other fixed-income securities soared in response to two moves by the Federal Reserve to reduce borrowing costs. The first was to cut the discount rate, which the Fed charges member commercial banks, to 5 1/2 percent from 6 percent.    The Fed's second and more important action was to flood the banking system with $3 billion of reserves. This caused the Federal funds rate, which banks charge one another for temporary loans, to drop to 5 3/4 percent from 6 percent. The funds rate is considered the basic cost of credit because most other interest rates are scaled upward from it. The rate is so termed because it is the interest rate most easily controlled by the Federal Reserve.

headline: PERSONAL ACCOUNT; Playwright, or Businessman?
abstract: Everyone knows that the really important part of business is done over lunch -- and involves a lawyer. And so it was that day in January 1989, shortly before "Other People's Money" was due to open Off Broadway, that I had lunch with a lawyer. As a businessman, new to the world of the theater, I wondered if I might have a libel problem.  Because I was writing about a contemporary phenomenon, the corporate takeover, I had used more than a few names of active raiders, not always in the most favorable light: Carl Icahn, Ronald Perelman, Saul Steinberg, T. Boone Pickens, the Bass brothers, the Belzbergs, Irwin Jacobs and Ivan Boesky. I also threw in the names of some investment banking firms including Morgan Stanley and Smith Barney.

headline: Rises Noted In Car Prices
abstract: Prices for 1991-model cars and trucks have been moving higher, with Mazda Motor of America raising prices three times, according to an automotive journal.   Automotive News said in Monday's issue that the new Mazda increase, an average of $168 a vehicle, followed increases of $312 in November and $40 in September.

headline: Send Al Sikes's Agenda to Capitol Hill
abstract: To the Editor:   "Al Sikes's Grand Agenda" (June 2) is really too much of an agenda for the Federal Communications Commission.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * A. B. Dick Co., a unit of General Electric Co. P.L.C., London, that provides graphic art supplies, named James L. Bast chief executive. He succeeds David Powell, who will continue to serve as a director of the parent company. * Baltimore Thermal Energy Corp., Baltimore, a subsidiary of United Thermal Corp. that provides steam systems, named Morris O. Hill president.

headline: Data Bank/May 12, 1991
abstract: Producer Price Index   April   March   Feb.        Finished goods, annual rate in percent   2.0   --3.9   --6.7        Consumer Credit   March   Feb.   Jan.        Percent change   --1.5   --0.3   --0.4       U.S. Productivity   I Q'91   IV Q'90   III Q'90        Percent change   1.0   0.3   0.6       Domestic Crude Oil   March   Feb.   Jan.        Thousands of barrels per day   7,552   7,501   7,370        Lumber    Feb.   Jan.   Dec.        Millions of board feet   3,374   3,534   2,917        Cash Wheat Price   May 10   May 3   April 27        No. 1 K.C., per bushel   $3.11   $3.00   $2.95        Auto Production   April   March   Feb.        In units    462,867   432,569   422,222        Freight Car Loadings   May 4   April 27   April 20        Billions of ton-miles   18.8   18.7   16.5

headline: A Correction: On Gorbachev Aid Plea for Billions
abstract: The New York Times and some other publications misunderstood a hypothetical reference by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in a news conference on Wednesday and mistakenly reported that he had made a specific request for $100 billion in aid from the West.   The Soviet leader did use the figure "100 billion" but only to argue that his country's economic salvation mattered as much as the costs of the Persian Gulf war.

headline: Big Bond Insurer Planning To Sell 11.5 Million Shares
abstract: MBIA Inc., which through its MBIA Corporation unit is one of the leading insurers of municipal bonds, said yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a secondary offering of 11.5 million common shares through underwriters led by the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.   The shares are held by MBIA Inc.'s owners, the Fund American Companies, the Cigna Corporation and the Aetna Casualty and Surety Company. Of the shares being offered, 9.5 million are exepected to be sold in the United States and Canada and the remainder internationally.

headline: Mutual Funds; For Direct-Sale Funds, a Rising Share
abstract: As competition in the mutual-fund industry intensifies, the market share of direct-marketed funds, which are mainly sold without sales charges, has steadily risen. Such funds are sold directly to investors, usually in advertising with toll-free numbers.   Some explain the growth by saying that investors are getting smarter, but others see it differently. For one thing, direct sellers have a bigger share of the growing market for 401(k) plans and other retirement accounts, says Joel M. Rosenthal of Strategic Insight, a fund research and consulting firm.

headline: 18 Reported Slain in Gang Strife at Mexican Prison
abstract: Anti-terrorist troops and riot police officers surrounded a state prison early today after a battle between rival drug gangs in which officials said 18 people were killed and five wounded.   Officials said the fighting at the Tamaulipas state prison, which is close to the United States border, began Friday night after a prisoner apparently tried to kill another inmate described as a Colombian drug lord. They said prisoners fought for three hours with guns, knives and firebombs.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * GFT USA Corp., New York, a subsidiary of Gruppo GFT, a maker of men's and women's apparel, named Colombe M. Nicholas president and chief operating officer of its Giorgio Armani Fashion Corp., a new post. * Jones Apparel Group, Bristol, Pa., named Andrew Grossman president, replacing Sidney Kimmel, who remains chairman and chief executive.

headline: Ames Stores Posts a Loss
abstract: Ames Department Stores Inc. reported a fourth-quarter loss today of $26.7 million. It was an improvement over the $198.9 million loss posted in the final quarter of 1989 by the discount retailer, which filed for bankruptcy protection in April 1990.   Net sales for the quarter that ended on Jan. 26 totaled $945.7 million, down 4.7 percent from 1989's adjusted net sales of $992.9 million. The 1989 figure excluded sales from 227 stores that were closed in a restructuring.

headline: More Self-Immolations in Seoul Protests
abstract: Tens of thousands of protesters poured into streets in cities across South Korea again today, clashing with the police in the fourth week of anti-Government protests.    Three more protesters set themselves afire, one fatally, as pressure mounted on President Roh Tae Woo to make concessions to quiet the streets.

headline: Assad and Mubarak Meet And Oppose Breakup of Iraq
abstract: In their first meeting since the end of the Persian Gulf war, the Presidents of Egypt and Syria said today that they were opposed to the splintering of Iraq, and they called for an international peace conference to resolve the Arab-Israeli conflict.    Neither the Egyptian leader, Hosni Mubarak, nor his Syrian counterpart, Hafez al-Assad, described their conversations, held here over two days, in any detail. But Arab diplomats said both nations were eager to stake out their positions as dominant Arab powers in postwar regional security.

headline: Seventeen's Success Invites Challenges
abstract: With its acquisition of Seventeen magazine, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company is gaining access to a huge and growing demographic market as well as one of the most profitable publications in Rupert Murdoch's portfolio.    Impressive though that may sound, information gleaned from confidential financial documents show that Seventeen is under pressure, mainly from its upstart competitor, Sassy. Although revenue rose to $47.9 million last year, from an estimated $45.5 million for 1989, profits contributed to the News Corporation were $9.7 million, down from $12.8 million, on an annualized basis.

headline: U.S. Wants Iraq to Finance Kurdish Relief Operations
abstract: The United States wants Iraq to pay for the American-led effort to help Kurdish refugees in the northern part of the country, senior Bush Administration officials said today.    Although the Administration is uncertain exactly how to require the Baghdad Government to finance the operation, which is expected to cost more than $500 million over six months, one option under consideration would link such payment to approval of Iraqi resumption of oil exports. Linkage would require the approval of the sanctions committee of the United Nations Security Council, which is setting the terms for lifting economic sanctions against Iraq.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   10.00        DISCOUNT RATE   5.50   5.50   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.89   5.99   7.00        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.46   5.46   7.75        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.62   5.65   7.67        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   7.90   7.92   8.62        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   8.28   8.28   8.58        TELEPHONE BONDS   9.32   9.32   9.69        MUNICIPAL BONDS**   7.22   7.22   7.53       *Estimated daily average, source Salomon Brothers **Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Toyota in Talks on Importing VW's and Audis to Japan
abstract: Facing growing political pressure from Europe, the Toyota Motor Company said today that it was negotiating with Volkswagen to market VW and Audi cars here, and said it was holding informal conversations with other car makers about importing their models as well.    If the two companies reach agreement, as seems likely, it would make Japan's largest auto maker into one of its largest importers as well. In the past, Toyota has staunchly refused to carry competing makes in its huge number of dealerships here, but company officials are increasingly concerned that Toyota might face exclusion from Europe's most lucrative markets if it does not form some close alliances.

headline: Need Is Seen Approaching For Health-Care Rationing
abstract: A new study by Tufts University economists says that employers and the Federal Government have virtually run out of ammunition in their battle to slow the growth of spending for health care.    "We are running out of ways to make savings and approaching the point where we will have to ration health care," said William B. Schwartz, a professor of medicine and a medical economist at Tufts.

headline: Chemical Sensor Uses Fiber Optics
abstract: Using fiber optics, researchers at the University of New Hampshire patented a chemical sensor this week that they say makes it easier to detect leaks in oil pipelines and to monitor processes ranging from beer brewing to drug production.    The most common sensors today employ chemically coated electrodes that react with particular substances and produce a measurable charge. Other approaches analyze the way a sample of material absorbs or deflects light. Although accurate, these sensors sometimes pose practical limitations: Electrodes buried with underground pipelines can be harmed by rust or the elements, and analyzing light diffraction requires isolating a sample for inspection.

headline: People
abstract: * Marianne Bess has been promoted to senior vice president at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, New York, from vice president. * Raymond L. Kotcher has been named to the board of directors of Ketchum Communications, where he is executive vice president and chief of United States operations of Ketchum Public Relations. Also, Paul Capelli has joined Ketchum Public Relations in Chicago; he previously was corporate communications manager at Backer Spielvogel Bates Inc., New York. * Kelly M. Shipp was appointed senior vice president of the public affairs group at Edelman Public Relations, Washington, from press secretary at the Department of Agriculture.

headline: Managing; Gay Rights, Issue of the 90's
abstract: The Xerox Corporation has a new policy prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.   The American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has designated a week in June as Gay Awareness Week.

headline: Shift in Command Made At K Mart of Canada
abstract: Donald A. Beaumont yesterday was appointed president and chief executive officer of K Mart Canada Ltd., a subsidiary of the K Mart Corporation, the third-largest American retailer. The appointment of the 56-year-old Mr. Beaumont, a Canadian, returns the subsidiary to the supervision of a Canadian for the first time since 1988.   Mr. Beaumont succeeds Keith R. Costine, 50, an American who has been with K Mart Canada since 1987, the last two years as its president and chief executive officer. Three times before Mr. Costine's appointment as the Canadian chief, K Mart named Canadians to supervise that subsidiary. Mr. Costine is being reassigned within the corporation. A K Mart spokeswoman, Jan Potter, said that the company traditionally reassigned its Canadian chiefs after several years.

headline: Money Market Funds Post Mixed Yields for the Week
abstract: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week that ended yesterday.    Analysts at IBC/Donoghue's say short-term interest rates are still coming down, but if economic indicators show that the recession is near its end, expect money market yields to settle near their present levels since the Federal Reserve may not lower interest rates further.

headline: Economic Scene; Car Wars: More Bad News
abstract: HAVE you driven a Ford (or a Chrysler or a G.M. car) lately? As Detroit learned in the 1980's, a customer lost to Japanese car makers is often lost for good.    But according to Fred Mannering and Clifford Winston, that is only the beginning of the bad news, not the end. American auto companies may finally be making cars that are attractive to owners of foreign cars. But the gap in brand loyalty between American and Japanese makes, the researchers conclude, virtually guarantees that the Detroit auto makers will continue to lose sales to their Japanese rivals.

headline: Tax-Exempt Issue Is Priced by Utility
abstract: A $177 million bond offering by the Modesto-Santa Clara-Redding Public Power Agency was priced yesterday for a maximum yield of 6.87 percent, for a bond due 2017.   Underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc. said shorter maturities were priced to yield from 5.70 percent in 1996 to 6.70 percent in 2005, and longer maturities were priced to yield 6.84 percent in 2011 and 6.81 percent for bonds due 2022.   The tax-exempt bonds are insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corporation, which covers interest and principal payments, giving the bonds a rating of Aaa by Moody's and AAA by Standard & Poor's.

headline: Turks Angry as Kurd Aid Backfires
abstract: To many Turks, whose country was chief benefactor for a long while to half a million fleeing Iraqis, the Kurdish refugee crisis has reinforced widely held resentments that they are not liked abroad and may well never be.   Whatever the ultimate fate of the Iraqi Kurds, their exodus has already proved to be a diplomatic debacle for Turkey.

headline: Sallie Mae Prices Short-Term Notes
abstract: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, yesterday priced $650 million in short-term floating-rate notes due Nov. 14, 1991, at a price of 100 through various securities dealers.    Sallie Mae usually issues such securities each month. The agency said the notes would float at 17.5 basis points above the bond-equivalent yield of the 91-day Treasury bill auction rate. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

headline: Great American
abstract: The Great American Bank said it was still not in compliance with its federally approved capital plan because of a first-quarter loss of $46.8 million. Great American said its noncompliance was a violation of an Office of Thrift Supervision order and could result in the appointment of a conservator or receiver, though Federal regulators had not yet taken any action. Great American said that although it expected to complete two transactions with Wells Fargo & Company that would result in a pretax gain of about $86.8 million, it would still fall short of compliance.

headline: Newspaper Executives Say It's Bad All Over
abstract: From the Times Mirror Company in Los Angeles to Knight-Ridder Inc. in Miami, executives from 15 newspaper companies who spoke at a two-day conference that ended here today told tales of lower advertising, revenues and earnings in the first quarter of 1991, after a dismal 1990.   For months, many executives had hoped that a boom in consumer confidence after the Persian Gulf war would end the advertising slump.

headline: Gorbachev's Tokyo Miscalculation
abstract: Only a week ago, as Mikhail S. Gorbachev headed here during the first visit of a Soviet leader to Japan, it seemed as if he might be on the verge of the deal of the Pacific century: an open spigot of Japanese investment and technology in return for a solution to the territorial dispute that has plagued relations between Tokyo and Moscow for four decades.    But as Mr. Gorbachev and his entourage of deal makers left here late Friday after meeting with some of Japan's most powerful industrialists, it became clear that far more than just the return of the Kurile islands is blocking Mr. Gorbachev's access to billions of dollars of help from Japan.

headline: Notes and Bonds Narrowly Mixed
abstract: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in quiet trading yesterday, as dealers began to prepare for a huge supply of new short-term securities.   This week the Treasury will sell $37.5 billion worth of new two-year and five-year notes as well as a 335-day cash management bill.

headline: Europeans Reach Accord On Sales Tax
abstract: Members of the European Community tentatively agreed today on a minimum national sales tax, temporarily ending differences that threatened to delay the creation of a single market at the end of 1992.   Britain had opposed any legally binding agreement to set the minimum standard for the value-added tax at 15 percent, effective on Jan. 1, 1993.

headline: Grand Jury Indicts El Paso Electric
abstract: The El Paso Electric Company, the largest provider of electricity in El Paso and the Rio Grande Valley of South Texas, was indicted by a state grand jury on charges of defrauding investors through its ties to a financial company that collapsed in 1987. The charges relate to the utility's involvement with a financial empire once controlled by an El Paso executive, Maury Page Kemp. The utility invested $96 million in annuities, most of which were secured by Treasury bills and other assets, that were sold by two insurance companies owned by Mr. Kemp from 1984 to 1986.

headline: Marlboro Plans 'Mediums' to Stem the Brand's Decline
abstract: Philip Morris, trying to stem the slow decline of its best-selling cigarette, plans to introduce a version of Marlboro called Marlboro Medium that has tar and nicotine levels between those of the regular and light versions.   The new cigarette is intended to slow the defection of Marlboro's own smokers. Marlboro continues to sell strongly in a declining industry and its rich profits helped finance the acquisition in the 1980's of General Foods and Kraft, which made the Philip Morris Companies the world's largest consumer-products company.

headline: Government to Suspend U S Sprint's Navy Contract
abstract: The General Services Administration dealt a setback to the U S Sprint Communications Company today, agreeing to put on hold a contract for it to provide a new, high-technology telephone system to the Navy.   Richard Austin, the head of the General Services Administration, agreed to suspend the contract for long-distance service at a meeting with Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan and chairman of the House Committee on Government Operations. Mr. Conyers has led a push for a rebalancing of the Government's telephone business between its two big long-distance providers, Sprint and A.T.& T.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * National Spa and Pool Institute, Alexandria, Va., a group that represents 4,500 manufacturers and suppliers, to Solin Associates Inc., New York. Billings are about $1 million.

headline: Dow Drops by 7.38; Loss for Week at 33.54
abstract: A late flurry of selling pushed the stock market into the minus column yesterday in a relatively active session.    As measured by the Dow Jones industrial average, the market closed down 7.38, at 2,886.63. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 largely blue-chip issues rose 0.20, to 372.39. For the week, the Dow lost 33.54, and the S.& P. index was off 3.35.

headline: Brave New TV World: 300 Channels
abstract: Advances in video technology are likely to transform the television landscape over the next several years, expanding the number of channels available on cable systems to as many as 300 from an average of 33 today.    The abundance of channels will affect the broadcast networks, the cable networks, the advertising industry, the audience-measurement business and even the companies that publish television listings.

headline: Toolmaker Acquiring Big Rival
abstract: In a move that will create the nation's largest machine tool producer, Giddings & Lewis Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Cross & Trecker Corporation. Giddings is known principally for its development of flexible manufacturing systems, while the larger Cross & Trecker is now the nation's third-largest maker of machine tools.   The combination will create a formidable machine tool producer that executives say can capitalize on what many in the industry consider to be brighter prospects in European markets and in future years in the automotive industry. The transaction, valued at $225 million, would push the combined company ahead of Litton Industries and Cincinnati Milacron Inc., now ranked first and second. Better Position Abroad     The acquisition, agreed to on Friday, will stretch the reach of Giddings & Lewis, which is based in Fond du Lac, Wis., into Europe and give it a stronger foothold in the American automobile market.

headline: New York Takes Over Big Insurer
abstract: New York State insurance regulators yesterday seized control of the Executive Life Insurance Company of New York, the New York unit of the First Executive Corporation.   Salvatore R. Curiale, New York's superintendent of insurance, said the move had been taken after worried policyholders rushed to cash in their policies, threatening the company's financial health. At a news conference yesterday, Mr. Curiale said he was indefinitely suspending all policy surrenders, the procedure for policyholders to withdraw their funds quickly.

headline: Chip Maker's New President
abstract: Micron Technology Inc., a maker of computer memory chips based in Boise, Idaho, appointed a new president and chief operating officer today in a reorganization aimed at strengthening the company's research and development and manufacturing efforts.    Steven R. Appleton, the vice president of manufacturing, was named to the posts, as well as to a directorship of the semiconductor company.

headline: Ethiopia Peace Talks Planned
abstract: The Ethiopian Government and the three rebel groups fighting to unseat it have agreed to sit down together with the United States later this month for their first peace talks, officials said today. The peace conference, to be led by Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen, will be held in London in about two weeks, the officials said. It will focus on ending the civil war in Ethiopia, one of the world's poorest countries. The war has been raging in some areas of the country for 30 years.

headline: OPEC Expected to Shun Divisive Output Issues
abstract: Because little in their production picture is likely to change this year, the oil ministers of OPEC are expected to sidestep difficult output issues this week at their first full-fledged gathering since the end of the Persian Gulf war.    The ministers appear united in their belief that neither Kuwait nor Iraq, two key members of the organization, will be able to resume oil exports before the end of the year.

headline: Stocks Plunge in Tokyo
abstract: Prices fell sharply on the Tokyo Stock Exchange today on higher interest rates and the dollar's continued strength.   The Nikkei average of 225 issues plunged 688.72 points, or 2.79 percent, to close at 23,996.75. On Tuesday, the index fell 257.62 points.

headline: Tokyo Agrees to Pay Off Shortfall in Gulf War Aid
abstract: In the midst of a week of tough trade negotiations, Japanese officials said today that they had decided to defuse one simmering dispute with the United States by agreeing to pay about $500 million in assistance to the Persian Gulf to make up for a shortfall in Japan's previously announced $9 billion contribution.   Although the amount is modest by world trade standards, the dispute had become increasingly bitter. Vice President Dan Quayle, who is visiting Japan, made an appeal to Toshiki Kaifu, the Japanese Prime Minister, to resolve the issue, and he publicly urged the Japanese today at a news conference to make the payment.

headline: Company News; Upjohn to Pay $600,000 Fine
abstract: The Upjohn Company will pay a record $600,000 fine and change the way it markets drugs after allegations that the pharmaceutical giant kept poor records of samples given to physicians, Federal prosecutors said today.    Riley J. Atkins, an assistant United States attorney, said the settlement would be the largest ever collected under the 1971 Federal Controlled Substances Act. He said investigators from the Drug Enforcement Administration had documented record-keeping problems involving samples of the drugs Xanax and Halcion in Oregon, Florida, Ohio, Michigan and Puerto Rico.

headline: Powell Sees Early Return of Troops in Gulf
abstract: Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, toured the Turkey-Iraq border area today and said he hoped American troops could be withdrawn from the region "more rapidly than we had expected or could have anticipated a few weeks ago."   "I think we are over the hump, and we're making great progress," the General told reporters at the allied base in Sarsang.

headline: Triborough Issue
abstract: About $348 million in Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority general purpose serial revenue bonds have begun trading, according to the underwriter, Goldman, Sachs & Company. The bond with the nearest maturity, Jan. 1, 1992, carries a coupon of 5.25 percent and was priced at 100.274. One of the longest bonds, the one that matures Jan. 1, 2020, bears a 7 pecent coupon and was priced at 97.25, to yield 7.229 percent, slightly less than the 7.24 percent average yield of other municipal bonds.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Procter & Gamble Company, Cincinnnati, to Burrell Advertising Inc., Chicago, for advertising aimed at black consumers for Tide detergent. Burrell, which creates ads aimed at black consumers for P.&G.'s Crest and Crisco brands, has worked on Tide projects. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: Stocks Rise After Report on Dip in Inflation
abstract: The stock market ended the week on a strong note yesterday, with three leading indexes posting records. Investors were heartened by the first decline in the Consumer Price Index in five years, which renewed hopes that the Federal Reserve would reduce interest rates soon.    The hopes were bolstered by a strong bond market, which sent long-term interest rates tumbling. But for the second day the Fed chose to prop up short-term rates by draining reserves from the banking system.

headline: Data Bank/May 19, 1991
abstract: Industrial Production Index   April   March   Feb.        Monthly percent change   0.1   --0.6   --0.8        Capacity Utilization                Output as a percentage of capacity   78.3   78.5   79.1       Consumer Price Index                Monthly percent change   0.2   --0.1   0.2       Sales at Retail Outlets                Monthly percent change   --0.1   0.4   2.2        Housing Starts                Thousands of units, annual rate   957   901   989        Business Inventories   March   Feb.   Jan.        Monthly percent change   --0.8   --0.2   0.5        Merchandise Exports                In billions    $33.9   $33.5   $34.3        Merchandise Imports                In billions    $38.0   $39.1   $41.5

headline: Gap Finds Middle Road to Success
abstract: The Gap Inc., which became a successful chain in the early 80's with casual clothing like unisex jeans, T-shirts and denim jackets, is doing even better in the 90's by separating the sexes and widening its appeal.   The Gap still sells jeans but has added a broader assortment and greater range of colors in clothing like blouses and dresses. In doing so, the company took a risk that it could keep its regular customers and add new ones.

headline: The Pains Are Sharp In Hungary
abstract: Like other Hungarian companies doing business with the Soviet Union, BEAG, a small concern that produces audio systems and recording equipment, was braced for bad news this year. But it was not prepared for the disaster that struck in January when the Soviet Union's state television and radio system suddenly canceled its contract, saying it had no money.    Without its Soviet contract, which produced 60 percent of its sales, BEAG had no choice but to declare bankruptcy, making it the 150th company to do so this year in Budapest Metropolitan Court.

headline: Long-Quiet Japanese Volcano Erupts With Fury
abstract: A volcano in southern Japan erupted late Monday, setting houses and forests aflame and raining superheated rocks on small villages.    Two people were confirmed dead, 31 people were missing and more than 20 people were burned, many of them critically, the authorities said.

headline: Video Game Uncovered in Europe Uses Nazi Death Camps as Theme
abstract: A home video game circulating in Austria and Germany puts the player in the role of a commandant of a Nazi death camp earning points for gassing prisoners and selling gold fillings, a Holocaust study center says.   The game, "KZ Manager," and about 140 others with titles like "Aryan Test" include graphics of swastikas, Hitler, and of gassed and tortured prisoners, the Simon Wiesenthal Center said. "KZ" is shorthand for the German word for concentration camp.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Ford Motor Co., Dearborn, Mich., to Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide for its Eastern European business. The agency won out over Young & Rubicam for the account, for which billings were not disclosed. O.& M. handles other Ford business overseas.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Economy    The F.C.C. proposed a rule to force local telephone companies to let rivals plug directly into their systems. The plan would be a big help for the growing number of companies that have built the high-speed fiber optic lines that by-pass the conventional telephone system and reduce the long-distance access charges.  [ Page D1. ]

headline: Germany Records a Deficit
abstract: Germany reported a large gap in its balance of payments for the second consecutive month today, a result of the difficulties of unification and the costs of the Persian Gulf war.    The Government said the balance of payments showed a deficit of 1.7 billion marks, about $1 billion, in February. It also issued a revised January deficit of 2.1 billion marks, or $1.24 billion, the worst monthly deficit in eight years.

headline: Lumber Output Down
abstract: Lumber production and shipments fell in 12 Western states last week, but orders increased, a trade association reported. The Western Wood Products Association said that lumber production was 403 million board feet in the week, 8 million less than in the previous week. But orders were 463 million board feet, 45 million more than in the previous week. Shipments were reported at 392 million feet, a decline of 50 million feet.

headline: Nigeria's Experiment -- A special report.; Marching to Military's Cadence, Nigeria Moves Back to Democracy
abstract: Four years ago, when Nigeria's military strongman made public an elaborate plan for returning the military to the barracks and leaving the task of governing to civilians, many Nigerians reacted with a mixture of cynicism and incredulity.   They recalled with bitterness Nigeria's dismal experience so far with democracy: soldiers have run the country for all but nine years since it won independence from Britain in 1960. There have been seven coups and three of the nation's eight leaders have been assassinated. Two brief periods of civilian rule collapsed amid allegations of incompetence and endemic corruption, a situation made still worse by deepening hatred between rival faiths and ethnic groups. Military Sets Rules     But Nigeria's leader, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, appears to have taken an utterly unpromising political situation and deftly turned it to his advantage, without sacrificing control of the process.

headline: Bank Funds And C.D.'s Drop Again
abstract: Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts were down for the week ended yesterday, extending a three-and-a-half-month slide.   At the Treasury Department's weekly auction on Monday, however, average discount rates moved up again for the second consecutive week to their highest levels in more than a month.

headline: Pretoria Panel to Study Issue of Blacks' Lost Land
abstract: Under pressure to do more for the blacks who were dispossessed in the name of apartheid, the Government today announced the creation of an advisory commission on land issues to consider appeals from those who want to return home.    The Government also said it was scaling back another proposed bill that would let neighborhoods set their own norms and standards after residential segregation ends. The bill had been criticized as providing opportunities for whites to keep blacks out of their neighborhoods on pretexts like overcrowding or noise pollution.

headline: South Korea Softens a Tough Security Law
abstract: In an effort to quell the protests that have disrupted the country all week, Parliament relaxed the country's strict national security law today. But tonight a fifth protester set himself on fire in a protest against the Government of President Roh Tae Woo.    The actions came as an uneasy peace settled over Seoul, after some of the worst battles with the police in four years. More protests, which were set off by the beating death of a student by the police three weeks ago, are expected through the weekend.

headline: Housing Starts Fell 9% in March
abstract: In reports suggesting that the recession could linger beyond midyear, the Government said today that the pace at which builders broke ground for new homes fell 9 percent in March while production of the nation's factories, mines and utilities fell three-tenths of a percent.   Private analysts generally took a dim view of the reports, despite a 2.4 percent increase in housing permits, the second straight monthly rise.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Archer Communications Inc., Calgary, Alberta, a sound enhancement technology company, named Robert B. Pfannkuch president and chief executive. * Bell Canada, Montreal, a subsidiary of BCE Inc., appointed Jean C. Monty chairman and chief executive and Robert Kearney president and chief operating officer.

headline: MGM-Pathe Gets Settlement
abstract: A Federal judge today approved a settlement between the MGM-Pathe Communications Company and creditors who tried to force the movie studio into bankruptcy.    The agreement, which calls for full payment of the creditors' $15 million in claims, also clears the way for a $145 million loan to the struggling studio from Credit Lyonnais, the European banking giant that is MGM-Pathe's chief lender.

headline: Semiconductor Accord With Japan Still Elusive
abstract: United States and Japanese trade negotiators met through the weekend in Washington but failed to arrive at a new semiconductor trade agreement between the two nations. Negotiations will resume on Friday in Tokyo.   "We think we had a fair amount of progress," Don Phillips, assistant United States trade representative for industry, said yesterday. But, he added, "there are still some specific issues dividing us."

headline: Punjab Campaigns to Resume In an Election Steeped in Fear
abstract: In Punjab, the only state in India where secession is a major campaign theme, politicians are beginning a delayed election race steeped in fear but determined not to be left out of the democratic process.   At stake is not only representation in Parliament but also the revival of state government after four violent years of central-Government rule.

headline: Indicators Are Up 0.5% In 2d Consecutive Rise
abstract: Sending an ambiguous message about the economy, the Government's principal forecasting index rose for the second straight month in March although most of its components fell.   The index of leading indicators rose five-tenths of 1 percent, after a 1.2 percent gain in February. The March increase was entirely caused by a surge in consumer expectations after the Persian Gulf war, but subsequent surveys have shown that that jump in confidence is ebbing.

headline: Market Place; America West's Fight to Survive
abstract: FOR most of this year America West has been trying to avoid a filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. To cope with its financial crisis, caused largely by the falloff in traffic and the high fuel prices that resulted from the Persian Gulf war, the airline has already cut salaries, reduced service to marginal cities and suspended payments on its aircraft leases.    Now more Draconian measures are being considered, including layoffs and more wage cuts and freezes.

headline: New England Bank Failures
abstract: Banks will continue to fail in New England for the next year, and their assets may equal those of banks that have already failed, a top official of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston said.   "Banking in New England is still in a pretty sad state of disrepair," Thomas Cimeno, senior vice president of the Boston Fed, said on Thursday. "You could easily have enough bank failures to equal in size of assets what we've already had."

headline: Bush's Banking Plan Still Faces Obstacles
abstract: Despite a significant political victory last week, the Bush Administration's ambitious plan to reorganize the banking industry still faces a long and bumpy road in Congress.    On Thursday, the House Banking Committee's Subcommittee on Financial Institutions agreed to move the bill to the full committee, providing the White House its first legislative victory on this front.

headline: Patents; An Electric Blanket for Premature Babies
abstract: William C. McCormack, a retired pediatrician in Ames, Iowa, this week patented an electrical blanket for premature infants.    Although premature babies are kept in incubators, they can become cold when nurses change intravenous tubes or other attachments.

headline: New Ladenburg Team To Focus on Banking
abstract: While legislators and lobbyists in Washington are working on broad-based legislation that would change the banking industry, financiers on Wall Street are rubbing their hands in anticipation of the transactions they expect will soon follow.    To prepare for the anticipated wave of financings, Kenneth L. Rilander, a 42-year-old executive from Paine Webber Inc., has assembled a team of traders and investment bankers who will operate as a "boutique" within the New York securities firm Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company. "I'll spend more time doing deals and less time on administrative and managerial duties," said Mr. Rilander, who was on the board at Paine Webber and was head of its financial institutions investment banking group.

headline: Stocks Tumble, With Dow Falling by 35.40
abstract: Propelled by exceptionally heavy program selling, stocks dropped sharply yesterday in the slowest trading in three weeks.    The Fed also drained money from the banking system to show it had no current plans to cut interest rates, dragging bonds down and taking stocks with them.

headline: U.S. Sees End of Slide In Housing
abstract: The housing slump appears to have bottomed out in much of the nation, the Government reported today.   In the latest sign that sales and values have picked up from a low point at the beginning of the year, a new survey of bank examiners and liquidators shows that residential real estate improved over the last six months in the West, the South and the Midwest. The survey found that even in the Northeast, which is reeling from overexpansion in housing and commercial real estate, more officials saw an improvement than further deterioration.

headline: ETHIOPIAN CAPITAL IN REBELS' HANDS
abstract: Rebels established full control over Addis Ababa today with a display of great firepower and discipline, but the dearth of visible demonstrations of support for the rebels suggested that many citizens in the capital were wary of their new rulers.    The three main Ethiopian rebel groups agreed in London today to meet no later than July 1 to form a transitional government. Meanwhile, the Tigrean-dominated forces now in Addis Ababa are to run the capital and exercise "state responsibility."  [ Page A6. ]

headline: McCann Yugoslav Unit In Training Program
abstract: Jadran McCann-Erickson, the Yugoslav agency of McCann-Erickson Worldwide, has set up a training program for students at the University of Zagreb in northern Yugoslavia.   The agency will accept five students, and two will be offered permanent jobs as account, media or research assistants. The students will study the agency's daily operation, undertake research assignments and spend a brief time in one of McCann's agencies in Western Europe, said Konrad Von Viereck, McCann's area manager for Eastern and Southeastern Europe.   "In Yugoslavia, as well as the other former Communist countries, marketing and advertising are unknown subjects," Mr. Von Viereck said. "We thought it might be a good idea to invest something to build up our own people."

headline: Judge Hears Phone Case Arguments
abstract: Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene today appeared to resist the notion that he should defer to the Justice Department on whether to lift restrictions that currently bar the regional Bell telephone companies from owning information services.   In oral arguments in the case, however, Judge Greene gave little clear indication of how he would eventually rule.

headline: American's Killing in Guatemala Hurts Drug Fight
abstract: Washington's hopes of enlisting Guatemala in its fight against cocaine trafficking rest on the resolution of a murder case involving an American innkeeper reportedly slain by Guatemalan troops, Bush Administration officials say.    The killing of the American, Michael DeVine, who was found June 9 along a jungle road with his hands tied and his head partly severed, has become the defining point in relations between Washington and Guatemala City.    The Administration cut off its $3.3 million annual military aid program in December to protest the army's refusal to interrogate two ranking officers implicated in the case.   Senior State Department officials said the new President, Jorge Serrano Elias, had made important strides in bringing the case to trial in the last few weeks. They cautiously expressed the hope that prosecutions of officers in the killing would open the way for the United States to enlist the Guatemalan Army in a coordinated effort to interdict cocaine flown from Colombia.   Melvyn Levitsky, the Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotics Matters, said Mexico had become so successful in interdicting cocaine flights over the last six months that many traffickers now land in Guatemala. From there, they either refuel or unload to ship their drugs by land through Mexico into the United States.    A senior State Department official said American military Awacs surveillance aircraft that fly over the Caribbean and the Pacific could share information on drug flights with the Guatemalan Army, which could then carry troops in helicopters to the landing sites. In turn, he said United States officials could benefit from information collected by the army's spy network to identify clandestine landing strips and opium poppy fields.   The United States has reported in recent years that Guatemala had became a major producer of opium poppies. An aerial eradication campaign in which the law enforcement officials of the two nations cooperated destroyed most of the crop in 1990, the State Department says.    "Until we have a military relationship again, we are hindered in our ability to help them in their drug effort," Mr. Levitsky said. "The DeVine case is one of the major impediments to full cooperation."   Officials in the State and Defense Departments are divided over whether the United States should cooperate with the Guatemalan Army, given the persistent allegations that it has directed death-squad activities.   Mr. DeVine, who was 49 years old and from Belleville, Ill., and his wife, Carol, had lived in Guatemala for almost 20 years.   After her husband was killed, Mrs. DeVine hired an American private investigator who found witnesses who said they had seen five soldiers and one peasant driving in the white pickup truck reportedly used as the getaway vehicle. The investigator said he had found that the truck belonged to the army base at the nearby town of Flores. The vehicle was found back at the barracks, repainted red, he said.   No motive has been established in the killing, although a United States Senate aide monitoring the case has speculated that Mr. DeVine might have come across a poppy field protected by the army on one of his hiking trips.    The case appeared to be stalled until last month, when the five soldiers -- who were identified and have been held since October -- volunteered to give depositions in which they declared their innocence but implicated two officers and seven other soldiers.    United States officials said the depositions say the soldiers either overheard the nine new suspects preparing for the crime, or saw them leaving the base to commit the killing.    A military judge has ordered that the two officers named in the depositions be compelled to testify.    A State Department official credited President Serrano with following up on the depositions by transfering judicial proceedings from remote Peten Province to the capital, "presumably to permit enhanced scrutiny."    A Guatemalan official who is monitoring the case said, "We are committed to getting to the bottom of this."

headline: Fannie Mae Tie To London Rate
abstract: The Federal National Mortgage Association said yesterday that it had begun to issue mortgage-backed securities tied to the London interbank offered rate, the rate used by major London banks as the basis for short-term borrowings in the international and domestic capital markets. The Fannie Mae securities are backed by adjustable-rate mortgages.    James A. Johnson, Fannie Mae's chief executive officer, said the issuance of the Libor-adjustable-rate security was another step in the corporation's effort to provide attractive products for overseas investors. To date 15 percent of Fannie Mae's mortgage-backed securities has been going to overseas investors.

headline: Dow Rises 42.33; Closes At 2,930.20
abstract: Wall Street got back on track yesterday, lifting stocks sharply in heavy trading. Most of the buying, though, came from small investors, not big institutions, which were selling while the others were buying.    "There was lots and lots of good news," said Hugh Johnson, chief economist at the First Albany Corporation.

headline: Advance in CD's Starts a New Battle
abstract: When the compact disk emerged from the laboratory as a consumer product in the mid-1980's, recording companies hated it. It would confuse consumers and ruin the recording business, they said. Today, records are indeed near extinction, but the recording business has doubled since CD's, with their scratch-free, hiss-free digital clarity, went on sale eight years ago.   Now the battle is about to be fought again -- this time over compact disks that record. The industry is choosing sides over a new technology called MD, for mini disk, a variant of the compact disk that the Sony Corporation is betting will make its own Walkman obsolete.

headline: Kurds on Turkey Border Scramble for the Basics
abstract: As if the Iraqi Kurds had not been punished enough, the heavens deepened their misery today with a pounding, cold rain.   That, they said with shrugs, was the least of their worries.

headline: GULAG STILL OPEN, FREED INMATE SAYS
abstract: A newly released inmate of the infamous Perm Labor Camp 35 has contradicted the Soviet authorities' insistence that the detention center for political dissidents has been closed.    Maksim Ivanov, an inmate for eight years in the Ural Mountains labor camp that was notorious as a gulag for outspoken Government critics, said that 16 dissidents remain in the camp, including two recent arrivals whose offenses should be classified as political, not criminal. He spoke in an interview on Thursday, a week after his release.

headline: Young Kurd Survives and Wonders What For
abstract: Burhan said he was 13 years old in 1974 when Iraqi warplanes destroyed his hometown of Halabja, Iraq, sending him and thousands of other Kurds fleeing down a looping mountain road to the safety of Iran, 11 miles distant.    In 1988, he said, Iraqi troops doused Halabja with mustard and cyanide gas and then leveled the town with aerial bombs. More than 5,000 reportedly died. "They killed my father and one brother from chemicals," he said. He took his mother down the looping road with 40,000 other refugees to Iran, determined never to return.

headline: Commons Votes Pit Bull Bill
abstract: A Government bill requiring American pit bull terriers and Japanese tosas to be neutered or destroyed after Nov. 30 was approved early today by the House of Commons and sent to the House of Lords, where approval is expected later this year.

headline: Shearson Is Paying $750,000 To Settle With Big Board
abstract: Shearson Lehman Brothers has agreed to pay $750,000 to the New York Stock Exchange to settle accusations of wide-ranging violations of the exchange's rules at one of the brokerage firm's most profitable branches.   In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Shearson said it had agreed to settle a variety of charges about improper practices at a Manhattan office, known as the Water Street branch, without admitting or denying guilt. The charges concern activities that occurred in 1986, when the market was booming.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * BBDO Chicago, in pursuit of the $19 million Illinois Lottery account, has formed a partnership with Michael Jones & Company, a marketing promotion firm specializing in lotteries. Mr. Jones, the company's president, was superintendent of the Illinois Lottery from 1981 to 1985 and has provided consulting services for nine other state lotteries.

headline: Copeland Forced Into Chapter 11
abstract: Creditors owed nearly $400 million have forced the owner of Popeye's Famous Fried Chicken and Church's Fried Chicken into bankruptcy proceedings. The creditors, led by the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and Merrill Lynch & Company, filed an involuntary Chapter 11 petition Thursday against Al Copeland Enterprises Inc. The action follows six months of negotiations between Mr. Copeland and the creditors. The Toronto-based Canadian Imperial Bank lent Mr. Copeland $249 million and Merrill Lynch lent him $142 million to acquire Church's in 1989.

headline: Wall Street; Protecting Limited Partners . . . Against Too-Slim Returns
abstract: Of all the properties managed these days by VMS Realty Partners, a troubled Chicago real estate syndicator, and its affiliates, the Boca Raton Hotel and Resort is thought to be the healthiest.    That is why limited partners like Eggert Dagson do not want to see it go on the block in a soft market just to help VMS, as the general partner, settle some debts. By his calculations, the property might fetch $230 million from a sale. VMS would then extract $63.6 million in upfront fees, while the limited partners would receive a mere $32.4 million of their original $50 million investment, after debts are repaid. What is more, the limited partners would need to use some of their proceeds to pay taxes triggered by the sale.

headline: Ireland's Easter: Amid Grieving, Hope's Renewal
abstract: More death has come to Northern Ireland along with the resurrection of hope this season, and so on Easter Sunday today, the Roman Catholic people of this little town had to bury three more victims of sectarian killing.    Some said they had hoped to be spared such rituals now that most of the political parties of Northern Ireland's sorely divided Catholics and Protestants are about to start the most serious talks on reconciliation in 20 years. Few really believed that they would be.

headline: Seoul Aches From 3d Day of Protests and Tear Gas
abstract: Demonstrators, tear gas and violence filled several neighborhoods of the capital today for the third day in a row as protests over the beating death of a student by the police last week turned the ralies that usually begin at this time into the largest in several years.    A May Day rally by students and some workers spilled from several university campuses into the streets here tonight, leading to a series of violent confrontations between 4,000 riot police officers and about 20,000 protesters.

headline: Prices of U.S. Issues Little Changed
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in light trading yesterday, momentarily stemming last week's steep slide.   To some traders, the lack of activity came as something of a surprise, given the sea change in market perceptions wrought by economic data that strongly suggest the recession is about over.

headline: A Modest Start for After-Hours Sessions
abstract: In the New York Stock Exchange's first sessions of after-hours trading yesterday, about 2.24 million shares changed hands in what exchange officials described as a small step toward 24-hour trading.   The two sessions saw both institutional and retail participation, with most of the shares traded during a session set up for program traders. Indeed, the reason the Big Board began the late sessions was to recapture business it was losing overseas, particularly program-trading business done on the London International Stock Exchange after the close in New York.

headline: Chip Technology's Friendly Rivals
abstract: It is one of the computer industry's nastiest rivalries, fraught with name-calling and accusations. The winners could well make the chip that will come to dominate the business.    On one side stands a group of companies led by MIPS Computer Inc. and inspired by John L. Hennessy, a computer scientist at Stanford. On the other side, a band of companies, led by Sun Microsystems Inc., that follow David A. Patterson, a computer scientist at Berkeley. Each group has its own chip, and each denounces the rival design as inadequate.

headline: Dow Gains 2.78 on a Day of Light Trading
abstract: Wall Street showed little reaction yesterday to President Bush's heart problem. In the first day of trading since the President suffered an irregular heartbeat while jogging on Saturday, the Dow Jones industrial average bounced back from a fairly small decline and ended the day at 2,941.64, up 2.78.   The broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 0.72 point, to 380.08. All other major indexes also fell -- but not by much.

headline: British Trade Deficit Widens
abstract: Britain's trade deficit grew to $:523 million, or $852 million, in May, from $:437 million, or $712 million, in April.   Other figures from the Central Statistical Office illustrated the depth of the recession, with the economy contracting for the third successive quarter. Britain's gross domestic product was down by 2.5 percent on a year-on-year basis in the first quarter.

headline: United Seen In New Talks About Routes
abstract: United Airlines has shown a renewed interest in acquiring large parts of Pan American World Airways in talks between the carriers in recent weeks, two people in the industry say.   Both persons, who asked not to be identified, said Stephen Wolf, the chairman and chief executive of United and its parent, the UAL Corporation, was interested in acquiring the Latin American routes of Pan Am, which have been profitable and which Pan Am has sought to build up through an expansion at Miami.

headline: Italian Coalition Is Formed, Ending 2-Week Crisis
abstract: Prime Minister-designate Giulio Andreotti ended a two-week political crisis today by putting together a coalition to serve as Italy's 50th postwar Government.   Mr. Andreotti, who heads the Christian Democrats, told President Francesco Cossiga he would present his list of Cabinet ministers on Friday, the President's office said.

headline: To Papers, Funnies Are No Joke
abstract: When The Washington Post recently tried to drop the venerable comic strips "Mark Trail," "Gasoline Alley" and "Steve Roper & Mike Nomad," the response was overwhelming and -- to old hands at the very serious business of syndicated newspaper comics -- predictable.   "Lots of letters pleaded that I be fired," said Polly E. Povejsil, an assistant managing editor who was behind the cartoon reshuffle, which included adding five comics tailored for children and young adults.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are this week's scheduled release dates for major economic indicators. Monday None Tuesday Housing Starts...March Industrial Production...March Capacity Utilization...March Wednesday None Thursday Balance of Trade...Feb. Friday None

headline: Real Estate; Cambridge Office Space Doing Well
abstract: AS an office market, Cambridge had long been considered a minor suburb of Boston on the wrong side of the Charles River -- when it was considered at all. In 1980 it had only two million square feet of office space, in contrast to 33 million square feet in Boston.  But to the surprise of some and the chagrin of others, Cambridge came on strong in the last decade, and it is now bearing up under the recession more successfully than its larger neighbor across the river. With total office space of 9.5 million square feet, its rent levels are off only about 15 percent, brokers say, with a vacancy rate of 13 percent.

headline: Shevardnadze Asks U.S. Food Credits
abstract: Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the former Soviet Foreign Minister, appealed to the Bush Administration today to extend new food credits to the Soviet Union, asserting that the fate of democratic change in Moscow may be at stake.   As Mr. Shevardnadze made his remarks in his first appearance in the United States since resigning his post in December, President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania offered the opposite advice only a few blocks away during the first day of his own visit to Washington.

headline: Stocks Off Sharply; Dow Loses 28.18
abstract: Stocks fell sharply yesterday in lethargic trading as investors brushed aside a report by the Government that its index of leading indicators increased in May for the fourth consecutive month.
