The Commerce Department report was merely the latest evidence that an economic recovery is under way, and together with yesterday's rally in bond prices, it ordinarily would have augured well for stock prices.

headline: Marks & Spencer To Cut 850 Jobs
abstract: Marks & Spencer P.L.C., the British retailer whose holdings include the Brooks Brothers clothing stores in the United States, plans to reduce its British work force by 1.4 percent. The company said it would cut 550 jobs at its London headquarters and 300 trainee and junior manager jobs at its stores. Six hundred of the cuts will be achieved through layoffs, and the remainder through attrition, the company said.   British retailing has suffered a serious slump since last year. Marks & Spencer said restructuring costs associated with the job cuts would reduce its current fiscal-year earnings by $27 million. The company employs 62,000 people in Britain, where it operates 291 stores. It also employs 13,000 people at 389 stores abroad.

headline: Qantas Bid Reported
abstract: Northwest Airlines declined to comment today on a report that it might take a stake in Qantas, the Australian international carrier. The Financial Times of London reported, however, that the chairman of Qantas, William Dix, had confirmed the report. The Australian Government wants to sell 49 percent of Qantas and all of its domestic carrier, Australia Airlines, in a move toward privatization.

headline: FORUM; Lift Sanctions Against South Africa
abstract: Just when our enforcement of sanctions against South Africa was enjoying high fashion in the United States, reality intruded. Last week, the South Africans scrapped apartheid laws and the Bush Administration said it would urge lifting our 1986 law enforcing the sanctions.  But let's not rush to congratulate ourselves for good works or allow the luxury of an extended Congressional debate over whether -- or when -- to lift sanctions.

headline: Staley Develops Starch Substitute for Fat
abstract: The pursuit of guilt-free food continues. The A. E. Staley Manufacturing Company said yesterday that it had developed a low-calorie fat replacement made from corn starch that was smoother, less likely to curdle and better tasting than products currently on the market.   Called Stellar, it has slightly more than 10 percent of the calories of fat, or about one calorie a gram, compared with nine for fat. It is made from corn starch and whipped into the consistency of cream through a process called shearing.

headline: South African Pact Imperiled by New Violence
abstract: The peace accord achieved to great acclaim between the African National Congress and the Inkatha Freedom Party nearly 100 days ago has been pushed to the brink of collapse by continuing political violence that has already claimed more than 600 lives this year.   The congress still avoids personal attacks on Inkatha's president, Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, who in turn expresses sympathy for Nelson Mandela, with whom he worked out the peace agreement in Durban on Jan. 29. But the congress accuses Inkatha members of plotting with the security forces to cause the latest violence, while Inkatha plays up the congress's alliance with the South African Communist Party as proof of a conspiracy to seize and monopolize power.

headline: Treasury Securities Fall in Price
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities dipped in light trading yesterday, as dealers took profits following Tuesday's mini-rally.    Despite the decline, market participants said there was no pattern to the trading. Dealers and investors remain focused on the release of March employment data tomorrow, they said.

headline: Talks in Manila on U.S. Bases Stall Over Length of New Lease
abstract: Negotiations on the future of the American military bases in the Philippines are stalled because of disagreement over the expiration date of a new treaty governing the lease, Foreign Affairs Secretary Raul Manglapus said today.   Mr. Manglapus said the main issue blocking an agreement was duration of the bases. He said the United States "wants a duration longer than the maximum of seven years that we are prepared to give."

headline: Wall Street; Tidying Up That Old Bottom Line
abstract: As usual, hard times are producing soft earnings.   Accounting rules, precise and objective as they may seem, actually give executives a lot of leeway when it comes to deciding which dollars find their way to the bottom line. And companies are likely to use every inch of maneuvering room when business turns sour, as it did for many of them in the second half of 1990.

headline: Japan's Top Securities Firms Report a Big Drop in Profits
abstract: Japan's major securities houses today reported their worst earnings in years, reflecting last year's stock market crash and a near-cessation in new issues of securities.   The so-called Big Four -- Nomura, Daiwa, Nikko and Yamaichi Securities -- reported declines in net income ranging from 52 percent to 67 percent. Smaller firms, which had been attempting to narrow the gap between themselves and the giants that control the markets here, suffered an even more severe drop in profits -- in many instances more than 90 percent.

headline: Gulf Oil Spill Vexing Cleanup Efforts
abstract: Oil spilled during the Persian Gulf war had for weeks been largely contained by favorable winds and a notch in the coastline north of here, but it has begun spreading more widely, although substantial progress is being made in scooping up oil still on the water.    During the war, much attention centered on the desalting plant here, which proides Riyadh, the capital, with half of its drinking water. For weeks the oil did not make it that far, caught instead in a pocket formed by Abu Ali island and the causeway that connects it to the mainland, a few miles to the north of the plant's water-intake system.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 9, 1991: MONDAY Alaska Air Group Nerco Inc First Intst Bancorp TUESDAY Chesapeake Corp Harnischfeger Consolidated Nat Gas Health Equity Pptys Fleetwood Enterprises Oklahoma Gas & Elec Flightsafety Intl Toro Fluor Corp Wyle Labs WEDNESDAY Caterpillar Morgan JP Co CBI Inds Nicor Handleman Co Sthrn New Eng Telecom Heinz HJ Wallace Computer Svcs THURSDAY Centel Corp Trinity Inds Engelhard Corp Universal Foods Millipore Corp Vestaur Secs FRIDAY Abbott Labs MBIA Inc

headline: Sears's Office Centers
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company said it would open home-office supply departments in 50 stores this year, adding to 10 it has operated for two years on an experimental basis. The expansion of the office centers positions Sears to serve the growing number of people who work at home, Sears said on Wednesday. The company estimated that the number of people working at home in the United States would grow to 60 million by 1993 from 45 million.

headline: CNBC Plays On Theme Of Merger
abstract: ONE of the most eagerly watched recent business mergers involved two companies that usually cover mergers, rather than participate in them. Now, the results of that transaction are the subject of an ambitious new advertising campaign aimed at three target audiences simultaneously.   Starting today, a print, television and radio campaign details the aftermath of the long-running takeover battle for Financial News Network Inc. NBC's Consumer News and Business Channel triumphed in a bidding war for FNN, which dominated CNBC in a two-network race in the growing cable television market for business news. CNBC won when a partnership of Dow Jones & Company and Group W Satellite Communications withdrew Friday from the three-month battle.

headline: Cuts by Michigan Papers
abstract: The Daily Tribune of Royal Oak and The Macomb Daily in Mount Clemens, two daily newspapers in the Detroit suburbs, said today they would drop the Saturday issuess and expand their joint Sunday issue. The Adams Publishing Corporation, which owns both newspapers, said the change would take place next weekend. Officials said that Saturday papers were not as well read, and the move would allow them to include more local news in the combined Sunday paper, which is called Suburban Sunday, and deliver it earlier in the day.

headline: Bank South Chief Quits
abstract: The chairman and chief executive of the Bank South Corporation resigned today, two months after shareholders complained about the bank's losses.   After the resignation of Robert P. Guyton, Bank South's directors named John C. Wilson as interim chief executive pending selection of a permanent successor.

headline: Moscow Journal; A Club for the Oppressed and Insecure: Millionaires
abstract: The founding of the Russian Club of Young Millionaires has been announced here only a brief limousine ride from Lenin's tomb. Young plutocrats need apply.    "Under this nation's strange laws, I am a millionaire today, and tomorrow I may be ruled a criminal," German L. Sterligov said, explaining that once he had made his first million rubles, he realized that his only hope of keeping it was to seek similarly troubled comrades who felt freakish for somehow making money despite Communism.

headline: KURDS FALL BACK FROM IRAQ FORCES
abstract: Kurdish rebels in Iraq were reported falling back on snowbound mountain fastnesses today as Baghdad's forces pressed a campaign of retribution into their adversaries' northernmost refuges.    Kurdish spokesmen in Damascus called the fast retreat from northern cities a tactical withdrawal to spare civilian lives, but Iraq's official press depicted the advance of President Saddam Hussein's troops as a victorious parade that spelled the virtual collapse of the revolt that has seized both northern and southern areas of Iraq since Baghdad's defeat in the Persian Gulf war.

headline: Japan's Socialist Party Leader Quits
abstract: The leader of the Socialist opposition, the best-known woman in Japanese politics, said today that she would resign to take responsibility for the party's recent electoral defeats.    The resignation of the politician, Takako Doi, after five years as the leader of the Japan Socialist Party marks the end of a failed revolution in postwar Japanese politics.

headline: Military Exports to Iraq Come Under Scrutiny
abstract: The Commerce Department has started an internal investigation of charges that officials of the agency altered documents related to the export of militarily useful technology to Iraq so that the material would appear less incriminating when examined by a Congressional committee, Congressional aides say.    The investigation, which is being undertaken by the department's Inspector General, came to light as a Washington public policy group provided examples of discrepancies between the Commerce Department's internal export control documents and those it presented to Congress and the public.

headline: Israeli's Hunger Strike Sets Off Storm
abstract: The Israeli Parliament fell into a screaming, cursing pandemonium today over Speaker Dov Shilansky's call to an Israeli pacifist to start eating again.   Weak of voice, his body a shadow of its former self, Abie Nathan, the well-known advocate of peace with the Aras, turned the Speaker down, saying, "I can only tell him with much sorrow in my thoughts and grief in my heart that I have to refuse."

headline: Different Names For the Storms
abstract: Cyclones, typhoons and hurricanes are the same kind of violent tropical storm, a spiral of high winds and heavy rain, but the names differ depending on where the storms occur.   Winds of at least 74 miles an hour near the center of the storm constitute a hurricane, the term used for the North Atlantic, eastern North Pacific and western South Pacific. Typhoon is the usual term for the China Sea and western North Pacific.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: INTERNATIONAL    The European Community may adopt a sweeping set of rules that would restrict the use of computerized information like personal medical and insurance records.  [ Page A1. ]   Toyota will begin selling cars in Israel despite the continuing Arab economic boycott, Toyota officials say.  [ D1. ]

headline: Bizmart to Be Bought In a $192 Million Deal
abstract: Intelligent Electronics Inc., which sells computers and computer services, said today that it would buy Bizmart Inc., an office-products supplier, in a deal valued at $192 million.    Intelligent Electronics said it would start a tender offer later this week for all of Bizmart's 11.4 million shares at $16.50 each. It said the deal would give it a new business opportunity in the office-equipment and supply industry and serve as an additional outlet for its products.

headline: Bally Debt Is Down
abstract: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation has eliminated almost a third of its debt since October, "without having to sell something that affected the cash flow," Arthur M. Goldberg, the chairman and chief executive, told stockholders. The Chicago-based company has agreements to sell Life Fitness Inc. for $62.5 million and Scientific Games Inc. for an undisclosed amount. Mr. Goldberg predicted that the deals would be closed by late summer. The company, which owns hotel-casinos in Las Vegas, Reno and Atlantic City, since October has missed $85.6 million in payments on its $1.1 billion debt.

headline: Peter Rogers Ends Affiliation
abstract: A six-month-old affiliation agreement between Peter Rogers Associates, New York, and Tatham-Laird & Kudner, Chicago, ended yesterday with Mr. Rogers taking back his premium fashion accounts, which he will again handle independently.   For legal reasons Mr. Rogers is creating a new shop with a new name. Pricey products like Baccarat crystal and Blackgama mink, which Mr. Rogers had handled for as long as 20 years before his brief association with Tatham-Laird, will move to the Peter Rogers Agency. Of his original list of accounts, only the Vidal Sassoon products will remain with Tatham-Laird.

headline: NCR Rise to $102 Reflects Doubt on $110 A.T.& T. Bid
abstract: The stock of the NCR Corporation rose $5.25 yesterday, to $102, after the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said on Sunday that it would be willing to pay $110 a share in stock for the company.   NCR said it would be prepared to accept the offer if its shareholders were protected from a drop in A.T.& T.'s stock price. While traders and analysts said an agreement seemed near, the fact that NCR's stock closed well below A.T.& T.'s new offer reflected some investor uncertainty.

headline: Rhode Island Bailout Urged
abstract: Rhode Island's Governor and Senators today pleaded for a Federal bailout of the state's private deposit insurance system, saying the state had been plunged into a financial crisis even worse than it suffered during the Great Depression.    Gov. Bruce Sundlun, a Democrat, shut down 35 credit unions and 10 banks on New Year's Day after the private Rhode Island Share and Deposit Indemnity Corporation collapsed.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Bankers Trust Company and Clark Melvin Securities Corp., Annapolis, Md., an investment firm, said they had signed an agreement giving American pension funds investment opportunities. * Boeing Co, Seattle, said Cathay Pacific Airways, the Hong Kong carrier, had ordered three 747-400 jets, valued at about $440 million.

headline: American Express and Japan Bank in Credit Card Pact
abstract: The American Express Company has reached an agreement with Sumitomo Bank Ltd. to establish a joint company that would issue personal charge cards and offer consumer loans in Japan, a senior American Express executive said yesterday.    Under the agreement, which is expected to be announced today in Tokyo, the jointly run company would market the American Express gold card to Sumitomo clients, said G. Richard Thoman, chairman and co-chief executive of American Express Travel Related Services, which oversees the company's charge card.

headline: Leningrad, Petersburg and the Great Name Debate
abstract: "Do you wish to restore to our city its original name, St. Petersburg?"   That question, put to Leningrad's voters on Wednesday alongside ballots for a mayor and the president of the Russian republic, has set off one of the most impassioned debates across the Soviet land since Mikhail S. Gorbachev first lifted the 70-year Communist monopoly on how history is written.

headline: Markets Closed For Holiday
abstract: Because of the Memorial Day holiday, financial markets in the United States were closed yesterday. News about overseas trading appears on page D14.

headline: Horizon Air's Dornier Deal
abstract: Horizon Air, a regional carrier in the Northwest, said it would buy up to 60 new aircraft from Dornier Luftfahrt G.m.b.H. of Germany. The deal includes firm orders for 35 Dornier 328 turboprop aircraft valued at about $260 million, and options for another 25 planes. Delivery is to begin in mid-1993 and continue through 1997.

headline: In Soweto-by-the-Sea, Misery Lives On as Apartheid Fades
abstract: For the 80,000 or more slum dwellers of this teeming shantytown near the Indian Ocean, the dismantling of apartheid undertaken by President F. W. de Klerk promises only continuing unemployment, homelessness, malnutrition and despair.    These walking casualties of four decades of apartheid are among the seven million of South Africa's 28 million blacks who scrape out an existence in shacks and squatter camps across the country. Their number easily exceeds the white population of five million.

headline: Corrections
abstract: An article last Sunday about Community Psychiatric Centers referred erroneously to a competitor, the Charter Medical Corporation. Charter operates hospitals across the country, not mainly in the East.

headline: Israelis Drop Order to Raze Home of a Slain Palestinian
abstract: The Israeli Army today canceled an order to demolish the three-room house of a Palestinian who was dead at the time that the military decided to punish him by tearing it down.    It is very rare for the army to rescind an order to demolish or seal a house. The military, which has destroyed hundreds of houses belonging to West Bank or Gaza Palestinians charged with security crimes, says the measure deters other Palestinians.

headline: Campbell Accord Criticized
abstract: A proposed settlement by the Federal Trade Commission of deceptive advertising charges against the Campbell Soup Company would allow Campbell to continue misleading consumers about health benefits of its canned soups, a Washington-based consumer group said yesterday.   The group, the Center for Science in the Public Interest, said that the proposed agreement would allow Campbell to contend misleadingly in advertising that its soups could help reduce the risk of some forms of heart disease, even though the soups are high in sodium. Excessive sodium consumption is linked to high blood pressure, a condition that increases the risk of heart disease.

headline: Searching for Gems in the Slush Pile
abstract: It's called the slush pile.   And as the name implies, it is the book publishing equivalent of the industrial slag heap, a mound of unsolicited proposals, sample chapters and full-length manuscripts. Even houses that bother to read slush, as the industry calls it, view it as a mixed blessing, while some prominent houses do not read it at all -- and do not return manuscripts unless postage is enclosed.

headline: Improving Employee Satisfaction
abstract: ALL work and no play does little for Bruce E. Roselle, a psychologist with Personnel Decisions Inc. of Minneapolis. By stressing the play aspects at work, he thinks, morale can be improved and boredom lessened.    "Playing at work doesn't mean taking an afternoon off to play golf," he explained. "My aim is to improve attitudes and the level of satisfaction at work."

headline: The Executive Computer; For the Boss's Office, Two Helpful Books
abstract: Just as it is rare to enter a modern company that has no personal computers, it is rare to enter the office of a chief executive and find a well-worn PC. Many senior executives simply do not compute.    "The real reason why C.E.O.'s don't use computers is that they don't see any connection between what the machine does and what role they have in the organization," said Mary E. Boone, author of "Leadership and the Computer." "The problem is that a lot of executives don't know that computers are capable of extending their creative and leadership abilities."

headline: Market Place; Blue-Chip Phase For Hostile Deals
abstract: THE merger deal finally reached on Monday between A.T.& T. and NCR illustrates the sea change that has occurred in takeovers in the last year, and may signal the beginning of a new stage in the business.    The American Telephone and Telegraph Company joins the ranks of the few well-capitalized and respected companies that have climbed onto the hostile-takeover stage in the last year, as the financiers and other corporate purchasers from the 1980's have stepped aside after the collapse of the "junk bond" market.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;
abstract: Baltia Air Lines, the little carrier with nothing to its name but a few routes, got a promise of money yesterday that would enable it to buy something else it should find handy: a few airplanes.    Baltia received a commitment of $148 million in financing from the Waterford Group, a Houston-based investment firm, which believes that the new airline will be able to build up traffic between New York, the Baltic states and the Soviet Union.

headline: Outweek, in a Shake-up, Ousts Its Editor
abstract: Outweek, the New York-based gay and lesbian magazine that has been trying to attract mainstream advertisers, dismissed its editor in chief last week after he refused to submit his resignation.    Steven Polakoff, the publisher, said the magazine needed to become more engaging than it had been under Gabriel Rotello, the editor and a founder of the two-year-old weekly. "The reader doesn't always want to be lectured and bored," he said.

headline: Isuzu and Phillips N.V. Change Media Plans
abstract: Two companies revamped their arrangements for media planning, buying and placement last week.   American Isuzu Motors Inc., City of Industry, Calif., said on Friday that it had selected the SFM Media Corporation of New York to manage its media planning and placement needs. One advertising executive estimated the billings at about $74 million. The account had been handled by Della Femina, McNamee of New York until a few weeks ago, when Isuzu announced that it was separating the creative and media portions and putting both up for review.    Also on Friday, the North American Philips Corporation, New York, a subsidiary of Philips N.V. of Eindhoven, the Netherlands, assigned D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles of New York to buy television slots for early morning, daytime, prime-time and news programming, the agency said. The deal, which covers Magnavox televisions, Norelco electric razors and other Philips products, leaves sports programming, late-night television and cable television to another agency. Several advertising executives said the billings for DMB&B would be $50 million to $60 million.

headline: People
abstract: * Tom Rich has resigned as president of the Pittsburgh office of Ketchum Advertising. Bob Kroyer, president of Ketchum Advertising/U.S.A., will run the office on an interim basis until a replacement is named. * Great Scott Advertising, New York, named Fred Golden executive director, Don Josephson senior vice president and Jon Bierman vice president.

headline: Citicorp Selling $1.405 Billion Issue
abstract: Citicorp is selling $1.405 billion in credit-card-backed certificates, due in 1996, through Standard Credit Card Master Trust 1 Series 1991-1, officials at Salomon Brothers International in London said today.   The certificates are being sold simultaneously in the United States and international capital markets. They are expected to be priced on Tuesday, officials at Salomon Brothers in New York said.

headline: Brazil Seeks To Resolve Debt Impasse
abstract: On the eve of a visit to the United States, Brazil's President and his new Economy Minister said in interviews here today that they planned to speed up talks with commercial banks over Brazil's $50 billion foreign debt.   "We have a sense of urgency," Marcilio Marques Moreira, the Economy Minister, said of the debt impasse which has moved little in the first 15 months of the Government here. "I hope that by the end of the year we might have it wrapped up."

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Elizabeth Arden Co., New York, a subsidiary of the Faberge Co., named Janice Handler vice president and general counsel. * Exxon Corp., Irving, Tex., named Carol C. Tatkon senior vice president of Exxon Company U.S.A.

headline: Holiday Inns Sets Cuts in Revamping
abstract: Holiday Inns Inc., the world's largest lodging chain, announced a corporate restructuring that includes moving its headquarters to Atlanta from Memphis. Bryan D. Langton, the chairman and chief executive, said the move would create 900 new jobs in Atlanta, including about 160 to be taken by current employees in Memphis. But he said the job losses in Memphis would affect about 1,000 of the company's 1,500 workers.    Mr. Langton said 160 middle-management employees in Memphis had been offered transfers to Atlanta, which the majority would accept. Another 350 employees are expected to retain their jobs when Holiday Inns sells its purchasing, financing and conference-planning operations. Mr. Langton said the company was selling the businesses to better focus on franchising, owning and managing hotels. Bass P.L.C. of Britain acquired Holiday Inns, with 1,600 hotels and nearly 320,000 rooms worldwide in February 1990.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Accounts
abstract: * Mall of America, a shopping and entertainment complex under construction in Bloomington, Minn., to Martin/ Williams Advertising Inc., Minneapolis. Billings are estimated at $2 million.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   10.00        DISCOUNT RATE   5.50   5.50   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.66   5.76   8.31        3-MO. TREAS.
