headline: A.T.& T. Revising NCR Bid
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said last night that it was willing to raise its bid for the NCR Corporation to $110 a share, from $90, provided that it could pay for the deal with its own stock and qualify for favorable accounting treatment.    NCR responded that it would study the offer, and would recommend that its board accept the bid if its shareholders were assured of getting $110 when the deal was completed.

headline: French Inflation at 3.2%
abstract: Consumer prices in France rose by three-tenths of a percent in May from the previous month, the Government said this week. The rise translated to an annual increase of 3.2 percent, the National Statistics Office said.

headline: U.S.-SOVIET ACCORD ON ISSUE OF ARMIES
abstract: Edging toward a long-delayed summit meeting, negotiators for the United States and the Soviet Union resolved key issues today in their dispute over a treaty to cut troops and tanks in Europe.   The progress was announced today after a meeting on Middle East issues between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, at a resort city in the Soviet Union.

headline: Congress: Landmark Party in Decline
abstract: When the politicians of the Congress Party moved yesterday to ask Sonia Gandhi to succeed her slain husband as party leader, it was hardly the first time that they were seeking to exploit family connections to link today's party to the one that led India to independence and then shaped the country's institutions and agenda.     This time, the move seemed desperate, since the widow of Rajiv Gandhi is an Italian-born woman who has stayed away from politics and who was not even an Indian citizen until eight years ago.

headline: Bush Threatens a Veto Of 'Baby Bell' Measure
abstract: The Bush Administration threatened today to veto legislation that would allow the seven regional Bell companies to manufacture equipment. Although the White House supports the bill's goal, it objects to a provision that would require the companies to carry out the manufacturing in the United States.   The threat came as the Senate began considering the legislation.

headline: Virginia Seizes Insurer, A Unit of First Capital
abstract: Virginia regulators today seized control of the Fidelity Bankers Life Insurance Company of Richmond, the smaller of the two insurance subsidiaries of the troubled First Capital Holdings Corporation of Los Angeles.    The action follows a decision announced Friday by California regulators to place harsh restrictions on the other subsidiary, the First Capital Life Insurance Company, which like Fidelity Bankers has much of its assets invested in "junk bonds."

headline: Texscan Trading Intrigues S.E.C.
abstract: THE Texscan Corporation has been losing money as its customers in the cable television business cut back on orders. Its only hope for a takeover fell through early this month, and its share price was suffering.    Then last week the stock suddenly took off on heavy volume on the American Stock Exchange. "Everybody called us, wanting to know what was going on," said William H. Lambert, the chairman and chief executive. "We had no idea where the buying was coming from." He said he knew of no news that would explain the activity.

headline: Earnings Plunge At I.B.M.
abstract: Stung by declining sales across almost its entire hardware product line, I.B.M. said yesterday that its operating earnings plunged 48.7 percent in the first quarter of 1991 and revenue fell 4.5 percent.   The computer maker, which is based in Armonk, N.Y., sent its stock into a tailspin last month after warning Wall Street analysts that first-quarter results would fall 50 percent short of its quarterly results a year ago. Most I.B.M. watchers were predicting that first-quarter earnings would be flat.

headline: Dow Up 12.38, to 2,933.17, on a Volatile Day
abstract: Stocks turned volatile yesterday as traders tried to figure out whether the Federal Reserve would bring interest rates down to revive the economy. Weakness in I.B.M. stock was a strong factor in keeping the market from moving higher.    Many concluded that the Fed would do nothing for now because it might feel the economy would improve on its own. And long-term bond prices moved up a bit, carrying stock prices slightly higher.

headline: Spotlight Is on Software at Show
abstract: With manufacturers of small computers continuing to report bad news this week, software publishers took the spotlight here as the personal computer industry convened for the spring version of the semiannual computer show, Comdex.    Although the number of exhibitors is the same as last year, there are 70 percent more software publishers among the 900 computer companies showing wares to 60,000 people at the four-day show ending on Thursday.

headline: Cairo Journal; Where Envoys Waltzed, Now the Wrecker's Ball
abstract: Glimpsed through wrought-iron gates, the elegant two-story building was just the sort of thing one might expect of an American embassy somewhere on the far side of the world: a whitewashed mansion framed by a wide marble staircase, and set against a deep yard of palm trees and dusty green grass.   But after more than four decades of serving American diplomats, the old chancellery building in Cairo is gone. Its stone facade has been broken by a wrecker's ball, and a small army of Egyptian workers is now carting away the debris, clearing the site for the construction of an eight-story high-rise inside a walled embassy compound with the sunless feel of a Wall Street canyon.

headline: Familiar Face Wins in Albania
abstract: Ramiz Alia, the Albanian Communist leader, was re-elected President today by the country's first freely elected Parliament in four decades, despite losing his seat in the recent general election. In the absence of a candidate from the country's fledgling opposition, and facing only a token challenger from his own party, Mr. Alia won 68 percent of the vote. The opposition abstained.

headline: NATO Agrees to Expand a Rapid-Reaction Force
abstract: The military planners of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have agreed on a plan to expand their multinational rapid-reaction force to as many as 100,000 troops to meet new demands inside and outside the alliance's area of operations.    The chiefs of staff of the armed forces of the 16-nation defense bloc ended a two-day meeting here on Friday by endorsing a plan for a flexible force that could respond quickly to post-cold-war threats.

headline: Brazil Effort On Loans
abstract: Brazil says it will ask the Inter-American Development Bank to explain reports that its loans are being blocked.   A Government spokesman said Saturday that Economy Minister Zelia Cardoso de Mello would "ask for an explanation" during the development bank's annual meeting in Nagoya, Japan, later this week.

headline: People
abstract: * Spencer Plavoukos has been appointed to the new position of president of Lintas Worldwide, New York. Tony Miller will assume his position as chairman and chief executive of Lintas New York. Succeeding Mr. Miller, as president and chief executive of MacLaren Lintas, Toronto, is its chief operating officer, Martin J. Rothstein. * Rick Plata has been promoted to senior vice president and director of business development at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, New York, where he had been senior vice president and media director. Also, Matt Smith and Galen Greenwood have joined the office as senior vice presidents and associate creative directors; John J. Heins has been named new business account manager, and Jonathan Mandell has transferred from Hill, Holliday's Los Angeles office, where he was vice president and associate creative director, to New York, where he has been promoted to senior vice president.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * American Restaurants Corp., Ventura, Calif., a restaurant chain, said it would sell its Wendy's division, consisting of 11 Wendy's restaurants in Southern California, for $6.5 million. * Atherton Technology, Sunnyvale, Calif., a developer of computer-assisted software, said it had completed negotiations giving Thomson CSF, Paris, a maker of military electronic systems, a majority stake. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: HIGH COURT EASES RULE ON UNIONIZING HOSPITAL WORKERS
abstract: In an important victory for organized labor, the Supreme Court today unanimously upheld a National Labor Relations Board regulation that will make it substantially easier for labor unions to organize workers at thousands of community hospitals.   Leaders of hospital unions, which have made little headway in the 17 years since Congress extended Federal labor law protection to hospital workers, hailed the decision. But many hospital executives have warned that the rule will mean that medical costs, already rising sharply, will increase even faster.

headline: Tax-Relief Prospects Called Dim
abstract: Varied proposals for reducing taxes have been floated on Capitol Hill, but despite the recession and the search by Democrats for a campaign issue, there is little likelihood that the tax burden will be eased.   One major obstacle to tax relief is the opposition of Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee and the most influential tax writer in the House.

headline: Salaries to Be Cut At Columbia Gas
abstract: The Columbia Gas System Inc., the embattled utility that serves 15 mid-Atlantic states, will reduce the salaries of its nonhourly workers by as much as 10 percent and freeze those of manual and clerical workers, effective July 1. The company said it expected the move to cut operating costs by $6 million for the rest of the year. The action affects 8,000 nonunion employees, the company said.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Olsen, Stern, Murphy & Hogan Inc., Cleveland, a management consulting firm, to Wyse Advertising, Cleveland, for marketing consultation, graphic design and public relations services. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: REBELS WHO SHED MARXIST RIGIDITY
abstract: The rebel faction that will provide what was being described by American officials as a temporary Ethiopian government has worked hard in recent years to shed its image as a movement devoted to the most rigid forms and models of Marxism, officials and analysts said today.   The rebel organization, the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front, is a coalition of several groups but is dominated by rebels from Tigre Province, which lies some 150 rugged miles north of Addis Ababa. The Tigrean rebels, including their leader, Meles Zenawi, are mostly former students at the University of Addis Ababa who were steeped in Marxist ideology from their days in various student movements after the reign of Emperor Haile Selaise was overthrown in the 1970's.

headline: Dow Up 10.51; 3,000 Mark Topped Briefly
abstract: After briefly surpassing the 3,000 barrier yesterday morning, the Dow Jones industrial average ended the day with a gain of 10.51 to close at 2,985.69.    Volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 161.6 million shares, from 127.7 million on Monday.

headline: Lionel Seeks Chapter 11 Protection
abstract: After more than a decade of unsuccessfully competing with Toys "R" Us, the Lionel Corporation filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code yesterday, its second such action since 1982.   Lionel operates so-called toy supermarkets under the names of Lionel Playworld, Lionel Kiddie City and Lionel Toy Warehouse. It is the third-largest chain of toy supermarkets after Child World and the industry leader, Toys "R" Us.

headline: Futures Trade Indictments
abstract: Three commodities traders and their companies were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Manhattan, which charged them with conspiring to cheat customers in gold and silver futures trades.   Preston H. Semel, 41 years old, of Armonk, N.Y.; Charles E. Federbush, 47, of Manhattan, and Michael Renner, 37, of Brooklyn were charged with breaking Commodities Exchange Act regulations by making trades that directly benefited them at their customers' expense. They were also charged with adjusting trading tickets to conceal their actions.

headline: Price of Aid for Egypt Is a Dose of Economic Pain
abstract: As the echoes of the Persian Gulf war fade, Egypt's huge economic problems are returning to top the list of this country's principal concerns. The situation is likely to be tougher than many Egyptians expected because there are indications that the rich Arab countries of the gulf -- Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and other emirates -- will not be as generous as their promises indicated.   The Arab countries have already written off some $7 billion in debt owed them by Egypt, and the United States has written off a similar amount of military debts, but the interest burden on the remaining debt is sapping Egypt's already fragile economy.

headline: Other Indexes Set Records, Like the Dow
abstract: As the Dow Jones industrial average closed above the 3,000 level yesterday for the first time, all other major share indexes set records for the second consecutive day.   Breaching the 3,000 Dow level held important psychological significance for many market participants, even though the average of 30 blue-chip stocks is no longer the principal yardstick of the market's performance, a role that professional investors assign to the 500-share Standard & Poor's index.

headline: Israel, Distressed by Twists in Peace Initiative, Feels Pressure
abstract: Only hours after Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d left Israel this morning, Government officials began saying they feared that his peace initiative might fail, and that they would get the blame.    "It seems he is trying to put us on the spot," said a senior Government official who is close to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir.

headline: U.S. Team Seeking Exodus of Ethiopian Jews
abstract: After talks with the Ethiopian President, Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, American officials expressed hope today that the embattled leader would allow the exodus to Israel in the next few weeks of up to 18,000 Ethiopian Jews, before feared chaos descends on the capital, Addis Ababa.   The officials said that Rudy Boschwitz, a former Republican Senator from Minnesota, traveled to Ethiopia as a special representative of President Bush to urge the rapid departure of the Jews. Colonel Mengistu told Mr. Boschwitz that he would speed the emigration. But this is similar to language that the Ethiopian President has used in the past.

headline: Mulroney Outlines New Unity Strategy
abstract: Amid indications that Quebec may resolve differences with the rest of Canada without breaking away, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney outlined a strategy of broad public consultation today as the key to national unity.    In his first major address to the nation since the collapse of an effort for constitutional change in June, the embattled Progressive Conservative leader, who is far down in the polls, promised economic and social changes as the constitutional issues are worked on.

headline: As Kurds Quit the Mountains, the G.I.'s Go Too
abstract: In these forbidding mountains where Iraqi Kurds sought refuge and found despair, American soldiers who were suddenly turned into relief workers folded their tents today and unceremoniously stole away.   It is a sign of how swiftly rescue operations have advanced that several hundred United States Special Forces troops can now be withdrawn all along Turkey's craggy border with Iraq.

headline: Further on Being Head of Household
abstract: To the Editor:   "Last-Minute Thoughts on Taxes" (April 7) left the impression that to qualify as head of household the single taxpayer must provide a home for a child who is a dependent. That is so for married children, but an unmarried child, of whatever age, does not have to be a dependent for the parent to claim head of household status. JEROME ABRAMS  Roslyn, N.Y., April 8  The author is a certified public accountant.

headline: HOUSE BACKS AID TO ANGOLA REBELS
abstract: The House voted today to continue covert American aid to Angolan rebels, less than two weeks after the country concluded a superpower-brokered peace accord ending its 16-year civil war.   But people familiar with the aid arrangements, which are supported by the Bush Administration, say the assistance is to be sharply pared back from the $60 million annual level the rebels have received through the Central Intelligence Agency in recent years, and will be strictly nonmilitary to conform with the peace agreement.

headline: South Africa Extends Cutoff Date For Prisoners Seeking Immunity
abstract: With a deadline for the release of all political prisoners only five days away, Justice Minister H. J. Coetsee said today that the process of indemnifying those who had committed crimes in opposition to apartheid would be extended into May.    In doing so, he tacitly acknowledged that not all the prisoners would be free by April 30, a date agreed on with the African National Congress last Aug. 6.

headline: Japan Concern Turns to Bonds
abstract: The Kinki Nippon Railway Company has submitted an application to sell 30 billion yen (about $215 million) in fixed-rate bonds to the Ministry of Finance, according to the newspaper Nihon Keizai. If approved, this would be the first sale of fixed interest-rate bonds in Japan since November 1988, except by public utility companies.    The resumption of fixed-rate bond sales would indicate that Japanese companies are continuing to have trouble raising funds through equity finance because of the slump in the stock market, the newspaper added.   Mitsubishi Estate was the last company to sell fixed-rate bonds.

headline: Soon: Faster and Wiser Networks
abstract: At an engineering laboratory here, Charles P. Thacker, a computer scientist at the Digital Equipment Corporation, ends a tour with a dramatic demonstration. Standing in the closet that houses the guts of the center's computer network, he yanks a cable out of its connector.   His action could have caused hundreds of desktop computers to suddenly stop operating at any other office. But computer users throughout this building never knew the connection was broken. That was because in a fraction of a second the intelligent network reorganized itself to go around the disconnected circuit.

headline: Making a Difference; Weighing the Facts for Congress
abstract: In issuing its report last week on the use of genetically engineered growth hormone to boost milk production in cows, the Office of Technology Assessment didn't shrink from controversy.   The Congressional agency issued a point-blank declaration that the hormone poses no danger to cows or to humans who drink their milk, a view at odds with what some consumer groups and state regulators have argued. By so doing, the agency increased the chances that the Government will approve the new drug for widespread commercial use and that Congress will concur.

headline: The Media Business: Advertising; Cigarette Companies Avoid Aggressive Publicity Efforts
abstract: NOWADAYS, the nation's leading cigarette companies are letting their advertising speak for itself -- though not entirely by choice.   It is increasingly common for marketers like Philip Morris USA, R. J. Reynolds Tobacco and the American Tobacco Company to play down, or forgo, the extensive, expensive publicity and public relations programs that were once key elements of introducing brands or advertising campaigns for existing brands.

headline: Measure Is Offered to Repeal South African Apartheid Law
abstract: The South African Government formally proposed a draft bill in Parliament today to repeal the Population Registration Act, a pillar of apartheid that classifies people by race.   President F. W. de Klerk pledged in February that the race classification law and all other remaining apartheid legislation would be repealed this year.

headline: Healthnet Bids Under Review
abstract: Healthnet, a California health maintenance organization, said today that its board would consider two buyout offers, though a spokesman indicated that neither would be accepted.    Healthnet, a not-for-profit health-care provider, has asked the state to allow it to convert to a for-profit operation. The move has attracted a number of offers.

headline: Market Place; Real Estate Issues Performing Well
abstract: DESPITE all the bad news about real estate, real estate investment trusts and other property-related stocks have widely outperformed the Standard & Poor's index of 500 major stocks over the last six months.    Equity real estate investment trusts posted total returns of 27.73 percent as of May (the latest available figures), easily exceeding S.& P.'s 19.7 percent return in the period, according to the National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts.

headline: Brazil Hits Oil Offshore
abstract: Brazil's state oil monopoly, Petrobras, said it had made a large oil discovery off the country's southeast Atlantic coast. A spokesman said the discovery in the Campos Basin, 57 miles from Rio de Janeiro, added some 830 million barrels of crude to the country's proven oil reserves of 2.8 billion barrels. It is too early to say how much the discovery will increase Brazil's daily oil production, currently 670,000 barrels, Petrobras said. Sixty percent of this oil already comes from the Campos Basin.

headline: U-Haul Financing
abstract: Eleven investors have provided $102.5 million to the parent company of U-Haul International Inc., as the rental truck concern struggles to trim its huge debt. E. J. Shoen, president of U-Haul and chairman of the parent company, Amerco, refused to say how much debt would be paid or the total amount of debt outstanding. Amerco's debt had been reported to total $810 million at the end of last year. The company said most of the $102.5 million loan would mature in 10 years. No interest rate was disclosed.

headline: QUARTER NOTES: A Trimonthly Expression of Opinion; Falling Short
abstract: Short-selling was, until recently, an activity conducted mostly behind closed doors by consenting professionals who talked about why the stocks they had sold were terrible investments that everyone ought to sell. Short-sellers borrow the stock they sell; they make money when its price drops and they can replace what they borrowed with shares they can buy at a lower price.  Theirs has always been a detested occupation because it's not considered nice to wish bad luck to other people. When a company's stock plummets, it usually means that employees and suppliers and customers as well as stockholders will take a beating. Wells Fargo Bank was one of the stocks most heavily sold short last fall. If the bank went bust, it would be a horror story for lots of California businesses and a number of towns -- including Palo Alto, home of the Feschbach brothers, fund managers who were the noisiest of the bears on the stock.

headline: Bonds Mixed in Light Trading
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in light trading yesterday, as market participants basically ignored Government reports on housing and industrial production.    The Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that industrial production fell by three-tenths of a percent last month.

headline: T.W.A. Acts To Buy Debt Below Value
abstract: Trans World Airlines yesterday offered to buy back debt securities from creditors far below face value, arguing that the creditors faced even larger losses if the airline was forced to file for bankruptcy protection.   The airline also threatened a Chapter 11 filing if its three unions did not agree to major concessions and if creditors did not resolve lawsuits that could result in the courts allowing them to repossess aircraft and spare parts.

headline: Limited Approval For Mentor Drug
abstract: The Mentor Corporation said the Food and Drug Administration had approved a new drug for treating incontinence in men but not in women. In an letter on Friday, the F.D.A. said it would issue a marketing approval order for the drug pending a review of final labeling.    Christopher Conway, Mentor's chairman, said the company will try to win approval for use by women as quickly as possible. Mentor's stock was one of the largest percentage losers in over-the-counter trading today, declining $6.875 a share, or 26 percent, to $19.375.

headline: Kollmorgen Selects Candidate for Top Post
abstract: The Kollmorgen Corporation, a maker of electric motors and controls and optical instruments, plans to appoint Gideon Argov as its president and chief executive. Mr. Argov will replace John L. Youngblood, who resigned on May 10.    Mr. Argov said in a telephone interview from Kollmorgen's headquarters in Simsbury, Conn., that he expected to assume his new posts as soon as he received the necessary Government security clearances.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Gold Bond Shifts Account
abstract: Gold Bond Ice Cream, whose brands include Popsicle and Good Humor, has moved its $6 million advertising account from the Grant Jacoby agency, Chicago, to McCann-Erickson.  The account, which Gold Bond reassigned without a review, had been with Grant Jacoby since 1986.   Dick Newman, vice president for marketing at Gold Bond, said the company had moved the account because its parent company, the Unilever organization, had a policy that similar brands be concentrated in the same agency. McCann's London office already handles several of Unilever's ice cream brands in Europe and the agency's New York office has handled a new Gold Bond product, Conello, since last year.

headline: Tech Notes; An Implant That Corrects the Cornea's Curvature
abstract: Keravision Inc., a start-up company in Santa Clara, Calif., recently gained Government approval to begin human trials of its Intrastromal Corneal Ring, a tiny plastic ring intended to correct vision problems by altering the curvature of the cornea.   Transparent and just three-tenths of a millimeter thick, the corneal ring is implanted through a small incision in the tissue surrounding the eye's optical zone. The operation can be done as an outpatient procedure and is reversible. The ring can flatten the cornea to correct nearsightedness, steepen its curvature to correct farsightedness or make the curvature more uniform to correct astigmatism.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * American Speedy Printing Centers Inc., Bloomfield Hills, Mich., named William D. McIntyre Jr. president and chief operating officer. * Cantisano Foods Inc., New York, makers of Francesco Rinaldi and Cantisano sauces, named John LiDestri president and Edward P. Salzano corporate executive vice president.

headline: Fisher-Price Vows To Oppose Bids
abstract: The chairman of Fisher-Price Toys, Ronald Jackson, said he would fight any takeover attempts after the company is spun off on Friday. The company, based in the Buffalo suburb of East Aurora, has been owned by the Quaker Oats Company since 1969. The food giant decided to spin off the toy maker last year after several years of losses.

headline: Cautiously, Advertisers Rush to Eastern Europe
abstract: With little fanfare, Hungarians have been eating Herz Salami for decades. Soon, they are going to learn why they should eat competing salamis, one ad at a time.   With the opening of the Eastern European economies over the last two years, Western advertising agencies have been rushing to set up shop in the region. Their biggest challenge is to develop strategies for marketing to people who have never seen an American-style ad campaign.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Acumos Inc., Foster City, Calif., a computer equipment company, named Douglas J. Bartek president and chief executive. * Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Allentown, Pa., named Harold A. Wagner president and chief operating officer.

headline: Dispute Delays Ireland Talks
abstract: A new round of Northern Ireland peace talks was postponed at the last minute because of a dispute over the site of future negotiations, British officials said today. Peter Brooke, Britain's Northern Ireland Secretary, was to have brought together political leaders for talks in Belfast on Tuesday, but officials here say the talks are being put off because of a dispute over the site of a June round of talks, which the Irish Republic is to join.

headline: Premiere's Promotion For September Issue
abstract: Premiere magazine has sent out a promotional mailing to invite potential advertisers to place ads in its September "Sex In the Movies" issue. A bright yellow condom was enclosed.   Marian L. Schwindeman, publisher of Premiere, said she had received more than 100 phone calls in response to the promotion, many of them from advertisers interested in switching their ads to the issue.   "If you look at all the people who use sex to sell goods, it made a lot of sense," she said. "Also, any time I have the chance to give condoms away, I will."

headline: Apple Ready to Introduce Delayed Macintosh System
abstract: System 7, the long-awaited upgrading of Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh operating system, is scheduled to be introduced next Monday.    By offering Macintosh users new abilities to exchange data between computers and between different programs, the new software could lift sales of Apple's more expensive machines, just as those machines have begun to lag.

headline: Expansion by United Seen
abstract: United Airlines said today that it would make an announcement on Monday that would have a "dramatic impact on Orlando and Florida." One report said the carrier planned to announce the establishment of a major hub serving the Southeast.   The move by the nation's No. 2 airline, after American Airlines, would put it into direct competition with Delta Air Lines and USAir, the dominant carriers serving Orlando.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; People
abstract: * Sandra L. Greenberg and Terri Meyer have been named senior vice presidents in the New York office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles. * Douglas Behm has been promoted to a creative director in the Chicago office of DDB Needham. * John Sircus has been named senior vice president and director of broadcast production and Lee St. James has been named vice president and associate creative director in the Dallas office of Bozell Inc.

headline: U.N. SEEKS ACCORD ON A POLICE FORCE IN NORTHERN IRAQ
abstract: The five permanent members of the Security Council are seeking agreement on establishing a United Nations police force in the Kurdish region of northern Iraq. The force would take over from American and allied military units, which have set up a refugee zone in the area.    The idea of sending United Nations policemen into northern Iraq, as opposed to a full-fledged peacekeeping force, is intended to avoid a debate in the Security Council over whether such an intervention in Iraq's affairs can be authorized without a request from the Baghad Government. Replacing American Soldiers     Sending in a United Nations police force to take over the military security role now being performed by the United States and its allies would save Washington from having large numbers of American soldiers indefinitely committed in northern Iraq.

headline: RAJIV GANDHI IS ASSASSINATED IN BOMBING AT CAMPAIGN STOP; INDIA PUTS OFF REST OF VOTING
abstract: Rajiv Gandhi, a former Prime Minister hoping to return to power in elections this week, was assassinated in a powerful explosion as he walked toward an election rally platform on Tuesday night in a small town southwest of Madras.    No organization or individual has yet taken responsibility for the attack.

headline: Kravis Acquires Ranch
abstract: Henry R. Kravis, a principal of the investment firm Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, paid $5.5 million in cash on Friday for the 4,500-acre Bricklin Ranch, a week before banks were to foreclose on the property.   The ranch, in northwestern Colorado, was owned by Malcolm Bricklin, whose auto companies have imported Subaru and Yugo cars and who developed a plastic-body sports car. Three thousand of the sports cars bearing the Bricklin name were sold in the 1970's.    At one time, Mr. Bricklin owned 16,000 acres near Meeker, but much of it was sold under distress or lost to foreclosure. The ranch bought by Mr. Kravis was Mr. Bricklin's last property in Colorado.   Mr. Kravis also owns property in Vail, Colo.

headline: 4 Ex-Officials of East Germany Arrested
abstract: Four of the most senior leaders of former East Germany, including the Prime Minister, were arrested today as part of a drive to find and bring to justice the officials responsible for ordering border guards to shoot to kill people fleeing to the West, prosecutors said.   The prosecutors said the former Prime Minister, Willi Stoph, was arrested with Heinz Kessler, the former Defense Minister; Fritz Streletz, the former secretary of East Germany's National Defense Council, and Hans Albrecht, another Council member.

headline: Iran Says One Million Iraqi Kurds Are on Its Border and May Be Admitted
abstract: The official Iranian press agency said today that more than a million Iraqi Kurdish refugees had massed on the Iranian border, hoping to cross. It added that they might all be permitted to enter the country.   The report carried by the agency, IRNA, said that as many as 1.5 million refugees were heading toward Iran, fleeing Iraqi troops. It said the source of the information was Ahman Ziaee, Mayor of the border city of Piranshahr. The agency said a million people were crowded at the border near Nowsud after fleeing their homes in Sulaimaniya, Kirkuk and nearby villages.

headline: Mix-Up Delays Asbestos Trial
abstract: A Baltimore judge dismissed 51 prospective jurors today in the nation's largest consolidation of asbestos personal-injury cases because a confidential defense document was mistakenly sent to the opposing side.   The misdirected fax, containing psychological profiles of prospective jurors prepared by defense lawyers for insulation manufacturers, was sent to lawyers representing the reported asbestos victims.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Bank of Nova Scotia, Toronto, named John F. Crean and Richard E. Waugh executive vice presidents. * Chemical Bank, New York, named Thomas S. Keating managing director in charge of its debtor-in-possession financing unit.

headline: Buyers Choose Airbus and Boeing
abstract: Airbus Industrie, a four-nation European consortium, said today that the International Lease Finance Corporation had placed orders for up to 15 Airbus jets in a deal worth more than $960 million.   Airbus's leading competitor, the Boeing Company, said Thai Airways International had placed firm orders for six 777 jets, and secured options on six more, bringing the total potential value of the agreement to $2 billion.

headline: Dollar Is Quiet Despite Fed Move
abstract: Last   Prior   Year       Week   Week   Ago              Japanese Yen   138.85   138.30   158.25       per Dollar       German Mark   1.7482   1.7515   1.6662       per Dollar       Canadian Dollar   1.1513   1.1523   1.1640       per U.S. Dollar       British Pound   1.6935   1.6885   1.6630       U.S. Dollar per British Pound       Gold   $353.50   $353.50   $371.30       Republic National Bank       Currency: Friday NY Close

headline: Life Insurer Failures Point Up Flaws in Safety Nets of States
abstract: The recent collapses of two huge Los Angeles-based life insurers present a sobering reality to regulators and consumers: the safety programs set up by 48 states to protect policyholders when their insurance companies fail may be woefully unprepared for a crisis of this magnitude.   The two insurers, the Executive Life Insurance Company and the First Capital Life Insurance Company, together have roughly a million policyholders whose insurance policies and savings and retirement annuities are worth billions of dollars. If those companies were permanently closed, industry experts say, many of the state safety nets, called insurance guarantee funds, could not meet the big financial demands suddenly made on them. Weaknesses Are Cited    In addition to arguing that the programs lack resources, critics point out that the programs are not run or guaranteed by state governments, that they are not true "funds" because they do not keep money in reserve, and that they are limited in how much they can ask each year from surviving insurers.

headline: Germans and Poles Pledge Mutual Help
abstract: The leaders of Poland and Germany signed a treaty of friendship and cooperation today that both men said would turn the two countries into long-term partners.   "We need the closest possible cooperation with united Germany," Prime Minister Jan Krzysztof Bielecki of Poland said before signing the treaty. "United Germany, our especially close neighbor, is Poland's most important partner in all areas."

headline: Israelis Held in Jerusalem Shooting Incident
abstract: The Israeli police detained a militant anti-Arab rabbi and 10 other Israelis today after shots were fired at Palestinians who threw stones at them in Jerusalem's Old City, the Israeli radio reported.   The group was walking in the Muslim quarter of the walled Old City, where a number of Jews have been stabbed by Arabs. The Israeli press agency Itim said they were apparently protesting inadequate security. Further details were unavailable.

headline: Hasbro-Tonka
abstract: Hasbro Inc. said it expected to complete its $486 million takeover deal for the Tonka Corporation, a rival toy maker, by next Tuesday. It said that as of Monday, Tonka stockholders had pledged to sell 8.7 million shares to Hasbro. Tonka's bondholders have already agreed to the deal. Hasbro is expected to finance the acquisition entirely on its own, probably through borrowing in the public and private markets, including a certain amount of bank debt. An equity element is "under review," the company said.

headline: Gallic Dart Distresses British Men
abstract: The weather in London and Paris has been awful for weeks, but the summer silly season has thankfully arrived on schedule, this time adding a tiff over the relative virility of English and French men to the old perennial of cross-Channel squabbling.   The first shot was fired by Edith Cresson, the first woman to become Prime Minister of France, who was quoted on Sunday as having said that 25 percent of Englishmen -- as well as Americans and Germans -- are homosexual and that, in contrast to Frenchmen, "Anglo-Saxon men are not interested in women."

headline: Kurds See Their 'Best Chance' With Baghdad Now
abstract: "We are closer than ever to autonomy," said Jalal Talabani, leader of one of the two largest political groups for Iraqi Kurds. "This is the best chance we've had this century."   With his comrades meeting this week in Baghdad to cement the reforms that the Kurds were granted last month, Mr. Talabani has more reason to be optimistic than ever before. One of those who met today with President Saddam Hussein was Massoud Barzani, perhaps the most powerful Kurdish rebel leader and a man whom Mr. Hussein has opposed for more than a decade.

headline: Patents; A Container to Store Radioactive Waste
abstract: Alternative Technologies for Waste Inc., a family-owned research concern in Goleta, Calif., has patented a new container and method for storing low-level radioactive waste.   Low-level waste comes from materials used in connection with radioactive isotopes and nuclear power -- anything from rags and cleaning chemicals used in a power plant to products used in the radiology departments of a hospital.

headline: Japanese Stocks Decline
abstract: Japanese stocks closed lower today after slumping in late afternoon trading. The Nikkei index of 225 issues ended the week at 23,290.96, down 252.07 points, or about 1.1 percent. For the week, the index fell 791.30 points, or about 3.3 percent.

headline: Wages Show a More Moderate Advance
abstract: Wages, salaries and benefits paid to American workers rose 4.6 percent over the last 12 months, a much slower advance than the year before, the Government said today in a report viewed as evidence that wage inflation was abating.   Analysts said the more moderate rise in the Labor Department's employment cost index, considered one of the best gauges of wage inflation pressures, probably played a part in the Federal Reserve's move to lower the discount rate.

headline: Dollar Strong,But on Hold
abstract: Last   Prior   Year       Week   Week   Ago              Japanese Yen   138.30   138.35   159.25       per Dollar       German Mark   1.7515   1.7360   1.6770       per Dollar       Canadian Dollar   1.1523   1.1551   1.1640       per U.S. Dollar       British Pound   1.6885   1.7215   1.6315       U.S. Dollar per British Pound       Gold   $353.50   $356.50   $371.50       Republic National Bank       Currency: Friday NY Close

headline: Matsushita Drives
abstract: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said it had developed a 3.5-inch hard disk drive that can store 210 megabytes of computer data, which it says is the highest storage capacity developed. Formerly, the highest-capacity 3.5-inch hard disk drives were made by the NEC Corporation and could store 176.5 megabytes, a company spokesman said. The new Matusushita disk drives, called the RD-210AA's, are likely to be used in work stations and high-end personal computers, the spokesman said. The company will start sample shipments by the end of this year and will start mass production in mid-1992, he said.

headline: Ketchum Unit Wins Yellow Pages Accounts
abstract: Ketchum Directory Advertising, Chicago, said yesterday that it had won two Yellow Pages accounts: the Allstate Insurance Company account for the Western half of the United States, with billings of about $7 million, and the Budget Rent A Car corporate account, with billings of about $8 million.   The Eastern half of the Allstate account will remain with the insurance company's incumbent agency, Woodward Direct in Skokie, Ill. The Budget account had been handled previously by the Communications Planning Corporation of Chicago, a Budget spokesman said.

headline: J. C. Penney's Woes Tied to Lack of Identity
abstract: The J. C. Penney Company had high hopes that by now it would be enjoying the fruits of its 1987 transformation from a full-line department store to primarily a clothing store.    Instead, it has run into a buzzsaw of problems that are cutting heavily into sales and earnings.

headline: Wall Street; The Dow Looks Even Mightier From Abroad
abstract: A Dow at 3,000? To Americans who think in dollar terms, that was an extraordinary event. But the strength of the dollar has meant that to foreign investors, American stocks have zoomed much further.   For an investor who thinks in German marks, the Dow Jones industrial average hit its high last Monday, when it was up 31 percent since the beginning of the year. That was the equivalent of the Dow at 3,453, indexing for currency changes from Dec. 31. For an American investor, the Dow had risen but 14 percent when it peaked at 3,004.46 on April 17.

headline: Retiree Status At Eastern
abstract: Eastern Airlines, which stopped flying in January after 65 years, has refused to bend on its threat to cut off medical insurance for retirees, a lawyer for a group of them said today.    "These retired employees face a major tragedy," said William Bell of the Eastern Airlines Retirees Association. The association says it represents 6,000 of Eastern's 14,000 retirees.

headline: Filipino Farmers Feel Smothered by the Ash
abstract: The rice crop is dead, buried beneath a foot of volcanic ash and rock, and the farmers who struggle here in the shadow of Mount Pinatubo wondered aloud this afternoon whether their soil might ever be fertile again.    Felix Manalac, a 62-year-old farmer who has tended rice fields in San Matias for a third of his life, kicked at a small mound of the gray-black ash that destroyed the summer harvest.

headline: WAR PREPARATIONS BY YUGOSLAV ARMY
abstract: With the nation's political leaders deadlocked over whether to impose martial law, the Yugoslav Army inched closer today to strategic locations in Croatia and Slovenia, the republics where separatist feeling has been strongest.    In some locales, the progress of army convoys remained blocked by civilians who barricaded the roads. But the military succeeded in airlifting fresh troops to Slovenia, the northernmost of Yugoslavia's six republics, a senior Slovene official said today.

headline: F.D.I.C. Is Selling Last Shares in Bank
abstract: Shares in the Continental Bank Corporation of Chicago will be sold by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The Government agency has been the largest shareholder of the banking company since 1984, when it acquired a controlling interest as part of the $4.5 billion bailout of the old Continental Illinois Corporation. The shares to be sold are the Government's last holdings in Continental. The F.D.I.C. had previously sold stock in 1986 and 1988.    Continental's shares lost 37.5 cents on the Big Board yesterday, closing at $13.50. At that price, the sale of 14.2 million shares by the F.D.I.C. would bring about $191.7 million and help reduce the Government's estimated $1.7 billion loss from the bailout. Since the Government rescue in 1984, Continental has sold its consumer banking operations and concentrated on its business customers and on trading. It has operated at a profit the last three years.

headline: Chiquita May Buy Stake in Doskocil
abstract: The Doskocil Companies said that Chiquita Brands International Inc. had expressed interest in acquiring a substantial minority equity interest in Doskocil upon its emergence from bankruptcy. Doskocil, a packaged-foods company that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors in March, said Chiquita, a unit of the American Financial Corporation, had suggested an exchange of shares for an equity interest.   Doskocil said the inquiry was preliminary and that its board had not yet met to discuss it. It said any transaction would depend on the completion of its reorganization plan. Doskocil stock closed unchanged at $2 a share today in over-the-counter trading, while Chiquita stock lost 25 cents a share to close at $40.125 on the Big Board.

headline: Congo Political Conference Gives Africa a Democratic Model
abstract: It seemed somehow appropriate that when a national conference on the political future of this Central African country ended recently, all 1,500 delegates solemnly took turns dipping their hands in the reflecting pool outside the Congolese national assembly hall.    The ceremony was meant to symbolize the washing away of the bile that often marred deliberations at the three-month conference. It was also an act of reconciliation, and a way of affirming the momentous changes that had taken place in what political leaders are calling Congo's democratic coup.

headline: House Panel Changes Rules On Shutting Weak Banks
abstract: The House Banking Committee approved new rules today that would permit Federal regulators to shut down weak banks sooner than they now can.    The proposal for earlier intervention, which would greatly restrict the latitude that regulators currently have in deciding when to close troubled banks, will be included in a package of changes to the Depression-era laws governing the banking industry. The proposal provides that banks with capital equal to less than 2 percent of their assets would be subject to prompt regulatory intervention, including seizure. The capital-to-asset ratio is a key measure of banks' health.

headline: Bank Loans Show Drop
abstract: Commercial and industrial loans on the books of commercial banks, excluding acceptances, fell $1.21 billion, to $311.82 billion in the week ended May 22, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

headline: Pacific Bell Debt To Yield 8.78%
abstract: Pacific Bell, a San Francisco-based subsidiary of the Pacific Telesis Group, priced $200 million in notes yesterday through underwritrers led by Lehman Brothers Inc.   The notes, which reach final maturity in 2001, have an 8.7 percent coupon and are priced at 99.473 to yield 8.78 percent, or about 45 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.    The issue is noncallable and is rated Aa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by Standard & Poor's.

headline: A Software Alliance Is Expected
abstract: The Lotus Development Corporation and Adobe Systems Inc., will announce today that Lotus will include computer font technology developed by Adobe in the version of its 1-2-3 spreadsheet program it is developing for the Microsoft Corporation's Windows software.    The alliance between Lotus and Adobe Systems, a software publisher of digital typography software and fonts based in Mountain View, Calif., is the latest move in the convoluted computer industry "font wars" that have set traditional allies against each other and made confidants out of competitors.

headline: Brazilian Routes Sought by United
abstract: United Airlines asked the Transportation Department for authority to fly daily between Los Angeles and Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro. The flights would begin in January, the carrier, a unit of the UAL Corporation, said. Southbound flights would originate at San Francisco International Airport and stop in Los Angeles.    The company said recent talks between United States and Brazilian officials provided an opportunity to increase air service between the countries. United said it would use Boeing 747's for the routes. Earlier this week, United sought permission to fly to Stansted Airport near London, which opened in March. UAL's stock fell $1.375 today, closing at $151 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Bush Tells Belgrade That U.S. May Consider Restoring Aid
abstract: President Bush has informed the Government of Yugoslavia that he would consider lifting suspension of all United States economic assistance to that country, a White House spokesman said today.    The aid cutoff began automatically on May 6 as a result of legislation enacted in November decreeing that unless Yugoslavia and its constituent republics ceased systematic human rights violations American aid would be terminated in six months. The law stipulates that unless the Secretary of State certified that Yugoslavia had met this test, the suspension would automatically go into effect. But Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d allowed the deadline to pass without comment.

headline: Palestinians Urged By Israel to Prepare Colleges for Opening
abstract: The Israeli military government in the West Bank told Palestinian university officials today that they should prepare their schools for reopening soon, Palestinian educators said.    The major universities in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip have been closed under military order continually since the Palestinian uprising began three and a half years ago. The authorities have asserted that the campuses were used as planning and staging grounds for violence.

headline: Warsaw Pact Formally Ends 36 Years As a Military Force
abstract: The Warsaw Pact, which held Eastern Europe under tight Kremlin control for 36 years, formally ended its existence as a military force Sunday when Soviet commanders surrendered their powers.   Gen. Pyotr Lushev, the pact's commander-in-chief, and Gen. Vladimir Lobov, chief of staff, gave up their powers under an agreement among the pact members: the Soviet Union, Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Bulgaria and Romania.

headline: Space Center or Not, Some Say It's Still a Jungle
abstract: In the 10-year life of Arianespace, the French-led European rocket venture, France has not only built the world's busiest commercial satellite launching center here, but has also sought to create from scratch a modern French city in the heart of this onetime equatorial penal colony.    Shiny Peugeots tool through Kourou's smooth new streets, pastis and familiar wines are served up in bars, and yellow- and blue-uniformed men from La Poste even deliver the mail by bicycle here, all contributing to a sense of urban French life.

headline: 3-Star Comment on 'Fast Track' Plan
abstract: Congressional committee hearings on important issues often star a Cabinet official. But a chorus of three Cabinet members turned up for today's hearing by the House Agriculture Committee on the Administration's authority to negotiate trade pacts.   Secretary of Agriculture Edward R. Madigan, Labor Secretary Lynn M. Martin and the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, sat shoulder to shoulder for more than two hours this morning, defending the Administration's position in an unexpectedly bitter domestic dispute over international trade policy.

headline: Canada Economic Index
abstract: Canada's leading economic indicator fell 1 percent in January after a revised seven-tenths of 1 percent drop in December, the Government statistics office said today.

headline: Making a Difference; Pepsi Takes On Coke at the Fountainhead
abstract: For years, Pepsi-Cola has been making great strides in selling its soft drinks in supermarkets. Not so in the fountain business, where Coca-Cola still dominates the little gurgling machines that spew out syrup and fizzy water in places like McDonald's and Denny's.   Richard Routhier, Pepsi's senior vice president for national sales, is trying to change that. In the past several weeks, Mr. Routhier and his salespeople have snagged a pair of plum Coke accounts: Howard Johnson's and the Marriott Corporation.

headline: A Hard Sell, Inspired by The Classics
abstract: Americans bought more than 3.5 million Penguin Classics last year, everything from Aesop's "Fables" to the history of Xenophon. But sales of the classics have been flat for a couple of years and competition is more heated than ever.    So Penguin U.S.A. recently embarked on a three-year promotion to persuade booksellers to carry more of the Penguin Classics -- presumably at the expense of its competitors.

headline: Money Fund Assets Fall
abstract: The assets of the nation's 548 money market mutual funds decreased by $1.23 billion, to $461.34 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 196 institutional funds decreased by $1.44 billion, to $131.66 billion. The assets of the 260 general-purpose funds were up by $301.0 million, to $178.47 billion. The 92 broker-dealer funds decreased by $93.3 million, to $151.21 billion, the institute said.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Economy    In the battle for use of the airwaves, the Commerce Dept. is pressing the first serious effort to capture for the Treasury the multibillion-dollar value of newly assigned frequencies.  [ Page A1. ]

headline: This Week's Numbers
abstract: Consensus          Last Period   Estimates*              Tuesday   May durable goods in percent   2.9   .5           June consumer confidence in percent   74.5   74.5          Mid-June auto sales in millions   5.9   6.2              Wednesday   First-quarter G.N.P. in percent   -2.6   -2.6          First-quarter G.N.P. deflator   5.1   5.1              Thursday   448   425          May personal income in percent   0l.1   0.4              Friday   May leading indicators in percent   0.6   0.3       Monday: Wholesale trade * Group of 7 meeting in London  Tuesday: Bundesbank Council meeting  Friday: Agriculture prices  (Sources: Bloomberg Business News; I.D.E.A. Inc.)

headline: Kuwaiti Collaboration Trials Now Scheduled for Saturday
abstract: Public trials will begin Saturday for people accused of collaborating with Iraqi occupation forces in Kuwait, officials here said today.    The trials, which were to have started last Saturday but were delayed, were said by the country's acting Attorney General, Hamad al-Othman, to involve up to 900 cases under investigation. More than 200 involve suspected collaboration. Those found guilty of espionage face the death sentence.

headline: Air War in the Credit Card Battle
abstract: In its latest counterattack against growing challenges from Visa and Mastercard, the American Express Company said yesterday that it would sharply expand the ways travelers could accumulate frequent-flier credits.    As do competing bank "affinity cards" with ties to airlines, American Express will give its card holders one frequent-flier mile for every dollar they charge on their Green, Gold, Platinum, Optima and Corporate cards. Any purchase, whether it be flowers, sweaters, college tuition or vacations, earns the miles, which are redeemable for free airline tickets or ticket upgrades to first class.

headline: Israel Angered by Baker's Remarks on Settlements
abstract: Israeli leaders reacted angrily today to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's complaints about the expansion of Jewish settlements during his visits to the region.    They blamed the Arabs for the slow pace of Mr. Baker's peace initiative and rejected Mr. Baker's statement before Congress on Wednesday that the new settlements were the largest obstacle to his mission.

headline: When Tax Audits Might Mean Windfalls to Companies
abstract: Audits by the Internal Revenue Service usually do not result in windfalls for taxpayers. But many big companies facing audits of tax returns from past years may now be entitled to big refunds, thanks to a recent court decision, accountants say.    On Thursday, a Federal tax court judge rejected the treatment of write-offs of good will that the Internal Revenue Service sought to impose upon the Philip Morris Companies, the tobacco and consumer products concern, as a result of its 1978 hostile takeover of the Seven-Up Company.

headline: CHINA SAID TO CURB FOREIGN RESEARCH
abstract: China appears to be moving to cut off access by foreign scholars to social survey data, according to Chinese academics and a secret document distributed recently.   The State Education Commission has already circulated a document that prohibits universities and other institutes from turning over to foreign scholars the results of social surveys, even if they were conducted as a joint effort. Now, the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, one of China's most prominent academic institutions, is planning to draft similar guidelines.

headline: The Pitfalls of Working With 'Informal Investors'
abstract: To The Editor:   In "Finding Money to Start a Business" (June 2), Mary Rowland sells venture capitalists short.

headline: Gasoline Prices Rise
abstract: A seasonal increase in demand for gasoline pushed prices up by nearly 3 cents a gallon in the last two weeks, according to an industry survey released today. The average price for all grades of gasoline at full- and self-service pumps increased 2.77 cents a gallon, to 122.61 cents, by Friday, according to the biweekly Lundberg Survey of 13,000 stations nationwide. The price increase reflected a surge in motorist demand as the weather has grown warmer, said Trilby Lundberg, an oil industry analyst. Ms. Lundberg noted that prices were at the highest levels for this time of year since 1985. The national average in May 1985 was 122.68 cents a gallon.

headline: Managing; A Revival of the Quality Circle
abstract: Quality circles.   Those words used to evoke a picture of a utopian world in which industry's lowest-paid workers solved its biggest problems. Today, they elicit bad memories. By the end of the 1980's, quality circles -- worker teams whose shop-floor experience and common sense were supposed to restore America's flagging productivity -- had all but disappeared.

headline: Money Market Fund Yields Mixed for 5th Straight Week
abstract: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the fifth consecutive week, ending yesterday.    Analysts at IBC/Donoghue's point to the current flatness in money market yields, which they say is a result of the market finally dropping to the level of the last easing by the Federal Reserve Board. Fund managers continue to hold securities with longer maturities in their portfolios without fear of interest rates rising.

headline: All About/Commercial Radio; Too Many Stations, Too Few Buyers and Depressed Prices
abstract: These are dog days for commercial radio and not just because the recession has hurt advertising. For starters, the radio dial has become far more congested in recent years because the Federal Communications Commission has approved well over a thousand new stations since the early 1980's in efforts to foster competition. The result: more broadcasters chasing the same advertising dollars, sometimes amid increased interference.    How bad are things? Advertising revenues last year were about $8.84 billion, virtually unchanged from the year before, according to the Radio Advertising Bureau, an industry group in New York. And the F.C.C. recently reported that 197 AM stations and 30 FM stations have simply chosen to go off the air, because they could not meet expenses or find anybody to buy their licenses. In the past, analysts say, it has been very rare indeed for stations to "go dark."

headline: Iraqis Fire to Bar U.N. Inspectors; 'We Can't Allow This,' Bush Says
abstract: Iraqi soldiers defied United Nations inspectors today for the third time this week, firing warning shots over the inspectors' heads and again preventing them from investigating machinery that the United States says Iraq is using to make nuclear weapons, diplomats said.    The move caused concern in Washington, where President Bush said, "We can't allow this." He hinted at the use of force to make Iraq cooperate fully with the United Nations plan to destroy its weapons of mass destruction as part of the cease-fire agreement that ended the Persian Gulf war.

headline: Poverty, Not Politics, Drives Cubans Out Now
abstract: When his only income dried up, money from the sale of secondhand clothes sent to him by relatives in the United States, Juan Alfredo Molenillo Grenup decided that he had had enough of spartan life in Cuba and set out in desperation on a raft for Florida.   Three days later, after being picked up by boaters off the Florida Keys, Mr. Molenillo had arrived, joining more than 600 other Cubans who have escaped their country on makeshift vessels this year in the largest wave of refugees from the island since the Mariel boatlift in 1980.

headline: An Unsettling Look Inherent In Recovery
abstract: People love to talk about the Dow as if they were talking about a person. "The market is feeling nervous," they say. "The market wants to go higher." These days the market is acting more like a lottery winner worried that the telegram is a practical joke.     Nobody can be absolutely sure that the recovery that seems to be underway is the real thing. "There's a possibility of a false start in the economy," said Laszlo Birinyi, a financial consultant. Indeed, the gross national product has popped up in the middle of half of all postwar recessions, only to slump anew.

headline: Canada Airline Proposal
abstract: Canadian officials will consider allowing American carriers to fly between destinations in Canada, James Harris, the top Canadian negotiator in the air travel talks with Washington, said last week. The chief American negotiator, Charles Angevine, said he would consider the Canadian proposals on the internal routes, but American officials have said they will not press for such an agreement.

headline: House Panel Backs Easing of RICO Law
abstract: The latest effort to roll back the long reach of the civil racketeering law known as RICO began today when a House panel approved legislation that would sharply limit its use in a wide array of cases against accountants, manufacturers, Wall Street firms and other businesses.   The legislation cleared the Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on Intellectual Property and Judicial Administration by voice vote with virtually no debate and in less than an hour, suggesting that its political prospects this year might be better than in the past.

headline: Aetna Profit Declines 24%
abstract: Aetna Life and Casualty said today that its first-quarter earnings fell 24 percent from last year largely because of declines in commercial real estate.   The insurance giant said it had earned $137.4 million, or $1.25 a share, down from $179.8 million, or $1.61 a share, in the first quarter of 1990. Revenue totaled $4.69 billion, down 17 percent from $4.77 billion.

headline: Patents; Designing Clothes on a Computer
abstract: A Michigan company has patented a software system to design clothing, from the composition of threads to the shape of the shoulders, without touching a bolt of fabric.   The system, developed by Computer Design Inc. of Grand Rapids, is designed to run on commercially available computer work stations. "Normally, designers have to produce fabric one year ahead of time," said Emory Shyong, senior software engineer and the machine's inventor. "With this, they can do it one month before the line of clothing is released. They can catch the fashion trend."

headline: Saturn Wrinkle On New-Car Sales
abstract: The Saturn Corporation said that cars it would use to replace 1,100 recalled vehicles would be counted as new-car sales. Saturn will not report how many of the replacement vehicles will be among the new-car sales reported by its parent company, the General Motors Corporation, during the next month or so, according to a Saturn spokesman, Mark Tanner. "We're not going to know that breakout," Mr. Tanner said. If supplied over a month's time, 1,100 vehicles would raise Saturn sales for that month by about one-fifth.

headline: Drug-Testing Charges Filed
abstract: Federal prosecutors charged a former drug company executive today with submitting rigged test results to the Food and Drug Administration to win approval of three generic drugs.   Prosecutors said Steven Colton, 39 years old, knowingly substituted testing data on other companies' drugs for data on his own company's products to the F.D.A.

headline: 40 KILLED IN INDIA AS VOTING BEGINS
abstract: India's 10th national election began today in an outburst of political violence that left at least 40 people dead and hundreds wounded. Dozens of polling stations were ordered closed, and several cities have been placed under curfew.    There were reports of battles in Calcutta between Communist and Congress Party supporters armed with guns and bombs.

headline: Chemical Leak in Korea Brings Forth a New Era
abstract: When South Korea decided that the country's only chance at economic pre-eminence lay in supercharged industrialization, it started here, in a scrubby valley formed by the Naktong River.    As a result, the region, the home district of President Roh Tae Woo, could now be mistaken for anywhere in the Silicon Valley of California. But a recent chemical spill that some critics link to South Korea's "industrialize at all cost" policies is causing the area and the nation much anguish.

headline: Papal Encyclical Urges Capitalism to Shed Injustices
abstract: In a major encyclical addressing the economic questions raised by the upheaval in Eastern Europe in 1989, Pope John Paul II warned capitalist nations yesterday against letting the collapse of Communism blind them to the need to repair injustices in their own economic system.

headline: Soviets Propose New Economic Changes
abstract: Three advisers to the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, presented the Bush Administration today with new proposals for Soviet economic and political reforms to stabilize the Soviet economy, but they were told by Washington that they would have to make concrete steps -- not just promises -- before any American aid would be considered.   "The United States is very interested in supporting both political and economic reform in the Soviet Union," Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said after meeting the Soviet delegation. "The first step, of course, is for the Soviet Union to undertake real market-based reforms, to use incentives to tap the very great potential that exists in the Soviet Union and the considerable resources and skilled people that exist in the Soviet Union."

headline: Brokers and Lenders Join To Push Cape Cod Sales
abstract: Anyone interested in buying property on Cape Cod and Martha's Vineyard this summer can get a quick one-stop look at what's available on Sunday when 22 real estate brokers, two mortgage loan companies and a Cape Cod bank will display their wares in a Hyannis hotel showroom.    The showcase has been organized by Premier Productions, a small promotions firm based in Brookline, Mass. Andrea Dale, a partner, said each broker and lending company would have a booth with pictures and fact sheets on the properties they are handling in a large meeting room at the Tara Hyannis from 10 A.M. until 5 P.M. Admission is $2.50 for adults; children will be admitted without charge.

headline: U.S. Warns Against Attack By Iraq on Kurdish Refugees
abstract: In a further attempt to respond to the staggering exodus of more than a million Iraqi Kurds, the Bush Administration said today that it had warned Iraq not to use its military forces in northeastern Iraq.    In a message conveyed last Saturday to Iraqi diplomats in Washington and at the United Nations, the White House told the Baghdad Government not to take any armed action in the region. It was the most explicit American demand on any Iraqi use of military within its borders since the war ended.

headline: Earlier Start for Trading Is Studied
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange is exploring beginning trading before the traditional opening at 9:30 A.M., although it is uncertain what time it would start, an exchange executive said yesterday.    Such an exploration was expected. The Big Board on Thursday began its first after-hours trading in what was described as a first step toward 24-hour trading by early in the next century.

headline: Stocks Flat in Tokyo
abstract: Stock prices were virtually unchanged here today after rising slightly in the morning. By the end of the afternoon trading session, the Nikkei index of 225 issues had lost 12.43 points, or just five-hundredths of a percent, to close at 26,111.25. Trading was described as extremely thin.

headline: SOVIET PRICE RISES IGNITE BIG PROTEST
abstract: Tens of thousands of workers took to the streets of an important provincial capital today in the first mass protest against nationwide price increases, while in Moscow, Boris N. Yeltsin began a surprise new power play.    The strike in Minsk, the capital of Byelorussia, was significant because the republic had seemed relatively unaffected by the passions gripping other parts of the nation.

headline: Stake in Husky Is Up for Sale
abstract: The Nova Corporation confirmed today that it wants to sell its 43 percent share in Husky Oil Ltd., one of Canada's largest oil and gas companies.    The company's announcement was the first time Nova had confirmed it was looking to divest itself of its interest in Husky, Husky's assets total $3.7 billion.

headline: Tokyo Stocks Firmer
abstract: Stock prices closed higher today in Tokyo, though the market slipped back from a strong surge in early trading. The Nikkei average of 225 issues ended at 24,275.08, for a gain of 192.82 points, or 0.80 percent.

headline: Scientology's Critical Ads
abstract: Every weekday for the next few weeks, readers of USA Today will find a different four-color, full-page advertisement taken out by the Church of Scientology International to protest Time magazine's May 6 cover article on the church.    The president of the church, the Rev. Heber Jentzsch, said in an interview yesterday that the cost of the campaign was "a couple of million dollars." He said a special advertising supplement in USA Today on June 14 would "document the whole story about Time magazine and give an overview on this attack on religion."

headline: Patents; Detecting Illegal Drugs in Newborn Infants
abstract: A pediatrician in Detroit recently patented a method of detecting traces of cocaine and other illegal drugs in the bloodstream of newborn infants whose mothers have been using drugs.   The test was invented by Dr. Eugene M. Ostrea Jr., chief of pediatrics at Hutzel Hospital, an inner-city hospital in which 44 percent of newborn babies were found to have been exposed to cocaine or marijuana. The purpose of the test is to alert doctors to the problem and obtain counseling for the mother. "The important thing is to diagnose the problem," the inventor said.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization                  April 19   Apr 12   April 20        1991   1991   1990        Gasoline production, daily   6.8   6.5   7.1        Distillate production, daily   2.8   2.8   3.0        Gasoline stocks   204.9   204.2   222.5        Distillate stocks   97.2   96.8   98.0        Crude imports, daily   4.5   6.5   5.7        Product imports, daily   2.3   1.4   2.1        Crude stocks   337.9   341.6   372.9        Crude production, daily   7.5   7.5   7.3        Refinery utilization (%)   83.9   84.1   86.2       Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: Bush Offers Trade-Pact Concessions
abstract: The Bush Administration, facing a critical vote in Congress next month over its authority to negotiate with other countries on trade, will make significant environmental and job-security commitments to accompany a trade pact with Mexico, Administration and Congressional aides said today.    The commitments are intended to sway votes in a battle that has pitted the Administration and proponents of free trade against organized labor, textile interests and others who fear that greater trade with Mexico will result in the loss of jobs and a weakening of environmental and labor standards.

headline: The S.E.C. And the Death Of Disclosure
abstract: Disclosure has been the foundation of American securities laws ever since the Securities and Exchange Commission was created, in the aftermath of the 1929 crash.   But while the people at the S.E.C. still talk a good game when it comes to disclosure, the fact is that the rules requiring it are being sacrificed at the altar of internationalization. It is getting easier for foreign companies to get American money without bothering to comply with America's accounting standards, which are generally more strict, and require more information, than their overseas counterparts.

headline: Selloff Hits Compaq on Profit News
abstract: Shares of the Compaq Computer Corporation lost more than a quarter of their value today after the company said it expected earnings to plummet at least 79 percent this quarter, mainly because of a sharp downturn in orders from some big retailers.   Joseph R. Canion, president and chief executive, said the earnings setback was caused by short-term problems as retailers with too much inventory trimmed orders, and he called the selloff an overreaction. But some analysts said Compaq's history of rapid growth since offering its first personal computers in 1982 might be over.

headline: The Latest Quest by the Idea Man of Communications
abstract: Jack Goeken is bursting out of a suit so old it has begun to shine. The soles of his shoes are flopping about. He drives a rusted-out 1981 Cadillac Eldorado, and he's broken so many briefcases jamming them with papers that he will on occasion carry a plastic garbage bag instead. More to the point, few of Mr. Goeken's many companies -- neither MCI, the long-distance carrier nor Airfone, the air-to-ground telephone company -- were ever profitable while he was at the helm.   So why is the entire telecommunications world so enamored of John D. Goeken? While he may not be much of an operations man or a strategic thinker, in the communications industry, Mr. Goeken is considered a brilliant entrepreneur. A frump, yes. But one with vision and dogged determination.

headline: American Express Unit Names New President
abstract: The data processing unit of the American Express Company yesterday named Jeremiah M. Callaghan as president of its newly formed Securities Information Group division.   The division was formed from the back-office operations of Shearson Lehman Brothers in January, as months of negotiations for a merger of operations with the Prudential Insurance Company of America's brokerage subsidiary were teetering on failure. Those talks subsequently broke off.

headline: Wary of Expense, Soviets Debate Bill to Ease Travel and Emigration
abstract: Soviet legislators today discussed the financial and human-rights considerations raised by a long-debated bill that would allow citizens the freedom to travel and emigrate. But they were unable to resolve their conflicting concerns and postponed a vote on the measure.   Although the Soviet Union has considerably eased its once overwhelming obstacles for those seeking to leave the country, on visits or permanently, it still does not have a law that grants its citizens the right to choose whether and when to go abroad.

headline: Aide Resigns in Dispute About Vietnam's M.I.A.'s
abstract: The head of a Pentagon intelligence unit assigned to account for United States servicemen missing in Vietnam has resigned, accusing Bush Administration officials of seeking to discredit and perhaps even cover up reports of sightings of Americans in the country.    The Army officer, Col. Millard A. Peck, left his job on March 28, stapling an unusual memorandum and farewell note to his office door that charged that his department was being used as a " 'toxic waste dump' to bury the whole 'mess' out of sight and mind in a facility with limited access to public scrutiny."

headline: Tokyo Stocks Finish Lower
abstract: Tokyo stocks were lower today in light trading. But brokers said that the downward trend lacked momentum, and that small selling moved the market because volume was so thin. Most leading overseas markets were closed on Friday and today for the Easter holiday, leaving Tokyo adrift.    The Nikkei index of 225 issues finished down 284.64 points, or slightly more than 1 percent, to 26,007.40. At midday, the Nikkei was down 292.14 points, or 1.1 percent, to 25,999.90. The midday drop was the first time the Nikkei fell below 26,000 since early March. The midday turnover was 140 million shares, down from 160 million at midday on Friday and the lowest since early February.

headline: Nycor to Keep Pressing Zenith
abstract: Nycor Inc., the largest shareholder of the Zenith Electronics Corporation, said it would press its effort to restructure the company despite failing to have its nominees elected to Zenith's board.    Zenith said its three nominees defeated, by a 2-to-1 margin, Nycor's three candidates in the April 24 election.

headline: MCI Chairman Is Back at Work
abstract: William G. McGowan, chairman of the MCI Communications Corporation, was back on the job today, just three days after his release from a hospital where he underwent chest surgery.    "I'm pleased to be here," Mr. McGowan said at MCI's annual shareholders meeting, "I'm pleased to be anywhere today."

headline: Kremlin and Striking Miners Reach Accord to Raise Pay
abstract: The Soviet Government and striking coal miners reached agreement today on a pay package that would double wages within a year in exchange for commitments on higher productivity.
