The agreement, announced after talks between representatives of the miners and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, made no mention of their political demands, including a call for Mr. Gorbachev's resignation.

headline: Struggling in a 40-Year-Old Straightjacket
abstract: To the Editor:   I am a (soon to be former) computer software analyst with a large information industry research and consulting company. I have a 3-year-old son, am pregnant with my second child and had asked to work less than full-time to accommodate the needs of my family as well as my career. My employer responded as Don Hewitt, executive producer of "60 Minutes" did to his correspondent, Meredith Vieira: He denied my request.("One of Its Own Gets '60 Minutes' Treatment," March 24)

headline: House Members to Explore Suspicions in '80 Campaign
abstract: Several senior members of the House of Representatives, encouraged by Speaker Thomas S. Foley, are beginning to explore informally charges that the 1980 Reagan-Bush campaign staff dealt with Iran to make sure 52 American hostages were not released until after the election.   Mr. Foley was asked at a news conference about a recent article on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times by Gary Sick, a professor and former National Security Council official, describing his research into a possible deal designed to keep President Carter from scoring an electoral coup with a release of the hostages before Election Day. Mr. Foley said, "I think we need to explore the allegations."

headline: Beijing University Students Mark the 1989 Crackdown
abstract: In a bold protest against China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, students at Beijing University early this morning smashed nearly 100 glass bottles to mark the second anniversary of the military crackdown here on the democracy movement.   Shortly after midnight, students began clapping, cheering and throwing bottles outside three graduate dormitories where policemen were patrolling, a witness said. In Chinese, "xiao ping," meaning "little bottle," is a homonym for Mr. Deng's given name, and protesters often express their feelings about Mr. Deng by shattering bottles.

headline: Mutual Funds; Time to Abandon the Indexes?
abstract: Funds that duplicate market indexes have jumped in popularity in recent years, partly because stock fund managers have failed to match the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index for eight years.  But stock fund managers beat the index for the seven years before that.    In the 80's, says A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services, corporate raids and leveraged buyouts pushed prices of S.& P. 500 companies higher than their earnings warranted. Meanwhile, many funds were invested in stocks of smaller companies, which lagged the broad market.

headline: Unemployment Rises in Canada
abstract: Canada's unemployment rate jumped to 10.5 percent in March, the highest in six years, the Government reported today. February's rate was 10.2 percent.    But economists said steadiness in the total number of jobs in the economy offered some hope that the worst of the recession was over.

headline: A Generic Version Of Lilly Antibiotic
abstract: Biocraft Laboratories said it was seeking Food and Drug Administration approval to produce a generic version of Eli Lilly & Company's antibiotic Ceclor, the top-selling brand antibiotic, with annual sales of more than $800 million. The drug is often used to treat respiratory and ear infections in children.   The main patent on Ceclor expires in December 1992, and Lilly, based in Indianapolis, is working on a successor, Lorbid, which could be on the market in mid-1992. Shares of Biocraft, based in Fair Lawn, N.J., gained 37.5 cents today on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $17.625, while Lilly's shares lost 75 cents, to $77.875.

headline: Pay-to-View Test Is Set For Denver
abstract: Three of the country's biggest telecommunications companies announced today that they would test whether cable television subscribers were interested in expanded pay-per-view services.    The expanded services will be provided to 450 cable subscribers through a joint effort by Tele-Communications Inc., A.T. &T. and U S West, the regional telephone holding company. John C. Malone, president and chief executive of Tele-Communications, said the market test, which will be conducted in the Denver area, would last about 18 months.

headline: Wall Street; Pity These Minority Shareholders
abstract: The head of Hercules gazes out of a catalogue from the Daedalus Gallery, a tiny exhibit space in the Fuller Building, at the hub of New York's uptown gallery scene. The owner of this heroic head is Asher B. Edelman, the former corporate raider.   The Daedalus Gallery itself is owned by the Canal Capital Corporation, a public company that Mr. Edelman controls. Once known as United Stockyards, Canal's shares still trade on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol "COW." But under Mr. Edelman, Canal has shed its stockyards and turned its hand to common stock and uncommon art.

headline: ERITREA'S CAPITAL REPORTED SEIZED
abstract: Ethiopian separatist guerrillas today captured Asmara, the second-largest city in the country after the capital, a senior Western diplomat said.   If accurate, the report would mean that the rebels had virtually completed a 31-year fight to conquer the Red Sea province of Eritrea.

headline: Bush Seeks Overhaul of Laws on Foreign Aid
abstract: Reviving a longtime tug-of-war between Congress and the executive branch over control of foreign policy, the Bush Administration has proposed an overhaul of foreign aid laws that would give the President far greater say in how the money is spent.   The ambitious plan, called the International Cooperation Act of 1991, would permit the President, among other things, to override the Congressional procedure of earmarking more than 90 percent of foreign aid allocations to a handful of countries under a fixed formula.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Allied Stores Corp., Cincinnati, announced the appointment of Robert DiNicola as president and chief operating officer of Bon Marche, its Seattle-based department store unit. * Bank of the West, San Francisco, elected Robert A. Fuhrman chairman to succeed Halsey Burke, who has retired. Michel Larrouilh, chief executive, was named to the additonal post of vice chairman, and Don J. McGrath was made president.

headline: Dow Rises 2.73, Ending a Three-Day Slide
abstract: After what looked much like another poor day on Wall Street, stock prices moved slightly higher late yesterday, ending a three-day losing streak.    "What we've seen here is a short-term selloff," said Kenneth M. Spence, director of technical analysis for Salomon Brothers. "The market is now trying to stabilize around 2,920."

headline: Trade Gap Narrows to 7-Year Low
abstract: Paced by a big drop in the bill for imported oil, the nation's trade deficit shriveled to $5.3 billion in February, the smallest in more than seven years, the Commerce Department reported today.   Although exports fell slightly, imports fell three times as much to chop the deficit -- the amount by which the country's purchases of foreign goods exceed its sales abroad -- by $1.8 billion, or 26 percent.

headline: FRANCE CONCEDES ITS FAULTS IN WAR
abstract: In the first public recognition by France that it was ill-prepared to fight the Persian Gulf war, Defense Minister Pierre Joxe conceded today that French forces were overwhelmingly dependent on military intelligence provided by the United States.   Announcing plans to unite the country's five often competing military intelligence bodies into a single branch of the armed forces, he said at a military seminar here, "Without allied intelligence in the war, we would have been almost blind."

headline: Top U.S. Marketing Post Is Filled at Zenith Data
abstract: Zenith Data Systems yesterday named Michael J. Poehner as its executive vice president for North American sales and marketing, its top United States marketing job. Mr. Poehner, 44, now heads national sales and marketing for Businessland Inc., a national computer chain.    A 20-year computer industry veteran, Mr. Poehner is taking charge of an effort to shift the focus of Zenith Data, a subsidiary of the French-based Groupe Bull. Zenith Data, whose niche in personal computers is in the government and educational markets, is seeking to enter the commercial mainstream. It is trying to broaden its distribution channel, and company officials said they were close to announcing two important new nationwide distributors. Zenith Data is now distributed nationally by the Compucom computer chain.

headline: Money Market Funds Post Declining Yields in Week
abstract: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report fell for the week ended yesterday.    Analysts at IBC/Donoghue's said short-term interest rates were still coming down weeks after the Federal Reserve cut the discount rate on April 30, while yields on longer maturities had begun inching up after the Government's quarterly refunding last week.

headline: Security-Force Pact Is Settled With Iraq, Official at U.N. Says
abstract: The United Nations and Iraq signed an agreement in Baghdad today allowing 400 to 500 United Nations security guards to move into northern Iraq.   The agreement, signed by the Secretary General's representative in Baghdad, Bernt Bernander, allows for the security guards to enter northern Iraq to protect United Nations civilian workers there as well as equipment belonging to the organization.

headline: Bill to Check Executive Pay
abstract: Salaries of corporate executives are "spiraling out of control," Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, said today as he introduced legislation to give shareholders a larger voice in setting the pay of top company officers.   The bill would allow stockholder votes on salaries and other compensation of chief executives and directors. It would also require broader disclosure of pay packages.

headline: Bonds Are Priced By Florida County
abstract: Orange County, Fla., tentatively priced a tax-exempt hospital revenue bond issue yesterday with a maximum yield of 6.809 percent for a debt security due in 2005 through an underwriting group led by Ziegler Securities.   The financing is on behalf of Adventist Health System Sun Belt Inc. and includes bonds with yields ranging from 5.25 percent in 1992 to 6 percent in 1996 to 6.60 percent in 2002. Underwriters said the issue had been rated Baa-1 by Moody's and AAA by S.& P., whose rating is based on insurance coverage by the Capital Guaranty Insurance Company.

headline: FORUM; Most Wanted in America: More Capital
abstract: Late in the spring, a San Diego biotechnology company, Viagene, signed a multimillion-dollar pact giving a Japanese company worldwide marketing rights for its newest AIDS drug. Afterward, the company's president, Robert T. Abbott, was quoted as saying: "If you can't find the investment to cure AIDS in the U.S., does that mean we shouldn't get the funds elsewhere?"  That's an important question.

headline: Time Warner Operating Income Off 1.1%
abstract: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that operating income for the first quarter fell 1.1 percent, to $530 million, from $536 million in the corresponding period a year earlier.    The company said it had a net loss for the quarter of $50 million, compared with a loss of $51 million a year ago. It attributed the latest loss to interest expense and accounting treatment associated with the 1989 purchase of Warner Communications.

headline: STATES AND CITIES WITH DEFICIT WOES MAY SLOW REBOUND
abstract: States and municipalities across the country plan to raise taxes and cut spending by tens of billions of dollars in the fiscal year that begins July 1, and economists fear that the money this takes out of consumers' pockets could inhibit recovery from the recession.    Edward M. Gramlich, a professor of economics at the University of Michigan who is studying the situation for the Congressional Budget Office, has concluded that belt-tightening by state and local governments could send unemployment up one-half of one percentage point nationwide and much more in New York, California and New England, where fiscal problems are the worst.

headline: Farm Credits for Soviets
abstract: Officials of the Agriculture Department and the Soviet Union met today to discuss the allocation of the first instalment of $1.5 billion in export credits, American officials said. The value of the export credits under discussion, the first of three instalments set for this year, is $600 million, much of which is expected to be used for corn.

headline: Trade Focus Has Changed
abstract: As the United States and Mexico discuss environmental cooperation under arrangements to lower trade barriers at the Rio Grande, they are demonstrating how profoundly the nature of trade policy has changed over the last two decades.    At one time, tariffs were the primary concern -- something external, remote and without high political visibility.

headline: Soybean Group Backs Chiefs
abstract: The American Soybean Association said today that its directors had voted to retain the group's top leadership, turning back a challenge amid allegations of financial mismanagement.    The directors of the powerful lobby group on Sunday rejected resolutions from several state organizations seeking the resignations of the chief executive officer, Ken Bader, and the executive vice president, Steve Drake, officials said today.

headline: WEALTHY NATIONS WARY ON OFFERING SOVIETS QUICK AID
abstract: Most key officials at a gathering of the industrial world's finance ministers said today that Western nations should not grant large-scale economic aid to the Soviet Union until Moscow first demonstrates its commitment to substantial economic reform.    At the two-day meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and other finance ministers all but ruled out quick action on a large-scale aid program for the Soviet Union.

headline: Compaq to Buy Stake in Silicon Graphics
abstract: The Compaq Computer Corporation will invest $185 million in Silicon Graphics Inc. as part of a strategic alliance that could upset the balance of power in the computer industry.    Under the terms of the agreement announced today, Compaq will pay $135 million in cash for a 13 percent stake in Silicon Graphics, a maker of powerful work stations used to display sophisticated images.

headline: Airbus Payment
abstract: Airbus Industrie, the four-nation Europoean aircraft consortium, said it would repay $900 million of the money it borrowed from European governments to build up its business. The payment would come on top of $500 million that was repaid last year, the company said. Last week, the United States complained to a committee of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which oversees world trade and resolves disputes, that the subsidies gave Airbus an unfair advantage over the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the nation's largest aircraft makers.

headline: Lebanese Magazine Reports That 2 U.S. Hostages Are Ill
abstract: The Lebanese magazine Al Shiraa said today that the lives of two American hostages, Terry A. Anderson and Alann Steen, were endangered by serious illness.   The magazine is usually well informed about the 12 Westerners believed to be held hostage in Lebanon. It quoted a "reliable source" as saying that Mr. Anderson and Mr. Steen were "in continuously deteriorating health condition" and that Mr. Steen, 55 years old, "was not responding to medical treatment that he has been subject to." Al Shiraa gave no details on the nature of the men's illnesses.

headline: Chrysler Officer Is Injured
abstract: Robert Lutz, president of the Chrysler Corporation, was treated for minor injuries after his helicopter crashed between airport runways Sunday as he tried to land it.    Mr. Lutz, 59 years old, was trying to land his Robison R-22 helicopter at the Ann Arbor airport when it crashed about 5:30 P.M. between two runways, the police in Pittsfield Township said. No other injuries were reported.

headline: Construction Outlays Fall A Slim 0.1%
abstract: Construction spending dipped by one-tenth of 1 percent in February, the Government said today, but analysts suggested that the barely perceptible drop pointed to an upturn ahead. Construction outlays have now declined for 11 straight months.   "I think we're pretty close to the bottom and we'll be seeing the construction number starting to edge up in the coming months," said David Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association.

headline: P.&G. Official Named To Ad Council Panel
abstract: John G. Smale, the chairman of the executive committee of the Procter & Gamble Company, has been named chairman of the advisory committee on public issues of the Advertising Council.   Mr. Smale succeeds William F. May, who resigned from the post. The committee helps the council determine the issues that it will promote with its public-service advertising.

headline: Slump or No, Short Fridays Remain a Right of Summer
abstract: "SUMER is icumen in," a 13th- century poet wrote. And so are summer hours.   The Memorial Day weekend is not only the unofficial start of summer but the official start of what advertising people call summer hours. The term refers to schedules designed to let employees take advantage of those lazy, hazy days ahead.

headline: India's Soon-to-Be-Ex-Premier Likes It That Way
abstract: It's his 65th birthday, and Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar, now serving as caretaker, is in an expansive mood as he discusses his experiences as the shortest-tenured Prime Minister in India's history here at the country retreat south of New Delhi that he has turned into a green oasis merely by conserving rainwater.   "The villagers said it couldn't be done," he said. "They told me nothing has grown here for a thousand years."

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Allen Group Inc., Melville, L.I., an electronic products company, will sell its Allen Automated Systems division to Lucas Industries, a United States subsidiary of Lucas Industries P.L.C., Birmingham, England, an automotive and aerospace equipment company. Terms were not disclosed. * Dresser-Rand Co., a 50-50 joint venture between Dresser Industries, Dallas, a maker of products for the energy industry, and Ingersoll-Rand Co., Woodcliff Lake, N.J., a maker of industrial machinery, has received a $120 million order from Maravan S.A., an affiliate of the Venezuelan oil company Petroleos de Venezuela S.A., to supply three gas compression plants.

headline: U.S. Complaint On Airbus Aid
abstract: The United States has charged that subsidies on airliners built by Airbus Industrie, the European constortium, violate free-trade rules, a trade official said today.    "It's a general complaint covering all aspects of support for the Airbus program," the official said, adding that it was a necessary step toward seeking an independent panel of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world trade body, to rule on the dispute should Washington press the case that far.

headline: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
abstract: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings for this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.    By late in the day Friday the outstanding three-month bill was bid at 5.59 percent and the six-month bill at 5.78 percent.

headline: Chrysler to Export Special Cherokees
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said it would build right-hand-drive Jeep Cherokees next year for export to foreign markets. The Cherokees will be produced at the Beijing Jeep Corporation, Chrysler's joint venture in China, and at the company's Toledo, Ohio, assembly plant. Karen Stewart, a Chrysler spokeswoman in Detroit, said the company would not disclose how many modified Cherokees would be produced at the two plants.   Ms. Stewart said there would be no change in employment at Toledo, whose 4,800 hourly workers produce Cherokee two- and four-door models, Comanche pickup trucks and Grand Wagoneer vehicles. She did not know if employment would change at Beijing, whose 4,900 hourly workers also build Cherokees. Chrysler said in a statement that it was considering all of the world's right-hand-drive markets for the modified Cherokees. Those markets include Japan, Britain, Australia and New Zealand.

headline: Transit Agency Notes Due in '92
abstract: The Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority yesterday priced $175 million in notes due March 2, 1992, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.   Underwriters said $125 million of the debt was not backed by a letter of credit, while $50 million was by one issued from Morgan Guaranty.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Carolina Power and Light Co., Raleigh, N.C., said the Nuclear Regulatory Commission had said it would likely be fined $87,500 for three violations at the Brunswick Steam Electric Plant near Southport, N.C. The company has 30 days to pay the penalty or appeal. * Georgia-Pacific Corp., Atlanta, sold 49,000 acres of timberland in Washington state to Trillium Corp. for about $48 million.

headline: U.N. Chief Proposes Plan for Referendum In Western Sahara
abstract: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar recommended today that a peacekeeping force be sent to Western Sahara to oversee a referendum to decide whether the territory is to become independent of Morocco.    The former Spanish colony was divided in 1975 between Mauritania and Morocco. Mauritania later yielded its portion to Morocco. The Polisario Front, founded in 1973 to fight for independence from Spain, has waged a guerrilla war against the Moroccans.

headline: Baghdad Chief Installs Kinsmen in Key Posts
abstract: In the three months since the end of the Persian Gulf war, experts say, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has sought to tighten his grip on power by turning over key functions of Government to trusted family members.    He has also taken steps intended to portray Iraq as committed to "democratization," by holding autonomy talks with Kurdish leaders, abolishing the secret Revolutionary Court, easing restrictions on travel and news organizations and promising to hold elections and disband the ruling Revolutionary Command Council.

headline: Sea Turtles Put New Friction In U.S.-Japan Trade Quarrels
abstract: With its hooked beak, scaly neck and stubby legs, the yard-long hawksbill sea turtle will win no beauty contests. But this homely creature, an endangered vestige of the dinosaur age, is suddenly at the center of a squall in United States-Japanese relations.    It does not have the grace of a dolphin, the majesty of a whale or the mournful appeal of a baby harp seal. But the hawksbill may well prompt the first use of an American law authorizing curbs on imports of fish and other wildlife products from countries that contribute to the disappearance of an endangered species.  Sanctions Seem Near     Barring a last-minute breakthrough in negotiations, President Bush is likely to inform Congress by Sunday that the United States will impose trade sanctions on Japan for the sake of this rare turtle, senior Administration officials said today. It would be the first time the United States has used trade sanctions to help protect an endangered species.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: THE ECONOMY    The credit drought may be easing as fewer banks are tightening lending practices. A Federal Reserve survey shows just over a fifth of the banks imposed stiffer terms on business loans in the last six weeks, compared with one-half in November.  [ D1. ]   Wall Street firms are searching for ways to finish a complex reorganization of back-office operations. Some firms are considering various strategies including moving operations out of Manhattan -- even to third-world countries -- to cut costs.  [ D1. ]

headline: Quake Jolts Soviet Georgia
abstract: A strong earthquake struck a mountainous region in the southern Soviet Union today, killing at least six people and leveling villages, officials said. Less destructive temblors also hit Japan and the South Sandwich Islands.   The Soviet earthquake took place near an area that was struck by a quake in April that left more than 100 people dead and 100,000 homeless. Specialists classified today's quake, which registered 6.3 on the Richter scale, as an aftershock from that April 29 temblor, which registered 7.0.

headline: Dow Up 13.41; Impact of Bond Sales Cited
abstract: Stocks took a cue from bonds yesterday and moved into higher ground.    Traders attributed the strength, such as it was, to favorable investor reception to the Treasury's record-setting refinancing, along with a stronger dollar and a decline in commodity prices to the lowest level in almost three months.    The Dow Jones industrial average, helped by a gain in I.B.M. and Du Pont, rose 13.41 points, to 2,930.90.

headline: Former Executive at Drexel Indicated in Conspiracy Case
abstract: A former senior executive with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. was indicted yesterday on charges that he engaged in an illegal conspiracy with Michael R. Milken and a former Drexel client to commit securities fraud, embezzlement and other crimes.    The former executive, Alan E. Rosenthal, had been the head of the convertible department in Drexel's "junk bond" division in Beverly Hills, Calif., and a close associate of Mr. Milken, the former head of the division who pleaded guilty last year to six felony charges stemming from his securities trading. Mr. Milken is now serving a 10-year prison term.

headline: The Media Business: ADDENDA; Coming and Going At TBWA Advertising
abstract: At TBWA Advertising, New York, there is news of an arrival and a departure.   The arrival is Lois Geller, 47 years old, who leaves AC&R Direct, New York, to found Geller Associates, TBWA's first direct marketing subsidiary.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: DEBT * General Motors Acceptance Corp., a unit of General Motors Corp., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of up to $2.3 billion in debt securities and warrants. * Marriott Corp., Washington, D.C., has filed for about $150 million in liquid yield option notes due 2006 through Merrill Lynch & Co. as sole underwriter.

headline: Business and Health; Debate on Plan To Limit Lawsuits
abstract: PRESIDENT BUSH sent a proposal to Congress earlier this month to limit medical malpractice lawsuits, accepting a recommendation that the American Medical Association had been pushing for five years. The association has said the limits work in California and has suggested that changes in the malpractice laws could ultimately reduce health-care spending.   But lawyers who file the malpractice suits insist that the doctors have not proved their point.

headline: Bank Accounting Shift Held Doubtful
abstract: A senior bank regulator said today that the Bush Administration's proposal to encourage more lending through the relaxation of a significant accounting standard might not be adopted by the Government because it had run into strong opposition from several large banks.    L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said the proposal, which would enable banks to report greater earnings by splitting bad loans into performing and nonperforming parts, had been criticized by several large banks that said it would have no effect on their financial statements. He did not identify the banks.

headline: Money Fund Assets Off
abstract: The assets of the nation's 556 money market mutual funds decreased by $5.27 billion, to $464.46 billion, in the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 203 institutional funds decreased by $3.69 billion, to $133.53 billion. The assets of the 263 general-purpose funds were down by $863.8 million, to $179.84 billion. The 90 broker-dealer funds decreased by $712.5 million, to $152.09 billion, the institute said.

headline: Elizabeth Visits Ulster
abstract: Queen Elizabeth II, making her first visit to Northern Ireland since 1977, saluted today the work of a British Army regiment. Roads were blocked and security was intense as the Queen arrived in this southern suburb of Belfast to present colors to the Ulster Defense Regiment, a locally raised and largely part-time force. The regiment enjoys strong support from Northern Ireland's Protestant majority.

headline: Israeli Economy Is Keeping Many Jews in U.S.S.R.
abstract: The Israeli Government is openly acknowledging for the first time that tens of thousands of Soviet Jews are postponing or canceling their moves to Israel because of the country's inability to provide jobs for those already here.   In dozens of emotional speeches over the last 18 months, Israeli leaders have tied the nation's hopes for the future to the successful absorption of the Soviet Union's Jews. Now they admit that they are failing.

headline: Lebanese Cabinet Tells P.L.O. Guerrillas to Disarm
abstract: Muslim and Christian Government leaders said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization must disarm thousands of its guerrillas in Lebanon and end its "state within the Lebanese state."    The officials, belonging to all religious denominations, said that henceforth, Palestinians would not remain outside the law. "What applies to Lebanese must apply to Palestinians," said Nabih Berri, a Cabinet minister who heads the country's largest Shiite Muslim militia, Amal. The Speaker of Parliament, Hussein al-Husseini, also a Shiite, said at a news conference: "We pay no heed to statements by the P.L.O. The Lebanese law must apply to outsiders before Lebanese."

headline: Peru Is Selling Stake in Mines
abstract: Peru has announced plans to sell stakes in its largest state- owned mines to private interests as part of a program to open the economy to foreign investment.    Fernando Sanchez Albavera, the Energy and Mines Minister, told reporters on Sunday that the Government would also sell 74 of the gasoline stations operated by the state- owned oil company, Petroperu.

headline: All About/Initial Public Offerings; Company Hunger, Investor Interest Mean a Hotter New-Issues Market
abstract: Initial public offerings -- companies' first sales of stock to the public -- have all the excitement of opening night on Broadway. Will the offering be a success? Will it flop? After months of meticulous preparation, Wall Street bankers and corporate executives hold their collective breath as the stock is tossed out onto the market and there, in the instant of a trading day, is judged a winner or shrugged off into oblivion.    Some offerings are, indeed, show stoppers. One of the most dramatic came in 1956 when investors lined up outside brokerage houses to get the first public offering of Ford Motor Company shares. In 1980, Apple Computer went public with similar fanfare. "Not since Eve has an apple posed such temptation," as The Wall Street Journal put it.

headline: Violent Impasse in Seoul
abstract: One of the more revealing moments in the flare-up of violence between student demonstrators and the South Korean Government over the last two weeks was the hasty retraction of comments by a senior member of the ruling party that the much-feared plainclothes riot police should be disbanded.     The politician, Kim Chong Hoh, the Democratic Liberal Party's floor leader in the National Assembly, told reporters he had asked the Interior Minister to dissolve these forces, which were notorious for their rough tactics long before they beat a student to death with steel pipes two weeks ago. But the party spokesman later insisted no such request had been made or was planned.

headline: I.B.M. Introduces Airline Software
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation said it had introduced a new software system for airline services and was working with USAir Group Inc. to develop applications for the airline industry. I.B.M. said USAir had participated in field tests for the new product, called the Airline Application Development System, and that it would begin installing the software in trial applications in July.    The new software is designed to handle flight information, gate scheduling and to link the reservation systems of several airlines, among other functions. I.B.M. said it could improve airline customer services and airport operations without costly changes to existing computer systems.

headline: Economic Scene; Soft Landing, Soft Recovery?
abstract: IS the recession over? Has the recovery begun? At least to the nation's most influential economic prophet, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, these are not two sides of the same question but two separate questions.    During his Congressional testimony last week, Mr. Greenspan answered the first question by saying that although the data might be revised up or down, "it's very difficult to get around the data of the last several weeks, which are strongly suggestive that the bottom is somewhere in the second quarter." Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, took the same position yesterday.

headline: Businessland Suits In Settlement
abstract: Businessland Inc., a personal computer retailer based in San Jose, Calif., said that its board had approved the settlement of five class-action lawsuits brought by shareholders against the company. The settlement, which is still subject to court approval, calls for Businessland to contribute $2 million in cash and shares of its common stock valued at $4 million into a settlement fund being established by the court. The suits were filed on Aug. 6, after Businessland reported a steep loss for its fourth quarter, ended on June 30, and that it would have to restate results for its second and third quarters, resulting in a sizable loss for the year.    Businessland has had five consecutive quarters of losses. The company said the settlement does not constitute an admission of liability or wrongdoing on its part.

headline: Media General Sells Cliggott
abstract: Media General Inc. said today that it had sold the Cliggott Publishing Company of Greenwich, Conn., to Cliggott's management.    Cliggott publishes four monthly medical journals, including Consultant, with a circulation of 125,000. The other magazines are the Journal of Respiratory Diseases, the Journal of Musculoskeletal Medicine and the Journal of Critical Illness, each with a circulation of 70,000 to 80,000.

headline: Poor Countries' Arrears
abstract: Eastern European and developing countries are falling further behind on their interest payments to commercial banks, an international banking official said yesterday. Interest arrears rose to nearly $27 billion at the end of March, from $18 billion at the end of last September, said Horst Schulmann, the managing director of the Institute of International Finance, a trade association in Washington.

headline: Pentagon Payment Decision
abstract: Two House panels are investigating the Pentagon's decision to allow manufacturers of the canceled A-12 Stealth fighter plane to defer repaying $1.35 billion to the Government.   Members of Congress have questioned whether the deal amounts to a bailout of two large military contractors, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and the General Dynamics Corporation.

headline: More Assets Shielded By Bankruptcy Ruling
abstract: The Supreme Court's decision yesterday will enable many individuals to emerge from bankruptcy proceedings with assets like investment real estate and stocks intact.   "Instead of having a fire sale, you may now have the chance to keep some of the things that you value," said Malcolm A. Makin, president of the Personal Planning Group, a financial adviser in Westerly, R.I.

headline: SOVIET REFORMISTS WEIGH BREAKAWAY
abstract: Momentum for forming a nationwide political movement to oppose the Communist Party appeared to grow today as a senior adviser and confidante to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said that party hard-liners had been considering whether to investigate him and possibly purge him from the party.    "I reserve the right to make the necessary decision," said the adviser, Aleksandr Yakovlev, referring to his right to quit in answer to the party hard-liners, who have been alarmed by reports that Mr. Yakovlev has been privately encouraging the formation of a full-fledged anti-Communist political opposition.

headline: Winds in Mauritania Kill 4
abstract: Violent winds left at least 4 people dead and 300 injured in this Mauritanian capital and another city, hospital officials said today. The winds, which ripped through the cities Friday night and destroyed many homes, left three women dead in Nouakchott and killed a child in Boutilinit, east of the capital, the officials said.

headline: U.S. MILITARY TAKES OVER RELIEF FOR KURDISH REFUGEES IN IRAQ
abstract: The United States began taking control Friday of the struggling relief effort for the Iraqi Kurds by outlining plans for the American military to feed 700,000 people a day and to set up temporary refugee settlements in northern Iraq, United States officials said.    "We will be doing this until the international community can get itself organized," an official involved in the planning said. Basically the Americans have concluded, with Turkey's agreement, that unless they move in quickly with troops and machines, thousands of deaths will occur among the estimated 550,000 Kurds who are camped on the harsh mountainous border between Turkey and Iraq. More than 1.2 million refugees are believed to be in and around the Iraq's border with Iran.  Military More Suited to Task     The feeling is that international operations, hampered by hostile terrain and bureaucratic delays, are moving too slowly -- and that only the United States military has the ability to put together a rescue operation right away.

headline: Blasts on Oil Tanker Increase Fears in Italy
abstract: A huge explosion and two smaller blasts rocked a burning tanker today, heightening fears that the sinking vessel could break apart and spill millions of gallons of oil onto the Italian Riviera.   In Rome, the Government declared a state of emergency, making the region eligible for special aid. There was no estimate on the amount of oil spilled from the tanker, which was loaded with nearly 41 million gallons of crude oil when it began burning on Thursday after an explosion in a holding tank.

headline: Coke's Splash in Eastern Germany
abstract: Wolfgang Schulze was running a ramshackle soft-drink plant in a former Weimar brewery when East Germany's Communist system crumbled last year. Now, he is overseeing construction of a fully modern bottling plant for one of capitalism's flagships: the Coca-Cola Company.   Mr. Schulze's swift conversion from Communist bureaucrat to technical director of the Weimar plant is no accident. It is a result of Coca-Cola's agility and resourcefulness in making a big move into the eastern German market. While most Western companies remain reluctant to dip into the economically troubled region, the soft-drink giant plunged in even before German unification. Now, Coke plans to spend $450 million over the next two years, one of its largest foreign investments anywhere to date.

headline: Chrysler Move On Research
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said it had entered a joint manufacturing research program with Mercury Marine that is expected to speed the development of a smaller, lighter and more fuel-efficient two-stroke engine.   Neither Chrysler nor Mercury Marine, the boat engine division of the Brunswick Corporation, disclosed the financial terms.

headline: Selling Planes That Won the War
abstract: President Bush and President Francois Mitterrand of France have recently called for limiting arms exports, but their message has clearly not sunk in at the Paris Air Show, the world's largest showplace for fighter-bombers, attack helicopters and air-to-air missiles.    Since the 10-day show opened on June 13, dozens of combat aircraft have been parked on the tarmac at Le Bourget Airport, including an oversized Soviet MIG-31, a British Tornado GR, a French Mirage 2000 and a stubby Yugoslav G-4 Super Galeb bomber. But the aircraft drawing the most attention among the 400,000 expected visitors is Lockheed's F-117A Stealth fighter, whose pinpoint bombing wreaked so much damage on Iraq during the Persian Gulf war.

headline: Sallie Mae Sets Note Offering
abstract: A $300 million issue of notes of the Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae, was priced yesterday through Morgan Stanley & Company, as sole underwriter.    The floating-rate notes scheduled to mature on April 24, 1995, were priced at 100, to float at 57.5 basis points above the Treasury's three-month bill.   Interest on the notes will be adjusted weekly and paid on a quarterly basis, with the first payment on April 22.

headline: Generic Drug Guilty Plea
abstract: A former employee of Vitarine Pharmaceuticals Inc. pleaded guilty today to submitting falsified test results to the Food and Drug Administration to win approval for the company's generic drugs.    The former director of research and development for Vitarine, Steven Colton, 39 years old, disguised brand-name drugs so they would appear to be Vitarine products and gave them to independent laboratories to be tested on humans, prosecutors said.

headline: COMPANY NEWS; G.M. to Sell Special Stock, Raising Cash
abstract: Betting on a bright future, the General Motors Corporation said today that it planned to raise as much as $600 million by selling an unusual type of stock that will save money for the company if the price of its common shares rises, but will cost it money if the common stock declines.   General Motors, which cut its dividend by nearly half in February and later announced a loss of $1.1 billion for the first quarter, needs the money to improve its weakened cash flow. The company, the world's largest auto maker, said it planned to use the money for its global automotive and financing operations.

headline: It's a Merrily Asynchronous World We Have
abstract: Last week seemed to prove that the world's stock markets are as tightly intertwined as the circuitry on a computer chip. Shocks from far   -   flung markets -- a potential cease-fire violation in Baghdad, a tax hike in Bonn, a financial scandal in Tokyo -- helped knock the Dow, which closed at 2906.75, down by 58.81 points for the week. But don't jump to the conclusion that the world's stock markets will keep marching in lockstep.   True, investors all over the globe are becoming decidedly less provincial. Every day more than $600 billion sloshes around the world's currency markets. Foreigners tripled their holdings of American stocks during the 1980's. American stockholders, meanwhile, quintupled their ownership of foreign shares.

headline: Iraq Asks U.N. to Permit Big Sale Of Oil to Pay for Imports of Food
abstract: Iraq asked the Security Council today to ease the United Nations trade embargo by giving Baghdad permission to sell almost $1 billion worth of oil on world markets over the next four months to pay for emergency imports of food and other essential humanitarian items.    The Iraqi request was contained in a letter to Austria's United Nations representative, Peter Hohenfellner, who heads the Security Council committee monitoring the economic blockade of Iraq. It said Baghdad wants to raise $942.5 million through such oil sales to finance a list of essential goods it needs.

headline: 8 Bids Spurned By Potomac
abstract: The Potomac Edison Company yesterday rejected all bids from investment banks on the sale of $50 million in first mortgage bonds, an official at the parent company, Allegheny Power Systems Inc., said.   The 30-year bonds were scheduled to be sold through competitive bidding in the morning, but the utility rejected bids from all eight underwriting groups involved because their interest rates were "all higher than we wanted to see," said Nancy Campbell, treasurer at Allegheny Power. She added that the company would monitor interest rates and could be in the market again if they came down.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Ameritrust Corp., Cleveland, a bank holding company, said it had received proposals to enter into merger talks. * General Electric Co., Fairfield, Conn., said its G.E. Information Services unit would take a significant minority interest in Data Management International Ltd., a distributor of G.E.'s teleprocessing services and related software in Korea. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Britain Moving to Allow Trials of Suspected Nazis
abstract: Invoking a rarely used constitutional procedure, the Government leader in the House of Commons moved today to overrule rejection by the House of Lords of a bill to permit prosecution of suspected Nazi war criminals living in Britain.   The bill will go to Queen Elizabeth II for immediate enactment. Members of the Commons passed the bill in March for the second time in a year, by 254 to 88, after the House of Lords first rejected it last June. The Lords did so again Tuesday night by voting for a delaying amendment, 131 to 109. The House of Commons is elected; the House of Lords is not.

headline: Sale by Banc One Of Preferred Stock
abstract: Several companies took advantage of the drop in Treasury bond yields to price new securities yesterday, after a larger-than-expected rise in the weekly unemployment claims data. But other issuers are expected to wait until today's employment news to see whether interest rates may be pushed even lower.   The Banc One Corporation priced $250 million in convertible preferred stock through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

headline: Overhaul Of Bailout Is Sought
abstract: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that he had asked the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to step aside as the day-to-day manager of the savings and loan bailout in favor of a "strong chief executive officer" still to be named.   The announcement came at a bitter, and at times emotional, hearing before the Senate Banking Committee. The hearing was marked by Democratic accusations that the Bush Administration, for political reasons, repeatedly and deliberately concealed the magnitude of both the banking and savings and loan crises.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Ernst of Improper Dealings
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a lawsuit yesterday accusing Ernst & Young, one of the nation's largest accounting firms, of having improper business dealings with two of its clients that caused those clients to violate Federal securities laws.    The complaint, filed in Federal District Court in Washington, contends that the firm lacked independence when it audited the Republicbank Corporation and the Cullum Companies. At the time of the audits, dozens of Ernst & Young partners had private business ties with the two clients, including bank loans from Republicbank to finance shopping centers where Cullum operated supermarkets.

headline: IMPASSE ON ARMS IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: The spear of the kind carried by Zulu migrant workers has become both the immediate cause and the sweeping symbol of the rupture that led the African National Congress on Saturday to suspend talks with the white minority Government on a proposed constitution.   Fighting between black factions, which pits supporters of the congress and those of the Zulu-dominated Inkatha Freedom Party, has killed 800 people so far this year. The congress accuses the Government of condoning and at times assisting Inkatha.

headline: U.S. Wants Saudi Torture Suit Settled
abstract: The State Department, which has been sharply criticized by some members of Congress for siding with the Saudi Government in a lawsuit involving an American businessman who said he was tortured by Saudi officials, has now urged the two parties settle the case.    The case involves Scott J. Nelson, a North Carolina businessman who has filed a suit contending that he was arrested at his job at a Riyadh hospital in 1984 and beaten so badly that his knee joints snapped. Mr. Nelson brought suit in Federal District Court under a 1976 law that allows people to sue foreign governments for their conduct if it is connected to commercial activity within the United States.

headline: Go-Video Plans To Appeal Verdict
abstract: Go-Video Inc. said it would appeal a jury verdict rejecting its claim that three Japanese electronics companies conspired to prevent introduction of a dual-deck videocassette recorder in the mid-1980's. "I'll never give up," R. Terren Dunlap, Go-Video's chairman, said. A United States District Court jury found Thursday in favor of the defendants, the Sony Corporation, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company and the Victor Company of Japan.   Go-Video filed an antitrust lawsuit in 1987 against more than 20 defendants, contending that they had conspired to block the manufacture and sale of the VCR-2 because they had not been able to put the device together themselves. Go-Video settled or gave up on all but the three defendants, receiving about $6.8 million in out-of-court settlements and an agreement with the Samsung Electronics Company of South Korea to manufacture the VCR-2.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Genzyme's Drug
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration approved Ceredase, a drug developed by the Genzyme Corporation of Cambridge, Mass., for the treatment of Gaucher's disease, a disorder that causes anemia and enlargement of the liver and spleen. The disease affects an estimated 10,000 to 15,000 people in the United States, of whom about 2,000 to 3,000 need treatment. Patients often suffer fatigue, distended abdomens and fragile and painful bones.    The new drug, alglucerase, replaces an enzyme that is missing in people who have the hereditary disorder, the F.D.A. said. The agency had made the drug available early to desperately ill patients. It also designated the product an "orphan" drug, which gives companies an incentive to research and seek approval for products that would be used by a small group of patients. Genzyme's shares closed unchanged at $38.50 each in over-the-counter trading today.

headline: Tech Notes; Adding a Cylinder for Kick
abstract: Since the earliest automobiles, most cars have had two, four, six or eight cylinders. An even number of cylinders allows the up-and-down motion of each piston to be offset by another piston. An engine with an odd number of cylinders tends to vibrate more. Nevertheless, a few companies have used engines with three or five cylinders. Honda's new four-door Vigor comes with a five-cylinder engine (right) so as to pack more horsepower in a small engine compartment. Honda engineers dampened the vibration by careful timing of each piston's stroke. Their design also incorporates hydraulic devices at points where the engine is attached to the car's frame. The all-aluminum engine displaces 2.5 liters and produces 176 horsepower. By contrast, the Honda Accord has a 2.2 liter four-cylinder engine that produces 125 horsepower.

headline: Mellon to Redeem Preferred July 19
abstract: The proceeds of the Mellon Bank Corporation's $100 million debt offering early this week through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers will be used in part to redeem its series A preferred stock.   Mellon, a major regional bank holding company, said the series A preferred will be redeemed on July 19 at $25.56 a share. It was issued at an average price of $25.59.   The rest of the proceeds are expected to be added to the corporation's general funds and be available for general corporate financing purposes.

headline: Wieden & Kennedy Wins 4th Client in East
abstract: Wieden & Kennedy, the Portland, Ore., agency that is rapidly making a name for itself on the East Coast, yesterday picked up its fourth client based in the East.    The new client is Morgans Hotel Group Inc., New York. The account, to create television commercials for the trendy Paramount, Royalton, Morgans and Barbizon hotels in Manhattan, has billings estimated at $1 million to $2 million.

headline: The New Hitler Youth Are Troubling Germany
abstract: The scarred tenement is being restored by a gang of skinheads, but nearby squatters have smeared it with the words Nazi Club.   "The squatters are leftists, and my boys are rightists," said Michael Heinisch, a social worker who is guiding the project with church money. "So there are frictions."

headline: Gain in Square D Deal Seen After Slump Ends
abstract: The agreement by Groupe Schneider S.A. of France to buy the Square D Company for $2.23 billion is one of the largest consolidations in the electrical equipment industry. But that industry is facing some serious challenges because of lower demand in the construction market, which accounts for more than 60 percent of Square D's sales.   The combination of Square D, the North American market leader in low-voltage electrical distribution and industrial control products, and Schneider, with its vast size and financial resources, will result in a stronger competitor for other global giants like Siemens-Nixdorf of Germany, ABB of Sweden, Mitsubishi of Japan and General Electric. The acquisition will also create the world's largest maker of electrical control devices like circuit breakers, switchboards and transformers.  Square D Stock Soars     In response to the agreement announced Sunday night, which calls for Schneider to pay $88 in cash for each Square D share, Square D's stock soared $6.375 yesterday, to $87.375, on the Big Board.

headline: Genentech Drug
abstract: Genentech Inc. said its blood clot-dissolving drug, t-PA, or tissue plasminogen activator, had received marketing approval from the Japanese Ministry of Health and Welfare as a treatment for heart attacks. Genentech said it had begun shipping the product to its Japanese licensees, the Mitsubishi Kasei Corporation and the Kyowa Hakko Company.

headline: World Bank Lending Favors Eastern Europe
abstract: The World Bank announced today that it had greatly increased its assistance to six formerly Communist countries in Eastern Europe with loans that will total $2.9 billion by the end of the month.    This figure is higher than what the lending institution had foreseen only a few months ago, said Eugenio Lari, director of the World Bank's Department of Eastern and Central Europe.

headline: Justices Back Suits by Shareholders
abstract: The Supreme Court today refused to adopt a uniform Federal rule governing lawsuits by shareholders who contend that corporate management has mishandled a company's affairs.   In a unanimous opinion, the Court held that Federal courts handling such "derivative lawsuits" -- those brought on behalf of a corporation by its shareholders -- must defer to state law on an important preliminary issue: whether the shareholders must first ask the corporation's directors to bring the suit, even if such a demand would be futile.

headline: Treasuries Up on Economic Data
abstract: An unexpected rise in initial unemployment claims, an increase analysts say virtually assures that March employment data expected to be released today will be weak, pushed up prices of Treasury securities yesterday.    The claims report, which is released each week by the Labor Department, showed that initial claims rose by 33,000 in the week that ended on March 23, to 543,000. It is the third straight week that initial claims have risen by more than 500,000.

headline: Federated Will Offer a Reorganization Plan
abstract: Fifteen months after entering bankruptcy, Federated Stores Inc. will ask a Federal judge on Monday to approve a reorganization plan that would offer cash and notes worth 100 cents on the dollar to the unsecured creditors of seven of its store groups, including Bloomingdale's, according to creditors and executives close to the company.    The plan also provides for an offer of Federated common stock to unsecured creditors of Abraham & Straus, another New York store division, and of the Lazarus stores in Ohio, they said.

headline: Tonka's Board To Assess Bid
abstract: The board of the Tonka Corporation said it would meet tomorrow to consider an amended bid from Hasbro Inc. that offers more money to bondholders and less to stockholders.    Hasbro increased its offer for Tonka's series A bonds to $928 per $1,000 of face value, from $800 per $1,000. It also increased its offer for Tonka's series B bonds to $932 per $1,000, from $750. It reduced the price for Tonka stock to $5 a share, from $7.

headline: Poles Brace for Soviet Pullout
abstract: The Soviet Union plans to withdraw 10,000 of its 50,000 troops in Poland this year and to leave the country completely by 1993, a Polish general said today.

headline: Layoffs Expanded By Caterpillar
abstract: Caterpillar Inc. plans to shut down its factory in Aurora, Ill., for the week of July 8 because of slumping demand for heavy machinery. Similar cutbacks were recently announced at other Caterpillar factories in the Peoria area. A spokesman said the 2,500 workers at the Aurora plant would be temporarily laid off during the shutdown.   The shutdown will be in addition to the two weeks in July that Caterpillar normally closes its plants. In the first quarter, Caterpillar put 379 factory workers on indefinite layoffs, and the company's overall employment has dropped to 57,106, a loss of 2,786 jobs, in the last year. It lost $32 million in the first quarter, breaking a string of 15 profitable quarters.

headline: World Bank Aids Poland
abstract: The World Bank awarded $680 million in loans to Poland today and said it hoped the financing would help stimulate economic recovery and foreign business confidence in the country.   Ian Hume, the World Bank's representative in Warsaw, said the loans would provide $280 million for the privatization of state-owned companies, $100 million for agricultural development and $200 million to develop banking. About $100 million would be provided to cushion unemployment, which reached 1.4 million, or 7.7 percent of the nation's work force, last month.

headline: In Adversity, El Al Turns a Profit
abstract: Last August, when the Persian Gulf crisis erupted, Rafi Harlev, president of El Al Israel Airlines, decided to act quickly, knowing that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait meant hard times for his business.   Even before tourist traffic began to fall, he and his managers converted three Boeing 747 planes, which can each hold 450 passengers, into all-cargo carriers. They laid off 650 of the airline's 4,000 employees. A few weeks later they raised fares by 10 percent and then an additional 9 percent in December to help offset soaring jet-fuel prices.

headline: 200 Million Hawaii Offering For Airport System Priced
abstract: A $200 million issue of airport system revenue bonds from the State of Hawaii was initially priced yesterday through a group of underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The maximum yield offered was 7.2 percent for a bond with a 7 percent coupon that was priced at about 97.572.   Underwriters said the issue was covered by an insurance policy from the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company that covers interest and principal payments, giving the bonds a triple-A rating by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: U.S. Sees Trade as Spur
abstract: International trade will continue to stimulate global economic growth, but at a slower rate this year before picking up momentum in 1992, the Bush Administration said today.    "World trade growth should continue to run at its historical rate of just over twice the pace of output growth, or 2.5 percent in 1991 and around 5.5 percent in 1992," it said in its "Annual Trade Projection Report to Congress."

headline: Police in India Put Toll in Train Attacks Between 76 and 126
abstract: Police accounts in the north Indian state of Punjab said today that somewhere between 76 and 126 people had died Saturday in attacks on two passenger trains near the industrial city of Ludhiana. Early reports on Saturday night had put the death toll between 80 and 110.   A reporter for the national news agency, The Press Trust of India, said that the uncertainty on the number of casualties was explained in part by wounded passengers' lying among the dead, either unable or too fearful to move after gangs of men with automatic weapons strafed compartments.

headline: Machine Tool Orders Declined 32.7% in April
abstract: Orders for machine tools fell 32.7 percent in April from a year earlier, an industry trade group says in its monthly report. Orders were 5.3 percent lower than in March.    In the report, which was prepared for release today, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said orders fell last month to $194.7 million. They totaled $205.5 million in March, and $289.3 million in April 1990.

headline: Deal Denied By Chrysler
abstract: A Chrysler Corporation spokesman today dismissed as "rumor and speculation" reports that the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation would assume $220 million in expenses at their joint assembly plant in Normal, Ill.   Japanese newspapers reported last week that the auto makers were close to a deal that would give Mitsubishi a larger stake in the joint venture, the Diamond-Star Motors Corporation.

headline: May Stores Offers 9.5% Debentures
abstract: The May Department Stores Company is offering $150 million, up from $100 million, of 30-year amortizing debentures, due April 15, 2021, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.    The 9.5 percent debentures are priced at 99.352 to yield 9.566 percent, or about 140 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. Noncallable by the department store chain before maturity, the issue is rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.& P.

headline: Retailer Said To Focus on 2 Candidates
abstract: The search for a successor to Marvin S. Traub, Bloomingdale's chairman and chief executive, has been narrowed to two finalists, industry executives said yesterday.    Mr. Traub, 66 years old, an internationally known merchant who has held the posts since 1978, is expected to retire within 18 months, and a successor will no doubt be in place long before his departure.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Durable Goods...May 10-Day Auto Sales...Mid-June Consumer Confidence...June Wednesday Corporate Profits...1st qtr. Real Economic Growth...1st qtr. Thursday Weekly Jobless Claims Personal Income...May Friday Leading Indicators...May Farm Prices...June

headline: Disease Stalks Iraq as Trade Ban Saps Its Strength
abstract: The 11-month-old international embargo on trade with Iraq is threatening the country with severe malnutrition and a rise in disease among the poor, American and other Western doctors inspecting hospitals this month say.    Some senior officials of relief agencies here have begun to criticize the prolonged trade sanctions because of their devastating effect on the general population and the burden they place on humanitarian organizations.

headline: Making a Difference; Duplicating Yew Bark in a Lab
abstract: Until last week, the Escagenetics Corporation was known as an agricultural biotechnology start-up company with technology for producing clones of food flavors like vanilla and strawberry in a test tube. Now the San Carlos, Calif., company is in the limelight for harnessing this technology to produce taxol, a promising anti-cancer drug found only in the endangered Pacific yew tree.    Derived from the bark and needles of the yew, taxol is being used to treat women with advanced breast and ovarian cancer, diseases responsible for more than 50,000 deaths in the United States each year. Unfortunately, it takes about a half-dozen 100-year-old yew trees to treat one patient for a year, and the yew has been rendered nearly extinct by loggers, who regard the tree as a weed.

headline: Labor Official to Leave
abstract: Janet L. Norwood, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics for the last 12 years, said today that she would not accept reappointment when her four-year term expires this summer. Dr. Norwood, who is 67 years old, said she planned to join a university or research organization and to write, teach and perhaps serve as a corporate director.

headline: Airlift to Stranded Kurds: Rations Familiar to G.I.'s
abstract: From the flight deck of a United States military cargo plane, Iraq's northern-most frontier is a line of cars parked helter-skelter and snaking for miles through brown mountains.    The people in and around those cars are hard to see from 800 feet up, but they are there, tens of thousands of them in just this one ragged column, Iraqi Kurds on a hungry, painful march toward Turkey and away from the army of Saddam Hussein.

headline: In Retail, It's Perilous at the Top
abstract: Frank Doroff, the chairman of Bonwit Teller stores, yesterday became one more merchant without a store. After spending more than half his life in retailing, he will be on the outside looking in, probably wondering which fork in the road proved the wrong one.   After five years of takeovers, shake-ups, slow sales and now recession, retail chains have set adrift hundreds of Frank Doroffs. And continuing consolidation and store failures guarantee that more will follow.

headline: Market Place; Shearson Gives Itself a Face Lift
abstract: ALMOST a year after it became a wholly owned subsidiary of the American Express Company, Shearson Lehman Brothers is prettying itself up.   The brokerage house -- the nation's second largest, after Merrill Lynch -- is negotiating deals to shrink its exposure to potential loan losses, Wall Street executives said yesterday. The moves are intended in large part to reassure the bond market, upon which Shearson depends for billions of dollars in financing, that the firm is moving toward better financial health.

headline: Yugoslav Premier in Plea to Republics
abstract: In a gloomy 11th-hour speech before the Croatian Parliament, Yugoslavia's Prime Minister appealed today for Slovenia and Croatia, this country's two most prosperous republics, to halt plans to declare themselves independent on Wednesday.   The Prime Minister, Ante Markovic, who has broad support abroad but only scant popularity throughout this country, warned that further decay of the moribund, six-republic Yugoslav federation and moves by Slovenia and Croatia to break it up could lead to an economic and social catastrophe.

headline: Jet Fighter Selection Today
abstract: The Pentagon will have $65 billion worth of good news and some bad news for struggling United States military contractors on Tuesday: its choice of a team of aerospace companies to build America's Stealth jet fighter for the 21st century.   Five companies, divided into two teams, are waiting. The good news for the winners will be big money and continued work at the cutting edge of technology in building 750 radar-avoiding Advanced Tactical Fighters.

headline: Productivity Down, Then Up, as U.S. Errs
abstract: In one of the most embarrassing statistical mistakes in recent memory, the Labor Department announced late today that American business productivity was up, not down, as it had said in the morning.   Productivity advanced at a 1 percent annual pace in the first quarter of the year, the agency said, instead of dropping nine-tenths of 1 percent as it reported originally.

headline: 2 Months After Ousting Despot, Somalia Faces Life as an Abandoned Pawn
abstract: Amid the debris of its civil war, Somalia is struggling to start anew.    But this sliver of a country on the Horn of Africa, once regarded as a strategic prize for the superpowers and now nearly forgotten, has little to work with other than the legacy of expensive and lethal cold-war weapons that helped propel its war, and the clan identifications and rivalries that were among its causes.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: General Assembly COMMISSION ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE LAW -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: General Cinema
abstract: The General Cinema Corporation did not extend or terminate its $1.4 billion tender offer to acquire Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. General Cinema's offer expired at 5 P.M. yesterday, but a statement is expected by this morning. There was no indication as to whether General Cinema wuld raise its bid, as Harcourt bondholders are asking. If General Cinema abandons the deal, Harcourt, saddled with $2 billion in debt as the result of its efforts to avoid acquisition by the Maxwell Communication Corporation, may have to consider a restructuring, including a prepackaged bankruptcy.

headline: Business and Health; Computer Says Take 2 Aspirin
abstract: THE Harvard Community Health Plan, a large New England health maintenance organization, is testing a computerized service that answers health-care questions and advises people in their homes. The sponsors say the service pleases consumers and may eventually save money by reducing calls and visits to health plans.    The system is being developed by Interpractice Systems, a joint venture of the Harvard Community Plan and Electronic Data Systems, the big Dallas-based unit of General Motors that provides data processing services to health insurers.

headline: Hero in His Own Time, Yeltsin Delights Capital
abstract: He no longer has to come in the back door of the White House and beg to see the President. Instead of the 10 Senators he met in the fall of 1989, hundreds of members of Congress waited in line today to shake hands with the newly elected President of Russia and shower him with such gifts as a cowboy hat, a leather belt reading "Boris," and a Senator's spy novel in which he is a character.   And when Boris N. Yeltsin dropped by the Lincoln Memorial this afternoon, history teachers conducting class trips to the nation's capital gave their students an impromptu lesson about the latest Soviet star, who was known around Washington today simply by his first name.

headline: ASSASSINATION IN INDIA: Woman in the News; The Tragedy's New Player; Sonia Gandhi
abstract: During Rajiv Gandhi's tenure as Prime Minister, many Indians clung to the belief that his wife, Sonia, wielded undue influence in the shadows of power.    "What rubbish," an aide scoffed, adding that Mrs. Gandhi had no interest in politics or the limelight.

headline: Top Executive Quits at G.P.U.
abstract: Standley H. Hoch resigned Friday as chairman, president, chief executive and a director of the General Public Utilities Corporation, the big electric- utility holding company that operates in New Jersey and Pennsylvania.   Mr. Hoch, 59 years old, had been on the job only 26 months. The Wall Street Journal said yesterday that an important factor was concerns about his relationship with G.P.U.'s vice president of corporate communications, Susan Schepman, who had joined the company from the St. Louis public relations firm Fleishman-Hillard about a year ago. The relationship came to light as a result of an anonymous letter received by the company about two months ago, and a follow-up investigation.

headline: Briton and Chinese Still Split on Hong Kong Airport Plan
abstract: The British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, pledged today to consult China on matters relating to Hong Kong's future but acknowledged that he had been unable to reach agreement with Chinese leaders on a major new port and airport complex for Hong Kong.    The failure to reach agreement, despite several days of talks between Mr. Hurd and Prime Minister Li Peng and other senior officials, is likely to create new uncertainties in Hong Kong as well as new doubt about whether construction of the port and airport can go ahead according to the present plans.

headline: BURNING OIL POOL KILLS 5 IN KUWAIT
abstract: At least five people were killed a few feet off an oilfield road here Wednesday afternoon, when they blundered with their vehicles into a shallow pool of burning oil, apparently disoriented by shifting clouds of smoke and spreading ground fires.   In a sequence made possible by this chaotic combination of oilfield and battlefield, a Canadian firefighter in a truck drove past the burning pool and saw the burned-out shell of the first vehicle, a Japanese compact sedan carrying two British journalists. But amid the destruction of war, he did not realize that it was a new wreck, and he continued on toward town. A few minutes later, a pumper truck and a water tanker also strayed off the road and into the pool, killing the occupants.

headline: BUSINESS DIARY/June 23-28
abstract: THE ECONOMNY Congress Finds It's Easier to Criticize on Savings and Loan Bailout

headline: E.P.A. Chief Is Hopeful on Pollution in Gulf
abstract: William K. Reilly, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, brought back encouraging news today from his tour last week of Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, where he was sent by President Bush to assess the "environmental catastrophe perpetrated by Saddam Hussein."   Mr. Reilly expressed his horror at seeing such vast pollution, but said initial studies indicate the damage is not as severe as first predicted.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: General Assembly ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE -- 3 P.M.    COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Joe Isuzu Loses a Big Client And So Does Della Femina
abstract: The advertising agency that created the popular "lying" Joe Isuzu car campaign was dismissed yesterday. No lie.   American Isuzu Motors Inc. announced it would end an 11-year relationship with Della Femina McNamee Inc., New York and Los Angeles, that dates to the American introduction of Isuzu's Japanese-built cars and trucks.

headline: Nomination To Fed Seat Is Expected
abstract: President Bush is expected to name Susan M. Phillips, a former chairwoman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, to a vacant seat on the Federal Reserve Board.   Administration officials said this week that Ms. Phillips's nomination had been tentatively approved by President Bush on the basis of a recommendation from Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, but would not be announced until the Federal Bureau of Investigation had completed its background check.

headline: When the Calories Go, Will the Taste Remain?
abstract: Like the fat substitutes that have preceded it, the biggest challenge to Stellar comes on the question of taste. Products made with some of the other fat substitutes have already been reformulated to improve their flavor. Stellar may find itself doing the same.   While fat contains nine calories a gram, and protein and carbohydrates contain four calories a gram, Stellar contains just one calorie. A three-and-a-half ounce serving of ordinary cheesecake, for example, has 19 grams of fat and 450 calories. But a cheesecake made with the fat substitute has 10 grams of fat and 300 calories.

headline: Berlin and Bonn Partisans Square Off as Vote for Germany's Capital Nears
abstract: A national debate over the character of the new Germany is to be resolved this week when Parliament finally decides whether the federal Government should remain in Bonn or move to Berlin.   Partisans of both cities have spent the last several weeks making speeches and twisting arms. They have rejected various compromises and are bracing themselves for a bruising debate and vote on Thursday.

headline: Philips Advances New TV Set Debut
abstract: Philips N.V., the Dutch electronics giant, said it would introduce its high-definition television sets in early 1994, a year ahead of schedule. The move marks an effort by the financially troubled company to pre-empt Japanese and American companies developing their own versions of such sets, which provide a larger and clearer picture.

headline: Dollar Is Little Changed in Quiet Trading
abstract: European currency markets were becalmed today with the United States and British markets closed for holidays. The dollar closed little changed in quiet trading.   Share prices in Frankfurt and Zurich finished higher, but in quiet Paris trading they drifted downward.

headline: VIETNAM APPEALS FOR FOREIGN HELP
abstract: Vietnam's ruling Communist Party announced today that it had elected a new leader, Do Muoi, a 74-year-old party loyalist who used his first news conference to plead for international help to end Vietnam's long years as a "poor and backward nation."    Mr. Do Muoi's remarkably blunt request for aid for his tattered nation came as the party replaced more than half of its policy-making group, the Politburo. The new, younger members, while no less committed to the party's absolute power, appeared to be more likely to support moves toward a free market in Vietnam.

headline: Fight Over Liquidation of Eastern
abstract: The unsecured creditors of Eastern Air Lines find themselves fighting with the former carrier's retirees over who will get about $125 million expected from its liquidation.   To the unsecured creditors the money would mean the recovery of a few cents on the dollar on about $2.4 billion in claims against the company. To the 10,800 Eastern retirees the money would mean the continuation of some medical benefits until they reach age 65 and become eligible for Medicare.

headline: Uncovered Short Sales Are Off 1.8% on Big Board
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that short interest dropped by 13.6 million shares in the monthly period ending on May 15.   The Big Board said as of that date its short interest totaled 710.3 million shares, down 1.8 percent from the total of 723.9 million shares in a short position on the April 15 settlement date.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: DEBT * Baxter International Inc. is offering $100 million in 8.2 percent noncallable notes due 99.896 to yield 8.23 percent through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The issue is rated A-3 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.&P. * Chandler, Ariz., is offering water and sewer tax-exempt revenue refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 7.15 percent through underwriters led by First Boston Corp. Yields on shorter maturities range from 5.25 percent in 1992 to 6.65 percent in 2001. Another bond due in 2006 is priced to yield 7.07 percent. The financing is insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company and rated triple-A by both Moody's and S.&P. * Sears Euro Accounts Receivable Select Trust, formed by Sears, Roebuck & Co. to securitize credit card receivables, plans to offer in the Eurobond market a $750 million issue of five-year bonds through Credit Suisse First Boston. * Society Corp., Cleveland, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $300 million in debt securities and up to $200 million in preferred stock. COMMON STOCK * Florida Progress Corp., St. Petersburg, Fla., has filed for an offering of 2.7 million common shares through Merrill Lynch & Co. * Healthsource Inc., Concord, N.H., has filed for 1.75 million common shares through Robertson Stephens & Co.

headline: An Ulster Protestant Group Says It Killed Irish Politician
abstract: A Protestant paramilitary group said today that it killed a prominent politician last month at his home in the Irish Republic.   Masked gunmen killed Eddie Fullerton, a member of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, at his home in Buncrana, in Donegal, 10 miles from the border with Northern Ireland, the Irish police said.
