headline: UNREST MEDIATOR NAMED BY DE KLERK
abstract: In an effort to sustain the modest momentum of his conference on politically motivated violence, President F. W. de Klerk appointed a prominent church layman today to mediate a search for peace that would encompass the African National Congress and other anti-apartheid groups that boycotted the Government's talks.    As the two-day conference ended, Mr. de Klerk asked Louw Alberts, who is active in the Dutch Reformed Church, to become the mediator after the Inkatha Freedom Party, the Zulu organization that was the largest black group attending the talks, objected to turning the task over to committees of churchmen.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Economy    Industrial production rose 0.1 percent, snapping a six-month decline, as assemblies of trucks and automobiles rebounded, the Fed reported. The rise was seen as indicating that the economy was nearing its low point and a recovery might be imminent.  [ Page D1. ]

headline: U.S., Citing Human Rights, Halts Economic Aid to Yugoslavia
abstract: The Bush Administration has quietly suspended all economic assistance to Yugoslavia, including support in international financial institutions for loans and credits.   In 1952, Yugoslavia, then a maverick Communist country, began receiving large amounts of United States aid to help it continue its defiance of Stalin. In recent years, the Belgrade Government benefited repeatedly from American backing for international loans and credits for its economy.

headline: Pittsburgh Sells Revenue Bonds
abstract: The Pittsburgh Water and Sewer Authority sold $248.3 million in water and sewer system serial revenue refunding bonds yesterday through an underwriter group led by Paine Webber Inc.   The tax-exempt issue was rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AAA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: Tokyo Stocks Gain a Bit
abstract: Japanese stock prices advanced slightly today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 157.31 points, or six-tenths of a percent, to end the week at 26,582.50. For the week, the index was down 184.83 points, or nearly seven-tenths of a percent.

headline: Dow Up 2.90 but Second-Tier Stocks Slip
abstract: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average and other blue-chip indexes edging higher but second-tier issues, which are normally favored by individual investors, not doing as well.    Helped by aggressive computerized buying programs, the Dow added 2.90 points, at 2,913.01.

headline: General Dynamics
abstract: The United Automobile Workers union and the General Dynamics Corporation's land systems division reached a tentative agreement on a three-year contract covering about 4,000 workers in Michigan, Ohio and Pennsylvania. Details were not released, but a U.A.W. official, who insisted he not be identified, said the pact included improvements in wages and benefits. A typical worker covered by the previous three-year contract, which expired Sunday at midnight, was paid $14.57 an hour.

headline: Fed Kept Policy Steady in February
abstract: The policy-making body of the Federal Reserve voted unanimously at its February meeting to leave credit policy unchanged, but with a tilt toward lower rates, minutes of the meeting show.   The Federal Open Market Committee agreed "that for now it was desirable to pause and assess the course of the economy and the effect of past policy actions," according to the minutes.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Can Products Be Marketed On TV Networks Alone?
abstract: JERRY SOLOMON runs the Busch Media Group in New York, which buys national television and radio commercial time for Anheuser-Busch, and he doesn't like to complain, but his job keeps getting tougher.  Mr. Solomon's company spends more than $300 million a year on advertising and his challenge is that prices are rising for commercial time but the size of the network audience is eroding.

headline: As Angola Turns to West, Cubans Are Resentful
abstract: The streets of the Angolan capital are festooned with posters of Fidel Castro, Che Guevara and other Cuban revolutionary heroes, and there are slogans on peeling facades proclaiming the valiant role Cuba has played in African liberation movements. But the feeling in Luanda these days is that these are outdated and perhaps naive artifacts from another era.   As Luanda's formerly hard-line Marxist Government moves fitfully toward becoming a Western-style multi-party democracy, the Cubans are increasingly seen as symbols of a policy that has failed and that many Angolans would like to forget.

headline: A.T.& T. Stock
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's stock continued to rise yesterday, bolstering the company's bid to complete its $110-a-share stock offer for the NCR Corporation. A.T.& T. rose 37.5 cents, to $37.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, after receiving a buy recommendation from a Paine Webber Inc. analyst, Jack B. Grubman. Mr. Grubman said A.T.& T. stock would hit $50 within the year. The stock rose $1.125 on Tuesday.    The companies are believed to be trying to reach an agreement on how much protection NCR shareholders should receive against a drop in the stock price of the telephone company. The companies declined to comment on whether talks were under way. Shares of NCR rose 12.5 cents, to $103.50. A.T.& T. has been attempting to acquire the Dayton, Ohio, computer maker since December.

headline: Texas Instruments In Pact With NEC
abstract: Texas Instruments Inc. said it had come to basic terms with the NEC Corporation of Japan for a new five-year semiconductor patent cross-license agreement to replace a five-year pact that had expired at the end of 1990.    Under the new agreement, Texas Instruments said it would receive royalty payments from NEC on worldwide sales of integrated circuits that "greatly exceed" the average amounts it had received under the old agreement. It said a new definitive agreement would still have to be negotiated and approved by the Japanese Government.

headline: Texas Instruments May Cut 550 Jobs
abstract: Texas Instruments Inc. said today that it would close a manufacturing plant in Colorado Springs that produced electronic warfare equipment like missile decoys and signal-jamming devices for aircraft. As many as 550 of the unit's 650 employees will lose their jobs, with the others being transferred to a similar plant in McKinney, Tex., north of the company's Dallas headquarters.    The consolidation will reduce operating costs for the company's military systems and electronics group amid further declines in the Pentagon budget, said William F. Hayes, president of the unit. As of April 1, the company had trimmed its payroll on military programs by 1,600, to 18,000. The company has 68,556 employees.

headline: Pacific Exchange Extension
abstract: The Pacific Stock Exchange said today that it would extend its trading hours to 1:50 P.M., Pacific daylight time, beginning on or before June 13. The exchange now trades until 1:30 P.M., half an hour longer than any other United States securities exchange.    "We'll be trading in a regular continuous auction market 50 minutes longer than the N.Y.S.E., not simply accepting and executing orders electronically at predetermined prices," said Lee Korins, the chairman and chief executive.

headline: Patents; Composition May Help in Treating Glaucoma
abstract: David F. Woodward, a researcher at Allergan Inc., a manufacturer of eye care and skin care products, has patented a composition that could prove useful in treating glaucoma.   Glaucoma, which can lead to blindness, occurs when pressure builds behind the eye because fluids are not draining properly. Although some treatments exist, their effectiveness is often uneven. Company officials said most treatments are based on inhibiting the formation of fluids. Some doctors are concerned that doing so may create other problems.

headline: Mattel Calls Debt
abstract: Mattel Inc., the toy company based in El Segundo, Calif., will redeem the remainder of its 14 3/4 percent subordinated sinking fund debentures. John W. Amerman, the chairman and chief executive, said redemption of the debentures and some preferred stock would produce an extraordinary charge of $5.1 million against second-quarter earnings, but would reduce net interest expenses in the second half by $4 million.

headline: Fiat Exports Up
abstract: Fiat S.p.A., the Italian automotive giant, said its European exports were improving but that its earnings for the year would probably be lower than in 1990. Fiat Auto, the group's car-making unit, posted a 7.5 percent increase European sales in the January-to-May period this year, compared with a year earlier. "Fiat Auto is making money," said Giulio Merlani, Fiat's finance director. Analysts have projected that Fiat's profits could drop to $538 million this year, from $1.2 billion last year, on a 5 percent rise in revenues, to about $46 billion.

headline: Rival's Building In Apple's Ad
abstract: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it would continue to run newspaper advertisements for its Macintosh software, even though a photograph of a competitor's office building is inadvertently featured in the ad.    The ad, which ran in three nationally distributed newspapers today and on Monday, shows a Macintosh computer hooked up to the I.B.M. Tower in Atlanta. Apple's ad agency, BBDO Los Angeles, said it obtained the photo from a studio after requesting a generic picture of an office building.

headline: McDonnell's Earnings Soar to $58 Million
abstract: Helped in part by an increase in deliveries of MD-11 jetliners, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation yesterday reported a strong increase in earnings for the first quarter.   Net profits jumped to $58 million, or $1.50 a share, compared with income of $2 million, or 5 cents a share, in the comparable period last year. Revenues rose 13 percent, to $4.32 billion, from $3.83 billion last year.

headline: Pope Delivers Angry Sermon on Abortion to Poles
abstract: In a voice rising in anger, Pope John Paul II today delivered an impassioned sermon against abortion and demanded that his fellow Poles make an accounting of their sins.   His normally sonorous, pacific voice shaking with rage, the Pope departed from his prepared text and assailed Poland's moral state as if it were a personal affront.

headline: Money Woes Aside, India Hopes to Add to Aid to Bangladesh
abstract: India declared today that it was prepared to increase emergency aid substantially to its cyclone-devastated neighbor, Bangladesh, and that it would not let internal political problems and a shaky balance-of-payments position stand in the way.    "We can send whatever they need and whatever we can give -- medicine, food, tents, clothes, other relief material," said Kamal Morarka, a senior aide to Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar. Mr. Morarka said in an interview that an initial aid offer of $750,000, and the use of three helicopters, was based on earlier, incomplete information about the scale of the destruction.

headline: Enzon-Genex Deal
abstract: Enzon Inc. agreed to acquire the Genex Corporation in an exchange of stock and warrants valued at $18 a share. Enzon, a biotechnology company, said the acquisition would reduce its reliance on outside suppliers of the proteins needed for therapeutic products. Enzon enhances protein-based drugs that are used to treat life-threatening diseases. The companies said the deal should be completed by September.

headline: In One City, Signs of an Upturn
abstract: If the chief characteristic of emerging recovery is that the various individual economic signals are mixed, Berks County is now watching a recession fade into history.    Fitfully, sometimes almost imperceptibly, business here is gradually improving, accompanied by growing confidence that, by summer's end, a rebound -- most likely a modest one -- will be obvious, to all.

headline: Morgan Creek, Warner in Pact
abstract: Warner Brothers Inc. said it had entered into an exclusive three-year deal with Morgan Creek Productions for all United States and Canadian distribution rights to a planned slate of about two dozen films. Morgan Creek is an independent Los Angeles-based film studio founded in 1987.

headline: Iraq Approval Starts Peace Schedule
abstract: Iraq's formal acceptance of the Security Council's Persian Gulf peace offer today meets the conditions for an immediate cease-fire and clears the way for the destruction of Iraq's most dangerous weapons, the establishment of a procedure for Iraqi reparations to Kuwait and the lifting of trade sanctions against Baghdad.    The 120-day timetable for carrying out the demands was spelled out in Security Council Resolution 687, which was adopted on Wednesday. Following the schedule, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar presented a plan today for sending a United Nations military observer force to monitor a demilitarized zone along the Iraq-Kuwait border.

headline: A Top Comsat Official Is Promoted to President
abstract: The Communications Satellite Corporation yesterday named Bruce L. Crockett president and chief operating officer. He has been with the company for 11 years and was president of Comsat's largest unit.   Mr. Crockett will report to Irving Goldstein, who continues as chairman and chief executive. Mr. Crockett is being promoted at a time when the Washington-based satellite company is struggling to get its businesses in order. Although revenues from its core satellite business have grown steadily in recent years, the company faces growing competition from transoceanic fiber-optic cables and from new satellite companies offering international communications.

headline: Managing; Putting the Best Face on Bankruptcy
abstract: ONE Saturday afternoon in September 1989, Jess Hay, the chief executive of the Lomas Financial Corporation, summoned the top officers of the troubled bank to an emergency meeting. The next morning, with 100 managers from around the country assembled at Lomas's Dallas headquarters, Mr. Hay broke the bad news: The company, with $6.5 billion in assets, would file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy that night.   "I felt it was critical to tell the whole story to our management team at once, so nobody would feel short-circuited," he said.

headline: Pepsico Net Up 12.9% on Foreign Strength
abstract: Pepsico Inc. reported yesterday that its first-quarter profits increased 12.9 percent, aided by especially strong foreign sales in soft drinks, snacks and fast food.    Net income rose to $205.4 million, or 26 cents a share, from $181.9 million, or 23 cents a share, earned in the comparable quarter last year.

headline: Federal Inquiry at F.D.A.
abstract: A Federal grand jury is investigating allegations that employees at the Food and Drug Administration took cash in exchange for informing brokerage firms when the agency would approve certain drugs, an F.D.A. official said today.   The official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said F.D.A. employees had been subpoenaed to testify before a grand jury in Baltimore.

headline: Supercomputing's Speed Quest
abstract: In the computer world, it is known as the race for the teraflop. The crowds will be sparse, the language arcane and most of the action will take place inside a big, boxy computer. The goal is to design a computer that is more than 1,000 times faster than the most potent current models -- a supercomputer capable of running more than a trillion mathematical calculations each second.    The Intel Corporation will rev up its preliminary entry, known as the Touchstone Delta, in a demonstration today at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif. The Touchstone does not achieve the teraflop speeds that Intel seeks, but it is four times faster than Intel's present supercomputer, a parallel system composed of an array of microprocessors that break apart large problems and perform hundreds of simultaneous calculations.

headline: New Assignment Seen For Rich's Chairman
abstract: Roger N. Farah, the chairman and chief executive of Rich's Inc., Atlanta, who announced on Wednesday the closing of the chain's downtown flagship store, will soon be reassigned by Federated Stores Inc., Rich's owner, to be chairman and chief executive of the company's New York buying office, Federated/Allied Merchandising Services, retail executives close to Federated said yesterday.    In the new post, Mr. Farah, who is 39 years old, will assume one of the hats worn by Allen I. Questrom, Federated's chairman and chief executive, who will now concentrate on those responsibilities. Besides Rich's, Federated operates Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and Stern's in the New York area; Jordan Marsh in Boston; Lazarus in Ohio, Burdines, Jordan Marsh and Maas Brothers in Florida, and Bon Marche in Seattle. Federated and its divisions have been in voluntary bankruptcy since January 1990.

headline: Mutual Funds; A Small Step Away From Repos
abstract: When it comes to money-market funds, three things matter: safety, safety and safety. That's because most investors treat money funds like savings accounts, not investments -- an idea that the industry does not discourage.   The focus on safety took a new twist recently, when the Boston-based Freedom Capital Management Corporation said its $295 million money fund, the Freedom U.S. Government Securities Fund, would no longer invest in repurchase agreements.

headline: Pan Am Joins Trump in Lower Shuttle Fare
abstract: Seeking to attract more leisure travelers, the Trump Shuttle yesterday offered a $119 weekday round-trip fare between New York and Washington or Boston. The Pan Am Shuttle quickly matched it.    Business travelers, who often grumble at paying $284 round trip, will find it hard to take advantage of the new fare because of some stiff restrictions. Tickets must be purchased 14 days in advance and can be used only from 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. and from 8 P.M. to 9 P.M.

headline: U.S. Uncertain of Death Rate at Kurds' Camps
abstract: Although the Administration says that as many as 500 Kurdish refugees fleeing from Iraq into Turkey are dying every day, State Department officials acknowledge that it is impossible to know such a number for certain.   Officials said today, as they have in recent days, that the number of Kurds dying in refugee camps near the Turkish-Iraqi border appears to have stabilized at about 500 a day. But they admitted that the figure was inexact because it is based on the extrapolation of incomplete figures from a limited number of camps.

headline: Continental Can and VIAG in Deal
abstract: The German industrial group VIAG A.G. said it had agreed to purchase Continental Can Europe from Peter Kiewit Sons' Inc., a mining and construction group based in Omaha. The Bonn-based aluminum and utilities group did not disclose financial terms. The Ball Corporation of Muncie, Ind., had reportedly offered $1 billion for Continental Can Europe, but backed out because of a lack of financing.   Continental Can Europe is a major packaging producer and employs about 10,000 people. It has operations in Germany, the Netherlands, Britain and France, and last year reported revenue of about $1.7 billion. Kiewit reportedly wanted to sell the European enterprises as part of a "strategic reorientation," program. Continental Can Europe specializes in glass- and metal-packaging products for food processing. Its operations mesh with VIAG, which is a major aluminum processor and already has large packaging-manufacturing operations.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Ad Scene; The Rush to Mr. Robinson's Neighborhood
abstract: WITH Bo Jackson sidelined, marketing experts have been wondering who will replace him as the best pitchman in advertising. Some believe the next superstar endorser is David Robinson. David knows basketball.    Mr. Robinson, the 7-foot 1-inch center for the San Antonio Spurs, is already the stuff of legend, a rare professional athlete whose basketball scores (25.6 points a game on average) were rivaled, relatively speaking, by his Scholastic Aptitude Test scores (1,320 out of 1,600).

headline: Ford Planning An Electric Car
abstract: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would build up to 100 electric-powered test cars by 1993 before going into mass production.   Although the General Motors Corporation has said it will mass-produce electric cars and the Chrysler Corporation has built test vehicles, Ford said it would take a more cautious approach, with full-scale production not planned until the second half of the decade.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Docucon Inc., San Antonio, a computer services company, has received a three-year, $12.4 million contract to provide document conversion and imaging services to the Navy and other government agencies. *Gazelle Microcircuits, Santa Clara, Calif., will join the previously announced merger between two other companies that sell computer chips made from gallium arsenide, Gigabit Logic of Newbury Park, Calif., and Triquint Semiconductor, a subsidiary of Tektronix based in Beaverton, Ore. The new company will be called Triquint.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Two Defy Age and Timing To Open Los Angeles Shop
abstract: THEY are two silver-haired gentlemen of advertising who should be settling comfortably into their statesmanship years. Yet Roger Livingston, at 54, and Paul Keye, at 61, have rejected the comfortable life, choosing instead to form Livingston & Keye in Los Angeles.  The timing for their venture is questionable, the market suspect. Recession continues to grip much of the advertising industry. And Los Angeles, frequently touted as an advertising hotbed, has yet to prove that it can support more than a small number of inventive shops.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Corporation yesterday priced $1 billion in certificates backed by credit card payments through underwriters led by Chase Securities.   Chase Manhattan Credit Card Master Trust 1991-1, the vehicle through which the certificates are being sold, is offering the securities with an 8 3/4 percent coupon at a price of 99.915, to yield 8.846 percent, or about 85 basis points more than five-year Treasury notes. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

headline: Honecker Has an Operation In Moscow, Paper Reports
abstract: Erich Honecker, the former East German Communist leader who was spirited out of Germany last month, has undergone bowel surgery in a Moscow military hospital, a German newspaper reported today.   "The operation went well, but Honecker's condition is very poor overall," the newspaper Bild quoted an informant in the Soviet capital as saying.

headline: U.S. and France Are at Odds Over a NATO Army
abstract: NATO's defense ministers are expected to endorse plans on Tuesday to establish a rapid-reaction force of about 70,000 soldiers, but friction has developed between the United States and France over who should control such a force, officials of the Western military alliance said.    The force, expected to be approved at a meeting in Brussels, would be part of a new NATO blueprint in which the 16-nation alliance would have fewer but more mobile forces as the United States reduces its troops in Western Europe. North Atlantic Treaty Organization officials said such a force would have British, Dutch, Belgian and other ground troops, and American attack aircraft and helicopters.

headline: Navy Drops Charges Against Two Muslims
abstract: The Navy said tonight it had dropped charges against two Muslim sailors accused of plotting to sabotage their ship to help Iraq during the Persian Gulf war.   Airman Apprentice Abdul H. Shaheed, 22 years old, of St. George, S.C., and Seaman Apprentice James L. Moss, 21, of Columbus, Ohio, had been awaiting court-martial at the Subic Bay base in the Phillippines. They denied the charges.

headline: Tele-Communications In United Artists Deal
abstract: Tele-Communications Inc. and the United Artists Entertainment Company, two of the nation's largest cable television operators, announced a merger deal today giving Tele-Communications the 46 percent of United Artists that it does not already own.    Under the $1 billion stock swap, 65 million shares of United Artists stock will be converted to Tele-Communications shares.

headline: House Panel Starts Work On Bank Bill
abstract: A Congressional panel sent a clear signal today in the opening debate on the heart of the Bush Administration's proposal to cure the banking system that lawmakers may expand the powers of banks by permitting the institutions to enter new businesses.    A series of preliminary votes by the Banking Committee's Subcommittee on Financial Institutions today was only the first step in what is expected to be a summerlong process. The panel's votes are regarded as an important political test of how far Congress may be willing to go in throwing out banking laws written during the Great Depression. Of the 52 members of the Banking Committee, 36 serve on the subcommittee.

headline: East Europe's Press Still Beckoning
abstract: More than a year after the start of a fierce bidding war among foreign publishers for newspapers and magazines in Eastern Europe, the involvement of American media companies there remains minimal.    Except for Time Warner Inc., which has a partial interest in developing and operating cable systems in Hungary representing 250,000 subscribers and is looking into developing a pay-television movie service there, none of the big American newspaper or magazine publishers are competing for ownership of Eastern Europe's emerging free press.

headline: Loss on Mail at $1.4 Billion
abstract: The United States Postal Service said today that it had a $1.4 billion loss in the first half of the fiscal year 1991, largely because of increased payments to the Federal Treasury.   A 1990 Federal budget change requiring the Postal Service to make retroactive payments to the Treasury for health benefits to postal workers who retired since 1971 cost $961 million, postal officials said.

headline: Executive Made Dean
abstract: William A. Hasler, vice chairman and director of KPMG Peat Marwick, the accounting and consulting unit of the Pittson Company, will become the new dean of the Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley. He will replace Raymond E. Miles, who returned to teaching.

headline: I.B.M. Sees A Gloomy 2d Quarter
abstract: I.B.M. told Wall Street analysts yesterday that its earnings for the second quarter were likely to fall below expectations and hinted that new cost-cutting moves could soon lead to further special charges.   The International Business Machines Corporation, based in Armonk, N.Y., also broadened its explanation of why it is ailing as it struggles to return to earlier levels of profitability and dominance of the industry.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: THE ECONOMY   The easy-riding mountain bike is sweeping the world in popularity and propelling American manufacturers to the front of the pack. The bikes have not only resurrected the U.S. industry; they are upstaging hand-crafted machines of Italian design.  [ Page A1. ]   Economists and planners fear that New York City's shrinking economy and inadequate services and the prospect of higher taxes are hastening the departure of the middle class.  [ A1 ]

headline: Social Democrats Explore Anti-Kohl Alliance
abstract: From the simple arithmetic of the vote in Rhineland-Palatinate on Sunday, the Social Democrats, who emerged victorious, can ally with either the Free Democrats or the environmentalist Greens to form a coalition Government.    But now, local and national leaders of the Social Democrats and Free Democrats have given their blessing to the start of exploratory talks toward a coalition, and the announcement sent ripples of concern through the national administration, where for nine years the Free Democrats, a liberal, probusiness party, have governed together with Mr. Kohl's Christian Democrats.

headline: Alaska Air Offers Zero-Coupon Debt
abstract: The Alaska Air Group is offering $300 million in zero-coupon convertible debentures through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.    The zero-coupon debt, which makes no interest or principal payments before maturity, has a maturity date of April 18, 2006, and if held to maturity yields 7.25 percent. The zeros are offered at a price of $343.61 for each $1,000 of bonds.

headline: Former Prudential Broker Sues Firm
abstract: A former stockbroker with Prudential Securities Inc. is seeking $15 million from the brokerage firm, accusing it of forcing him from his job because he threatened to divulge information about what he says was a fraud committed by the firm.    His complaint says Prudential marketed as a low-risk investment a real estate security that proved to be laden with risk. Some investors experienced huge losses.

headline: Ameritrust Plans To Consider Bid
abstract: The Ameritrust Corporation said it would evaluate a merger offer from the National City Corporation as one of several alternatives, which also include remaining independent. On Monday, National City offered a stock transaction for Ameritrust worth $870 million, or about $23 a share. A union of the two Cleveland-based companies would create the nation's 17th-largest banking concern.    Ameritrust said it was not surprised by the National City offer. "We have strong core businesses in attractive markets, so we fully understand why such a merger would be attractive from the point of view of national city," said Craig R. Smith, chairman and chief executive of Ameritrust. Ameritrust shares gained $1.625 in over-the-counter trading today, closing at 21. They had gained $2.50 on Monday.

headline: Bush Hails Salvador Chief, Saying Rebels Block Peace
abstract: President Bush praised President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador today for strides taken to end that country's decade-long civil war, and blamed leftist guerrillas for blocking the final path to peace.    After a two-hour meeting between Administration and Salvadoran officials, the State Department's senior Latin American specialist, Bernard W. Aronson, amplified Mr. Bush's remarks, accusing the rebels of "stalling deliberately" on a cease-fire plan while stepping up their violence.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   10.00        DISCOUNT RATE   5.50   5.50   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.69   5.79   8.18        3-MO. TREAS. headline: Turkey's Chief Urges Global Aid to Resettle Kurds
abstract: President Turgut Ozal of Turkey, faced with what he called the "extraordinary difficulties" of the presence of two-thirds of a million Kurdish refugees, appealed tonight to the world to help resettle them in Iraq.    "If this is not done, I fear the results will be appalling," President Ozal said in a nationwide television address.

headline: Baltimore Bancorp
abstract: The Baltimore Bancorp said its leading institutional investors had succeeded in electing six directors to the board. It said in announcing the results of a recent shareholders' vote that a dissident shareholder group was unable to seize control of the 18-member board. The dissidents, led by Edwin Hale, a Baltimore executive, wanted to increase the board's size to 28. David Eisner, the senior vice president at Providence Capital Inc., a New York firm that advised several large investors, said investors were unhappy with the performance of Baltimore Bancorp in recent years and its rejection last year of a merger offer by another Maryland bank.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   10.00        DISCOUNT RATE   5.50   5.50   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.69   5.79   8.19        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.58   5.56   7.76        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.75   5.73   7.63        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.16   8.13   8.52        30-YR. TREAS. headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: MONDAY: Industrial production for April * Federal Reserve reports on selected interest rates.  TUESDAY: Consumer price index for April * Early May automobile sales * Federal Open Market Committee meets to decide monetary policy for next seven weeks * Retail sales figures * Industrial production and plant capacity figures * Real earnings figures.

headline: BankAmerica's Bid Discounted
abstract: The BankAmerica Corporation was said to have offered the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation a cash premium of $237 million, almost 10 times the amount the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group agreed to pay to take over the failed Bank of New England.    But the F.D.I.C. did not count it that way. Alan Whitney, a spokesman for the agency, said officials reduced the value of BankAmerica's bid because it was "nonconforming to the ground rules of the overall transaction." He would not elaborate on the ways in which the bid did not meet the Government's guidelines, but he did say that when it was analyzed it turned out to be worth less than the $125 million in stock and cash offered by Fleet.   Mr. Whitney said the F.D.I.C. might soon release details about its analysis of the bids. The agency's deliberations are not public.   BankAmerica declined to comment.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Ashland Oil Inc., Ashland, Ky., said its APAC Construction group would sell properties in Arizona to a unit of Onoda Cement Co. Ltd., Yamaguchi, Japan, for undisclosed terms.

headline: Bush Accuses Iraq of Lying About Arms
abstract: President Bush accused Saddam Hussein today of "cheating and lying and hiding" on the issue of nuclear inspections, as a top State Department official vowed that the United States would "solve this issue, one way or another."   A day after Iraqi soldiers prevented United Nations inspectors from investigating machinery thought to be related to Iraq's nuclear capability, Mr. Bush said he believed that "the authority exists" for military force under existing United Nations resolutions but said he had not discussed that option.

headline: Northwest Air Settles Suit
abstract: Northwest Airlines has agreed to set aside $3.5 million over five years to enhance the hiring and promotion of blacks in settlement of a 1989 racial discrimination lawsuit.    Northwest, based in Eagan, Minn., also agreed to give $535,000 to 28 plaintiffs.

headline: Axa Backtracks on Equitable Life Stake
abstract: Groupe Axa, one of France's largest insurance companies, announced today that it had reached an agreement with the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States to obtain a major stake in the troubled New York-based insurer.   But later in the day the company backed off from the remarks saying that a definitive agreement had not been worked out.

headline: To Our Readers
abstract: Beginning today, the chart on top of the Business Digest omits the gold price and lists oil instead. The oil price will be the previous day's closing quotation for the nearest month's crude oil futures contract on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The change reflects oil's greater importance to the economy.

headline: Compromise on Financial Regulation in Jeopardy
abstract: A legislative compromise that would resolve a long-festering dispute among futures and securities regulators appeared to be in jeopardy when it was denounced by a number of key Democrats and Republicans at a Senate Banking Committee hearing today.   Richard C. Breeden, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, also challenged the provision, contending it would stifle innovation and drive certain financial business offshore.

headline: U.S. to Push for Lower Rates At Group of Seven Meeting
abstract: The United States will emphasize the need to lower world interest rates when it meets in Washington this weekend with its chief economic allies in the Group of Seven, a top Treasury official said yesterday.    But even before this public acknowledgement of what the United States has been quietly lobbying for in recent weeks, Karl Otto Pohl, the president of the Bundesbank, said the German central bank was not considering lowering interest rates.

headline: Wall Street Acts to Calm the Policyholders of Insurer
abstract: The deteriorating financial condition of First Capital Holdings has set off a scramble among a number of Wall Street firms to calm clients who purchased insurance policies from the company's subsidiaries through the brokerages.    Wall Street executives said the largest sales of the policies during the 1980's were made by Shearson Lehman Brothers, which holds a 28 percent stake of the company; the Paine Webber Group Inc., and Prudential Securities. The three firms sold policies from either the First Capital Life Insurance Company, the California subsidiary, or the Fidelity Bankers Life Insurance Company, the Virginia subsidiary.

headline: Amway in Hungary
abstract: The Amway Corporation, which sold $2.2 billion in cleaning and other products last year through one million distributors, expanded its operations today into Hungary. Amway is privately held but reported the $2.2 billion in sales in the 12 months that ended last August. The company expects $3 billion in sales this year, 63 percent from the 50 foreign countries and territories in which it operates, said Dan Shuster, the head of the company's international operations.

headline: A Slaying Inflames Chilean Rightists
abstract: Angry demonstrations erupted here today after the killing of a prominent Chilean Senator and close adviser to Gen. Augusto Pinochet.    Calling for a return to power by the military and shouting insults at the democratically elected Government of President Patricio Aylwin, hundreds of supporters of Chile's far-right political party, the Independent Democratic Union, flocked to a memorial service in downtown Santiago for the adviser, Jaime Guzman, who was killed on Monday evening.    "Pinochet, Pinochet!" the crowd called. "Aylwin killed him! Aylwin killed him!"    Mr. Guzman was gunned down as he left the Catholic University Law School in Santiago, where he was a professor. Though doctors at the Military Hospital tried to save him, he died three hours later.  A Crisis for Government     Mr. Guzman, 44 years old, was legal adviser to the Pinochet military junta and played a central role in writing the new Constitution that the general established in 1980.    Though acts of political violence have been on the rise for a number of weeks, the shooting of Mr. Guzman is by far the most serious and politically explosive to date, since it is the closest that terrorists have reached to General Pinochet's inner circle of current and former advisers.    It also creates a crisis for the year-old Aylwin Government, which many Chileans accuse of being soft on terrorism and unprepared to cope with the rise in terrorist attacks. Moreover, it complicates an already touchy political climate for Mr. Aylwin, who plans to leave on an 18-day tour of Europe on Saturday.    A month ago, Mr. Aylwin made public a human rights report that essentially blamed General Pinochet for the killing or disappearance of more than 2,000 Chileans during his 17-year rule, which began with a coup in 1973. But while blaming the army commander, it went no further. It could not force investigations or prosecutions of police, top army commanders or General Pinochet himself.  Nation Deeply Divided     General Pinochet and others on the right had warned before the release of the report that it would incite violence from the left.    The killing of Mr. Guzman and the demonstrations that followed showed how this country, just having returned to a democratic Government a year ago, remains deeply divided in its sentiments about General Pinochet's rule. While many Chileans acknowledge that under military rule there were abuses of human rights, they nevertheless add that the military Government restored law and order, which many now fear is being threatened.    And while only a minority seem to want a Pinochet comeback, the general's presence as army commander serves as a constant reminder of the fragility of the democratic process.    Today, two left-wing groups claimed responsibility for the killing, the Patriotic Front of Manuel Rodriguez and the Rebel and Popular Forces of Lautaro.    General Pinochet refused to talk to reporters today, saying only that he considered the killing an assassination rather than a random killing. Military officials said that their patience was wearing thin.    Mr. Aylwin, at a brief news conference, rejected charges by opposition political parties that his Government was unprepared to deal with terrorism and rejected calls that he cancel his European trip.    "If I suspended this mission because of a terrorist act, that would be the equivalent of saying that the Government is at the mercy of the terrorists," Mr. Aylwin said.

headline: Investment Abroad Easing
abstract: American companies plan to increase investments overseas by 6 percent this year, down from the 19 percent average increase posted during the previous three years, the Government said today.   The Commerce Department said a survey conducted in December showed that majority-owned foreign affiliates of United States companies planned $61.2 billion in capital spending this year, up from $56 billion in planned spending in 1990.

headline: Conagra Merger Data Requested
abstract: Conagra Inc. and Golden Valley Microwave Foods Inc. said they had each been asked by the Federal Trade Commission to provide more information about their April 19 merger agreement. Under antitrust law, the F.T.C. move extends the waiting period for reviewing the transaction until 20 days after compliance with the request. Both companies, which said they would cooperate with the commission, said it was not unusual for the commission to request more information in this type of merger.

headline: A New Lite and New Ads, As Miller Seeks the Young
abstract: A FASCINATING experiment in advertising's ability to shape consumer perceptions gets under way this week when the Miller Brewing Company begins the test of a beer that could have been called Miller Lite Junior.    New Lite Ultra, described on its label as "a new generation in Lite beers," is making its debut in four test markets: Arizona; Louisville, Ky.; Madison, Wis., and San Diego. Advertisements created by Leo Burnett USA, Chicago, employ youth-oriented imagery that is intended to position Lite Ultra as a younger sibling of Miller Lite.

headline: Germany Lets Poles In Without Visas
abstract: The borders dividing Eastern and Western Europe continued to fall today as five countries in the West began allowing Polish citizens to come and go without visas.   Thousands of cars and buses were already in line at the Polish-German border when the visa restrictions were officially lifted at midnight Sunday. By dawn today, lines of vehicles waiting to cross into Germany stretched for as long as 25 miles. Trains from Warsaw to points west were packed.

headline: Weekly U.S. Jobless Claims Down by 17,000 in Mid-June
abstract: The number of Americans filing new unemployment claims declined in the second week of June, the Labor Department reported today, supporting hopes the nation's jobs market is on the upswing.   For the week ended June 15, some 431,000 Americans filed new claims for unemployment, 17,000 fewer than the previous week's 448,000.

headline: Madrid Air Service Dispute Is Settled by U.S. and Spain
abstract: The United States and Spain agreed yesterday to allow American Airlines and United Airlines to begin service to Madrid today and to let Delta Air Lines fly to Spain from Atlanta.   Under a memorandum of understanding reached by both sides, Continental Airlines may offer daily service to Madrid from Newark International Airport beginning in 1993.

headline: Germans Sigh and Say, 'Charge It'
abstract: After decades of scorning credit cards as a plastic plague threatening Germany's economic health, the nation's banks are discovering virtue in cashless consumerism.   Credit cards were often treated as luxuries for German business executives and tourists to use outside the country. Bankers used to warn that promoting the cards at home could encourage department stores, oil companies and auto makers to invade the banks' turf and take some of their business.

headline: Ethiopia's New Rulers Try to Shed Ethnic Baggage
abstract: The people who are emerging as the new rulers in Addis Ababa are members of the small ethnic and linguistic minority, the Tigreans, who come from a region hundreds of miles from here.    Their current control of this ancient city marks a break from centuries of almost uninterrupted rule by the Amhara ethnic group, which provided both the dynasty whose last ruler was the Emperor Haile Selassie, and Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, who seized power after the Emperor was overthrown in 1974 and imposed a dictatorship on a Soviet model, while maintaining the old dominence of the Amharas.

headline: New Managers For Ball Corp.
abstract: Delmont A. Davis was elected president and chief executive of the Ball Corporation today and Alvin Owsley was named chairman.   They succeed Richard M. Ringoen, who retired as chairman and chief executive effective today. Mr. Ringoen, who will be 65 in June, was facing mandatory retirement as chief executive.

headline: Stormin' Jonathan's Mission Is To Rescue America West
abstract: America West Airlines may not have a general in command as it flies into battle against the nation's leading carriers, but the advertising campaign it is introducing today features all the trappings of a military briefing, not to mention a well-known impostor who bears a striking resemblance to Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf.   The impostor is the bear-like comedian Jonathan Winters, who dons desert fatigues for the first print and television ads in a $20 million campaign designed to build business travel on America West. The campaign's primary goal is to herald the airline's latest fare cuts.

headline: G.M. Subsidiary Acquires Infocel
abstract: Electronic Data Systems Inc. has acquired Infocel Inc., a provider of information systems for local governments. Electronic Data, the Dallas-based computer services unit of the General Motors Corporation, bought 30 percent of Infocel in March 1990 with an option to acquire the remaining equity. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Fed Nominee Discusses Rate Cuts
abstract: Lawrence Lindsey, nominated to be a Federal Reserve Board governor, suggested to the Senate Banking Committee today that he would have cut interest rates more than the Fed did last fall. But he also endorsed the Fed's most recent rate cuts as adequate for the moment, and he hesitated to say the economy was now in recession.   "Certainly it was in recession in the first quarter," and it "probably" is now, although recovery appears near, Mr. Lindsey said at a two-and-a-half-hour confirmation hearing.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Hilton Nevada Corp., Las Vegas, to Kobs & Draft Advertising Inc., Chicago, for a direct-marketing campaign. The billings were not disclosed. * F. I. Service Inc., Milwaukee, a financial-data services company, to Cramer-Krasselt, Milwaukee. The agency said billings exceed $1 million.

headline: Ameritech Part Of Bid in Poland
abstract: The Ameritech Corporation said it was a member of a consortium with France Telecom that is one of three finalists in the competition to build and operate a cellular communications system in Poland. Poland's Ministry of Communications will make the final selection by the end of June, Chicago-based Ameritech said in a statement.   The Polish Government has said the winning consortium will own a 49 percent interest in the system and the Polish Government 51 percent. Ameritech is the parent of Bell companies in Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin. France Telecom is the national telephone company of France. Ameritech shares gained 12.5 cents today, to $64.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Death Toll Exceeds 30 in Eruption Of Volcano in Southwest Japan
abstract: More than 30 journalists, scientists, farmers and emergency workers died in a volcanic eruption in southwestern Japan on Tuesday, military officials said today, virtually all of them in a village that was burned away in a torrent of lava and stone.   Soldiers who tried to enter the hardest-hit area, called Kita-Kamikoba, in armored cars and tanks said they had counted 28 bodies before they were driven away by explosions that gained intensity this afternoon. Only four bodies were picked up, and none of the 28 were positively identified. Five other people have died in hospitals, mostly from breathing the superheated, asphyxiating gases.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Endicott Johnson Retail Corp., a footwear retailer, to the New York office of Earle Palmer Brown. Billings were not disclosed. * Tultex Corp., Martinsville, Va., a fleece and jersey clothing manufacturer, to McKinney & Silver, Raleigh, N.C. Billings are estimated between $4 million and $6 million.

headline: Consumer Index Up Only 0.3%; Output Higher
abstract: In another batch of favorable data, the Government reported yesterday that the economy appeared to be growing again without pushing up the inflation rate. Most economists consider that combination essential if the nation is to shake off the recession.    The Consumer Price Index rose in May by only three-tenths of 1 percent, the Labor Department said. When combined with other modest increases this year, the May rise suggests an annual inflation rate below 3 percent, or less than half of last year's 6.1 percent.

headline: Pretoria and Blacks Discuss Strife
abstract: Representatives of the South African Government, the African National Congress and the rival Inkatha Freedom Party sat down together for the first time today to discuss how to end violent clashes between black factions.    The Government, the African National Congress and Inkatha have had bilateral discussions but not broader talks together. The participation of Inkatha and the congress were considered essential to the talks because their supporters have been involved in most of the violence.

headline: On the Gringo Trail, With Flower Children's Heirs
abstract: Under the dry, penetrating sun of the Guatemalan highlands, a jewelry maker from Berkeley strung beads, a South African draft dodger dug into a plate of waffles and a young woman from London seasoned a broccoli and tomato salad.   A few feet away, on the covered terrace of Al Chisme Restaurant, a group of American men decades older than those at the first table talked about the circumstances of fate and luck that brought them to this village beside Lake Atitlan over the last 30 years.

headline: Weirton Cutbacks
abstract: The Weirton Steel Corporation said it would begin temporary layoffs to cut costs. The company reported a $28.5 million loss for the first quarter, compared with a profit of $5.2 million, or 18 cents a share, for the 1990 period. Sales were $253,2 million, down almost 19 percent from $311.9 million in the quarter a year earlier. Weirton's stock gained 37.5 cents today, closing at $5.375 on the Big Board.

headline: President Is Reacting Coolly To Aid Plea by Gorbachev
abstract: President Bush said today that he was keeping "all options" open in his desire to spur Soviet economic reform, but he reacted coolly to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's suggestion that the industrialized democracies should help the Soviet Union financially.   "A hundred billion is a large piece of change," Mr. Bush said at a Rose Garden news conference, adding that he still had reservations about whether huge infusions of aid would be of much use at this stage in Soviet economic development.

headline: Excerpts From Bush's Remarks on China
abstract: Following are excerpts from President Bush's speech today at Yale University, as recorded by Federal News Service, a transcription company:    Some argue that a nation as moral and just as ours should not taint itself by dealing with nations less moral, less just. But this counsel offers up self-righteousness draped in a false morality. You do not reform a world by ignoring it.                    . . .

headline: United Telecom In Note Offering
abstract: United Telecommunications Inc. is offering $200 million in notes due in 2003 through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company.   The notes have a 9.25 percent coupon and are priced at 100, to yield about 125 basis points more than the 10-year Treasury note. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

headline: State Taxes on Cable TV Upheld by Supreme Court
abstract: In a decision likely to open the way for new state taxes on cable television, the Supreme Court ruled today that the First Amendment permitted states to impose a tax on one form of communication while exempting other forms.   The Court ruled, by 7 to 2, that Arkansas did not violate the Constitution's free press guarantee when it imposed a 4 percent sales tax on cable television services while at the same time exempting newspaper and magazine sales from the tax.

headline: Colombia Ties Drug Cache to 3 in Jail
abstract: Are the Ochoa brothers trafficking in cocaine from jail?    Certainly not, protest the Ochoas, who say they have given up their multimillion-dollar cocaine exporting business and are now model prisoners in a Government rehabilitation program.

headline: Court Ruling Sets Back Insurers
abstract: A Federal appeals court ruled today that insurers could be sued for certain price-fixing activities, setting back the insurance industry, which has long contended that it is exempt from antitrust law.    Ruling in a case brought by 19 states against 32 American and foreign insurance companies, the United States Court of Appeals in San Francisco found that a lower court had erred in dismissing the case largely on the ground that the insurers were exempt from antitrust suits under the McCarran-Ferguson Act, which Congress passed in 1945. The act provided what had been considered sweeping exemptions to the insurance industry from antitrust law.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * ABB Henschel Waggon Union G.m.b.H., a unit of ABB Asea Brown Boveri, has received an $80 million order for railway cars from Deutsche Bundesbahn, Frankfurt. * Computer Sciences Corp., El Segundo, Calif., a computer services company, will acquire Butler Cox P.L.C., London, an information technology consulting firm, for about $22 million.

headline: THE ROMANIANS SEE MORE WOES AHEAD
abstract: The leaders of this country, the unhappiest of the formerly Communist nations of eastern Europe, concede that it is going through hardship as it jettisons the Communist legacy and struggles toward a market economy.   "This year will be dominated by economic difficulties, as last year was by political confrontations," President Ion Iliescu said in an interview in Cotraceni Palace. "There will be problems with the labor force. The number of jobless is mounting. Optimists say there will be 400,000, 500,000 unemployed. Pessimists say up to a million, and perhaps that is more realistic."

headline: Newsprint Use Down
abstract: Early estimates indicate that United States newsprint consumption in April dropped 10.6 percent from a year earlier, to 927,603 metric tons, the American Newspaper Publishers Association said today.

headline: Yale Tries to Strengthen Its Studies in the Sciences
abstract: Yale University has begun a drive to strengthen its science programs, redesigning its curriculum, building laboratories and aggressively recruiting science majors.   The effort recalls an 1860 campaign to create separate a Scientific School at the university. But while in the 19th century professors worried about losing top science students to European universities, today's professors worry about losing potential majors to the liberal arts departments for which Yale is best known.

headline: Strong Profits Are Reported At Intel and Advanced Micro
abstract: The Intel Corporation and Advanced Micro Devices Inc. reported unexpectedly strong first-quarter results today. They attributed the results to strong demand for microprocessors, the computers-on-a-chip that are the brains of personal computers, as well as some larger machines.    "We are delighted with this performance, given the current turbulence in the economy and in our industry," said Andrew S. Grove, Intel's president and chief executive. All Intel products exceeded order and shipment goals, he said.

headline: Clorox, in Revamping, to Drop Detergent
abstract: The Clorox Company said today that it would restructure parts of its operations and get out of the detergent business to focus on core products and future profitability.    The company estimated that it would take a $125 million charge against earnings in the April-June quarter to cover the restructuring. It also said the restructuring would reduce earnings in the fiscal year by $80 million, but that it would still be profitable. Clorox's fiscal year ends June 30.

headline: Chairman of Polaroid Plans to Retire May 7
abstract: William J. McCune Jr. plans to retire as chairman of the Polaroid Corporation on May 7 after the company's annual meeting, the company has announced. Polaroid said I. MacAllister Booth, its president and chief executive, is expected to be given the additional post of chairman.   Mr. McCune, who is 75, has been associated with Polaroid for 52 years and succeeded the company's founder, Edwin H. Land, as chairman. A 1937 graduate of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, he joined Polaroid in 1939, two years after the company was founded by Dr. Land, who died on March 1 at the age of 81. Mr. McCune's first job was to establish the company's quality-control program.

headline: PALESTINIANS FACE LEBANON TRIBUNAL
abstract: For the first time since the Palestine Liberation Organization established a foothold in Lebanon more than two decades ago, the authorities have begun prosecuting Palestinian guerrillas on charges of illegal possession of weapons, military officials said on Friday.    The prosecutor at the military court here, Jamil Bairam, brought the charges aginst six members of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine and two members of Al Fatah, the mainstream movement headed by the P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat. The Popular Front, headed by George Habash, is the second-largest of eight guerrilla factions affiliated with the P.L.O.

headline: March Inventories Fell 0.8% While Sales Declined by 1%
abstract: Businesses cut their inventories by eight-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the second consecutive monthly decline, and analysts said it could be a sign of increased production and jobs when sales improved.   "It's certainly good news that they're not stockpiling inventories," said Evelina Tainer, an economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. "The minute that demand picks up, producers will pick up production."

headline: Long-Term Interest Rates Resist Downward Pressure
abstract: After 10 months of recession, long-term interest rates remain stubbornly high, and a number of credit market analysts are beginning to wonder whether bond yields may have reached a trough in February, when they briefly dipped below 8 percent.   Persistently high long-term rates must be a source of concern at the Federal Reserve, which has aggressively pushed down short-term rates but has virtually no power to influence the direction of long-term bond yields. And as long as these bond rates remain high, recovery in important sectors like housing and capital spending will be muted or delayed.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Abitibi-Price Inc., Toronto, a maker of newsprint and specialty papers, said it would sell its Barber-Ellis/ Kaplan division, a maker of fine papers based in Seattle, to Spicers Paper Ltd. of Australia, for about $8.7 million in United States currency.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 23, 1991: MONDAY Ameron Inc Del Hart Stm Blr Insp & Ins Bellsouth Corp Standard Prods Co General Mills Unocal Expl Corp TUESDAY Aquarian Co Montana Pwr Co Bell Atlantic Corp Public Svc Co Colo Centerior Energy Corp Rubbermaid Inc Delmarva Pwr & Lt Co WEDNESDAY Brooklyn Un Gas North Sts Pwr Co Minn Central Me Pwr Co Wash Gas Lt Co Hunt Mfg Co Wolverine World Wide THURSDAY 1838 BD-DEB Trading FD Handy & Harman Bank of Boston Corp Pfizer Boston Edison Co Sara Lee Corp Campbell Soup Co FRIDAY Cent Hud Gas & Elec Sthwst Bell Corp Excel Income Shs Super Value Stores Pacific Telesis Group

headline: Making a Difference; The Lawyer With a Patent
abstract: When Albert P. Halluin was vice president and chief intellectual property counsel for the Cetus Corporation, he earned a reputation as a tenacious and aggressive defender of the company's inventions in biotechnology. But Mr. Halluin, 51, also is a biochemist, and last week he received a patent for a novel invention of his own, one that could prove to be a significant treatment for heart attacks.    The patent covers any drug formed by combining a biotech blood clot dissolver known as TPA with heparin, an anticoagulant. Normally, heparin and TPA are given separately to heart attack victims to prevent the reoccurrence of a clot. But on their own, TPA does not last long in the body and heparin can cause strokes.

headline: Two Families Flee Iraq To a World of Unreality
abstract: A cloud of dun-colored dust billowed from under the tires of a passing truck and rolled across the sea of blue and orange tents. An unshaved man, summoned by the scuffle and the voices of visitors, crawled from a tent, rubbing his eyes in the dust. He held a blue passport emblazoned with an American eagle.    "I'm an American," he said, opening the passport. "And here I am."

headline: Grumman Settles
abstract: The Grumman Corporation said it would reduce first-quarter earnings by $46.5 million to reflect a settlement with Tracor Aviation Inc., a Goleta, Calif. subcontractor that recently began bankruptcy proceedings. Grumman said the settlement was for a fraction of its claim, but the charge should not have a material effect on earnings.

headline: Mexico's Leader to Defend Trade Pact in U.S.
abstract: In an effort to rally political support for a proposed North American free-trade agreement, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari is to make a campaign-style trip to the United States and Canada beginning Sunday.   The trip by Mr. Salinas, who will meet Sunday with President Bush in Houston before starting a week of meetings in seven Canadian and American cities, comes amid rising concern here about opposition to a free-trade accord in the United States Congress. The Mexican leadership has staked its political future on the benefits of closer economic ties with the United States.

headline: Britain Plans to Cut Its Army by One-Fifth
abstract: Defense Secretary Tom King announced today that the British army would be cut by more than one-fifth, to 116,000 soldiers by the mid-1990's.   He told Parliament the cuts were in line with estimates in a cost-saving defense review made public last year.

headline: The Executive Life; A Lawyer's Switch to Aid a Hostile Takeover
abstract: The current dearth of takeover activity has left many of Wall Street's mergers and acquisitions specialists idle, waiting for the economy -- and the merger market -- to heat up again.  But one thing that never seems to slow down is their penchant for gossip, and these days, much of the lunchtime talk up and down Wall Street has centered on the apparent turnaround on hostile deals on the part of the takeover lawyer, Martin Lipton, who is representing the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in its hostile bid for the NCR Corporation.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; People
abstract: * Joseph Markovitch and John Luciani have been named vice presidents and management supervisors in the Vancouver and Toronto offices of Campbell-Mithun Esty Advertising Ltd. * Jeff Ginsberg has been named president and Jane Stark has been named vice president at Milton Samuels Advertising, a New York agency.   APPOINTMENTS AND EXECUTIVE CHANGES   254223910503   Late Edition - Final   05   03   1991   422391

headline: U.S. to Cut Chile's Debt In Plan to Foster Trade
abstract: Chile will become the first country to reduce its debt to the United States Government under a year-old Bush Administration plan to stimulate Latin American trade and investment.   Treasury officials said President Bush would officiate at a White House ceremony Thursday at which the Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, and Chile's Finance Minister, Alejandro Foxley, will sign an accord writing off $16 million in obligations Chile incurred in buying American food with Federal financing under the Public Law 480 food export program.

headline: Inquiries by the F.T.C. on Intel Cited
abstract: Federal Trade Commission lawyers have been inquiring about the business practices of the Intel Corporation, computer industry executives said today.    It does not appear the F.T.C. has begun a formal investigation yet, and Intel said today that it had not heard from the agency. Rather, industry executives said, it appears the agency is making some preliminary inquiries because it has received complaints about reportedly anti-competitive practices by the Santa Clara, Calif., semiconductor company, which dominates the business of supplying microprocessors for computers.

headline: Armenians Mourn Dozens Slain in Azerbaijan
abstract: Tens of thousands of Armenians packed the central square of the Armenian capital, Yerevan, today to mourn victims of the latest eruption in the Armenian-Azerbaijani blood feud.    After hourlong services in the city's main square, crowds followed five flower-bedecked coffins to different cemeteries for burial services, reports from Yerevan said.

headline: Switzerland Plans to Abolish Anonymous Bank Accounts
abstract: Switzerland, where discretion has long been the watchword among bankers, is abolishing most of its anonymous bank accounts to crack down on criminal transactions, the Federal Banking Commission said today.   Form B accounts, which preserved anonymity by allowing clients to conduct all bank transactions through a lawyer, notary or trust administrator, have become a notorious cover for money-laundering by drug-runners and corrupt dictators.     "Existing Form B accounts will have to be replaced by a written statement on the identity of the real owner by Sept. 30, 1992, at the latest," the banking commission said in a statement.   Registrations of account holders will begin on July 1.   The commission said, however, that banks would still be allowed to open anonymous accounts if the deposits they held pertained to running legal proceedings such as divorces or inheritances.   At the end of 1989 Swiss banks held some 30,000 Form B accounts, according to commission statistics. Swiss banking secrecy laws, some of the tightest in the world, date back to 1934.   Until now the only deterrence for criminals has been a rule requiring a customer's legal representative to attest that the client was not attempting to conceal illegal activity.   The banking commission's vice director, Daniel Zuberbuehler, said, "This statement that the account was not an attempt to conceal criminal activity was interpreted far too liberally."   Two years ago Switzerland was shaken by a billion-dollar money-laundering scandal that forced the resignation of its Justice Minister.   Since then it has tried to improve its reputation as a haven for drug cartels and dictators such as the late Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines, who was alleged to have stored billions of dollars of plundered state funds in Swiss banks.

headline: Mandela Group Backs Off Demands on Pretoria
abstract: The African National Congress has reportedly backed away from a threat to stop talking to the Pretoria Government about the country's future unless the continuing political violence is brought to an end within a month.   At private briefings in Cape Town on Tuesday, Nelson Mandela, the congress's leader, assured diplomats and South Africans that the demands made by its congress's national executive committee, in an open letter last Friday, constituted a plea for peace and not an ultimatum.

headline: Some Disappointment at Trammell Crow
abstract: Several large pension funds that invested about $200 million in Trammell Crow Equity Partners anticipating annual returns of 15 percent to 20 percent will be told today why the returns will be closer to 5 percent, several investors and a Trammell Crow executive say.    Trammell Crow Equity Partners was organized in late 1987 by the Trammell Crow Company of Dallas, the nation's largest real estate developer. In the last year and a half, the Trammell Crow Company has been buffeted by huge losses on its development projects and the collapse of real estate values across the country.

headline: Net Falls 48% At Polaroid
abstract: The Polaroid Corporation reported a 48 percent drop in first-quarter earnings today, saying the weak economy hurt consumer spending on the company's instant film.    For the three-month period that ended March 31, Polaroid reported net income of $16.4 million, or 13 cents a share, compared with $31.8 million, or 43 cents a share, during the corresponding period a year earlier. Sales totaled $441.2 million, just a 1 percent rise from $436.2 million in the first quarter of 1990.

headline: Utility Officer Resigns
abstract: The General Public Utilities Corporation said yesterday that Susan S. Schepman, its vice president of communications, had resigned on Friday. Her resignation came three weeks after Standley H. Hoch, the utility's chairman, resigned after an investigation into his relationship with Ms. Schepman. The resignations came after an anonymous letter, sent in April, disclosed their relationship. In a one-sentence memorandum, G.P.U., based in Parsippany, N.J., said Ms. Schepman "chose to resign." Ms. Schepman could not be reached for comment.

headline: Singer to Relocate And Offer Stock
abstract: The Singer Company, the 140-year-old sewing-machine concern that has changed hands several times in recent years, is planning a public offering worth $250 million to $300 million, company officials said. Singer plans to offer 15.6 million shares at $16 to $19 apiece to shareholders in the United States and overseas.    The Singer Company has been based in Hong Kong since 1989, when a subsidiary of Toronto-based International Semi-Tech Microelectronics Inc. bought it. Singer's headquarters will be moved from Hong Kong to the Netherlands Antilles. Its name will be changed to the Singer Co. N.V., and it will be listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Costs Soar for On-the-Job Injuries
abstract: The workers' compensation system of insurance, the 80-year-old program in which employers pay for job-related injuries, is struggling to stay afloat in at least seven states.   Surging medical costs and multimillion-dollar lawsuits brought by injured workers pushed national spending on workers' compensation up nearly 13 percent last year, to $53 billion. Since 1985, the spending has jumped a stunning 83 percent.

headline: Connecticut Sells $200 Million Issue
abstract: Connecticut sold a $200 million tax-exempt issue of special tax bonds yesterday initially priced to yield a maximum of 6.904 percent for a security due in 2011. The pricing of the bonds was done through negotiation with underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.    Shorter-maturity bonds were initially priced to yield from 5.2 percent in 1992 to 5.75 percent in 1996, 6.35 percent in 2001 and 6.8 percent in 2007.   The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and AA by S.& P.

headline: FORUM; Paying the Price for Living on Credit
abstract: If the recession is ending -- or indeed, even over -- that may provide some relief for American corporations plagued by sluggish demand and declining production and for cities whose tax revenues for much-needed services fall below budget forecasts.  But how much relief will the recovery provide for the scores of corporations and municipalities that have incurred substantial debt in recent years? Probably not much.

headline: Vehicle Sales Decline, but Hope Is Seen
abstract: Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks dropped 10 percent in May from a year earlier, but on a seasonally adjusted basis car sales alone were slightly stronger than in the previous month, leading to some hope that the automotive recession may have bottomed out.   Car sales, a barometer of economic health, are being closely watched for signs that a recovery may be under way. But statistics from a single 10-day period or just one month are often misleading, as they were in January and February when many analysts thought the bottom of the automotive downturn had been reached. Subsequent sales reports in March and April were weak, squelching the optimism.

headline: 2 Guilty in Pentagon Case
abstract: A Federal District Court jury has convicted two former executives of Litton Data Systems of illegally obtaining confidential Pentagon procurement data to help their company obtain three Navy contracts.   On Wednesday, the former executives -- Thomas D. McAusland, Litton's former vice president for business development, and Christopher Pafort, former director of business development -- were found guilty of conspiracy, illegally converting Government property and wire fraud.

headline: U.S., Seeking Negotiations, Warns Iberia of Suspension
abstract: The Department of Transportation threatened yesterday to suspend the right of Iberia Airlines to serve Miami and New York from Madrid because the Spanish Government has not allowed American Airlines and United Airlines to fly there from the United States.    A suspension is the most severe step that can be taken by a government under the agreements that regulate air service between countries. Such suspensions have been put into effect, but they are unusual.

headline: Other Brokers in Japan Are Linked to Scandal
abstract: Japan's new stock scandal widened today with reports that two more brokerages had paid big clients compensation for investments that lost money.   The Kyodo News Service quoted Finance Ministry officials, who were not identified, as saying that the Daiwa Securities Company and the Yamaichi Securities Company paid more than $72 million to some large customers to cover stock losses.

headline: RJR Nabisco Buying Back Costly Debt
abstract: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation is taking another big step to reduce the cost of history's most expensive leveraged buyout. The company announced yesterday that it was buying back more than $1.8 billion in high-interest debt for 100 cents on the dollar, plus some unpaid interest.   The paper that the company is redeeming is a 17 percent debenture due in 2007. It is the company's second-most-expensive debt, after a 17.375 percent issue due in 2009. That issue, totaling about $450 million, is only a quarter of the size of the 17 percent issue that the company is redeeming.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Economy    The nation's senior auditor predicted that the banking industry may be headed for a large taxpayer bailout, and based on the past assessments of the Comptroller General, Charles A. Bowsher, there is good reason to believe him.  [ Page D1. ]

headline: Managing; The Learning Curve in Day Care
abstract: The Lego Creative Childcare Center, with its kid-sized entrances and a facade that seems built out of giant Lego bricks, looks like a rich kid's playhouse. But it's run like a serious school.   Five-year-olds attend classes in music appreciation. Toddlers dress up and give plays. Eight-year-olds who come in after school can program computers to run motorized models of factory conveyor belts. For these older children, there is also a quiet place to do homework, as well as instructors to help them if they need it.

headline: Views Differ on Increase in Rates
abstract: As the second quarter nears its close, credit market analysts and participants are full of doubts about prospects for the economy and the inflation rate. But one tenet is still widely held: to insure a recovery, the Federal Reserve will refrain from pushing up short-term interest rates for some time, possibly for the balance of the year.   The Fed's past performance, however, strongly suggests that it will dash those expectations and move much faster.

headline: Pan Am Posts Wider Loss In Quarter
abstract: The Pan Am Corporation, battered by high fuel costs and a drop in traffic during the Persian Gulf war, said yesterday that it lost $249.2 million in the first quarter, compared with a loss of $190.7 million a year earlier.    The first quarter is usually the toughest for Pan Am and some other international carriers since traffic to Europe is lowest then. Pan Am filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code on Jan. 8.

headline: Conflict in Yugoslavia: In Slovenian Villages, a Fierce Determination but a Shortage of Firepower; Republic's Soldiers Wait for a Charge by Federal Army
abstract: A handful of young Slovenian militiamen sat nervously at the border post here today, clutching assault rifles and waiting for the Yugoslav Army to attack.    "They are all around us," said one of the militiamen, Anton Serbak, a bearded truck driver. "If they come, we'll do our best, and try to defend. Then maybe we have to run, because what can you do against a plane or a tank?"

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Motorola Codex, Mansfield, Mass., a telecommunications company, to Lawner Reingold Britton & Partners, Boston. The agency said that the account, previously at Brouillard Communications, New York, has billings between $2 million and $4 million.

headline: KUWAIT'S RULERS PICK NEW CABINET
abstract: After nearly two months of speculation and indecision, the Prime Minister named a new Government today. But businessmen, bankers and political opponents dismissed the move as largely a shuffling of posts that preserves power for the ruling Sabah family.    The new Cabinet was announced late tonight in a brief report on Kuwaiti radio. No members of the opposition were included despite suggestions that strenuous efforts had been made by the Crown Prince and Prime Minister, Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, to lure critics into the Government. Opposition leaders maintain that a token presence of critics would do little to restructure what they view as an incompetent administration.

headline: U.S. URGES TURKEY TO OPEN BORDERS TO FLEEING KURDS
abstract: Despite domestic and foreign pressure to help thousands of Kurds attempting to flee the Iraqi Army, the United States limited its actions today to calling on Turkey to open its borders to the refugees.   In talks with the American Ambassador, Morton I. Abramowitz, the Turkish Government refused the American request, saying it could not afford to permit a mass entry of perhaps as many as 500,000 refugees.

headline: Economic Progress in China Has a Seedy Side
abstract: A petite Chinese woman, with a skimpy skirt and a blouse revealing more than it covered, walked daintily across the lobby of the best hotel in this city. A few yards away, several smartly clad women sipping tea in the coffee shop smiled alluringly at the male guests.
