It is an open secret that here in Shenzhen, a special economic zone just across the border from Hong Kong, economic progress has brought with it the seedy side of the free market: prostitution, corruption, smuggling and even drug trafficking.    Shenzhen is China's best-known boomtown, and it is renowned throughout the country for its economic growth, high salaries, modern fashions and adherence to "bourgeois" morals, if any. To many people in the rest of China, Shenzhen is a lawless place.

headline: King Hussein Signs Charter Reviving Jordan Democracy
abstract: King Hussein and Jordanian politicians signed a document today to revive multi-party democracy 34 years after political parties were banned.   The 40-page National Charter culminates nine months of heated discussions by 60 Jordanians appointed by the King to draft the charter.

headline: Your Own Account; Are 'Wrap Arounds' Overpriced?
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is looking into potential abuses in wrap accounts, one of the most rapidly growing financial services products.  The accounts, available from many brokerage houses and financial planners, provide investors with a money manager. Wrap refers to the fees that "wrap around" all of the assets in such accounts. The fees are capped, usually at 3 percent a year, and typically cover the manager's services, trading commissions, custody of securities and a cut for the broker for servicing the account.

headline: Bull Replaces Chief Of U.S.-Based Unit
abstract: Groupe Bull said yesterday that Axel Leblois had been named president and chief executive officer of Bull HN Information Systems Inc., the subsidiary responsible for the company's North American and Pacific Rim operations. Based in Billerica, Mass., Bull HN manufactures a broad range of computer systems and includes the former computer operations of Honeywell Inc. and the Zenith Data Systems Corporation.    Mr. Leblois, who is 42 years old, was previously vice chairman of the International Data Group, Framingham, Mass., and chairman and chief executive officer of its International Data Corporation subsidiary, a leading publisher and market research organization for the computer and communications industries.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Accounts
abstract: * Pet Inc., a grocery manufacturer whose brands include Progresso Italian foods, to the St. Louis office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles for all media planning and buying. D.M.B. & B. already handled Pet's creative assignment, with billings estimated at $45 million. Media planning and buying had been handled since 1973 by the Haworth Group, Minnetonka, Minn. * Doubletree, a chain of hotels in the southwestern United States, to Ayer Inc. with a budget estimated at $10 million. Canadian Pacific Hotels and Resorts, which acquired Doubletree last year, has had its account at McKim Advertising, Ayer's Canadian agency, since 1916.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Blockbuster Entertainment Corp., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., an operator of video rental stores, said it had closed on the acquisition of Erol's Inc., also an operator of video stores. The purchase price was approximately $30 million in cash, common stock, debt assumption and notes. * Bombardier Inc., Montreal, said it had won a contract to build 140 bi-level cars for Amtrak worth $400 million. The order includes an option on 39 additional cars worth about $85 million.

headline: People
abstract: * Bruce Hopman, Ralph Palamidessi, Drew Burke and Rule Johnson-Morris have been named senior vice presidents at Lintas New York. * Robert Tramondo has been named New York advertising manager for Penthouse magazine.

headline: Pro Bono
abstract: * Bradford & Maloney Inc., a Greenwich, Conn., ad agency, is creating a campaign for the Center for Graphic Communications Management and Technology at New York University. The print campaign, intended to raise awareness of career opportunities in the graphic arts, features graduates who have become executives.  * City-as-School, a New York City high school program that offers students academic credit for their business internships, has enlisted Calet, Hirsch & Spector, New York, for a campaign to increase its enrollment. The campaign will include bus, subway and print ads.

headline: Market Place; A Clash of Views On Daimler-Benz
abstract: THE price of Daimler-Benz shares has risen steadily since Jan. 1, much to the surprise of many auto industry analysts. Despite the surge, Germany's largest industrial conglomerate remains conspicuously absent from their lists of recommended equities because of problems in its electronics business.   The divergent opinions are rooted in Daimler-Benz's bold but risky diversification over the last five years into aerospace and high technology and away from its core business of building Mercedes-Benz cars and trucks. Investors seem to see a thriving car company with peripheral problems, while market experts view the company as a high-technology conglomerate that is taking shape much more slowly than expected.

headline: The Executive Computer; Trying to Assess the Potential Hazards of Video Terminals
abstract: Several recent studies have provided more information about the health effects of computer use, and one of them included what appears to be reassuring news about the effects of electromagnetic fields on pregnant women.   Previous studies of video display terminal use among women have yielded conflicting and inconsistent results, producing growing concern among workers and managers about the prudence of assigning women of child-bearing age to computer-related jobs. Some studies have suggested -- but not proved -- a link between computer radiation and a variety of pregnancy problems, including miscarriage, birth defects and birth problems.

headline: Time Plans Big Stock Offering
abstract: Time Warner Inc. announced an offering to stockholders yesterday that would enable them to buy about 34.5 million new shares for a price between $63 and $105 a share, depending on how many accept the offer.    Wall Street was clearly not impressed, as Time Warner's stock plummeted for a second day, closing at $99.50, down $11.25, or 10 percent. With more than 1.5 million shares traded, Time Warner was the eighth-most active issue on the New York Stock Exchange. On Wednesday, the stock fell $6.25.

headline: Impasse Lingers on Next U.S.-Soviet Arms Round
abstract: President Bush said today that plans for a summit in Moscow are still "predicated" on being able to sign a new treaty on long-range nuclear weapons, but held open the possibility of a more informal meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev even if the arms control impasse cannot be broken.   Mr. Bush also said he would not agree to a full-scale summit meeting at the Kremlin if the Soviet Union does not satisfy American concerns about another major treaty, the pact on reducing non-nuclear arms that has been signed by 22 nations but not ratified by their legislatures.

headline: Digital Plans New Effort In PC Market
abstract: Kenneth H. Olsen, president of the Digital Equipment Corporation, announced yesterday that the company would market a new line of powerful personal computers made by the Intel Corporation and Ing. C. Olivetti & Company.    Since 1983, Digital, the nation's second-largest computer maker after the International Business Machines Corporation, has tried and failed several times to become a significant player in the personal computer business. Its original desktop machines were not completely compatible with I.B.M.'s, and as a result, the machines' ability to use popular software was limited, and so they were not widely accepted by business customers.

headline: Buyers Snap Up RJR 'Junk Bonds'
abstract: With investors clamoring for its "junk bonds," RJR Nabisco Inc. doubled its sale of the high-yield securities yesterday to $1.5 billion, or more than the value of all junk bonds offered last year.   Combined with nearly $1.3 billion from a sale of its common stock, the tobacco and food giant that has emerged from history's largest leveraged buyout suddenly finds itself awash in cash. Investors have cited their confidence in the RJR Nabisco management team and its chairman, Louis V. Gerstner Jr., and their enthusiasm over the strong cash flow from the company's famed brand names, like Winston cigarettes, Oreo cookies and Ritz crackers.

headline: New-Home Sales Rose 1% in March
abstract: Sales of new homes picked up by 1 percent in March, the second consecutive monthly advance, the Government said today in a report that reinforced the belief that the housing recession has reached bottom.   "It confirms our judgment that the bottom of the cycle was in January," said David F. Seiders, chief economist at the National Association of Home Builders. But he added that the recovery from the two-year housing slump would be moderate.

headline: Careers; Deans Try New Courses For M.B.A.'s
abstract: DEANS and faculty of graduate business schools all over the country are scrambling to keep up with the fast-changing world. That means changing programs, adding courses, deleting courses, hiring different types of faculty and arranging internships here and abroad, among other developments to meet the needs of future managers.    For example, at Southern Methodist University in Dallas an entirely new program is being put into place this fall. The former intensive 12-month M.B.A. program is being replaced with a more typical two-year program, like those at Harvard and Columbia.

headline: Bristol-Myers, Warner-Lambert Lift Profits
abstract: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company and the Warner-Lambert Company each said yesterday that strong drug sales had led the way to record first-quarter growth, adding to a string of pharmaceutical company reports of double-digit earnings increases.    Bristol-Myers Squibb, which dominates the cancer treatment market, said earnings rose 20.4 percent, helped by a 34 percent increase in anti-cancer drug sales. Analysts said the company's oncological drug sales could reach $1 billion this year for the first time.

headline: India Wary of U.S. Relief Force in Bangladesh
abstract: As American forces move into Bangladesh to assist in cyclone relief and rehabilitation work, hackles began to rise today in India, where there is a tradition of criticizing any United States military presence in the region as a direct threat to New Delhi.   The "foreign hand," a phrase that became a code name for the United States during the Government of Indira Gandhi, sets off a particularly high level of anxiety here in West Bengal, a state that has had a Communist-led government for 14 years.Calcutta, where the street on which the American Consulate is situated was renamed after Ho Chi Minh and where leftist radicals once sacked the American Center, still harbors the potential for quick-fire protests against the United States. Leftist columnists in the local press have begun the attack in the last two days.

headline: Awards Sprouting With the Spring
abstract: Ah, late spring, time for fresh peaches and advertising awards.    At the One Club's One Show last night in New York, GGK, a London agency, won best of show for its television commercial for the Electricity Association. The spot featured claymation animals discussing "creature comforts."

headline: Investor's T.W.A. Plan
abstract: Kirk Kerkorian, the California investor, said today that he wanted 60 days to try to buy troubled Trans World Airlines with its London routes intact. Representatives of Mr. Kerkorian's Tracinda Corporation gave Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner a plan for expanding T.W.A.'s routes in the United States and overseas, replacing its aging fleet of aircraft with quieter, fuel-efficient planes and attracting new management. They asked Mr. Skinner to block American Airlines, which wants to buy TWA's London routes, from interfering in talks between Tracinda and TWA's current owner, Carl Icahn.

headline: GORBACHEV PLEADS FOR $100 BILLION IN AID FROM WEST
abstract: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev pleaded today for $100 billion in economic aid from the democratic world, asserting that it would be well worth it to the West to bolster global security by priming a Soviet recovery.    The Soviet leader put his own print on what has been an unofficial and far from successful Kremlin lobbying campaign of the Group of Seven industrialized democracies for a voice at their summit gathering and for considerable cash aid for the staggering Soviet economy.

headline: Pretoria Overturns Death Sentences for 14
abstract: The country's highest court today overturned the death sentences of 14 blacks convicted of murder in the 1985 killing of a policeman.   Three judges on the appeal court in the central city of Bloemfontein ordered 11 of the so-called Upington 14 released today. Murder convictions for the other three were upheld, and they received prison terms ranging from 8 to 12 years.

headline: Barcelona Journal; Catalan Spoken Proudly Here (Listening, Madrid?)
abstract: It was an exuberant morning, the sun splashing between rushing clouds, and the cathedral square was coming alive.    Young women bundled twigs of laurel and thyme and arranged them on stalls draped with Catalonia's red and yellow flag. A group of matrons unpacked enough votive candles to burn down the entire cloister and praised their wares in loud Catalan. In the cathedral, a reading from the Bible too came in the hefty, dark tones of the language of Catalonia.

headline: Business Diary/June 9-14
abstract: COMPANIES  Can Apple and I.B.M. Find Common Ground?

headline: Indicators Index Posts a 4th Gain
abstract: The Government index designed to forecast the direction of the economy rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in May, the fourth straight monthly advance after six straight declines, the Commerce Department reported today.   The increase solidified expectations of a rebounding economy during the second half of the year. But most economists still say they believe the recovery will be relatively weak, and some analysts, in fact, contend it will be short-lived.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Air Canada, Montreal, said it would eliminate an additional 400 management positions by midyear, beyond those identified last year. * Alltel Corp., Hudson, Ohio, a telecommunications company, will sell its Ocean Technology subsidiary to Lagnaf Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: All of United Artists Sought By Tele-Communications
abstract: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operator, said yesterday that it was offering to buy the 46 percent of United Artists Entertainment that it does not already own.    United Artists Entertainment owns both cable systems and movie theatres.

headline: Sit-In by 1,000 on Taiwan
abstract: About 1,000 students and teachers conducted a sit-in today at a train station here to protest the arrests of four campaigners for independence. Advocating independence is a crime in Taiwan.

headline: World Markets; Waiting for the German Market
abstract: The stock market in Frankfurt rallied last week, rising 4.7 percent despite the announcement by Karl Otto Pohl that he would depart as Bundesbank President and the real prospect of another increase in German interest rates.    But except for David C. Roche, the international strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company in London, not many analysts think this surge is a signal to get back into the market, which had been so popular after the fall of Communism in Eastern Europe and the fall of the Berlin Wall at the end of 1989.

headline: No Offers of Billions to Soviets, Tokyo Says
abstract: Japan and the Soviet Union, seeking to overcome decades of mistrust, are expected to establish greater trade, technology and cultural ties as the centerpiece to a visit this week by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, officials of both countries say.    But the officials said they doubted that Japan would extend aid approaching the billions of dollars speculated upon in recent weeks, even if there is a breakthrough of some kind on the territorial dispute that has long blocked an improvement in relations.

headline: Searching for a Really High-Profile Investment?
abstract: The Empire State Building is for sale, and for a mere $45 million to $50 million -- a pittance for a prime property in midtown Manhattan.    But there's a catch, and it's 85 years long.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * AW Computer Systems Inc., Mount Laurel, N.J., has received an order for more than $800,000 of Aware/4680 equipment and service from Safeway Stores Inc.  * Abitibi-Price Inc., Toronto, a newsprint, wood and paper products company, will sell its Pine Falls newsprint operation in Winnipeg, Manitoba, to the local group that manages and operates it. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Stocks Fall Further; Dow Declines 37.87
abstract: Stocks fell sharply again yesterday, with analysts citing investor uncertainty about the economy and interest rates.   After falling 33.67 points on Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 37.87 more yesterday, to 2,927.72. Volume was moderate, with 164.4 million shares traded, compared with 195.5 million on Friday.

headline: Baker's Hope: Jordan River As Peace Sign
abstract: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has not been able to get Arab and Israeli leaders to sit around a conference table yet, but for one fleeting moment today he got Israeli and Jordanian soldiers together on a tiny wooden bridge over the Jordan River.    In a sudden shift of plans, Mr. Baker told his aides he wanted to get a better feel for the land in dispute between Israel and its neighbors, so instead of flying between Amman, Jordan, and Jerusalem he went by car, crossing the Jordan River border by foot on the Allenby Bridge. It was the first time any American Secretary of State has driven from Amman to Jerusalem, and it took only about 90 minutes.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * The International Olympic Committee, Lausanne, Switzerland, to Grey Advertising and its public relations subsidiary, GCI Group, for the 1992 Winter and Summer Olympics. Billings are not yet determined. * K Mart Corp., Troy, Mich., to Burrell Advertising, Chicago, for black consumer marketing. Billings were not announced.. * Rayfield Morton Unlimited Productions Inc. to Andreozzi Scharfman Aucone, New York, for its account billing $2 million to $3 million. No previous agency.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Market Place; Rosy Accounting At Japan's Banks
abstract: A FUNNY thing happened to Japan's big banks on the way to reporting their annual profits.    For months newspapers have been filled with stories of the huge financial problems at the banks' real estate affiliates and the high level of corporate bankruptcies here.

headline: Beijing Students Issue Leaflets on Democracy
abstract: In a rare political protest, students at Beijing University have distributed leaflets and hung a banner commemorating those killed in the military crackdown at Tiananmen Square two years ago.    The leaflets, which were flung out of dormitory windows on Tuesday shortly before noon, called on people to mourn the students who died in the crackdown on the democracy movement.

headline: Debt Update From Trump
abstract: Donald J. Trump has told state gaming regulators that he has resolved his casino's debt problems and that his banks are reviewing the situation.    Mr. Trump must keep the New Jersey Casino Control Commission updated on his progress in reorganizing the billion-dollar debt of his three casinos in order to keep them licensed. The casinos -- the Trump Castle, Trump Plaza and Trump Taj Mahal -- are the subject of a financial stability hearing on June 17 before the commission.

headline: To Suriname Refugees, Truce Means Betrayal
abstract: In the sullen refugee camps and ramshackle riverside huts here that house thousands of Surinamese who have fled their country's four-year civil war, recent word of peace has brought only feelings of bitter helplessness.   Far from rejoicing over a tentative agreement to end the conflict that relief workers say has destroyed virtually every village in their native region of eastern Suriname, the refugees, descendants of 17th-century runaway African slaves known as Maroons, speak of betrayal.    When Ronny Brunswijk, the 29-year-old guerrilla leader who founded the Maroon-based Jungle Commando insurgency in 1986 secretly negotiated an end to his sputtering guerrilla war late last month, refugees and former fighters here say, even his senior-most comrades-in-arms were caught by surprise.

headline: Bolar Agrees to Compensate Stockholders
abstract: The Bolar Pharmaceutical Company said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $20 million to thousands of stockholders to make up for losses they incurred when the company's share price fell after Bolar was accused of engaging in fraudulent practices to obtain approval of its products.   The company, based in Copiague, L.I., declined to comment, saying the agreement, which was signed on Wednesday, is subject to approval by Judge Leonard Wexler in Federal District Court in Hauppauge, L.I.

headline: Reforms Alter the Landscape of Czechoslovakia's Farming
abstract: In 1953, local Communist authorities forced Marie Pracna's parents to bring their small farm into a new agricultural cooperative.    Resistance was futile. The family had already seen neighboring farmers deemed too rich or intransigent exiled or sent to prison.

headline: U.S. Criticizes Albania Vote, But Backs Multi-Party Rules
abstract: The United States said today that Albanian elections had been less than free and fair, but called on Albania's citizens to help the new multi-party system work.   "Based on reports from U.S. observers and other international election monitors, it appears that the electoral process fell short in several key areas of C.S.C.E. standards for free and fair elections," said the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler. She was referring to the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe.

headline: Islamic Radicals Lose Their Tight Grip on Iran
abstract: The revolution that transformed Iran's Western-oriented cosmopolitan society into a militantly Islamic republic seems to be on the wane.    After 12 years of rule by radical Islamic clerics, an eight-year war initiated by Iraq, fierce internal repression of religious minorities and opponents, and a decade of economic drift and mismanagement, the revolution's repressive aspects are being relaxed, and ideology appears to be getting less attention.  Fear Is Still Pervasive     Once omnipresent in this capital, pictures of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the much revered architect of the Iranian revolution, have largely disappeared except in Government buildings. The Teheran radio has begun occasionally omitting "The Words and Path of the Imam Khomeini," short homilies from the Ayatollah that once preceded every afternoon news broadcast.

headline: Beijing Is Said to Allow Prison-Made Exports
abstract: Chinese prison officials have encouraged a practice of forcing inmates to produce goods for export, according to issues of a restricted-circulation Chinese magazine obtained by Asia Watch, the human-rights organization.   Incidents have come to light in recent years in which prison labor was used to produce goods that were later exported. But the materials released today by Asia Watch suggest a broad pattern in which prisons are often encouraged to take advantage of their low labor costs to ship goods to the international market. Prison inmates are paid little or nothing for their work.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; President of GlenFed Submits Resignation
abstract: Keith P. Russell Jr., the president and chief operating officer of GlenFed Inc., parent of the nation's fourth-largest savings and loan association, has resigned, the company said yesterday.   GlenFed gave no reason for the resignation except to say that Mr. Russell was leaving "to pursue other business interests." His duties have been assumed by Norman N. Coulson, GlenFed's chairman and chief executive.

headline: Philadelphia Water Bonds Are Offered
abstract: The Philadelphia Water and Sewer Authority negotiated the sale of $300 million in tax-exempt water revenue bonds yesterday through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.   Investors are offered securities initially priced to yield a maximum of 7.875 percent for bonds due in 2010 and 2018. The shorter maturities were priced to yield from 6.5 percent in 1993 to 7.1 percent in 1996 and 7.6 percent in 2001. A longer-term issue, due in 2021, was priced to yield 7.2 percent.    Underwriters said the issue carried a conditional rating of Baa by Moody's and a BBB rating by both S.& P. and Fitch Investors Service. The only bond in the financing that is insured is the bond due in 2021, which is insured by the Capital Guaranty Insurance Corporation and thus rated AAA by S.& P.

headline: Mental State of Red Square Pilot Questioned
abstract: Mathias Rust, the German aviator who became a folk hero in 1987 when he flew a small plane to Red Square in Moscow, is mentally disturbed and should not be held responsible for attacking a student nurse, a psychiatrist said today.    Mr. Rust, 23 years old, is on trial for attempted murder in the 1989 stabbing of a fellow hospital worker here. Dr. Johann Burchard, a psychiatrist testifying for the defense, described Mr. Rust as "seriously disturbed" and said he could not be held responsible for his acts. Dr. Burchard said that when the student nurse, Stefanie Walura, spurned Mr. Rust, he was deeply hurt and might have reacted instinctively.

headline: Train Hits a Truck in Japan; More Than 300 Are Injured
abstract: More than 300 commuters were injured today when a packed train smashed into a truck at a crossing in western Japan, the police said.   The train was carrying between 450 and 500 passengers, most of them students, when the collision occurred in Fukuchiyama, about 50 miles from Kyoto, Japan's ancient capital.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the scheduled release dates of major economic indicators this week. Monday  None

headline: 10 Yugoslav Officers Said to Die in Strife
abstract: Serbian militants and police officers battled in two Croatian villages on Thursday, leaving at least 10 Croatian police officers dead, the authorities said early today. There were unconfirmed reports that as many as 20 civilians were also killed.    It was the worst day of violence between the groups in their continuiing conflict over whether the central Government will maintain its sway over this patchwork nation's secession-minded ethnic minorities.

headline: TRUMP DISCUSSING EMPIRE'S BREAKUP TO PAY OFF BANKS
abstract: The empire that Trump built is about to be dismantled.    Less than nine months after signing a sweeping rescue package for Donald J. Trump, the banks that lent him nearly $2 billion to build his empire have abandoned the original agreement and are now close to signing tentative agreements that would give them some of his key properties.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Atlantic Richfield Co., Los Angeles, named Allen C. Holmes vice president and general tax officer. * Hoechst Celanese Corp., Somerville, N.J., a chemicals manufacturer and subsidiary of Germany's Hoechst A.G., named Alban J. Schuele president of Celanese Canada Inc. and Hoechst Canada Inc.

headline: International Paper To Acquire Leslie
abstract: The International Paper Company agreed to buy the Leslie Paper Company in a move to expand the paper giant's distribution network. International has 250 wholesale and retail distribution operations nationally. International, based in Purchase, did not disclose terms of the deal, which it expects to be completed before September.

headline: Pohl Plans A Statement
abstract: Germany's central bank said today that Karl Otto Pohl, its president, would issue a statement later this week to address news reports that he planned to resign.   Mr. Pohl has been traveling abroad on business since Friday and "regrets the rumors circulating about his alleged intention to resign," the Bundesbank said in a statement. "At present, he is not willing to make any comment," the statement added. "He will make a statement after the meeting of the Central Bank Council on Thursday, May 16."

headline: World Markets; Why Swiss Bank Shunned Gold
abstract: When the Swiss Bank Corporation's private banking group did its projections for financial markets in the second quarter, it predicted that the price of gold would rise to $370 an ounce by the end of June, an increase of 3.6 percent.    This was one of the better returns projected as the group looked at financial markets around the world and forecast outlooks for stocks, bonds and short-term interest rates on cash. But when it came to allocating clients' money among these numerous markets, the bank did not buy gold.

headline: For India, Will It Be Change, Secularism or a Right Wing?
abstract: India, in political ferment at home and no longer certain of its international role, is heading toward a national election in May that could change the course and character of the world's second most populous nation.    For the first time since independence in 1947, the choice offered voters will not be merely for or against the Congress Party, the century-old organization once led by Mohandas K. Gandhi and Jawaharlal Nehru that has dominated political life for four decades. In 1991, the Congress Party, now led by Nehru's grandson, Rajiv Gandhi, is only one among three almost equally weighted political forces competing for power.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Advest Inc., Hartford, a brokerage and underwriter, named Murry M. Beach senior vice president and head of corporate finance. * Apple Bank for Savings Inc., a unit of Apple Bank Corp., named Robin Thomson senior vice president of commercial real estate lending.

headline: Firefighters Extinguish Kuwait Oil-Well Blaze
abstract: A Texas firefighting team today extinguished the first of 500 oil-well fires set by Iraqi troops and declared a "small victory" that could mark a turning point in the operation.   The team from a Houston-based company, Boots & Coots, using liquid nitrogen and water, put out a relatively small fire on its second attempt this morning.

headline: Market Place; At Last, Dow Closes Above 3,000
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 3,000 for the first time yesterday, marking another milestone in a bull market that has seen stocks around the world rise sharply since last fall, when concerns peaked over the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and higher oil prices.    Propelled by lower interest rates and by expectations that the recession will end soon, the Dow gained 17.58 points, on strong volume of 246.9 million shares, and closed at 3,004.46. It has risen 27 percent since Oct. 11.

headline: Oppenheimer Executive Is Promoted to President
abstract: Bridget A. Macaskill was named president yesterday of the Oppenheimer Management Corporation in a move intended to strengthen the balance of talents at the top of the mutual fund management company.    Ms. Macaskill, 42, had been executive vice president and chief operating officer before her promotion and will continue as chief operating officer. She succeeds Jon S. Fossel as president; Mr. Fossel remains as chairman and chief executive.

headline: BUSINESS DIARY/June 2-7
abstract: COMPANIES Where's That Time Warner Synergy?

headline: Money-Market Fund Yields Down Moderately in Week
abstract: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down moderately for the week ended yesterday.    IBC/Donoghue's analysts said the short end of the fixed-rate market continued to trend down, affecting money-market fund yields.

headline: Pan Am Warns It May Fail
abstract: The Pan Am Corporation, which filed in January for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from its creditors, has told the Government that it has doubts about whether it can survive through the end of the year.   In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the airline company said the availability of financing was "severely restricted," that it had no available credit and that most of its remaining assets were "encumbered."

headline: County Borrowing
abstract: Los Angeles County priced a short-term borrowing totaling $1.3 billion yesterday through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The tax and revenue anticipation notes, which are due on July 1, 1992, were initially priced to yield 4.55 percent. Many municipalities issue these types of note as a temporary form of borrowing in anticipation of the collection of taxes or other expected revenues.

headline: Getting Out of China Harder Than Going In
abstract: Arranging a $175 million investment in a coal mine in China was hard enough. It took several handshakes with Deng Xiaoping and other top Chinese leaders to get Beijing's agreement.    But now, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation has set itself up for what may become an even tougher task: getting rid of the investment without a huge loss.

headline: Why 'Green Taxes' Won't Work
abstract: To the Editor:   Sandra Postel indulges in wishful thinking ("The Greening of America's Taxes," Forum, May 19) when she says that new corporate taxes -- "green taxes" -- on industries that hurt the environment could fight pollution and help the economy at the same time.

headline: Tenneco Unit Fights Loss of Submarine Job
abstract: The Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company said today that it had filed a lawsuit challenging its loss of a contract to build the Seawolf submarine.   The suit, filed on Monday in Federal District Court in Norfolk, seeks to set aside the Navy's awarding of the $1.8 billion contract last week to the General Dynamics Corporation's Electric Boat division in Groton, Conn.

headline: New Jersey Utility Raises $300 Million
abstract: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company of Newark is offering a total of $300 million in first and refunding bonds through competitive bidding.   Merrill Lynch & Company led an underwriting group that was awarded $150 million of the bonds, due 2003. The bonds were then reoffered to the public with a coupon of 8 7/8 percent at a price of 99.807 to yield 8.90 percent, or about 60 basis points more than a 10-year Treasury note. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

headline: Inquiry Starts on Chip Patent Dispute
abstract: The Patent and Trademark Office has opened an inquiry to re-examine a disputed patent that covers the basic design of computer chips.   At issue is the patent obtained last July by Gilbert P. Hyatt, an inventor in La Palma, Calif. He says his patent applies to many of the central processors that are the brains of everything from calculators to personal computers. He applied for the patent in 1970 and spent 20 years overcoming objections at the Patent Office.

headline: Pope Names 22 Cardinals; Chinese Prelate Is Identified
abstract: Pope John Paul II appointed 22 new cardinals today, including two Americans, and revealed that 12 years ago he had secretly named a Chinese archbishop who spent 30 years in prison for refusing to renounce his loyalty to the Vatican.   In his first designation of cardinals since the collapse of Communism across Eastern Europe, the Pope also selected three prelates from former Warsaw Pact countries -- a Romanian, a Czechoslovak and a German from what used to be East Berlin.

headline: Journal Swap Offer
abstract: The Journal Company, which owns The Trentonian and eight other daily newspapers, said it was extending a debt exchange offer and would make an overdue bond interest payment. The company said it had received a loan from affiliates of E. M. Warburg, Pincus & Company, its controlling shareholders, to meet a $7.6 million interest payment that was due May 1. The grace period was to have expired today on the semiannual payment on debentures paying 14.825 percent and 14.625 percent interest. The Journal Company, a unit of the Journal Register Company, also said it was extending through June 12 a debt exchange offer announced May 1 that was to have expired Wednesday.

headline: New Claims By Jobless Rise Sharply
abstract: The number of Americans filing new unemployment claims surged in early June, the Government reported today.    The jobless claims number, which rose 47,000 for the first week of June to cancel out a decrease of nearly that amount the week before, added to conflicting evidence of late about the health of the nation's economy, analysts said.

headline: Stocks Higher in Tokyo
abstract: Stock prices rose today in Tokyo. The Nikkei index of 225 issues finished up 113.03 points, or less than 1 percent, to 26,695.53. At midday, the Nikkei was stronger, at 26,864.09, up 281.59 points. On Friday, the index fell 48.53 points, to 26,268.86. Trading today was dominated by a stronger yen and hopes that interest rates would soon be lowered, traders said, because of Friday's drop of one-tenth of a percent in the United States Consumer Price Index for March.

headline: Data Bank/April 14, 1991
abstract: Business Inventories   Feb.   Jan.   Dec.        Monthly percent change   --0.2   0.5   --2.4        Mfg. Inventory-Sales Ratio        Current dollars   1.57   1.58   1.53        Sales at Retail Outlets   March   Feb.   Jan.        Monthly percent change   --0.8   2.0   --1.3       Electric Power   April 5   March 29   March 22        Millions of kilowatt hours, weekly total   49,684   50,787   51,559        Coal Production       Thousands of net tons   19,429   19,629   20,109        Money Supply Growth   3 mos.   6 mos.   12 mos.        M-1, annual percent change   5.9   4.7   4.4        Money Supply Growth        M-2   3.6   2.9   3.2        Money Supply Growth        M-3   4.2   2.6   2.1

headline: First Capital Has Big Loss
abstract: The First Capital Holdings Corporation said today that it lost $770 million in the first quarter after accounting for the recent seizures of its life insurance subsidiaries by regulators in California and Virginia.    The company, which is based in Los Angeles, also said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it expected to seek protection from its creditors by converting an involuntary bankruptcy petition filed by its lenders this month in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Los Angeles into a voluntary petition.

headline: Kohl Says West Has a Duty to Step Up Aid to Former East Bloc
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany said today that "all Western countries" had a responsibility to provide greater economic aid to the Soviet Union and the former Communist countries of Eastern Europe to help them make the transition to free markets. But it is unclear whether Bonn is willing to go much beyond the money it has already committed to the Soviet Union and the former East Germany.    Addressing a group of foreign ministers from the United States, Canada and Europe who are taking part for the first time in a post-cold war session of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, Mr. Kohl said of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union: "Additional assistance is needed to bolster the necessary transformation in the reformist countries, and I would emphasize that this assistance must come from all Western countries. It will be help toward self-help. We know that this is a worthwhile investment in peace and stability."  Germany's Own Burden     The Germans are already committed to giving about $31 billion in grants and credits to the Soviet Union, in part because of Moscow's assent to the unification of Germany. But Bonn, faced with mounting costs in eastern Germany, has recently appeared wary of further large-scale aid programs.

headline: Tokyo Journal; Best College Money Can Buy (Can It Be Bought?)
abstract: To a generation of Japanese who created the world's most disciplined work force from the chaotic ruins of World War II, Tsuyoshi Mitsuzawa was the hero of an era, an ace amateur pitcher who parlayed an accurate arm into a career as a university coach, television commentator and successful businessman.   But to members of a very different generation that often find themselves trapped in the system their parents built, Mr. Mitsuzawa was apparently a hero of a different kind: a man who knew his way around the notoriously rigid university entrance-exam system.

headline: Hamilton Standard
abstract: The Hamilton Standard Company, a unit of the United Technologies Corporation, said about 150 employees would be furloughed over the next three months. Hamilton said the furloughs would be at its aircraft repair plant in East Windsor, Conn. The company said reduced commercial air travel had resulted in a shortage of work at the plant.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Best Buy Co., Minneapolis, named Brad Anderson president and chief operating officer and Allen Lenzmeier executive vice president and chief financial officer. * Contel Cellular Inc., Atlanta, an indirect majority-owned subsidiary of GTE Corp., named Paul G. Kozlowski chairman. He succeeds Charles Wohlstetter, who will remain on the board.

headline: Untimely Rivalry Weakens Spain's Socialists
abstract: After nine years in office without a serious challenge from the opposition, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez has been unexpectedly tested by a bitter power struggle between members of his Government and leaders of his Socialist Workers' Party.    On one level, the dispute is between Cabinet technocrats who put a priority on economic growth and party politicians who believe the Government should renew its commitment to social justice. On another level, it is a battle for the right to succeed Mr. Gonzalez if and when he steps down.

headline: Real Money in Fantasy Baseball
abstract: Fantasizing about baseball has become a big business.   Publications, computer companies, newspaper games, even "900" toll telephone services have sprung up to address the growing market for fantasy baseball, a pastime believed to have several million fanatical adherents.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: MONDAY: Securities and commodities exchanges in the United States will be closed in observance of Memorial Day.  TUESDAY: Existing home sales for April will be released by the National Association of Realtors * End of five-week survey of Alaska to determine how much more cleanup is needed from Exxon Valdez spill.

headline: Many Palestinians Look for New Leaders and a Chance for Peace With Israel
abstract: A growing number of officials of the Palestine Liberation Organization, stunned by the damage to their movement from its support of Iraq in the Persian Gulf war, are openly calling for changes in the group's leadership and greater democracy in its decision-making process.    These officials say their aim is to dampen the role of hard-liners in the Palestinian leadership in exile -- in Tunisia, Syria, Iraq, Lebanon and elsewhere -- and to give Palestinians who are living under Israeli occupation in the West Bank and Gaza Strip a greater say in shaping future P.L.O. policies, including the terms of any settlement with Israel.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: DEBT * Ford Capital B.V.'s $300 million issue of 9 1/2 percent notes was priced to yield 9.52 percent, according to the underwriter, First Boston, who also said that the noncallable issue was rated A2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's.

headline: As Economy Sags, Gorbachev Faces New Demands
abstract: Amid the bleakest economic readouts in six years of promised reform, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev faced a demand today from rebellious hard-line deputies that he defend his record at an emergency session of the national Congress.    At the same time, his latest anti-crisis program was dismissed by his former free-market economic reformers as a ruse to fool the West and an attempt at warmed-over Communism for the struggling Soviet consumer.

headline: A Glamour Account To McElligott Wright
abstract: Chalk up another account victory for Tom McElligott, who resigned last year as executive creative director of Chiat/Day/Mojo in New York and later helped found McElligott Wright Morrison White in Minneapolis.   The fledgling agency yesterday picked up the trade account for Glamour magazine, a Conde Nast publication. The billings were not disclosed. Tony Wright, the agency's president, said the agency's billings would now total $18 million.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: COMMON STOCK * Coastal Healthcare Group Inc., Durham, N.C., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of 3 million common shares through Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. * Hartmarx Corp., Chicago, has filed for a public offering of 4 million common shares, 3.2 million to be offered in the United States through the First Boston Corp.

headline: Baker-Assad Talks Called Inconclusive
abstract: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d tried today to persuade President Hafez al-Assad of Syria to agree in principle to an American proposal for a regional peace conference between Israel and the Arab countries.    Officials here, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the two three-hour sessions were inconclusive and that President Assad did not give a final response to the ideas offered by Mr. Baker. But a Syrian official said the talks were "friendly, and reflected determination on both sides to maintain the dialogue until they realized the goal of a just and durable peace."

headline: Managua Journal; Victor's Lament: To the Losers Belong the Spoils
abstract: When Violeta Barrios de Chamorro took over the presidential office suite a little over a year ago from her defeated Sandinista rival, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, she found on hand four rocking chairs painted violet.   And little else in the way of office furnishings, she says.

headline: Battle for Control Of Banyan Trust
abstract: THE VMS Short Term Income Trust offered by VMS Realty Partners looked like a conservative investment, and it was sold as one.   But the trust, which made mortgage loans to help buy properties that VMS would then sell to other investors, turned into a disaster. Shares in the trust, sold at $10 in 1984, are now trading at $1.375 on the American Stock Exchange. - After VMS Realty went broke, the eight real estate investment trusts it had created declared their independence and changed their names to substitute Banyan for VMS. They hired Leonard G. Levine, a former VMS official, to run them.

headline: Technology; A Way to Hear Stock Quotes While Watching Cartoons
abstract: There is more to stereo television sets than enhanced sound. Even though 24 percent of all American households own stereo TV's and VCR's, few viewers realize their equipment enables them not only to hear better, but also to hear more programs.   Each stereo set has a button that switches the viewer to a different audio band than the one that provides the sound for regular and cable channels. Although the technology has been available since the mid-1980's, broadcasters are only beginning to see the potential for this secondary audio programming sideband, commonly known as SAP.

headline: Interim Chief At Fibreboard
abstract: The Fibreboard Corporation said today that it had appointed an interim president and chief executive and an interim chairman to replace Lawrence C. Hart, who resigned from the positions on Tuesday.    The company, based in Concord, Calif., said that James D. Costello, who had been vice president of wood products, would be the interim president and chief executive and that Philip R. Bogue, a member of the board, would be the interim chairman.

headline: Gorbachev on Peace Mission to Japan
abstract: Appealing for reconciliation after an enmity long predating the cold war, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived in Japan today with hopes of achieving a new relationship harnessing Japanese investment and technology to help the Soviet Union out of its economic crises.    Even before the arrival of Mr. Gorbachev, the first Soviet leader ever to visit Japan, Japanese attention was focused on what was taken as an extraordinary gesture -- a visit to the site of several Japanese graves in the Siberian city of Khabarovsk.

headline: Market Message: From Bust to Boom?
abstract: The recession seems to be ending. But the overwhelming consensus is that the recovery will not amount to much. There is talk of a "double dip" downturn, and few expect strong growth.   The stock market, however, seems to have a different opinion, That contrary notion, of coming strength in the economy, is conveyed not just by the fact that the Dow Jones industrial average last week rose 113.59 points, to 3,027.50, setting a record and closing above 3,000 for the first time since April 17. It may also be significant that it is no longer the recession-resistant consumer stocks, like Procter & Gamble and Philip Morris, that are leading the charge.    Of the 30 stocks in the Dow, four are now at least 10 percent higher than they were when the average first closed over 3,000. All are big, grimy, cyclical stocks: Du Pont, Goodyear, General Motors and Bethlehem Steel. International Paper and Union Carbide have risen almost as much. If those moves are to make sense, then this economy needs than a weak recovery.    The bond market's refusal to rally may also be sending a signal of surprising economic strength,. The Federal Reserve has pushed short-term interest rates dopwn sharply, and American investors have taken the hint. Sales of mutural funds are booming.    And yet, as Fred Leiner, an economist at Continental Bank, points out, long-term interest rates have been stalled for six months, making minor moves but essentially going sideways. "I'm concerned by some similarities with late 1986," he said. "We see money pouring into bond funds, yet the bond market is unable to move higher. Those similarities suggest the market may move lower from these levels."    In late 1986 and early 1987, he recalled, the bond market stalled while stocks leaped. Then bond prices crashed in the spring, and stock prices followed the fall.    This year, there are certainly plenty of reasons to doubt that the economy can rebound strongly. The debt overhang that helped to bring on this recession has not disappeared, and the Government's efforts to fight the recession have been limited by the severe fiscal problems brought on by the profligacy of the 1980's. It is hard to imagine a new boom in commercial construction.    Moreover, the evidence that the recession is ending, while persuasive to a lot of stock traders, is still limited,. The leading indicators have risen for three consecutive months, and factory orders turned up in April. Consumers tell pollsters the present is bad, but the future will be better, and they seem to translate those beliefs into cautious spending, not a panicky increase in savings. Stock market analysts note that secondary stocks, which were leaders in the winter rally, are lagging as summer begins, Their particiaption would make this rally a more impressive one.    But for all that, it is a fact that the economy usually finds a way to surprise the seers. A strong recovery this year would certianly qualify as a surprise. Perhaps, just perhaps, that is the current message of the markets.

headline: American Air Adds Flights to Britain
abstract: American Airlines announced an expanded schedule between the United States and London after acquiring routes into Heathrow Airport last week from Trans World Airlines. American, the biggest United States carrier, will fly 12 times a day from seven American cities to London with the inclusion of T.W.A. routes from New York-Newark, Boston and Los Angeles. The Boston service and most of the routes from the New York-Newark area begin on July 1. The rest begin on July 20.   The airline will have three flights a day between New York's Kennedy Airport and Heathrow and one between Newark and Heathrow. There will be one flight daily between Los Angeles and Heathrow and between Boston and Heathrow. The airline is shifting flights from Chicago and Miami and London's Gatwick Airport to Heathrow.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: DEBT * Republic New York Corp. is offering $100 million in 9.3 percent 30-year subordinated notes at 99.643 to yield 9.335 percent through Merrill Lynch & Co. The notes are noncallable through maturity and are rated A-1 by Moody's and AA- by S.& P.

headline: U.S. Bond Prices Rise Moderately
abstract: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds posted a moderate recovery yesterday, pushing interest rates down slightly, while the shorter maturities had smaller gains.    Dealers attributed the modest improvement to some bargain-hunting by retail buyers who had been largely absent from the market during the sharp price declines of the last three trading sessions.

headline: I.B.M. Going on Offensive To Promote Key Software
abstract: I.B.M., the world's largest computer company, has been pushed out of the personal computer and software spotlight by its software partner, the Microsoft Corporation, and this week, it begins a slow process of trying to push itself back in.   In a series of meetings with analysts and software developers, I.B.M. will begin a lobbying and marketing campaign that trumpets the virtues of the operating system it will bring out later this year. At issue is not just who produces the better personal computer operating system -- which acts in the computer like the conductor of an orchestra, issuing orders and coordinating players -- but who sets industry standards.

headline: 2 Leaders Urge Gorbachev Role
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany said today that they wanted to invite President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union to the Group of Seven summit meeting in London in July.    At a news conference that followed the 57th French-German summit meeting, Mr. Mitterrand also said France would not take part in the rapid reaction force of 50,000 to 70,000 soldiers that NATO defense ministers endorsed this week in Brussels.

headline: 'Mistakes,' Says Hussein Aide
abstract: The Deputy Prime Minister of Iraq, Tariq Aziz, said in an interview that the Government of President Saddam Hussein had made "mistakes" because it had been in power so long, The Washington Post reported today.   Because of the mistakes, Mr. Aziz said, Iraq has made an irrevokable decision to adopt a constitution acceptable to the majority of its people.

headline: Gorbachev Offers to Resign as Party's Chief, but Is Given a Vote of Support
abstract: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev cut short a chorus of invective from hard-line Communist Party chiefs today by abruptly offering to quit as their leader and winning an overwhelming vote of support.    Participants at the closed session said Mr. Gorbachev's move was less a tactical maneuver than an eruption of pique after two hours of charges that he was personally responsible for the crisis in the party and the country. Several speakers demanded his resignation.

headline: COMPANY EARNINGS;
abstract: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's No. 2 steel producer, reported a first-quarter loss of $39.2 million yesterday, saying the recession had diminished demand for steel sheet products that go into automobiles and appliances.   Bethlehem's loss compares with income of $21.3 million, or 20 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1990. Sales fell 13.2 percent, to $1.05 billion, from $1.21 billion in the period a year earlier.

headline: Rebels Black Out Much of Peru
abstract: Maoist guerrillas bombed and shelled embassies and banks and blacked out much of the country Friday night in their most extensive attack since President Alberto Fujimori took office nine months ago, the police said today.   The Japanese, Israeli and Colombian embassies were targeted with bombs, dynamite and bazookas, the police and local radio stations said. No injuries were immediately reported.

headline: Oracle in Venture With Japanese
abstract: The Oracle Systems Corporation, a software company that has been experiencing financial management difficulties, said it would receive $200 million in long-term financing from the Nippon Steel Corporation as part of a new venture.

headline: USX Expects Large Loss
abstract: The USX Corporation, the nation's largest steelmaker, will post a significant first-quarter loss, Charles A. Corry, its chairman, said today.   "The recessionary climate experienced so far in 1991 has greatly reduced demand and depressed prices in domestic steel markets," he said. "The duration of the current recession cannot be predicted."

headline: NCR's Profit Dips 12%; A.T.&T. Gets Just 4 Seats
abstract: The NCR Corporation said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings fell 12 percent, largely because of the cost of fighting a takeover attempt by A.T.&T.   The earnings were at the high end of analysts' expectations and may strengthen the company's resolve to continue to try to fend off the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

headline: British Official Starts Beirut Hostage Mission
abstract: A senior British Government official arrived here today in a fresh effort to win the release of Western hostages believed held by Shiite Muslim fundamentalists aligned with Iran.   Douglas Hogg, a minister in the Foreign Office, said he would be ready to meet anyone able to help free the hostages. Among the leaders Mr. Hogg is to see is Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, spiritual mentor of the pro-Teheran Party of God. Sheik Fadlallah, a prominent Shiite Muslim scholar, says he has no organizational link with the Party of God, which in turn insists it is not involved in hostage taking.

headline: Data Bank/April 21, 1991
abstract: Housing Starts   March   Feb.   Jan.        Thousands of units, annual rate   901   989   850        Industrial Production Index       Percent change   --0.3   --0.9   --0.5        Capacity Utilization        Output as a percentage of capacity   78.7   79.1   80.0       Merchandise Exports   Feb.   Jan.   Dec.        In billions    $33.5   $34.3   $33.3        Merchandise Imports        In billions    $38.8   $41.5   $39.6        Steel Production   April 12   April 5   March 29        Thousands of net tons, weekly total   1,604   1,595   1,581        Automobile Production   April 19   April 12   April 5        In units    110,952   98,678   92,362        Cash Wheat Price        No. 1 K.C. per bushel   $2.98   $3.03   $3.00

headline: Gasoline Up 2.15 Cents
abstract: Retail gasoline prices rose 2.15 cents a gallon during the last two weeks, according to an industry survey released today. The average price for all grades of gasoline at full- and self-service pumps on Friday, was 1.2492 a gallon, according to the Lundberg Survey of 13,000 stations nationwide. The price rise reflected the regular increase in demand that comes with the summer driving season, said Trilby Lundberg, an oil industry analyst. She said demand was likely to peak in July and August. On Friday the average price of regular unleaded was $1.1287 a gallon, including taxes, at self-serve stations. Premium unleaded was $1.2865, and regular leaded was $1.0714. At full-service stations, regular unleaded was $1.3951; premium unleaded was $1.5359, and regular leaded was $1.3648.

headline: Edsel Ford Becomes Finance Unit President
abstract: A familiar name was heard yesterday in the announcement of an important promotion at the Ford Motor Company.    Edsel B. Ford 2d, the 42-year-old son of the late Henry Ford 2d and the great-grandson of the company's founder, was named the president of the Ford Motor Credit Company, the financing arm of the nation's No. 2 auto maker.

headline: Accusations of Bias Tarnish a U.S. Army School
abstract: The United States Army Russian Institute trains military officers and civilian defense personnel to become Soviet affairs experts. The school has been called the Pentagon's crown jewel in tribute to the acknowledged quality of its program and the majestic beauty of its setting here in the Bavarian Alps.  But that reputation is being tarnished by friction between the institute's military administration and its teachers, most of whom are Soviet emigres and some of whom are Jewish. Some current and former faculty members and students say that the military command is prejudiced against Russians and Jews, and that this bias has shown up in psychological and sometimes physical intimidation.

headline: Bonn Names Pohl Successor
abstract: The Finance Ministry said today that Helmut Schlesinger, a vice president of the central bank, had been named to replace Karl Otto Pohl as the Bundesbank's chief.    The two have worked closely on German financial policy for years and Mr. Schlesinger is expected to continue the central bank's tight control on inflation.

headline: Thomson and Bull Get $1.1 Billion From France
abstract: To bolster France's beleaguered electronics industry, the French Government announced today that it was injecting a total of $1.1 billion into two large state-owned companies: Bull, the computer manufacturer, and Thomson, the military and consumer electronics company.    Saying that European electronics manufacturers are at a disadvantage in world competition because of their small size, France's Minister of Industry, Roger Fauroux, said the money was a down payment on the industrial policy he said Europe needed to preserve its electronics industry.

headline: The Media Business; New Daily Takes On Racing Form
abstract: After buying a copy of The Racing Times at a Manhattan newsstand, Ed Piesman, a dentist and an avid horse-racing fan, said he preferred the new paper to the venerable Daily Racing Form because "the columnists are much better" and some of the statistics "are much, much better."   But the news dealer who sold him the paper said people like Dr. Piesman were few. "The Racing Times, I sell two a day, maybe five when there is a big race," said Ashok Patel, whose stand at 72d Street and Broadway is adjacent to an off-track betting parlor. "The Daily Racing Form, I sell 40 or 50 a day."

headline: Retail Sales Data Viewed as Sign That Economic Decline Is Halting
abstract: Evidence mounted today that the economy has halted its slide and that the improvement already under way in housing may have begun to spread.   The Government revised its retail sales figures for March to show a rise of four-tenths of 1 percent instead of an eight-tenths drop and it said sales essentially held this gain in April.

headline: Boeing Agrees to Sell Its de Havilland Unit
abstract: The Boeing Company said today that it had agreed to sell its unprofitable de Havilland commuter aircraft division in Canada to Aeritalia S.p.A. of Italy and Aerospatiale S.A. of France.   De Havilland, which Boeing purchased from the Canadian Government in 1986, builds turboprop aircraft with 36 to 74 seats and is based in Downsview, Ontario. The buyers build the ATR-42 commuter plane, which competes most directly with de Havilland's Dash-8 commuter planes.

headline: Stocks Mixed as Dow Rises 7.83, to 3,035.33
abstract: Stock prices ended on a mixed note yesterday, with the blue chips extending their gains for the sixth straight day but the broader market moving lower.    Drug shares gave way as investors switched from growth stocks to cylical stocks in anticipation that the recession may soon be over.

headline: From Moscow to Leningrad, Russia's Timeless Heartland
abstract: To drive from Moscow to Leningrad in the springtime is to wander through the backroads of Russian history.    The high-rise boxes of Moscow give way quickly to a panorama of whimsically painted wooden huts listing in the mud, to a vast horizon of birches, fields and swollen rivers punctuated by the onion dome of a village church. Grizzled men still wield razor-sharp axes to shape raw logs and grannies wrapped in thick shawls tend goats by the roadside.

headline: Faith in British Justice Is Shaken by Forced Confessions and False Jailings
abstract: Noel R. Bell nervously clasped his hands together as he sat at a table with his parents in the visitors' center at Maghaberry Prison and talked about the confession, seven and a half years ago, that put him behind bars for life for a murder he says he had nothing to do with.   "I just told the police what I thought they wanted to hear," Mr. Bell, who is 27 years old, said in the accent of his native Armagh. "I was afraid they'd keep beating me until they got it. I was sure it would all be straightened out, like a joke. It sounds naive, doesn't it?"

headline: Boom in Mountain Bikes Revives the U.S. Industry
abstract: The easy-riding mountain bike -- a fat-wheeled bicycle devised for the dirt trails of California -- is sweeping the world in popularity and propelling American manufacturers to the front of the pack.    When many other American industries have been overtaken by foreign competition, bicyclists the world over now look to American companies like Trek, Specialized and Fat City for technical innovation and cachet.

headline: Qualex Chief's Strategy To Beat Photo 'Minilabs'
abstract: Although customers of photofinishing labs operated by Qualex Inc. usually wait 24 to 48 hours to get their photos, the company's new president is relatively unconcerned about the proliferation of laboratories that can process film in under an hour.   Peter D. Fitzgerald, who was named Qualex's president and chief executive yesterday, said the company had a strategy that can beat the one-hour laboratories, or "minilabs," at their own game.

headline: Hungarian Diplomat Ordered to Leave Post
abstract: Hungary's flamboyant Ambassador to United States has been given 48 hours to pack up and leave his post, the Foreign Ministry said today in a statement after a week of gossip-laden scandal at the top echelons of Hungarian diplomacy.   The Hungarian Government announced last week that the Ambassador, Peter Zwack, an emigre businessman named in September to head the embassy in Washington, would end his tour in July. But his departure was speeded after Mr. Zwack criticized Foreign Minister Geza Jeszenszky in accusations published this week in the Budapest press.

headline: Texaco Net Up 26.5% as Chevron Has 17.8% Gain
abstract: In a continuation of first-quarter profit gains among international oil companies, Texaco Inc. said today that net income rose 26.5 percent, and the Chevron Corporation reported a gain of 17.8 percent.    The Phillips Petroleum Company, with operations primarily in the United States, said net income fell 38.2 percent, but with the effects of non-operating transactions removed, earnings rose 39 percent.

headline: U.N. Plan Could Have Iraq Yield 25% of Oil Revenue
abstract: The United States and the four other permanent members of the Security Council have drawn up a plan under which Iraq could be compelled to pay 25 to 30 percent of its $20 billion annual oil revenue as reparations for the invasion and looting of Kuwait and as repayment of its debts to foreign governments.    Such a limit on reparations would mean that the most Iraq could be asked to pay in any year would be roughly equivalent to the $5 billion or so it spent annually buying foreign weapons before the Persian Gulf war. And the Security Council might set the payment at a lower level than the maximum. The total reparations to be demanded of Iraq could run as high as $50 billion.

headline: Advanced-TV Pact in Europe
abstract: The European Community and the Continent's television industry have tentatively agreed to develop a common strategy for high-definition television and an independent transmission standard, community officials said today.    A community official who insisted on anonymity said he hoped the agreement would end internal bickering over Europe's belated common approach to HDTV and would pave the way for a full agreement at a ministerial meeting on June 3.

headline: A.T.&T.'s Income Rises As GTE Posts a Decline
abstract: A.T.& T., the nation's largest long-distance carrier, reported a modest gain in its net income for the first quarter yesterday, while the GTE Corporation, the largest owner of local telephone companies, reported a sharp decline.   Taking into account special charges from acquisitions and divestitures, and looking at the companies as if they had been in their present forms a year ago, GTE actually did better than its larger rival. Analysts said the reports met expectations.

headline: Apache-Maxus
abstract: The The Apache Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to sell the majority of its natural gas properties in the Texas and Oklahoma panhandles to the Maxus Energy Corporation for $51 million. Apache said its share of the proceeds would be about $28 million and the rest would go to interests it represents. Apache said recent net production from the 300 wells involved has been averaging 25 milliion cubic feet of natural gas and 550 barrels of condensate a day. On Thursday, Apache said it would pay $546 million for domestic oil and gas properties of the Amoco Corporation situated mainly along the Gulf coast and in the Rocky Mountains.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * American Isuzu Motors Inc. has hired the consulting firms Morgan, Anderson & Co., New York, and the Canaan Parish Group, New Canaan, Conn., to assist in its search for a new agency on the creative portion of its national advertising account, which has reported billings of $75 million to $100 million. The previous agency, the Los Angeles office of Della Femina, McNamee, Los Angeles, was dismissed on May 9. * Ayer Inc. has signed a joint venture agreement that will bring $12 million in billings to its Detroit office. Brogan & Partners Advertising will leave its Southfield, Mich., offices next month and move in with Ayer. The two will consolidate services and facilities, though each will maintain separate management. The agencies said Brogan & Partners' clients include the Chevrolet division of General Motors and the K Mart Corporation.

headline: Newmark Tie To Ayer Is Brief
abstract: Less than a month after Newmark & Lewis, the consumer-electronics retail chain, awarded its $18 million advertising account to Ayer, the relationship has been terminated.   The retailer and the agency had "a verbal agreement and a handshake, but we never did get a written agreement," Jerry J. Siano, Ayer's chairman and chief executive, said late yesterday. Problems developed last week, Mr. Siano said, that indicated to him the chain no longer wanted the image-oriented creative work Ayer presented before landing the account on April 18.

headline: States Lead on Environment And Industries Complain
abstract: As a result of Federal inaction, many important environmental policies are being set at the state level, often to the dismay of the industries affected.    In response to the states' advocacy of environmental matters, some industries are rushing to Washington, seeking uniform Federal rules.    Maine, for instance, has banned the multilayer boxes that are used for children's drinks because they are not recyclable.    California enforces stiffer standards for auto emissions than most states, and last year Massachusetts required vehicles to meet the California standards.    And in 1988, seven Northeastern states required oil companies to lessen the volatility of gasoline in summer months, seeking to reduce the amount of smog-forming chemicals in the atmosphere.   The Northeastern states, which have the most severe trash disposal problems, may soon take the lead in measures to reduce the generation of solid waste. Once again, the lack of action at the Federal level is inducing state level initiatives.    "Over the past 10 years public opinion has become more supportive of the environment, and state officials have recognized it better than Federal officials," said Michael E. Kraft, a professor at the University of Wisconsin.    Students of government say the anti-regulation, free market orientation of the Reagan and Bush Administrations produced a power vacuum on some environmental issues.    "Most state officials would argue that these things should be done at the Federal level, but they are not getting done," said Richard Dennison, a scientist with the Environmental Defense Fund, a research and litigation group based in New York. "So you are going to have a lot of different approaches by the states, and you have to anticipate some failures along with successes."    Fearful of a crazy-quilt pattern of state regulations, the consumer products industry recently asked the Federal Trade Commission to issue guidelines on the use of labels that claim environmental benefits.    The industry's action was prompted by different sets of regulations adopted by New York, California and Rhode Island, and by a challenge from a group of state attorneys general to the claims of some manufacturers.    The trade commission agreed last week to hold hearings on the issue, although it may act without pre-empting state laws.  National Standards Sought     "Consumers, industry and state attorneys general want and need national environmental marketing guidelines," said John R. Cady, president of the National Association of Food Processors, which led the industry's appeal.    Without some Federal action, the industries' desire for uniformity could mean that a relatively few large states might set what amount to national standards. This appears to be the case with auto emissions, environmentalists and state officials say.    When Congress passed the Clean Air Act last year, it set new limits on emissions of hydrocarbons, carbon monoxide and oxides of nitrogen. As it has in the past, Congress permitted California to issue more demanding standards and allowed other states to adopt the stiffer California standards.    Previously, other states were content with the Federal standards, but last year Massachusetts imposed the California standards, while New York officials issued a rule requiring that cars meet the California standards starting with 1993 models and have begun another proceeding to embrace the stiffer rules California will begin in 1995.    Michael Bradley, executive director of Northeast States for Coordinated Air Use Management, a group of air-pollution officials, said as many as nine other states were considering adopting the California standards.    Officials and environmentalists say that if enough big states take this step, auto makers will be forced to improve the emissions performance of their cars across the board. "If Texas joins New York and California, that is critical mass," said Thomas C. Jorling, the head of New York's Department of Environmental Conservation. "And there is legislation pending now in Texas."  Auto Makers Fight Back     The Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association, which represents domestic auto makers, has filed suit in the state courts to block the New York action. "We have a lot of problems" with states regulating auto emissions, said Michael J. Stanton, the association's director of state relations.    "What if what works in California does not work in New York because of differences in climate or type of gasoline?" he asked rhetorically. "How would that be handled?"    Mr. Stanton said differing state requirements also caused problems for dealers. "If a dealer is in a Federal state, he could not sell across the state line if the next one had California rules," he said.    In some cases, action by states has led to tougher Federal standards. After seven of the eight Northeastern states changed the rules on gasoline volatility in 1988, the Environmental Protection Agency in 1989 adopted stiffer standards that will be fully effective in 1992.    Largely because of Reagan-era budget cuts, the E.P.A. has not addressed solid-waste problems other than to propose technical standards for landfills. And while the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, which could address the problems of trash disposal, is due for revision in Congress, officials of environmental and industry groups say they expect little change soon.    So the Northeastern states may well take the lead by issuing rules to mandate recycling or to ban items like yard waste from landfills.    The states have already influenced national policy on toxic elements in packaging. The Coalition of Northeast Governors, comprising the Governors of the six New England States plus those of New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, drafted model legislation in 1989 limiting the amounts of four toxic heavy metals in packaging, largely in printing inks. The legislation was adopted by six states in the region, as well as Iowa and Wisconsin.  Printing Ink Ingredients     Paul Volpe, technical director of the National Association of Printing Ink Manufacturers, said most producers were moving to comply with the rules regardless of their location. "This has gone beyond the Northeast," he said.    Now the coalition is trying to unite state officials, environmentalists and industry representatives in a group called the Source Reduction Council to find ways of reducing the amount of packaging waste that goes to landfills. Packaging is coming in for special attention because it accounts for as much as one-third of all trash by weight and half by volume.    The group came up with a list of principles for preferred packaging, like small size and materials that can be recycled. But the negotiations bogged down on details of how to accomplish these goals, and late last year the environmental groups walked out.  11 States Weigh Action     Environmentalists and consumer advocates are backing legislation to ban packaging made of materials that cannot be recycled and re-used to reduce the amount of trash generated. According to the Environmental Action Foundation, a Washington-based environmental group, legislation to encourage recycling and reduce packaging waste is scheduled to be introduced in 11 states this year, including New York and New Jersey.    "In the absence of Federal leadership, these 11 states are putting the packaging industry on notice that it is time to change," said Jeanne Wirka, a solid-waste specialist with the organization.    The legislation is based on a proposal that was forced off the ballot in Massachusetts last year as a result of a challenge by a group of business interests. A similar proposal in Oregon was defeated.    In general, the bills would ban packaging by the mid-1990's that could not be re-used at least five times or that did not contain a certain level of recycled material.  Effort Called Simplistic     Jeffrey Nedelman, a vice president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, said industry would oppose the bills as an overly simplistic attempt to solve the trash disposal problem. "Single-shot actions like bans and taxes do not accomplish the goal," he said. "There are no silver bullets to kill the werewolf of solid waste."    Robert Ruddock, a vice president of Associated Industries of Massachusetts, said his group, which stopped the ballot initiative last year, would fight the measure in the Legislature. "Recycling is a three-legged stool: collection, processing and marketing," he said. "They would leap all the way to marketing and force a ban on packaging that does not meet their politically correct standards."   Nevertheless, some state officials expect packaging and other environmental legislation to succeed.
