"I think we will see action on packaging reduction, fugitive emissions and incinerator standards," Mr. Jorling said. "National policy will evolve, but not in the most efficient way."

headline: Silicon Graphics In Diasonics Deal
abstract: Diasonics Inc., a maker of medical imaging equipment, and Silicon Graphics Inc., a computer graphics company, agreed to jointly develop medical imaging systems. Under the accord, Diasonics, based in South San Francisco, Calif., will incorporate Silicon Graphics' technology into its development process and its imaging and other products.   The companies said the alliance was a result of parallel developments in the medical imaging and technical work station markets. Silicon Graphics provides three-dimensional graphics, color and motion technologies for medical imaging. In trading on the American Stock Exchange today, Diasonics shares rose 6.25 cents, closing at $4.1875. Silicon Graphics rose 50 cents, to $32.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: MONDAY: The Senate Banking Committee considers the nomination of Lawrence Lindsey to Federal Reserve Board. * Deadline for HBJ bondholders to tender to General Cinema.

headline: Iran's Oil Output Goal
abstract: Iran is likely to fall short of its target of expanding oil production to five million barrels a day by 1993, the Middle East Economic Survey said on Monday. The weekly's editor, Ian Seymour, quoted offcials at the National Iranian Oil Company as saying that the level of sustainable production by then would more likely be about 4.6 million barrels a day.

headline: Jury Fines Peat on Audit
abstract: The accounting firm of KPMG Peat Marwick has been fined $3 million by a jury for failing to uncover in an audit the bad business practices of a defunct real estate syndicator.   Two Illinois investors who put $1 million into the failed Oklahoma real estate company, Pepco, were awarded $1 million in actual damages and $2 million in punitive damages by a Federal District Court jury late last week, the investors' lawyer, Michael Freed, said.

headline: Xoma Drug Called Closer to Approval
abstract: The Xoma Corporation, a biotechnology company based in Berkeley, Calif., said that an advisory panel of the Food and Drug Administration had recommended approval of the company's drug for treating a potentially fatal complication of bone-marrow transfers.    The drug, Orthozyme-CD5+, is the first of a type called immunoconjugates to be recommended for approval, Xoma said. Such drugs use monoclonal antibodies, highly specific replicas of the immune system's main defense agents, as targeting agents for drugs that treat the disease. While the bone-marrow complication affects only about 2,000 patients a year, approval of the drug opens the door to other immunoconjugates for more common diseases. If Xoma wins F.D.A. approval, Ortho Biotech, a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson, would market the drug.

headline: In the Turkish Mountains, U.S. Hears an Echo: 'Lead Us to Dohuk'
abstract: Dohuk is important to Lazden Doski and about 90 percent of the 40,000 other refugees camped in the slopes and valleys of southeastern Turkey. It is their former home, lying just south of the security zone carved out of northern Iraq by American, British, French and other Western troops.    Now the refugees are trying to convince the Western troops that they must take the provincial Kurdish capital, then stay and protect the Kurds from the wrath of Saddam Hussein.

headline: Study of British Stockholders
abstract: The Conservative Government of Britain has had limited success in promoting a nation of stockholders. Although the number of Britons owning stock has nearly quadrupled since 1979, to 11.1 million people, or 25 percent of the adult population, the portion of shares owned by individuals has fallen steadily in recent years.   Individuals own 21 percent of all outstanding shares today, down from 28 percent in 1981, according to the London Stock Exchange.

headline: Japan to Ease Insurers' Bar
abstract: Japan is moving to let life and non-life insurers enter each other's core businesses as part of its program of financial deregulation, Ministry of Finance officials said today.    They added that discussions on whether to let insurers enter the securities and banking industries had stagnated. The Finance Ministry is reviewing the insurance business for possible revision for the first time since 1940. Insurance concerns want to be able to underwrite corporate bonds, execute customer orders for government and other bonds, and engage in trust banking and foreign exchange.

headline: Armstrong Suit Raises Questions
abstract: SINCE the news broke late Friday that a jury had awarded a small Paramus, N.J., company $246 million in damages against Armstrong World Industries, Armstrong's stock has fallen sharply. On Monday, it was down $2.375, to $27.25. By yesterday's close, it had slipped a bit more, to $26.875, off 25 cents for the day. That put it nearly 30 percent off its 52-week high of $37.875.    "There was tremendous pressure on the stock," said Gregory Nejmah, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers. "There is an uncertainty that exists that did not exist before." Last year, Armstrong earned $141 million, on sales of $2.5 billion. Thus a $246 million verdict, should it be upheld on appeal, would be a significant blow to the Lancaster, Pa., building-products company.

headline: A Soldier for Every Resident in Falklands
abstract: Nine years after the Falkland war with Argentina, Britain continues to maintain a garrison of about 2,000 troops on the remote, windswept islands -- nearly one soldier or sailor for each of the 2,121 year-round residents.    British officials say the presence of the troops is one measure of Britain's continuing commitment to keep the British flag flying over the Falklands, which are regarded as a British Dependent Territory.

headline: Waterford by Another Price; Will It Sell More Sweetly?
abstract: Perched on a linen tablecloth, next to expensive china and gleaming silver, Waterford Crystal has long been a symbol of the life of the well to do.    But Waterford is about to step out of character and introduce a more moderate line of glassware aimed at a less well-heeled audience. In August, it will bring out nine patterns of stemware priced from $29 to $37.50 a glass, and 40 other gift items that, for Waterford, are moderately priced. Waterford's traditional prices range from $50 to more than $100 a glass.

headline: Legal Scholars Debate Refugee Plan, Generally Backing U.S. Stand
abstract: The Bush Administration's legal justification for using armed forces to establish sanctuary sites for Kurdish refugees on Iraqi soil has generally won support from international legal scholars, although some questions have been raised about the United States' acting on its own.   Administration officials have said that a Security Council resolution enacted this month provides specific authority for the relief operation. They put forward the defense after Javier Perez de Cuellar, the United Nations Secretary General, questioned whether the United States could lawfully intervene in Iraq without new and explicit authority from the Security Council.

headline: Mass Graves Linked to Colombia Rebels
abstract: Soldiers searching a former guerrilla mountain headquarters have uncovered mass graves estimated to contain about 400 bodies, army officers say.    Army officials say deserters from the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia led them to the site, which the guerrilla army had used for internal trials and executions.

headline: Survey Looks At Recession
abstract: Most members of a prominent business economists' association believe the recession will end soon, followed by a slower-than-usual recovery, a survey found.    "Sixty percent of the respondents to the May survey believe that the recession will end in the second quarter, while another 27 percent place the trough in the third period," the National Association of Business Economists said in the survey, released Thursday.

headline: Algerians Campaign In an Election to End Single-Party System
abstract: Campaigning opened today for Algeria's first multiparty parliamentary election in 29 years in an atmosphere dominated by uncertainty over whether fundamentalists would participate or take to the streets to pursue their demands for an Islamic state.   Candidates from the ruling National Liberation Front began wooing voters in their constituencies. But the main opposition, the Islamic Salvation Front, left in doubt whether it would take part in the general election.

headline: New Reports Say 1980 Reagan Campaign Tried to Delay Hostage Release
abstract: Persistent but unproven accusations that Ronald Reagan's 1980 presidential campaign negotiated a secret deal with Iran to prevent the release of American hostages until after the election are being revived this week with fresh accounts of meetings between campaign officials and an Iranian cleric.   One of the accounts is provided by Gary Sick, a Middle East specialist who helped handle the Iranian hostage crisis as a member of the White House staff in the Carter Administration. Mr. Sick, in an article published Monday on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times, says he has heard what he considers to be reliable reports that a secret deal involving the hostages was begun during two meetings between William J. Casey and the Iranian cleric in a Madrid hotel in July 1980.

headline: Quakes Strike 3 Areas Within Half an Hour
abstract: Three earthquakes occurring in a span of 22 minutes shook three widely separated areas of the world yesterday in what scientists said was a coincidence but not a cause for alarm. No deaths or damage were immediately reported.    The first struck the Caucasus mountains in Soviet Georgia, about 100 miles northwest of the city of Tbilisi, at 8:59 P.M. Eastern standard time, or 6 A.M. local time, said John Minsch, a geophysicist with the National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo. It measured 6.3 on the Richter Scale and was an aftershock to an earthquake that caused massive damage and more than 80 deaths in that region on April 29, Mr. Minsch said.

headline: Top Shearson Official To Join Smith Barney
abstract: The top ranks of two Wall Street firms shifted yesterday, when Robert Druskin, the chief financial officer of Shearson Lehman Brothers, agreed to join Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. He will take on the titles of senior executive vice president and co-chief administrative officer at Smith Barney.    Mr. Druskin, 44 years old, joined one of Shearson's predecessor firms, Shearson Hamill & Company, in the management training program in 1969. He became chief financial officer in 1984.

headline: Lawsuit Gain Aids Manville
abstract: The Manville Corporation reported yesterday that it netted $35 million, or 26 cents a share, in the first quarter, up 41 percent from $24.9 million, or 18 cents a share, a year ago. But a one-time, $40 million gain from settlement of a patent infringement lawsuit accounted for all of its profits.   Operating income fell nearly 37 percent, to $41.6 million from $65.5 million a year ago. Revenues fell 4.3 percent, to $495.7 million for the quarter, compared with nearly $518 million a year ago.

headline: A.I.D. Is Criticized on Population Control
abstract: The Agency for International Development, a primary force in shaping the world's favorable attitude toward population control, is now in disarray on population matters, a private organization says in a new report.    The group, the Population Crisis Committee, said in a report issued Sunday that "over the past decade the U.S. population assistance program has been battered by ideological controversies and constrained by the creeping bureacratization which now characterizes most U.S. foreign aid efforts."

headline: Banking Overhaul Bill Clears a Big Hurdle
abstract: The Bush Administration's plan to free the banking industry of decades-old restrictions cleared a significant hurdle today when a Congressional panel unanimously voted to send it to the House Banking Committee, suggesting that it might be politically possible to reshape the banking industry this year.    The Administration contends that the changes it proposes would help both the economy and the ailing industry by permitting banks to diversify into other businesses and to expand across state lines.

headline: Philip Morris Is Criticized
abstract: Three health groups criticized the Philip Morris Companies today for marketing low-nicotine cigarettes, which they said would mislead smokers into believing these brands were safer and less addictive than other cigarettes.    The American Heart Association, the American Lung Association and the American Cancer Society said they were trying to stop the nationwide marketing of Next and Benson and Hedges De-Nic. Philip Morris has been test-marketing the two brands in several states since 1989, and is now selling the cigarettes in Tampa, Fla., and Phoenix.

headline: P.& G. Shifts Executives
abstract: The Procter & Gamble Company, the giant consumer products concern, said that it would announce high-level management changes today.   Under a realignment of the company's United States operations, B. Jurgen Hintz has resigned as executive vice president for paper, food and beverage products, the company said, and has also resigned his board seat. Mr. Hintz, who is 49 years old, will continue to serve with the company for a short period on special assignment to Edwin L. Artz, the chairman and chief executive.

headline: New Tandy Stores To Sell Discount PC's
abstract: The Tandy Corporation said today that it planned to enter the discount computer retailing market by opening six superstores this year and as many as 15 annually for the next few years.    The new chain, which Tandy is calling Computer City, will be the first computer discounter to sell models made by the largest American manufacturers in the personal computer industry: I.B.M., Apple and Compaq, as well as Tandy's own line.

headline: Detroit Strives to Reclaim Lost Generation of Buyers
abstract: When Sue Anderson passed her driver's exam 10 years ago, she inherited the family Mazda. After graduation from college, she bought her family's Saab. Last year, the 26-year-old graphic designer from Grand Rapids, Mich., bought her first new car. It was a 1990 Mitsubishi Eclipse.    "I never really considered buying an American car, which is not to say I wouldn't," said Ms. Anderson, who aspires to buy another Saab. "I guess buying a foreign car has been kind of ingrained in me."  Foreign Cars Favored     Ms. Anderson is part of the auto industry's "lost generation." A new wave of young drivers are shopping for their first new cars and trucks, and their biases spell deep trouble for the American auto industry. In large part, they are the children of the drivers who first traded their Fords, Dodges and Chevrolets in the 1970's for Hondas, Toyotas and BMW's. As they were growing up, their family cars were typically foreign makes, and they knew mostly horror stories about Detroit's products. Shaped by their parents' tastes, these young adults rarely set foot in the Big Three's car dealerships.

headline: Market Place; Precedents in Rules for Extended Trading
abstract: In offering two radically different after-hours trading sessions, the New York Stock Exchange is seeking to lure traders back by compromising in two key areas -- public disclosure of trading and the cost to the brokers.   By eliminating the cost of trades in the special sessions and by disclosing only the sketchiest of information about those trades, the Big Board hopes to recapture specialized business that has moved over the years to London. But the result could be a shift in some business that would normally have been conducted at the exchange during normal trading hours and for normal fees.

headline: Dow Falls 37.57 Following a Drop in Bonds
abstract: Stocks plunged yesterday in sympathy with a sharply depressed bond market.    Bond dealers said they were still trying to work off a big backlog of long-term bonds left over from last week's $37 billion Treasury refinancing. Others warned that the Treasury would soon be back looking for more money -- a move expected to depress stock prices further.

headline: U.S. Clarifies Summit Conditions
abstract: A White House spokesman said today that President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev could hold a summit meeting without prior agreement on a treaty to limit nuclear weapons.   At a press briefing today, the spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said, "We wouldn't tie specific conditions to a summit."

headline: New USX Stock To Begin Trading
abstract: The USX Corporation said that the stock representing its newly created steel company would begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Friday on a "when issued" basis. Under its plan to split its energy and steel holdings, which is set for a shareholder vote on May 6, USX will create two New York Stock Exchange stocks: one that reflects its Marathon Oil energy business and one that reflects the value of its steel, mining, real estate and other ventures.    Initially, USX would pay a $1.40-a-share annual dividend on the Marathon stock and 20 cents a share on the steel stock. USX currently pays a $1.40 annual dividend. USX said the plan would increase the number of authorized shares, with 550 million being Marathon stock and 200 million being steel stock. USX shares closed at $33 each today, up 12.5 cents on the Big Board.

headline: Creditors React to Offer By Retailers
abstract: Merchandise creditors of Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores reacted with general approval yesterday to the companies' reorganization plan because they would get the biggest share -- about $513 million -- of the $850 million in cash to be offered.    But they said that many problems in the plan, which was filed on Monday, must be resolved before they could give formal consent. A Federal judge cannot allow Federated and Allied to emerge from voluntary bankruptcy until at least 50 percent of each class of creditor, representing at least two-thirds of the class's debt, has approved the plan.

headline: A Roar, Then Blackness: 'I Have Lost Everything'
abstract: Mufizur Rahman said that before he blacked out, he saw waves "as high as mountains" sweep toward his village with a powerful roar.   When he regained consciousness hours later, he said, his wife, son and three daughters had been swept away. There was little left of the small coastal village where his forefathers had settled. 'I Have Lost Everything'    "I have lost everything. I have lost everything. God, why has it happened to me?" Mr. Rahman repeated over and over, sobbing helplessly.

headline: 65% Profit Rise for Microsoft
abstract: Despite a slump by many companies in the personal computer business, the Microsoft Corporation reported on Tuesday that it had a 65 percent increase in profit on a 57 percent increase in revenue.   For its third quarter ended March 31, Microsoft had net income of $123.8 million, or 98 cents a share, up from $75.2 million, or 62 cents, for the comparable period a year earlier. Sales rose to $486.9 million, from $310.9 million. Per-share figures reflect a 4 percent increase in shares outstanding, to 126.3 million.

headline: Safeway Offering Of Common Stock
abstract: Safeway Inc. is offering about $350 million in common stock through an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company as part of a previously announced capital exependiture plan.   The offering of 17.5 million shares of common was priced at $20.50 a share, with proceeds from the sale used to help finance Safeway's plans to spend about $3.2 billion for capital expenditures, including lease obligations, running from 1990 through 1994, according to the company.

headline: Stocks Gain in Tokyo
abstract: Stock prices rose today in Tokyo. The Nikkei index of 225 issues ended the week at 25,701.94, up 181.67 points, or about seven-tenths of 1 percent. For the week, it fell 572.35, or about 2.2 percent.

headline: U.N. Commander Is 'Confident'
abstract: The commander of the United Nations peacekeeping force at the Iraqi-Kuwaiti border said today that he was confident that the refugees in the buffer zone were safe and that Baghdad would cooperate in solving the problem.   But the commander, Maj. Gen. Gunther Greindl, did not say when the 1,400 peacekeepers would relieve United States troops helping to protect and feed the estimated 40,000 refugees who have fled to the buffer zone in fear of President Saddam Hussein's army.

headline: Plan to Raise Foreign Cash For Airlines
abstract: The Bush Administration will seek legislation to allow foreigners to own up to 49 percent of the voting stock of United States airlines, Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said today. The proposal is intended to attract foreign capital to shore up the troubled American industry.   In January, Mr. Skinner decided to allow foreign carriers to buy up to 49 percent of the equity of American airlines, but a 25 percent limit remained on voting rights. He said today that the change had proved insufficient to attract as much foreign capital as the airlines need.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Economy    Payroll jobs fell in April, but at a much reduced pace, the Labor Department said, and the unemployment rate edged down 0.2 point, to 6.6 percent. Over all, analysts said, the figures point to an economy that seems to be approaching its low point, while probably not yet starting to recover from recession.  But they cautioned that the decline in the unemployment rate, the first in almost a year, was probably an aberration.  [ Page 1. ]

headline: European Group Pressing Its Offer for Executive Life
abstract: A day after California regulators seized the Executive Life Insurance Company, a European consortium pressed ahead today with its offer to acquire the troubled insurer while policyholders and other customers tried to assess their risk of losses.    The offer is "still in the discussion stage" with the regulators, according to Robert Guenther, a spokesman for Altus Finance, the investment arm of Credit Lyonnais, the French banking company, which is leading the consortium. "We've presented a definitive plan for the rehabilitation of Executive Life," Mr. Guenther said. "We hope we're able to reach some kind of agreement."

headline: 42 KILLED IN JAPAN IN TRAIN COLLISION
abstract: A crowded tourist train slammed head-on into a local train on Tuesday in western Japan, killing 42 people and injuring 415 others in the nation's deadliest railway accident in 28 years.   The last body trapped in the crushed train cars was removed early today after 14 hours of rescue work following the collision at Shigaraki, 230 miles west of Tokyo, the police said.

headline: People
abstract: * Bob Sauer has been promoted to executive vice president and creative director at Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson Inc., New York, from senior vice president and creative director. * Dane Solomon has been named director of account services at Henszey & Albert, New York. He had previously held the same position at Kirshenbaum & Bond, New York.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Jel Sert Co., Chicago, manufacturers of Fla-Vor-Ice and Pop-Ice frozen bars, to the Chicago office of BBDO. Billings are more than $1 million.

headline: MGM-Pathe Faces Filing By Creditors
abstract: A group of creditors has increased the financial pressure on the MGM-Pathe Communications Company by filing a petition seeking to force the company into involuntary bankruptcy.   The group, which includes entertainment production companies, claimed in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Los Angeles on Friday that the Hollywood studio owed it as much as $20 million.

headline: Slow Progress Frustrates All Involved as Oil Wells Burn at $1,000 a Second
abstract: Nearly two months after the Iraqi Army blew up more than 500 oil wells, firefighters have extinguished and capped about 54, a painstakingly slow start that is straining relations between Kuwait and the firefighters, mostly Americans.    The frustration of the Kuwaitis is evident as oil burns at a rate of more than $1,000 a second. A large well here dumps enough oil each hour to send a car 2.5 million miles. Kuwait is burning almost as many gallons of oil each day as the United States consumes of gasoline. The fires have cast a pall over most of the country and sent soot as far as the Himalayas.

headline: Dow Rises to High Of 3,027.50
abstract: Propelled by solid signs of a reviving economy, stocks rose strongly yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average sprinting past the record it set six weeks ago.    The Dow, which hit its previous high of 3,004.46 on April 17, closed at 3,027.50, up 27.05 points for the day and 113.59 for the week. The 3.9 percent weekly rise was the largest in more than four months.

headline: Saudi General Has Kinship for 'Norm'
abstract: The first thing Prince Khaled bin Sultan did after being appointed joint commander of the anti-Iraqi coalition forces was to transfer the gym equipment at his farm to his office at the Defense Ministry. He vowed to exercise four times a week, war or peace.   Then the Persian Gulf war began, and despite countless push-ups, deep-knee bends and chest presses, he gained weight. So did his co-commander and American friend, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf.

headline: Vice President Quits Shearson
abstract: Melvin B. Taub will join Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company as executive vice president of operations and systems groups at the end of the month, the Wall Street investment house announced yesterday.    Mr. Taub, who has worked on Wall Street for 27 years, is currently executive vice president and director of securities and commodities operations at Shearson Lehman Brothers, a unit of the American Express Company.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt * New England Telephone and Telegraph Co., Boston, a Nynex Corporation subsidiary, has filed wiith the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $350 million in debt securities.

headline: A New Palestinian Flexibility Is Seen
abstract: In this wretchedly poor, violently militant town and its adjacent refugee district, a palpable sense of despair and apathy has settled over Palestinians who once clung to great hopes for their future.    But incongruously, in their present desperation, Arabs here and throughout the occupied territories are becoming more flexible about making peace with Israel.

headline: MCI Profit Down 20.6% In Quarter
abstract: Citing the recession and competitive pressures, the MCI Communications Corporation said yesterday that net income in the first quarter of 1991 fell 20.6 percent, to $130 million, from $163 million in the 1990 quarter, despite strong revenue growth.    Revenues in the quarter were $2.03 billion, up 12.2 percent from $1.81 billion a year ago.

headline: Rig Count Up in Week
abstract: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the nation jumped by 26 last week, but still trailed figures from last year, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. The oilfield tool maker said 850 rigs were operating nationally, 141 less than a year earlier. The previous week's count was 824. Of the rigs working, 344 were seeking gas, 463 oil and 43 others were listed as miscellaneous. The count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for petroleum and natural gas, not those producing oil and gas.

headline: Zhulebino Journal; A Village Turns Tough, Not Wanting to Be Eaten
abstract: A black-and-white official sign marks the beginning of this small village, a cluster of wooden houses with carved shutters and people working away in gardens of tomatoes and onions.   But if the authorities have their way, the sign noting the edge of Moscow will be moved a few miles east and Zhulebino will suddenly be like so many anonymous neighborhoods on the farthest reaches of the capital metropolis, its homes and orchards replaced by the huge concrete apartment blocks that oppress the city's soul.

headline: TBS Airport Channel Set
abstract: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. announced plans today for the Airport Channel, which will provide live newscasts and consumer and travel reports to the nation's airports.   A six-week pilot program to test the channel will begin in June in three of the nation's largest airports -- Atlanta, Chicago and Dallas -- Turner said.

headline: Ciba-Geigy Stake In Vaccine Maker
abstract: Ciba-Geigy Ltd. agreed to acquire a majority interest in the vaccine business of Sclavo S.p.A. of Italy for undisclosed terms. The Chiron Corporation, Ciba-Geigy's partner since 1987 in the Biocene Company, a venture to commercialize new vaccines, also has rights to acquire an equal interest in Sclavo from Ciba-Geigy, which has options to acquire up to 100 percent of the company over 10 years.    Chiron said it expected that its initial investment could be $25 million to $30 million in cash, and that it might be required to provide more money to the Sclavo vaccine business. Sclavo, a private company controlled by the financier Guelfo Marcucci, markets vaccines in Europe. Chiron, based in Emeryville, Calif., and Ciba, based in Switzerland, expect Biocene to introduce its first commercial vaccine products in the mid-1990's.

headline: Mitsubishi-Volvo
abstract: The Mitsubishi Motor Corporation of Japan will buy a one-third stake in the Dutch car maker Volvo B.V., a Dutch newspaper reported. Under the terms of the agreement, reported in Het Financieele Dagblad, the Dutch state will reduce its current stake from 70 percent to one-third to lift Swedish Volvo's current 30 percent share to a third and free up a third for purchase by Mitsubishi. In addition, Volvo B.V. will increase its production to 220,000 vehicles a year from the current 150,000. Spokesmen for Volvo A.B. in Sweden, Volvo B.V. of the Netherlands and Mitsubishi declined to comment on the report.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Companies    America West said it would cut most of its full coach fares by an average of almost 40 percent. The cuts will bring down the cost of business travel on many major routes.  [ Page D1. ]

headline: Stocks Rose Broadly in Quarter
abstract: The stock market just completed one of its strongest quarters since 1980. Investors, who stood on the sidelines after Iraq invaded Kuwait, gleefully dived back into the equity markets in the first quarter, which ended last week, after the American-led assault in the gulf seemed a success.   "This was the fourth-best quarter in the last 11 years," said Laszlo Birinyi Jr., president of the Wall Street research house Birinyi Associates. "Given the kind of breadth, momentum and other indicators we have seen, you are not talking about a short-term or trading rally -- you are talking about a sustained market rise."

headline: Eagle-Picher Has $2.3 Million Loss
abstract: Eagle-Picher Industries said it lost $2.3 million in the second quarter, partly because of costs associated with its bankruptcy reorganization. The maker of automotive and industrial parts also blamed the depressed economy.   Eagle-Picher said its loss came on revenues of $154.9 million in the period from April through June. In the corresponding period last year, the company earned $22.5 million, or $2.11 a share, on revenues of $184.3 million. Eagle-Picher, which filed for reorganzation under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in January, has been hit by lawsuits filed by people who say their health was damage by exposure to a pipe sealant the company made for ships from 1931 to 1974. The sealant contained asbestos.

headline: Top Position Is Filled At World Color Press
abstract: Robert G. Burton, who for a short time was a professional football player, has been named chairman, president and chief executive of World Color Press Inc., which claims the distinction of being the nation's largest printer of consumer magazines.   Mr. Burton, who is 53 years old, takes over the top post on May 1, after 10 years as president of AC Publishing, a subsidiary of Capital Cities/ ABC Inc. In those years, he said, ABC Publishing posted record earnings every year but one.

headline: Computer Said to Be The Fastest
abstract: Thinking Machines Inc. said today that it was reclaiming its title as maker of the world's fastest supercomputer by introducing a machine that as many as 100 scientists or engineers could use simultaneously.   The Thinking Machines CM-200 supercomputer is almost twice as fast as the company's previous model, the CM-2, which once held the speed record. And the new machine is slightly faster than an Intel Corporation supercomputer that was installed last week at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif.

headline: Cable Concern Bows to Suits
abstract: Tele-Communications Inc. agreed today to drop its plan to charge cable-television customers for a new channel unless they cancel it.   Under the original "negative option" billing plan, all Tele- Communications customers were to receive the channel and be billed $1 to $4.95 a month for it unless they canceled the service.

headline: Market Place; Trends Expected To Aid Brinker
abstract: STOCKS of restaurant companies with casual themes and varied moderate-priced menus have lit up Wall Street this year, rising in market value as a group by nearly 50 percent.    The group is prospering despite the recession because of the bulging numbers of aging adults and families with school-age children who often favor more leisurely full-service meals over quick trips to a McDonald's or Burger King.

headline: Iraq Delivers Food to Shiites And Kurds Returning to Iraq
abstract: Iraq is distributing bread and powdered milk to Kurds and Shiite Muslims returning to their provinces, and has sufficient food stocks for all refugees, an official said in a report published today.   Trade Minister Mohammed Mehdi Saleh said trucks loaded with wheat flour and other food leave Baghdad daily for northern and southern Iraq, where loyalist forces violently repressed a rebellion last week.

headline: Busch Theme Park Unit Names 3 to Top Posts
abstract: The Anheuser-Busch Companies, whose theme park business has been hurt by the recession, yesterday named the No. 2 executive at its theme park unit as president and made two other executives officers of the subsidiary.   John B. Roberts, formerly executive vice president and general manager of the Busch Entertainment Corporation, was named its president, effective immediately. Busch is the nation's second-largest operator of theme parks after the Walt Disney Company. Its nine parks include Sea World parks in Florida, Texas, California and Ohio, as well as Busch Gardens in Tampa, Fla., and Williamsburg, Va.

headline: Yield at 8.312% on Offering By MBNA Credit Card Trust
abstract: MBNA Credit Card Trust 1991-A, a unit of the MBNA Corporation, is offering $750 million in securities backed by Visa and Mastercard receivables through underwriters led by J. P. Morgan Securities.    The 8 1/4 percent securities were priced at 99 30/32 to yield 8.312 percent, or about 86 basis points more than the combination of yield on three-year and five-year Treasury securities. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

headline: Philips Stake To Whirlpool
abstract: Philips N.V., the troubled Dutch electronics giant, said today that it would sell its remaining stake in its home-appliance manufacturing venture with the Whirlpool Corporation. Philips will receive about $600 million from Whirlpool.   "We believe that transferring these activities to a company that is fully dedicated to this business is the best guarantee for long-term growth and success," said Jan Timmer, the president of Philips, in a statement issued by the two companies. "The proceeds of this transaction will enable Philips to strengthen its financial position."

headline: Consarc Gets Big Award Against Iraq
abstract: A Federal judge awarded a $64 million default judgment against Iraq today to an American company whose sale of industrial furnaces to Iraq was blocked by President Bush.    The judge, Stanley Sporkin of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, awarded the judgment to the Consarc Corporation, whose sale of industrial furnaces built to Iraqi specifications was blocked last July. The action came after the Defense Department learned that the furnaces were to be used to develop nuclear weapons rather than to make prosthetic devices for Iraqi war veterans, as the Iraqi Government had said.

headline: Lonrho Allowed To Pursue Fight
abstract: The British conglomerate Lonrho P.L.C. can proceed with a court battle against the Fayed brothers of Egypt over their 1985 takeover of the London department store Harrods, the House of Lords ruled. The Lords decided that Lonrho's accusations -- wrongful business interference and conspiracy -- against the Fayeds and their adviser, the investment bank Kleinwort Benson Group, must be answered in court.

headline: Armco to Cut Jobs At Offices and Mills
abstract: Armco Inc. said it was cutting 70 corporate positions from its offices in Middletown, Ohio. The company also said that a few of its Middletown corporate functions would be consolidated and moved to Armco's New Jersey headquarters, but that the majority would be folded into the Armco Advanced Materials division in Butler, Pa.    The company also said that its Armco Steel Company joint venture with Japan's Kawasaki Steel Corporation would cut salaried positions by 13 percent over the next 12 months. About 300 of Armco Steel's 2,200 salaried employees will lose their jobs.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   10.00        DISCOUNT RATE   5.50   5.50   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.59   5.69   8.31        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.39   5.39   7.75        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.61   5.62   7.75        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   7.93   7.93   8.70        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   8.29   8.29   8.66        TELEPHONE BONDS   9.30   9.30   9.74        MUNICIPAL BONDS**   7.23   7.22   7.54       *Estimated daily average, source Salomon Brothers **Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: AMR Wary On Quarter
abstract: American Airlines, the nation's largest carrier, said today that its second-quarter net income would come in below most Wall Street estimates, suggesting that the airline industry's problems continue.   The stock of the AMR Corporation, American's parent, fell $1.875, to $61.375, on the news, along with stocks of other airlines. Analysts said the Dallas-based airline sent them its latest results and projections and cautioned that many of their earnings estimates were too high.

headline: Colorado Studies United Air Aid
abstract: The Colorado Attorney General is examining a $150 million incentive package the State Legislature is offering United Airlines to build a maintenance operation in Denver, Gov. Roy Romer said. The Governor said he might also ask the Colorado Supreme Court to examine the constitutionality of the package. The state's borrowing costs would be lower if the bond market can be assured the incentive package can pass constitutional muster.   Part of the incentive plan calls for Colorado to float a bond issue to raise as much as $115 million to pay United for up to three years. Another $33 million in state tax breaks is also available under the measure. The Denver City Council is also pushing a plan to give the carrier, a unit of the UAL Corporation, $175 million in city tax breaks if it brings the operation here. It is expected to create at least 6,500 jobs.

headline: KURDS BEGIN MOVE OUT OF MOUNTAINS TO AN ALLIED ZONE
abstract: Kurdish refugees slowly began moving down from the mountains today as allied troops took effective control of this northern town with the final pullout of several hundred armed Iraqis.    But there was a new complication in the United States' plan to resettle the Kurds in an encampment near here. Kurdish rebels re-emerged from mountain hideouts and sought to discourage refugees from returning, saying they were not convinced that the proposed safe zone in northern Iraq was free of Iraqi forces.

headline: Iran's Leader Asks for More Aid to Sustain Kurds
abstract: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran arrived here today and appealed for more foreign aid to help his country look after Iraqi refugees.   "The Iranian Government hosts over a million people who have no shelter," President Rafsanjani said in Damascus, where he is paying a state visit. "Thousands of them are Kurds who walked through rugged mountains and valleys to take refuge in Iran."

headline: Award in G.E. Age Case
abstract: A Wayne County jury awarded $1 million to a former salesman for the General Electric Company who sued the company and a G.E. joint venture on age discrimination charges, his lawyers said today. Richard N. Pietsch, 58 years old, also accused the companies of breach of employment contract and of failing to abide by promises made to him when G.E. hired him in 1981. The award could benefit other employees whose jobs have been lost or are threatened under "reorganization," "reduction in force" or other actions cited by their employers, the statement said.

headline: Unocal Sees Falloff In Quarterly Net
abstract: The Unocal Corporation said its second-quarter profits would be substantially lower than last year because of lower West Coast refining and marketing margins, depressed domestic natural gas prices and soft prices for crude oil in California and Alaska. The Los Angeles-based company had a net income of $33 million in the second quarter of last year before a one-time gain of $132 million from the sale of a Norwegian oil and gas subsidiary.

headline: People
abstract: * Rein Luik has been named director of client services, a new post in the New York office of DDB Needham. * John Dinkel has been named director of product communications in the Los Angeles office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos Inc.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: DEBT * Barnett Banks Inc., Jacksonville, Fla., is offering $100 million in 9 7/8 percent subordinated notes due 2001 at 99.50 to yield 9.955 percent through First Boston Corp. The noncallable notes are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.& P. * CPC International Inc., Englewood Cliffs, N.J., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of $250 million in liquid-yield option notes due 2006 through Merrill Lynch & Co.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Cartier Inc., New York, a subsidiary of Cartier International Inc., named Robert Filotei vice president of its wholesale division. * Food Lion Inc., Salisbury, N.C., named John P. Watkins senior vice president of operations.

headline: Data Bank/May 26, 1991
abstract: New Orders for Durable Goods   April   March   Feb.        Monthly percent change   2.9   --4.5   --0.2        Lumber    March   Feb.   Jan.        Millions of board feet   3,629   3,410   3,545        Steel Production   May 24   May 17   May 10        Thousands of net tons   1,565   1,581   1,571        Auto Production                In units    107,566   128,835   114,515        Truck Production                In units    78,631   78,753   68,510        3-Month Treasury Bills                Yield in percent   5.39   5.42   5.44       Electric Power   May 17   May 10   May 3        Millions of kilowatt hours   56,624   51,442   51,197       Coal Production   May 11   May 4   April 27        Thousands of net tons   18,440   19,154   18,844

headline: Dollar Hits a High for 1991 Against Mark and the Yen
abstract: The dollar surged to a new 1991 high against the mark and yen yesterday, lifted by the hope for a faster economic recovery in the United States and the absence of any central bank intervention to slow the rally.    The surge yesterday brought the dollar to a high of 1.7945 marks in trading during the day, which meant the United States currency had risen by 24 percent since this rapid rally began in early February. The dollar rose to 142.10 yen during the day, up 11 percent since February.

headline: Times Mirror-Cahners Deal For Broadcasting Magazine
abstract: Broadcasting, the 60-year-old weekly trade magazine, will be acquired by Cahners Publishing Company for $32 million from the Times Mirror Company, the two concerns announced yesterday.   Cahners, the largest publisher of business and trade magazines in the United States, is the American arm of Reed International, a $3 billion publishing and information company based in London. Cahners also publishes 13 special-interest consumer magazines, including Modern Bride, American Baby and Sail.

headline: Perrier Sales Back
abstract: Sales of Perrier mineral water in the United States have recovered 55 to 60 percent of their level of 1989, before traces of benzene were found in the production process, Source Perrier S.A. said.

headline: WPP Receives Bank Approval
abstract: Martin Sorrell, the chief executive of the WPP Group, has persuaded a 30-member syndicate of banks to approve a plan to reorganize the giant communications and advertising company's $800 million in debt.   But he has had to pay a higher price than expected. Bankers involved in the negotiations said that as part of the agreement Mr. Sorrell would have to name an non-executive director to the company's board. The banks insisted on the appointment because they wanted someone to act as a check on Mr. Sorrell's power and as their voice, the bankers said.

headline: Capital Cities/ABC Pact
abstract: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to purchase, with the French companies Canal Plus and Compagnie General des Eaux, the television division of the W. H. Smith Group P.L.C. of Britain. The division includes the European Sport Network, a satellite television network; production operations, and a 19.6 percent interest in Yorkshire Television Holdings P.L.C. Capital Cities said its interest in the deal would be purchased through ESPN Inc., which is 20 percent owned by the Hearst Corporation.

headline: FRANCE WILL SIGN 1968 NUCLEAR PACT
abstract: Twenty-three years after a treaty banning the spread of nuclear weapons went into effect, France announced today that it would finally join the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and 139 other nations as a signer of the accord.   The French announcement was coupled with a package of ambitious proposals for arms control worldwide, including calls for the destruction of chemical weapons, a ban on production of biological weapons, reduction of nuclear arsenals and negotiations to limit the multi-billion-dollar trade in conventional armaments.   The plan was announced by President Francois Mitterrand just days after President Bush proposed a ban on weapons of mass destruction in the Middle East. French officials said the two plans were complementary, although the French initiative favors a global approach to arms control.   Both proposals are to be taken up in Paris this month at a meeting of arms control experts from the permanent members of the United Nations Security Council: the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France.   Officials said the French plan was conveyed to both President Bush and the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, over the weekend. French officials said Mr. Bush telephoned President Mitterrand to congratulate him on France's decision to sign the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.    The treaty, the subject of intensive negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union in the mid-1960's, bans the export of nuclear weapons and nuclear arms technology. It emerged after the two superpowers and Britain in 1963 signed the first important arms control treaty, banning nuclear tests in outer space, the atmosphere and underwater. The treaty went into effect in 1968.  Protecting a Monopoly    The treaty was controversial because it sought to make permanent the nuclear weapons monopoly of those nations then possessing such weapons -- the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China -- and sought pledges from other countries not to acquire any. The treaty also committed the nuclear powers to work toward total nuclear disarmament and to help nonnuclear nations signing the accord in developing peaceful uses of nuclear energy.    From the start, France and China refused to sign the treaty, although France has always insisted that it has adhered to its provisions. In refusing to sign, President Charles de Gaulle maintained that France was not adequately consulted by Washington and Moscow when the treaty was being negotiated. But France's refusal was more broadly based, being part of de Gaulle's wish to signal that France had its own foreign and defense policy. The same reasoning led de Gaulle to pull France out of NATO's integrated military command in 1966.    Today, French political experts said that non-adherence to the treaty had not only lost its usefulness as a symbol of France's political independence, but could also weaken international support for the French disarmament proposal.    In Bonn, a Government spokesman said today that Germany supported France's initiative. Chancellor Helmut Kohl was personally briefed on it by Mr. Mitterrand last week. A British spokesman also welcomed France's decision.    The signing of the treaty by France will leave China as the only permament member of the Security Council not to have done so. The French disarmament plan was also sent to the Chinese Government over the weekend, but French officials who visited Beijing last month said China had given no indication that it might join the nonproliferation pact.   India, which has exploded a nuclear device, and Pakistan, Israel, South Africa, Argentina and Brazil, countries thought to possess advanced nuclear technology, have also refused to sign. But most countries have accepted it, including nations like Iraq and North Korea that are believed to have ambitions of developing nuclear weapons.    Western diplomats said that while the decision by France to sign the treaty was aimed at bolstering its arms control initiative, they considered it the major feature of the plan. "It's all part of France's effort to position itself on the world stage after the gulf war," a diplomat said.    As with the American plan announced last week by President Bush, Mr. Mitterrand's move has been prompted by the Persian Gulf war and fears of a new postwar arms race, but it also reflects France's embarrassment at having been the principal Western supplier of weapons to Iraq from 1975 to 1990.   While France has called for global controls on weapons production and transfers, however, the American plan focuses only on the Middle East, contemplating a freeze and eventual ban on ballistic missiles, a ban on biological weapons, an end to production of materiel that could be used for nuclear weapons and guidelines on transfers of conventional weapons.   "Our objectives are clear," the French statement said. "Chemical arms should be eliminated. Bacteriological arms should not be produced. Nuclear arsenals should be brought down to the lowest possible levels compatible with dissuasion. Nonproliferation of nuclear arms remains imperative."   On conventional weapons, France adopted a British proposal for establishment of a registry of arms sales at the United Nations and it proposed negotiations to achieve "a balance of forces" in all regions of the world.   Borrowing from the 34-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, it suggested that different regions should adopt such confidence-building measures as the exchange of military information and set up agencies to monitor weapons.   French officials emphasized that France was not trying to establish a weapons monopoly for the world's principal military powers because it recognized that many third world nations had legitimate security concerns. "This is not a Cocom of weapons," one French official said, referring to the committee of 17 Western nations that has long controlled the export of sophisticated technology to Soviet-bloc and third world nations.   But the French initiative nonetheless underlined the special responsibility of the permanent members of the Security Council, who account for over 80 percent of all foreign weapons sales. France is believed to be the world's third largest arms exporter after the United States and the Soviet Union.   In its statement today, France also made it clear that it was still not willing to consider dismantling any of its three-pronged nuclear capability: missiles, submarines and aircraft. It said it supported efforts by the Soviet Union and the United States to reduce their nuclear arsenals and would be ready to join nuclear disarmament talks once conditions spelled out by Mr. Mitterrand in 1983 were met.   These include the reduction of Soviet and American nuclear weapons stockpiles to the same levels as those of France. And as one Western diplomat put it, "That's still a long way from happening."

headline: DE KLERK SEES GAIN ON HALTING UNREST
abstract: President F. W. de Klerk held talks tonight with Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, leader of the Inkatha Freedom Party, and appeared to have made progress toward persuading Chief Buthelezi to have his Zulu supporters lay down their so-called traditional weapons in the interests of restoring peace.    After more than three hours of talks in Cape Town, Mr. de Klerk said at a news conference that further announcements and actions would follow. Mr. de Klerk said he first wanted to consult with Nelson Mandela, the deputy president of the African National Congress.

headline: At One Site, a Fire Laughs at the Problems in Fighting It
abstract: Near the center of Kuwait's biggest oilfield, 16 miles south of here in Ahmadi, the problems piling up for the firefighters of the Red Adair Company were a case study in frustration last Sunday.    At 7:30 A.M., a crew from the Adair Company, the world's foremost oil-firefighters, was ready to do battle with the flaming, smoking dragon of a well. Nine hours later, thwarted by equipment breakdowns, the crew members went back to their camp having accomplished nearly nothing, hoping to do better the next day.

headline: Donnelley Prices 8 7/8% Bond Issue
abstract: A $150 million, 30-year bond issue by R. R. Donnelley & Sons, the Chicago-based commercial printer and publisher, was priced yesterday through a group of underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.   The corporate bonds due in 2021 have a 8 7/8 percent coupon and are offered to the public at a price of 99.735 to yield 8.90 percent, or about 81 basis points more than Treasury securities with similar maturities. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.    The underwriters said the bonds were noncallable by the company before maturity and were rated Aa-3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: British Ford Posts a Loss
abstract: The British subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company today reported its first pretax loss in 20 years.   The Ford Motor Company Ltd. said it lost $:274 million, or $472 million, in 1990, compared with a pretax profit of $:407 million, or $701.5 million, in 1989.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Companies    Nomura Securities admitted that it had discriminated against the majority of its customers by improperly compensating some of its biggest clients for stock market losses. A Nomura executive also confirmed reports that the company, which wields enormous political influence, had provided more than $150 million in financing to one of Japan's most powerful and best-known crime families. The money was apparently used for a stock-manipulation scheme that Nomura helped execute.  [ Page 1. ]

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; CBS Sales Executive Joins Backer Spielvogel
abstract: Just hours after CBS television announced on Tuesday that it had promoted Robert I. Silberberg to oversee its news, daytime and children's sales, Mr. Silberberg informed the network that he was leaving to join Backer Spielvogel Bates Inc.   At the agency, Mr. Silberberg will be executive vice president-director of national broadcast and programming. He will replace William Croasdale, who left the agency for personal reasons.

headline: McDonnell Awards Job
abstract: Alenia, an Italian aeronautics group, said today at the Paris Air Show that it had signed contracts to provide the McDonnell Douglas Corporation with 500 fuselage panels for the MD-80 passenger plane and estimated the deal would be worth up to $1 billion over eight to nine years.

headline: NCR Talks Said to Be At Impasse
abstract: Negotiations between the NCR Corporation and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company appear to be at an impasse, with neither side indicating any willingness to budge on the amount it believes NCR is worth, people involved in the deal said yesterday.    The meetings are resulting in a growing sense of bitterness at the two companies, advisers for both sides said. That bitterness began to show itself yesterday when NCR accused A.T.& T. of violating an agreement not to speak to the public, and an A.T.& T. spokesman said such an agreement did not exist.

headline: Economic Scene; Consumers' Role In a Recovery
abstract: THERE is less to the consumer debt crisis than meets the eye. Some economists doubt that households are too deeply in debt to spend the nation out of a recession. As the economy recovers, slow growth in incomes is more likely to restrain consumer spending.    True, Americans borrowed during the 1980's as never before. They increased their debts, including mortgages, to almost a year's income, compared with a couple of months' income in 1950.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Y.&R.; Loses Lipton Ads To Ogilvy
abstract: The Thomas J. Lipton Company shifted about $7 million worth of food advertising assignments yesterday from Young & Rubicam to Ogilvy & Mather in a consolidation move.  Lipton, a subsidiary of Unilever with annual sales of about $1.5 billion, said the accounts affected were Wish-Bone and Wish-Bone Lite salad dressings and Lipton Side Dishes, including Lipton Noodles and Sauce and Rice and Sauce.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: COMPANIES    Some of Donald Trump's key properties will go to the banks that lent him nearly $2 billion to build his empire if tentative agreements become final.  [ Page A1. ]   Exxon said its earnings rose 75 percent, to $2.24 billion, its highest ever.  [ D1. ]  A judge rejected the Exxon Valdez settlement, saying the criminal fine was too small.  [ A1. ]

headline: New York Magazine Hurt by City's Slump
abstract: New York magazine, perhaps the best-known city magazine, has seen better days.   With the New York economy in a tailspin, the magazine's total advertising pages dropped from 3,126 in the 1989 fiscal year to 2,905 in the 1990 fiscal year. Indeed, it has only been through aggressive increases in the price charged per ad page that the magazine has stemmed some of the decline in ad revenues, and it is only through continued such increases that it expects to turn ad revenues around by the 1992 fiscal year.

headline: U.S. Denies That It Donated Shoddy Blankets to Teheran
abstract: The United States today denied Iranian accusations that it had sent used blankets to help Iraqi refugees in Iran.   A State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said Iranian assertions that the blankets were "somehow old, worn or unusable" were "just not true."   "The blankets shipped to Iran as part of the U.S. humanitarian effort were new," Mr. Boucher said.   Iran appealed again today for international help for a million Iraqi refugees on its territory, saying many had no shelter and were threatened by epidemics.   The head of Iran's Red Crescent Society, Seifollah Vahid Dastjerdi, said the help Iran had received so far had been "negligible."

headline: All About/Car Recycling; An Afterlife for Automobiles
abstract: The entire building shakes and shudders as a 6,000-horsepower electric motor drives a rotary shredder that reduces whole automobiles to fist-sized recyclable pieces of metal scrap in about 30 seconds. The pieces fall onto a moving conveyor that passes under a magnetized drum, which lifts off the steel and iron. The drum leaves other metals, plastic and miscellaneous materials for hand sorting. The iron and steel chunks are stored in huge piles nearby until they are shipped to steel mills around the world to be made into new products.   This is recycling that works. As governments and industries struggle to establish recycling programs for newspapers, plastics and other household trash, the Prolerized Schiabo Neu Company, a privately held recycling company here, turned 300,000 old cars into high-grade iron ore last year. With scrap at about $90 a long ton, a typical car fetches about $100. For the shredder, costs vary widely depending upon location, the age of the equipment in use and the costs of disposing of what cannot be recycled.

headline: Your Money; At Tax Deadline Without the Cash
abstract: For thousands of reputable middle-class Americans, April 15 represents a guilty secret. They fail to file income tax returns, and there are indications that with layoffs rising their numbers may grow this year.   Failing to file is a serious mistake but can be rectified. Even people who owe taxes but lack the money should file returns, experts say, and work out payment plans to avoid or minimize penalties.

headline: Forum; A Vote for Peer Pressure
abstract: The moaning and groaning coming from American corporations seems excessive. It has been going on since well before the United States Sentencing Commission presented its recommendations on penalties for corporate crime to Congress last week, and it may even accelerate while Congress studies the report.   But the recommendations have less bite than they should, mainly because the commission bent to heavy corporate lobbying. They direct judges to impose tougher fines than are now in effect for such Federal crimes as theft, fraud and antitrust violations. The hitch: They allow judges to greatly reduce penalties if companies add internal compliance programs to insure observation of the law.

headline: U.S. GENERALS SEEK BIGGER IRAQ HAVEN
abstract: Senior American military commanders here said today that they wanted to extend the allied safe-haven area in northern Iraq to include the city of Dohuk in an effort to draw hundreds of thousands of Kurdish refugees down from their perilous mountain camps.   The commanders said Kurdish leaders had told them that if the area was not extended to Dohuk, a major center about 50 miles south of the Turkish border, several hundred thousand refugees, or half the total in the border area, might stay in the camps. The refugees were said to prefer risking death from summer heat and disease rather than return to homes and villages still under the control of President Saddam Hussein's army.

headline: Air Products Official Promoted to President
abstract: Air Products and Chemicals Inc., the large supplier of industrial gases, specialty chemicals and environmental and energy systems, elected Harold A. Wagner president and chief operating officer yesterday. Mr. Wagner is currently executive vice president of the company's gases and equipment division.    To many analysts the selection of Mr. Wagner, who has been with the company for 28 years and was a former head of its European business, seems to pave the way for him to succeed Dexter F. Baker, the company's chief executive, who will retire next April at age 65.

headline: More Economic Pain Seen for Soviets
abstract: The economy of the Soviet Union faces a decline in output of 10 percent, an inflation rate exceeding 100 percent and the likelihood of a "radically worse" year, American intelligence agencies said today.    Those forecasts were included in the annual report to Congress on the state of the Soviet economy by the Central Intelligence Agency and the Defense Intelligence Agency.

headline: Angola Accord May Help Heal Old Wounds
abstract: Perhaps out of exhaustion, perhaps because of caution, Portugal's mediator offered no overt signs of satisfaction on Wednesday night as he watched representatives of Angola's warring factions finally initial a peace accord to end 16 years of civil war.   But for the mediator, Jose Manuel Durao Barroso, as well as for the Lisbon Government, the brief ceremony was not only the climax of 12 months of arduous negotiations, but also a turning point in Portugal's troubled relations with its former African colonies.    Many historians have blamed Portugal for the internal warfare that broke out in Angola as soon as Portugal hurriedly granted the territory independence in 1975. But Government officials here believe that Portugal, by playing a central role in the peace process, has now made amends for its past.

headline: A New Chief Executive Is Named at Courtaulds
abstract: Courtaulds P.L.C., the international specialty industrial materials group, has appointed Sipko Huismans chief executive, effective Aug. 1.   Sir Christopher Hogg, who has held the combined roles of chairman and chief executive since 1980, will continue as chairman.

headline: Business and the Law; Deciding the Fate Of Asbestos Cases
abstract: A PANEL of Federal judges will hear from dozens of lawyers today in a proceeding that could turn out to be one of the most significant arguments in the history of product liability.   The fight is over a forum -- whether and how the Federal courts should consolidate before one or a handful of judges the tens of thousands of asbestos personal injury cases that are now clogging many dockets. If the panel consolidates the enormous caseload, as it has indicated, the move will represent a pivotal procedural change in handling asbestos cases.

headline: Esteem Said to Concern Official at Commerce
abstract: An official close to Under Secretary of Commerce Dennis E. Kloske acknowledged today that Mr. Kloske had planned to resign and said the Under Secretary considered his departure as a way "to preserve his reputation and that of the Commerce Department."   In testimony to Congress on Monday, Mr. Kloske criticized the Administration's policy on the flow of sensitive technology to Iraq.  On Tuesday some Administration officials said Mr. Kloske, the Under Secretary of Commerce for Export Administration, had been asked to resign for telling Congress on Monday that the Administration had ignored warnings to limit the export of American technology to Iraq before the invasion of Kuwait. The White House has steadily denied that Mr. Kloske was dismissed in reaction to his testimony but said he would be leaving on May 1.

headline: Monsanto to Sell Feed-Unit Lines
abstract: The Monsanto Company said today that it had agreed to sell most of its animal feed ingredients business to two Japanese companies.    It said Mitsui & Company and the Nippon Soda Company were expected to form a new company based in St. Louis to carry on the business.

headline: Egyptian Drug Arrest: Kuwaiti Sheik
abstract: Egyptian officials said today that they had arrested a member of the Kuwaiti ruling family on charges of possessing nearly two pounds of heroin and trafficking in the drug.    Under an Egyptian law promulgated two years ago to fight hard drugs, the offenses could be punishable by the death sentence.

headline: For This Quiz, The Answer Is More Confusion
abstract: Take out your pencils for a multiple-choice test. The best and brightest forecasters at Wall Street's leading blue-chip firms think that:   a. The recession is over, the recovery will be tame and inflation will be low.

headline: Syria and Iran Agree Militias Can Remain in Parts of Lebanon
abstract: After three days of talks here, the leaders of Syria and Iran agreed today that armed, Iranian-backed forces could remain in southern Lebanon near an Israeli-controlled border enclave and in the eastern Bekaa region, Iranian officials said.   The agreement between President Hafez al-Assad of Syria and President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran on the deployment of troops of the Iranian-backed Party of God appeared to be a compromise falling far short of the terms of an Arab-brokered reconciliation accord for Lebanon reached in Taif, Saudi Arabia, in 1989. Under that agreement, all militias in Lebanon are to be disbanded by May 1 in an effort to restore normal life to the country after 16 years of civil turmoil.

headline: Big Chains Plan to End Bankruptcy
abstract: The bankrupt department store chains once controlled by Robert Campeau, the Canadian financier, filed a preliminary reorganization plan yesterday that calls for many suppliers who are owed money to get no cash. Instead, they would get stock in a new company that would control some of the nation's largest department-store chains.   Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation, which have been in voluntary bankruptcy since January 1990, said the plan, filed with the Federal court in Cincinnati, called for payments to creditors that would reduce the total claims of $8.2 billion to about $2.8 billion by Feb. 3, 1992, when the companies hope to emerge from bankruptcy.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Companies    The Labor Department said it had filed suit against two corporations that financed payments to retirees with annuities bought from an insurer whose financial problems later left it unable to meet all its obligations. The move is an attempt to clamp down on companies that refinance pension plans by buying investment contracts from insurance companies.  [ Page D1. ]   Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield will eliminate group coverage for more than 100,000 members of professional and trade associations and fraternal orders.  [ D1. ]   The last issue of The National Sports Daily will be sold today. The paper spent 16 months trying to make a success of being the nation's first daily paper devoted to sports.  [ D1. ]   Racal Electronics plans to restructure by distributing its 80 percent stake in Racal Telecom P.L.C. to stockholders.  [ D4. ]   Mesa Limited Partnership eased its bulging debt troubles by raising $616 million in long-term debt.  [ D5. ]   A group boycotting G.E. for five years to force the company to withdraw from nuclear weapons work said it had made a dent in the company's sales of medical diagnostic equipment.  [ D5. ]   A $16.28 million dioxin-spill verdict agianst Monsanto was thrown out by an appeals court.  [ A20. ]   A vaccine by MicroGeneSys may help people infected with the AIDS virus stave off the viral attack.  [ B10. ] The Economy    The F.D.I.C. has come to operate in the commercial world with a range of discretionary powers and exemptions from Federal checks and balances.  [ A1. ]   The savings and loan industry posted its first quarterly profit in four years, the Government reported. The $626.8 million profit for the first three months does not include the huge losses at hundreds of savings associations that have been seized by regulators.  [ D1. ]   A certified public accountants group proposed a far-reaching new rule that would prohibit its 300,000 members from getting new loans from audit clients.  [ D2. ] Markets    New trading sessions that begin on the New York Stock Exchange are being greeted with uncertainty and ambivalence by some stock traders and brokers.  [ D10. ]   The American Stock Exchange disclosed details of its plan to allow listed companies to issue separate classes of stock with unequal voting rights for shareholders.  [ D10. ]   The Dow lost 23.92 points, to 2,961.99. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 167.6 million shares.  [ D10. ]   Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply, and long-term interest rates rose to their highest level in nearly seven months.  [ D18. ]  Yields were down moderately on money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report.  [ D9. ]   The dollar surged to a new 1991 high against the mark and yen, lifted by the hope for a faster economic recovery in the U.S. and the absence of any central bank intervention to slow the rally.  [ D19. ]   Wheat futures prices reached a 10 1/2-month high on the Chicago Board of Trade after the Government cut its estimate of the wheat crop and guaranteed $1.5 billion in loans to the Soviets.  [ D19. ] Today's Columns    Washington officials are fighting over who should regulate the thousands of brokers and banks that sell trillions of dollars in government securities. Stephen Labaton: Business and the Law.  [ D2. ]   Real estate investment trusts and other property-related stocks have widely outperformed the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks over the last six months. Market Place.  [ D10. ]   The Grand Effie Award went for an unusual series of humorous ads that helped a candidate for the United States Senate win election. Stuart Elliott: Advertising.  [ D22. ]

headline: Bethlehem Steel Unit Is Being Sold
abstract: TMB Industries, an investment company, said it and the Onex Corporation iin Toronto had agreed to buy the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's freight-car unit for an undisclosed price. The operation, based in Johnstown, Pa., makes all types of freight cars except tank cars. Its sales totaled about $200 million last year.    Bethlehem said the sale was in line with its plan to divest itself of its non-steel businesses. It said the sale included the unit's car-building shops and plants. TMB was founded by Thomas M. Begel, the former chairman and chief executive of the Pullman Company, and Onex, a Canadian concern with $2 billion in revenues.

headline: U.S. Bailout For Banks Predicted
abstract: The nation's senior auditor said today that the banking industry might be headed for a large taxpayer bailout.    Some members of Congress and analysts of the nation's commercial and savings bank industry have made such warnings before. But the prediction by the Comptroller General, Charles A. Bowsher, is significant because he is widely considered the most credible impartial voice in Government. His early assessments of the problems of savings and loan institutions and later of the huge costs in that bailout have proved prophetic.

headline: Armenian Chief Steers With Subtlety
abstract: The Armenian counterrevolution of Levon Ter-Petrosyan is quiet -- mercifully, strategically quiet -- and this is all the more reason for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the rest of the world to pay close heed.   While so much else in the Soviet nation is reeling with political fury and dire warning, Mr. Ter-Petrosyan, the new President of the Armenian republic, is carving a different path to the very same full independence that far more celebrated republics like Lithuania and Georgia are seeking in headlined confrontations.

headline: Chief Is Said to Be Selected For Prudential Securities
abstract: An executive committee of the directors of the Prudential Insurance Company of America yesterday approved the selection of a former executive with Shearson Lehman Brothers to be the chairman and chief executive of its brokerage subsidiary, Prudential Securities Inc., people informed of the decision said yesterday.    The executive, Hardwick Simmons, 50 years old, is the former head of Shearson's retail division. It had been rumored on Wall Street that Mr. Simmons was leading contender for the job. Last week, Prudential's top management decided to move quickly to fill the position.

headline: De Benedetti Sells Insurer
abstract: The Italian entrepreneur Carlo de Benedetti has sold an insurance company for about $400 million in the latest in a string of sales to cut the debts of his business holdings.    Mr. de Benedetti, who controls the computer maker Ing. C. Olivetti & Company, sold Latina Assicurazioni S.p.A. to another Italian insurer jointly controlled by his cousin Camillo de Benedetti.

headline: Textron Unit to Pay E.P.A. Penalty
abstract: Textron Lycoming, a unit of Textron Inc., agreed to pay a $147,500 fine for shipping hazardous waste to Canada without notifying United States regulators or getting Canadian Government approval. The Environmental Protection Agency said that the aircraft engine company shipped at least 834 loads of metal hydroxide sludge, a byproduct of its manufacturing process, to Stablex, a Montreal hazardous waste company, from 1987 to 1989.    The E.P.A. said many of the shipments crossed the border without the consent of the Canadian Government or knowledge of United States regulators. Federal law requires the reporting of any transport of hazardous waste. The shipments by Textron Lycoming were detected by a spot check at the Vermont border by Customs agents.

headline: As Shiite Camp Faces U.S. Pullout, Even Stout Hearts Waver
abstract: Hassan, whose mother said he was 10 but who could have passed for 7, raised his shirt to show the six-inch scar down the center of his chest from his surgery last summer in Baghdad. It was the first of two operations needed to correct an otherwise-fatal heart valve defect.   How he will get the second is not clear. The surgeon, an American, left Baghdad after Iraq invaded Kuwait, and Hassan cannot go back either, said his mother, a teacher from Karbala. She said the Iraqi police were looking for her because she had expressed doubts to neighbors about the value to Iraq of the Persian Gulf war.
